item.title: Datadog ($DDOG)
item.description: The Dog in the SaaS Fight
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to MT Capital Research! If you’re new, join a group of 4400 Informed Investors who receive frequent reports on the World’s Most Interesting Tech Companies by subscribing below: 

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an in-depth analysis on Datadog. Within I will break down the company’s technology and associated end-markets/use-cases, delve into the magnitude of the opportunity the company has in front of it and attempt to convey the sheer velocity of development cadence that shareholders of the company have become accustomed to. In addition, I will delve into the company’s financials, analyze some important KPIs and convey my reasoning for being long Datadog. The format of this research, as per usual can be seen outlined below. Feel free to skip ahead to the sections that you will find most useful: 

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Opportunity

3.0 Technology 

4.0 How Datadog makes $$$

5.0 Financials 

6.0 Key Performance Indicators 

7.0 Valuation, Competition and Thesis

8.0 Conclusion 

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as  substitute for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investment. 

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on Twitter: 

Follow Me!

With all of that out of the way, let’s get started. 

1.0 Introduction 

The origin story of the company I am delving into today arguably started more than 10 years ago, when Oliver Pomel and his co-founder Alexis Lê-Quôc were working at Wireless Generation. With the former running the company’s development team and the latter operating as the company’s Director of Operations, the two became increasingly aware of the disjointedness of their teams as a whole. If one looks at the interconnectedness of the modern software-oriented enterprise, this may come as a surprise, however, at the time, teams were fragmented. Developers, i.e. the individuals that wrote the code for companies, would finish an application, and throw said application over the fence, so to speak, to members of the operations team, i.e. individuals charged with building and maintaining servers, ensuring network functionality etc., whom, once the application was received, would be in charge of maintaining its functionality, troubleshooting issues etc. The siloed nature of these interactions created inefficiencies within software organizations, greatly increasing complexities and leading to headaches experienced by all those involved. Luckily, Datadog arose from these struggles, with Oliver stating the following in a 2020 fireside chat, a statement that nicely encapsulates the blossoming of a billion dollar idea from metaphorical ashes: 

“So the starting point for Datadog was that there must be a better way for people to talk to each other.  We wanted to build a system that brought the two sides of the house together, all of the data was available to both and they speak the same language and see the same reality.  It turns out, it was not just us, it was the whole industry that was going this way.”

With the benefit of hindsight on our side, the company quite evidently got itself in front of two major trends. The first was the rise of the “Devops”, i.e. the unification of the development and operations facets of software engineering and the exact opposite of the previously outlined phenomena above. The second was the rise of the cloud, a happening that would fundamentally alter the functionality and capabilities of software as a whole. The amalgamation of these two trends resulted in the creation of Datadog’s cloud-based monitoring and analytics platform. Originally focused on infrastructure monitoring, application performance monitoring and log management, the company has leveraged second-to-none product release rates in order to offer additional functionality ranging from Network and Database Monitoring to Continuous Improvement Monitoring and Workload Security, as examples, in order to power modern DevOps, and more recently DevSecOps teams. 

With this brief introduction in mind, let’s take a look at some of the key trends and opportunities Datadog aims to leverage as spurring tailwinds in the coming years.

 2.0 Opportunity 

Before delving into projections associated with the end markets Datadog’s products are geared towards, it is useful to stay more surface level for a second and pinpoint some key happenings within the modern enterprise that Datadog is set to react positively to. More specifically, the company is likely to benefit from the continued digital transformation, mainly spurred by further cloud penetration, of almost every business, as well as the resiliency of the associated spend as a whole. A recent survey performed by MS, of which detailed responses of CIOs of some large technology companies yielded some interesting corroborative insights, particularly how approximately 25% of application workloads currently resided in the cloud, a value that is anticipated to reach 44% by 2024. Judging by the success Datadog has already been able to garner with cloud adoption, as well as the fact that adoption still has a significant runway, this is an exciting prospect. In addition, Security Software, Cloud Computing, Digital Transformation and AI+ML + process automation, remained the 4 IT projects that were the least likely to get cut within associated enterprises, encouraging given the level of exposure Datadog has to each of these facets, as well as the fact that the anti-fragility of these areas allows for us to successfully underwrite continued growth in Datadog’s business, despite looming macroeconomic conditions that are likely to be stress factors for many other high-flying SaaS companies.

IT Operations Management, the market that encompasses most of the company’s technology offerings, is expected to represent a $44B opportunity, as per the company’s 2021 10-K.  Though a tall figure, this estimate is largely based on on-prem infrastructure, and both fails to consider and largely underestimates the role of cloud and hybrid cloud environments. Ramblings aside, Datadog is uniquely positioned amongst competition to stand out within various associated facets. Delving deeper we can gauge third-party opinion on the competitive position of companies that are able to offer solutions for observability use-cases, such as AIOps and Application Performance Monitoring. The company’s general business structure, cadence and platform status, as evaluated by GigaOM, relative to incumbents can be seen outlined below: 

Datadog was also positioned near the top of the summit as per Gartner’s Magic Quadrant evaluation of the Application Performance Monitoring Competitive Landscape, as well as per Forrester’s Wave for AIOps: 

What the above discussion does not convey is the sheer speed at which Datadog is releasing their products, a phenomenon that only increases the number of addressable markets the company is targeting with their technology, and the total value that is ripe for the taking as a result. To further cement what I am trying to convey here, it is useful to look at what the Datadog platform has consisted of over the course of the few years that the company has been public. In the 2020 10-K, Datadog outlines that, as of December 2019, their platform contained Infrastructure Monitoring, Application Performance Monitoring, Log Management, Synthetics and Real User Monitoring, Network Performance Monitoring and Security Monitoring, for a total of 7 product categories. By December 2020, the company had added two new products, Incident Management and Continuous Profiler. Flash forward to early 2022, after extreme bouts of activity and announcements made in last year’s annual Dash Conference, the number of products has risen to 14, with new additions including CI Visibility, CSPM (Cloud Security Posture Management), Workload Security, to name a few. In short, the company is leveraging substantial amounts of R&D spend as well as the occasional M&A effort to continuously improve their product offerings, an endeavour that expands their reach into a variety of different end-markets that are likely to undergo substantial growth in the coming years.

But why does all of this matter? Before delving deeper into the company’s technology we must first understand, broadly, its usefulness. Observability, from a fundamental perspective, can be defined as the ability to measure the internal states of a system by examining its associated outputs. Applied to Datadog’s platform, and associated IT systems as a whole, the ability to leverage telemetry data ranging from metrics, to logs and traces, is immensely powerful, seeing as it allows for teams to be able to gain heightened insights into the functionality of their systems, quickly pinpoint root causes of underperformance or failures and work to resolve issues, and determine different sources of underperformance or areas for improvement. With the rise of the cloud, an increasing abundance of applications that are crucial for the modern enterprise and their clients, as well as a constantly expanding network of intertwined servers, databases, etc. this has never been more important. 

In short, I would like you take away the following from this opportunity. Observability and IT Operations Management is a significant opportunity for Datadog to capitalize on. With rapid entrance into new product categories, digital trends that both aid and abet Datadog’s value proposition, and strong competitive positioning within their more established product offering end-markets, the company presents itself as a very exciting SaaS player. 

3.0 Technology 

Datadog’s 14 product categories can be seen outlined below. I will spend this section outlining the functionality contained therein.

Infrastructure Monitoring

Within a modern organization, IT infrastructure is omnipresent. Said infrastructure includes a variety of assets ranging from data centers, servers, networks, computer hardware etc. These monitoring tools allow DevOps to monitor the performance and any issues associated with their entire environment, whether said environment is on-prem, cloud or hybrid cloud-based. This tooling aggregates an abundance of data from each of the aforementioned infrastructure components, which can then be leveraged within dashboards to visualize, analyze and make conclusions based off of said data. 

Log Management

Log data are essentially a record of events that took place at a certain time, either within or involving a certain application, pieces of infrastructure etc. These may include records of interaction or an error encountered by the user. Within most companies now, these logs are abundant given the sheer breadth of sources these are gathered from, ranging from containers to mobile devices and web browsers. Datadog’s log capabilities collect and archive all of the company's logs, then allowing for indexing to occur, metrics to be generated from patterns/anomalies to be associated with said data. 

APM and Continuous Profiler 

The primary objective of APM (Application Performance Management) is to monitor and manage the performance of an enterprise’s applications, maintaining a degree of usability and expected level of service for its associated end-users. Datadog’s APM solution correlates traces, i.e. information that details how long a request took, which components of an application were interacted with and the latency involved with each interaction, with both front-end and back-end data in order to provide insights regarding, errors, performance hindrances etc. Continuous Profiler functionality goes one step further, going code-level to to various components of an app to gain insight and address problems associated with performance. 

Database Monitoring 

Datadog’s database monitoring tool provides insight and visibility into an enterprise’s database across their hosting environments. Within, dashboards can be created to track different metrics, identify database queries that are resource intensive, identify the root cause of slow queries, as examples. In addition, explain plans help with the understanding of how a database returns queries, of which can be used to identify bottlenecks and improve efficiencies. 

Synthetic Monitoring 

Synthetic monitoring is essentially a process by which applications and systems are monitored through the simulation of user interaction with said app, API or system. Datadog allows for these hypothetical interactions to be created and executed, powered by AI. As a result, teams can gain heightened insight into performance, errors, request handlings etc. This functionality can be run alongside Continuous Improvement pipelines or used as mock deployments in order to pinpoint faulty systems or designs before real users encounter the same issues. 

Incident Management 

Datadog’s incident management features allows for devops teams to identify and declare incidents, undergo a unified incident response with team members based upon data-driven insights, delve into the possible failure points and impacts of said incident that are often prevalent within distributed systems/environments and then leverage post-incident reviews with notebooks that give team members a look into the exact cause of an occurrence. 

Datadog also supports automated workflows that can be used to create automatically occurring incident responses, for example if a customer checkout page on a website is experiencing more errors than usual, an incident can be automatically created and team members can then be notified and delve into its response.  

Real Time User Monitoring 

Datadog’s RUM functionality allows for teams to gain insight into the front-end components of their applications from the perspective of users. Whether their application is a javascript app, android or iOS app etc., Datadog allows for data to be collected on each user’s interaction with the app, of which can then be visually displayed and analyzed, utilized for troubleshooting etc. within different dashboards. In contrast to Synthetics, RUM works with actual user interactions within an app rather than their simulated counterparts. 

CI Visibility

CI, or Continuous Integration, is essentially a DevOps practice where developers merge and integrate their code within a central depository. This process is usually paired with CD, or Continuous Delivery, in order to take code that is located in the central depository and then deliver it to production. As one can imagine, these CI/CD pipelines can be complex, prone to error and can exist as an all around time-sink if done improperly within an organization. Datadog’s CI functionality allows for developers to monitor and pinpoint pipeline failures, monitor trends and execution times and leverage data to garner insights as to how the pipeline can be improved for future performance, costs can be reduced etc. 

Serverless

As you may have guessed, Serverless development consists of developers building and running applications, all whilst not managing an intertwined server. These development practices are often centered around functions and are able to scale up and down to demand as needed. Datadog provides solutions that allow teams to monitor their serverless application stack, resolve AWS lambda function failures, monitor serverless configuration changes with deployment tracking and more. 

Network Monitoring 

Becoming increasingly important within the modern enterprise is the ability to monitor network traffic. Datadog’s solutions give insight into network traffic occurring between different containers, microservices and allows for Devops members to optimize different network traffic patterns, view network dependencies across the stack, pinpoint outages, manage cloud traffic costs etc. 

Cloud SIEM 

This functionality is geared at providing threat detection for cloud environments, allowing for operational data and security logs to be analyzed in real time and leveraged in conjunction with pre-built detection capabilities to flag and work to resolve suspect activity, occurrences etc. When one thinks about this logically, it is quite evident that security goes hand in hand with Datadog’s observability functionality, seeing as the functionality omnipresent on their platform can pinpoint if application usage starts behaving in an irregular manner, as an example, which can then be used as a precursor to security threat mitigation efforts. 

CSPM 

Being released in response to the ever growing governance, risk and compliance issues associated with moving to the cloud, CSPM extends Datadog’s Cloud Security Platform in order to track and ensure that an organization’s environment is compliant, automates audit evidence gathering, and helps to ensure that there are no misconfigurations within an organization’s infrastructure that would be susceptible to breaches. 

Sensitive Data Scanner 

Datadog’s platform functionality in this area allows for customers to standardize the classification of sensitive log data (i.e. based on source or risk level), discover and search for sensitive data that may be situated across their cloud environment, scrub sensitive data from logs with predefined scanners, build compliance strategies with access controls etc. 

Workload Security

Put simply, workload security, and in particular cloud workload security, is the act of protecting cloud resources, of which range from virtual machines and containers to databases and applications. Datadog’s Workload Security product allows for process and file activity to be monitored in real time, with teams then able to leverage process execution monitoring, if desired, to pinpoint suspicious or abnormal activity and work to resolve said activity accordingly. 

In short, Datadog has a variety of products that cater towards most, if not all, the needs of DevOps and now DevSecOps teams. With their rapid and continual pace of new functionality releases, I look forward to writing about the additional platform capabilities Datadog will be able to bolster in the coming quarters.

4.0 How Datadog makes $$$ 

Datadog’s business model is centered around charging customers for their usage of each of the aforementioned products. A general overview of the pricing model associated with each product can be seen outlined below: 

  • Infrastructure: Free for up to 5 hosts, Pro Tier with 500+ integrations and pre-built dashboards available for $15/host/month (any physical or virtual OS instance) or Enterprise Tier at $23/host/month with advanced features such as ML alerts and premium support attached.

  • Log Management: Ingest Tier at $0.10/per GB (scanned or ingested)/month with the ability to ingest, process live tail and archive all logs. Retain or Rehydrate Tier at $1.70/million log evens/month, comes with advanced functionality ranging from log patterns and analytics as well as the ability to rehydrate from log management archives as needed. 

  • APM and Continuous Profiler: APM tier at $31/host/month which allows for services and code deployments to be monitored and analyzed, traces correlated with metrics and log data etc. APM and Continuous Profiler Tier at $40/host/month includes functionality that helps to optimize production-level code, pinpoint bottlenecks etc. 

  • Database Monitoring: $70/per database host/month allowing for queries to optimize and application performance to be monitored/improved.

  • Synthetic Monitoring: API Test Tier at $5/thousand test runs/month allowing for site availability to be proactively monitored and alerted for or Browser Test Tier at $12/thousand tests/month that allows critical user journeys to be monitored and tested for. 

  • Incident Management: $20/user/month for fully integrated, in-app, incident management. 

  • Real User Monitoring: $0.45/thousand sessions/month for Mobile and Browser Tiers, allowing for issues within each associated app-type to be analyzed, alerted for, and correlated with backend traces. $1.80/thousand sessions/month for Session Replay tier, which extends the Browser tier, allowing for user replays to be used for troubleshooting, debugging and behaviour analysis. 

  • CI Visibility: Pipeline Visibility Tier at $8/committer/month that aggregates CI pipeline data and monitors performance or Testing Visibility tier at $20/month that provides more granularity into test performances. 

  • Serverless: $5/million invocations/month and includes serverless metric tracking, 15-month metric retention, trace function capabilities, out of the box service maps etc.

  • Network Monitoring: Network Performance Monitoring Tier at $5/host/month allowing for traffic patterns to be visualized, tag analysis to occur etc., or the Network Device Monitoring tier at $7/device/month that allows for the health and performance of on-prem network devices to be tracked and maintained. 

  • Cloud SIEM: $0.20/GB of analyzed logs/month which includes pre-built detection rules, threat detection on ingested data, 15-month retention of security signals and associated analytics etc. 

  • CSPM: $7.50/host/month, which includes configuration rules for clouds, containers, etc., visibility into configuration statuses, misconfigurations to be alerted for, regulation and compliance standard adherence etc. 

  • Sensitive Data Scanner: $0.30/scanned/GB/month. Includes pre-built and customizable detection rules and sensitive data detection across all log data sources. 

  • Workload Security: $15/host/month allows for hosts and containers to be monitored for threats, files and processes to be monitored etc. 

Separately pricing each of their products ties directly into both Datadog’s sales and marketing and development strategy. Starting off with the former, Datadog has a “land and expand” sales strategy. 

In essence, this entails that the company is intensely focused on the initial obtainment of a customer, and works on ensuring that the longer the relationship is between themselves and said customer, the more products the customer will end up using over time. On the development side of things, how each product is designed compliments this strategy quite nicely. More specifically, customers, when they opt into a new Datadog product, are able to extract value from said product almost instantaneously. In comparison to other SaaS company competitors, where time-to-value is often substantially longer, this greatly reduces the risk in leveraging Datadog’s services from the customer’s point of view. In addition, with Datadog’s second-to-none development speed, they are constantly adding on functionality and products to their platform that compliment one another and both align and offer essential capabilities to the modern digital enterprise. With this development cadence, the company is able to land and expand in a way that customer’s cannot, and will be able to demonstrate strong DBNR and ARR numbers that incumbents will have a difficult time replicating, but I will touch upon that more later. 

5.0 Financial Analysis 

Within this section I will delve into Datadog’s most recent Income Statement, Balance Sheet and Cash Flow Statement for Q4’21 and FY’21 as a whole. 

Income Statement 

Revenue

Datadog’s Revenue came in at $1.029B representing a 70% increase YoY. The change in Revenue over the last few years can be seen outlined below: 

On a quarterly basis, the same level of rapid top-line growth can still be observed. Total Revenue for Q4’21 came in at $326M, representing a 84% increase on a YoY basis and 21% increase on a QoQ basis. With their development cadence and sales strategy this is unlikely to change. Looking at the change in QoQ growth rate over the last 11 quarters is astounding to say the least, especially given the amount of scale they’ve added since 2019: 

We are also starting to see slight improvements in the company’s International Expansion Efforts. Although the company still derives the majority of their Top-Line in North America, this value will likely continue to shrink in the coming years. 

Cost of Revenues

Cost of Revenue came in at $234M for 2021, representing a 80% YoY increase. This value increased slightly faster than top-line YoY as a result of an increase in third-party cloud hosting and software costs. On a quarterly basis, COR came in at $67.1M, representing a 64% increase YoY. COR, relative to top-line, is fixed in nature seeing as this metric is primarily composed of infrastructure and software costs, and has been operating in a strict relative range since 2017, a positive given how Datadog has sized up. 

Operating Expenses

Operating Expenses came in at $814M for FY’21, an increase of 67% YoY, a slower rate to its Top-Line constituent. A similar phenomenon can be observed on a quarterly basis can be observed, with Total OPEX coming in at $251M, representing a 72% increase YoY in comparison to Revenue’s 84% increase. The change in Total OPEX, on a yearly basis, can be seen outlined below: 

Delving deeper, we can start to see the true beauty of Datadog’s business. G&A expenses have remained in a fixed range over the last few years, however, moving over to its counterparts is where the true magic lies. Over the years, we’ve seen a substantial decrease in relative S&M spend as well as a steady increase in the company’s relative R&D spend. As an example, S&M increased 40% YoY in comparison to R&D increasing 99%! What this equates to is a sustainable and fast-paced development cadence that results in new products being released on a frequent basis. These phenomena also corroborates both the effectiveness of the company’s land and expand sales model as well as their presence as a technical powerhouse, seeing as value is continually able to be extracted from new and current customers alike with less laborious S&M efforts. 

Margins and Profitability 

Datadog’s Gross Profit increased at a slightly lower rate to Top-Line as a result of the slightly higher increase in COR YoY. With GP coming in at 77% for the year, at the high end of the spectrum amongst its SaaS company counterparts, this metric aligns with management’s medium to long term GP performance target and is likely to remain in a similar range in both the coming years and quarters. The change in GP on an annual basis can be seen outlined below: 

Moving on, the company is not profitable on a GAAP-basis, an assertion that is corroborated when looking at Operating Income, Net Income and EBITDA values and associated margins, as outlined below: 

Despite that fact, losses are narrow and I would not be surprised to see these values approach positive territory given the clear operating leverage the company has started to exhibit over the last few quarters and years. 

Balance Sheet

The structure of Datadog’s assets, as of Q4’21, can be seen outlined below: 

Datadog’s assets are primarily liquid, consisting predominantly of approximately $1.3B in marketable securities, followed predominantly thereafter by essentially equal weightings of Cash and Equivalents and Accounts Receivable. Long Term Assets on the other hand are comprised mainly of Goodwill, followed by Operating Lease Assets and Deferred Contract Costs in order of descending magnitude. The structure of Datadog’s liabilities can be seen outlined below: 

Datadog’s Liabilities are predominantly Long Term. Current Liabilities consist mainly of Deferred Revenue and Accrued Expenses whereas Long Term Liabilities consist mainly of $735M in Senior Notes Liability, followed thereafter mainly by Operating Lease Liabilities. 

Overall, with abundant amounts of working capital as well as a manageable and thought-out debt load, Datadog’s balance sheet doesn’t appear to be a source of hindrance going forwards. 

Cash Flow Statement

The change in Datadog’s Cash from Operations, Financing and Investing, as well as Free Cash Flow and associated FCF Margin can be seen outlined below: 

CFO came in at approximately $286M for FY 2021, increasing by approximately 163% YoY, albeit comprised by large SBC adjustments which will be outlined in just a moment. CFI came in at $(274)M, attributable primarily to the purchases of marketable securities, and cash paid for business acquisitions, skewed towards the positive direction by inflows attributable to the maturities of marketable securities. CFF came in at $34.94M for FY’21, attributable to proceeds from the issuance of common stock attributable to employee purchase programs and proceeds from the exercise of stock options. FCF increased approximately 167% YoY with margins improving by 1000bps YoY. Delving deeper, we can take a look at the impact of SBC adjustments below: 

SBC has been increasing proportionally to the company’s headcount and doesn’t appear to be getting out of hand at the moment, increasing from 12% of Revenues to 16% of Revenues YoY. This value should continue to be monitored by investors. Regardless, Datadog is generating commendable levels of FCF given their growth, and its trajectory is likely to continue to be positive in the following year. 

6.0 Key Performance Indicators 

In order to understand Datadog more deeply, we can take a look at some Key Performance Indicators that allow us to peer under the hood so to speak. Starting off with customers, Datadog’s customers came in at 18,800 at the end of FY 2021, increasing by 33% on a YoY basis. The change in this metric over the last few years can be seen outlined below: 

Although YoY Customer Growth is slightly decelerating (by 200bps YoY), the company will likely continue to be able to grow this metric at a 30%+ rate for the foreseeable future.

Datadog is not only growing Total Customers, but they are also showing significant progress in their ability to grow large customers. Customers with more than $100,000 in annual run rate grew at 60% YoY, coming in at 2010 total customers: 

We are also seeing large customers continue to contribute more to both ARR as a whole, as well as the fact that large customers relative to total customers has been on a steady uptrend over the last few years as well: 

Datadog is continually demonstrating the ability to extract more value from current customers, and spurs a large component of their top-line growth as such. This assertion is corroborated when looking at the company’s Dollar-Based Net Retention Rate (DBNRR), a value that has come in at 130%+ multiple years running, as outlined below: 

Ignoring the fact that 2017 and 2018 values were slightly elevated in comparison to their counterparts, as a result of annual run-rate values that were significantly smaller in magnitude, these values are indicative of the fact that on average, Datadog’s customers were spending 30% more this year in comparison to its predecessor. With the company continually adding new products at a rapid pace, this value is unlikely to change, especially since each of their products intertwines so well with their counterparts. We are seeing this exhibited by the number of customers using more than 2, 4 and more recently tracked, 6 products, as outlined below: 

The company’s product suite also doesn’t appear to be any signs of slowing down. Datadog’s most popular products, i.e. log management and APM, of which contribute almost a half of ARR themselves, are still growing and new products had significant ARR contribution as outlined within their most recent earnings call: 

“In addition to that, APM suite and log management products continue to be in hyper-growth mode. And we're very pleased to report that our newer products added about $100 million in ARR in 2021.”

With Datadog’s rapid product release cycle, it is exciting to think about the ARR impact in the future. New products are evidently having immediate impact, and as products mature, they are showing exponential adoption trajectories as a result of the company’s effective sales model. 

With all of these ramblings in mind, the KPIs evidently highlight the fact that Datadog is a top-notch SaaS companies that is not showing signs of pumping the brakes any time soon. 

7.0 Valuation, Competition and Concluding Thesis

One of the most frequently touted gripes against Datadog is their valuation. At surface level this may make an analyst seem smart as they compare NTM EV/Rev multiples with historical means, however, I believe these assertions become intellectually dishonest when one starts to delve deeper. Datadog’s execution has been essentially flawless, spare the slight difficulties they had during the initial emergence of the pandemic, a phenomenon that should not garner too much attention given many SaaS companies experienced the same headwinds as budgets were slashed due to understandable uncertainties. Looking past that, growth has been impeccable, expectations have been consistently exceeded, new products are consistently being released and the company is demonstrating operating leverage that most SaaS and end-market peers have not been able to replicate. When we take a look at EV/NTM revenues and 2022E-2024E Revenue (Millions) CAGR (%) of some of the most popular SaaS/high-growth companies in the market today, it is evident the company is valued richly, however they are also above the mean in terms of forward top-line growth at a scale that is larger than a lot of incumbents: 

As expected, Datadog bolsters the fourth highest valuation out of the list of approximately 40 high-growth tech names I compiled. Weighting expectations with growth estimates, i.e. with EV/NTM divided by 2022E-2024E Top Line CAGR, yields a similar conclusion as the previous figure:

Lastly, we can take a look at the company’s relative trading strength over the course of the last few months. As I’m sure you’re all aware, the market has not been very friendly to tech companies of late, with many high fliers having had their multiples slashed by a substantial margin as we head into times filled with macroeconomic pressure, geopolitical uncertainty etc. Being that as it may, Datadog has had the second strongest price action out of the group of stocks I analyzed, only down 17% from 52W highs over the course of the last few weeks, in comparison to the mean of down 48% for the group, as outlined below: 

With all of this data in mind, what am I trying to convey here? In short, Datadog is not cheap, but this a phenomenon that has been rampant over the course of history when we are dealing with the best companies in the world. I have already mentioned their development cadence, however, it is worth highlighting the history that the company has of lowballing expectations and beating them by a significant margin. In their most recent earrings release, Datadog provided Top-Line guidance of $1510M and $334M for FY’22 and Q1’22 (low end of associated ranges), of which would represent a 47% YoY increase and 68% increase YoY, respectively. Looking at the company’s average beat of approximately 11%, as outlined below, this is likely to be exceeded with ease in the coming quarters. As such, I would not be surprised if the company achieves high 50% Top-Line growth for FY’22 as a whole. 

In short, I view the valuation of Datadog as its biggest risk. Execution will have to be near flawless in the coming quarters and I am okay with taking that risk. Management has continually over achieved, the company’s end market is far from developed and we are in the midst of a technological trend in the cloud that is changing modern companies in an unprecedented manner. This presents itself as an asymmetric opportunity and is exactly the type of hyper-growth story I like to expose myself to.

Before concluding this deep-dive, it is important that we understand Datadog’s competitive positioning relative to other incumbents. Main competitors, in public markets, to make note of are Dynatrace, New Relic, Splunk and Elastic, each of which have capable, albeit inferior, technology to Datadog, in my opinion. To spare you a 100+ page deep analysis, I am going to stay high level here and look at some key metrics for comparative purposes. If you wish to go deeper on the nuances of peers’ technology, I recommend reading Software Stack Investing Pieces on Datadog, in which he breaks down in depth the latest activity of competitors and outlines very clearly where the company stands relative to its peers. In addition, Mujii at Hhhypergrowth has broken down Datadog and some competitors in a meaningful manner. Both of these individuals have decades of experience and will do a better job than I of breaking down the competitive landscape of this tech. With that in mind, let’s compare Datadog and Peers using Customer Numbers, Revenue, YoY Revenue Growth, Gross, Operating and FCF Margins and R&D/S&M as % of Revenue as the main financial metrics of interest. 

Starting off, there are some reporting nuances that complicate this comparison. More specifically, 2021A for NEWR, DT and SPLK represent the 9 months ended December 31 2021, whereas the 2021A for ESTC represents the 6 months ended December 31. Thus, in these periods margins, customers and relative R&D/S&M spend are the points of interest rather than top-line itself. Other points to be aware of are the fact that NewRelic switching to a self-serve initiative and consumption-based business model, a decision which resulted in a large amount of customers qualifying for the newly created free customer tie, hence the dip from 2019 to 2020 seen in Customer Numbers. In addition, Splunk stopped disclosing the number of customers just in time for the release of their FY’21 earnings, roughly inline with 2020A. Staying surface level on Splunk for a second, I am always cautious when a company stops reporting a key performance indicator so long after they IPO’d. In general, if a company felt it necessary to disclose a metric in the S-1, shareholders should generally expect this to continue in every reporting period thereafter, unless the company has significantly altered their business as a whole. This phenomenon, especially when viewed alongside the fact that Splunk’s incumbents are growing so fast, is a red flag to me and leads me to believe they’ve had a material slowdown in the amount of customers since then, a phenomenon which is correlated by the relative stagnation seen in Top-Line of late. 

Delving deeper into metric-specific conclusions, and if we assume that Splunk has Customers in the low 20,000s, Datadog has the second highest customer numbers, and is demonstrating best-in-class growth. Datadog has the second highest top-line, a phenomenon that is likely to change in the coming years as their rapid development cycle spurs continued growth and likely eventually leads to them overtaking Splunk sooner rather than later. As a thought exercise, the company had less 1/10 of Splunk/s Revenue in 2017, a value that likely shrinks to ½ as Splunk reports the final quarter of their fiscal year. This goes to show how fast Datadog has grasped market share, a phenomenon that is unlikely to stop given their guidance. Moving over to margins, Datadog’s Gross, Operating and FCF margins are inferior to only Dynatrace, despite operating at nearly double the Top-Line scale. Datadog’s Gross Margins are likely to remain similar to what they are now, however, the company has been showing more and more operating leverage of late , so I am confident that Operating Margin is likely to head into positive territory in the coming years. Looking at relative R&D and S&M spend for Datadog is clearly where the business shines. The company showcases the most efficient S&M spend in comparison to peers, and has decreased this magnitude by the largest margin in comparison to its counterparts. R&D on the other hand has been creeping up and is second only to Splunk in the most recent reporting period (despite Splunk showing much more inefficient sales and marketing efforts). In essence, this value will likely an important driver of Datadog being able to continue grow at a rate that is not possible with competition, seeing as they will be able to continue test and enter into new end-markets with their rapid product releases. 

In short, I am long Datadog. With the company’s best in-class products, rapidly expanding addressable market and strong associated tailwinds, demonstration of continually improving operating leverage, a growing array of products that should only expand as the company continues to focus on R&D (as outlined by my favourite graph of the piece below), extremely strong competitive position, a founder-led team and guidance that points towards a hypergrowth trajectory that the company doesn’t appear to getting off of any time soon, Datadog is the definition of a modern SaaS company that warrants excitement. 

8.0 Conclusion

In 2020, you almost certainly could’ve made money choosing randomly from an ever-expanding tech companies. Flash forward to today, the markets are much more unforgiving. Only the companies with near perfect execution, that not only meet but beat expectations and guidance will survive the onslaught of impending multiple compression. After completing substantial amounts of research on Datadog, I find it likely that this company is one of the lucky few that does just that. Thank you for reading my research.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, subscribe and share!

Share

Subscribe now

If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

Leave a comment

item.title: Spotify ($SPOT)
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to MT Capital Research! If you’re new, join a group of 4250 Informed Investors who receive frequent reports on the World’s Most Interesting Tech Companies by subscribing below: 

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an in-depth analysis on Spotify. Within I will provide brief overviews of the history of Spotify and the music industry as a whole, delve into the main tailwinds the company will aim to benefit from in the coming years, outline their technology and break down their business model. In addition, I will delve into the company’s recent earnings report, discuss some KPIs and growth levers and outline my thesis for being long Spotify. The format of this research, as per usual, can be seen outlined below. Feel free to skip ahead to the sections that you feel are most useful: 

1.0 Introduction and History

2.0 Opportunity 

3.0 Technology 

4.0 How Spotify makes $$$ 

5.0 Financials 

6.0 Key Performance Indicators 

7.0 Thesis

8.0 Conclusion 

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitute for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investment. 

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content and analysis, give me a follow on Twitter: 

Follow Me!

With all of that out of the way, let’s get started.

1.0 Introduction and History 

A song I’ve been listening to a lot lately is the White Buffalo cover of The Highwayman, originally written by Jimmy Webb. Within this composition the listener is exposed to a tale of reincarnation, where a man describes his experiences across multiple different lifetimes, the first as a Highwayman, followed successively by lives as a Sailor, a Damn Builder and the Captain of a Starship. Within the last verse, the man ponders his next medium of existence, as outlined below: 

Ill fly a starship

Across the Universe divide

And when I reach the other side

I'll find a place to rest my spirit if I can

Perhaps I may become a highwayman again

Or I may simply be a single drop of rain

But I will remain

This song is a powerful representation of the hypothetical scenario by where one’s spirit lives on past the finite existence of their body, and I couldn’t help coming back to it as I learned more about the music industry over the course of this deep-dive. There is something deeply powerful about music as an art-form. It has the ability to evoke feelings ranging from joy to sadness, can spur nostalgia or the reminiscence over a specific moment in time, and is one of the few things in life, in my opinion, that can dim one’s anxieties over the past or the present and transport them truly into the now. Music’s origins, arguably, stem back to the earliest instances of humanity and will likely exist alongside our species until the very end. Taking the framework outlined by The Highwayman, the medium by which music is housed may differ with respect to time, but, at the end of the day, music will remain. 

To get a little bit of background on how the industry as a whole has evolved, we must first split music into three main sound constituents: analog, digital and virtual, each of which contain their own associated revolutions and have brought us to where we are today. Starting off with Analog, two key evolutions can be contained within, the emergence of the magnetic tape recorder and vinyl. The former has roots in Nazi-Germany, with the US obtaining audio recording technology that was developed during the war, post-allied victory, eventually using this information as a foundation for the first magnetic tape recorder, of which was released in 1948. The latter emerged around the same time, with the first records existing as 7-inch discs that could be played at almost 80 RPMs, supporting less than four minutes of playback on each side. Each of these technologies not only spurred consistent consumption of music by providing access to the art form that was only possible previously through live performance, but also resulted in a large amount of power being obtained and centered within record labels. With expensive equipment such such as pre-amplifiers, compressors, equalizers, soundboards and recording machines all being required to create music, and substantial resources needed to market and release said music, artists were largely at the mercy of these entities, a phenomenon that is omni-present today.

Moving on, in the late 1970s, the music industry started to feel the fact that vinyl record sales were dropping, a happening that resulted in the emergence of CDs in 1982. With the rise of digital recording methods decreasing costs associated with music production, the emergence of computers, as well as heightened consumption of music on the consumer-side of things, industry revenues went through the roof, reaching levels that have never been seen again. Being that as it may, the rise of the internet started to exploit holes in the value proposition labels were directing at customers. Elegantly explained within a Business Breakdown Podcast of UMG was the fact that there was an extremely high threshold for music consumption, with the industry being front-loaded to have revenue generated and profits made with initial purchases rather than over the lifetime of a customer, as seen with streaming today. With the rise of virtual sound, spurred by both Mp3 algorithms allowing for audio file sizes to be drastically reduced and widespread adoption of internet, ripping services soon took off, arguably coming into fruition as a response to the aforementioned consumer issues. The most popular of these technologies was Napster, a P2P file sharing service that allowed for users to obtain music with no upfront cost, solving some of the previously outlined issues with physical consumption mediums. Being that as it may, there were still UX issues ranging from the time-consuming nature of obtaining said music and the illegality of the process as a whole. 

iTunes came onto the scene shortly thereafter, a product that solved some of the UX issues that Napster suffered from, but fell victim to the fact that users had to incur additional costs with an increase in incremental music consumption. All of these happenings laid the groundwork for a disruption that would fundamentally alter the nature of the music industry as a whole, of which eventually became intertwined with the media consumption habits of modernity, streaming. 

Daniel Ek, founder and CEO of Spotify, has a very interesting twitter handle that one should take note of, @eldjsal. The Swedish form of this word is eldsjäl, roughly translating to “A Fiery Soul” in English and, as outlined by Ek on a Tim Ferris podcast appearance, is a label for someone who is intensely passionate about something and, through the good and the bad times, ends up persevering. It is clear, when one looks at the product roadmap that Spotify has traversed over the years, that fiery souls have been at the helm of this company from its very inception. In a 2010 keynote, Ek showcased a fully functional music-centered product, technology that was deemed innovative the time and eventually succeed where its predecessors and counterparts did not, engaging users with a vast music library and eventually becoming the market leader in a new rapidly expanding industry.  

Flash forward to today and the functionality that millions have come to rely on is built on the same foundation, however, Spotify’s vision is not. The company’s vision, and the upside I believe is associated with it, is now centered around all things audio. Not only is the company dominant with their share of music streaming, they have also branched out and established commendable footing in the podcast space, and more recently, delved into the realm of audiobooks. While some may have overlooked this opportunity due to relatively stagnant equity performance over the last few years, I will spend this research piece outlining the value proposition I believe the company offers investors and consumers alike. 

With all of that in mind, let’s delve into the main tailwinds and opportunities the company aims to benefit from in the coming years. 

2.0 Opportunity 

With Spotify’s newfound all-things-audio ambition, we can take note of some noticeable happenings within the broad media category as a whole. Staying surface level for a moment, users spend an extremely significant amount of time consuming audio on a daily basis, representing an enormous opportunity for monetization as a whole, with an Edison Report outlining the fact that the average US consumer spends an estimated 4 hours per day listening to different forms of audio. 4 hours!! 

In addition, with commendable mobile presence, Spotify is likely to continue to benefit from the fact that mobile phones have become the most dominant device in everyday life, a huge value proposition if the company is able to maintain its presence as the de facto location for mobile audio in the future: 

Lastly, it is worth touching upon the substantial amount of ad-market share that is still attributable to those that listen to AM/FM radio (shocking I know), an occurrence that is ripe for disruption attributable to Spotify. To put things into perspective, a 2020 Edison Research Share of the Ear Report estimated that approximately 30% of Audio Consumption occurs in the car. As a result, the majority of ad-supported audio time attributable to different age groups is also linked to AM/FM radio media consumption, as outlined below: 

With the rise of vehicles now being shipped with Apple CarPlay or Android Auto, it becomes highly likely that as the years progress, AM/FM audio stops becoming the default transportation-based audio consumption method and shifts to streaming as a result of technological enablement, which is likely to result in a shift in the amount of ad-spend directed at radio towards streaming mediums. 

Delving deeper, we can also start to look at category-specific happenings, i.e. those attributable to Music, Podcasts and Audiobooks. 

Music 

Starting off with Music, the two main happenings I am excited about are streaming’s evident dominance as the main music consumption method and digital live performances, each of which Spotify stands to substantially benefit from. Mentioned earlier, total US Recorded Revenues peaked in the late 90s as physical mediums started to face headwind pressures from digital transformation aided by the internet. As the years have gone on, Streaming has become the go-to medium for music consumption, a phenomenon that has started to increase US Revenues as a whole, existing as tailwinds the company can benefit from: 

It is also worth pondering the rate of digitization that has occurred with music as a media form in comparison to other content forms such as Video and Video Games. The latter has seen a rapid rise in SVOD and the former has seen arcades left in the dust, with industry-wide revenues in both avenues being at all time highs in comparison to what we can see outlined in the above image, with Audio still trying to reach levels seen in the 90s. Daniel Ek had his own take of this phenomenon in a recent Invest Like the Best Podcast. The CEO noted the fact that audio has been relatively slow to fully digitally transform, an exciting prospect given the growth Spotify has already sustained thus far. With analog consumption methods still remaining prevalent, such as previously mentioned radio, or people relying on traditional speaker technology, there is still has a long way to go. Thinking about the popularization of new, culturally-engrained, manners to listen to music, such as TikTok, or the rising prevalence of consumers leveraging smart speakers, of which BPI estimates increase streaming-based music consumption by anywhere from 10-15%, audio consumption does not appear to be fizzling out anytime soon. 

Moving on, in a Matthew Ball piece denoted The Audio Opportunity, the author outlined the significant growth seen in Concert Revenues over the last two decades, mainly attributable to smaller artists (non-top 100 tours):

With Digitally-enabled platforms offering the opportunity for artists to perform to millions of people without the constraints of traditional concerts, this not only fixes the scale issue that popular artists have struggled with (i.e. charging more people for a performance) but also allows for smaller incumbents to reach their smaller, niche audiences. Both are exciting prospects, existing as a call option of sorts on Spotify’s ability to continually monetize music consumption. 

Podcasting 

Spotify stands to benefit from the rise of Podcasting in a two-fold manner in the coming years. First off, Podcast Listeners are expected to reach approximately 505M total users, representing almost 24% of internet users by 2024, a staggering statistic, as outlined below: 

As previously alluded to with my radio assertions and Ek-backed analog to digital transformation happenings that are likely to drive continual growth in audio usage, it is highly likely that advertising spend is directed at these mediums increasingly in the coming years. With Global Podcast Revenue expected to reach $1.6B in FY’22, I believe these projections are significantly misrepresenting the opportunity here (radio advertising expenditures totalled $28B in 2021 and these expenditures do not benefit from data-driven targeted advertising like Spotify is capable of). Secondly, many are projecting Spotify to maintain a dominant footing on the podcast side of things in comparison to its main competitor Apple Podcasts, with projections for the US outlined below and similar dynamics existing globally, a phenomenon that is likely to be exacerbated as Spotify continues to work on generating and obtaining significant amounts of Spotify Original and Spotify Exclusive Content: 

Audiobooks 

Lastly, although it will be hard-pressed for Spotify to compete against the likes of Audible in the audiobook realm, the company’ activities in this space are far from negligible and will be of use from both a user acquisition point of view and to bolster UX as a whole. To gauge how the size of the Industry and the activity contained therein, one can take a look at Omdia Global Audiobook Revenue estimates, which are estimated to be recorded as $4.8B for FY’21 and grow at a 13.9% CAGR to $9.3B by 2026. In addition, Audiobooks are increasingly becoming a more substantial component of Spoken Word Audioshare, alongside their Podcast counterparts which have been steadily taking share from AM/FM radio over the last few years, as outlined below: 

In short, Spotify has an abundance of opportunities, that if executed upon, will sustain themselves as the clear leader in an industry undergoing massive transformation and being underestimated by many.

3.0 Technology 

Normally in this section of my deep-dives, I like to delve into the technical nuances of the various products that the associated company offers their customers. With Spotify however, I am going to frame this section a little differently. Since most of us are at the very least vaguely familiar with how their platform works and what it offers consumers, I am going to gloss over these features and focus instead on some key developments, acquisitions, strategies and happenings that I believe are imperative to understanding the company’s value proposition as a whole. 

Starting off high-level, the company offers users access to its platform in two distinct manners, with a free membership or through a premium counterpart. One can consume a significant amount of content ranging from music to podcasts, largely uninhibited with free access, however there are some annoyances ranging from ads present in music, lower sound quality, etc. Full differences can be seen outlined below: 

Using my own Spotify as an example, the platform evidently has an extreme focus on discoverability, and is one of the key reasons in my case that i’ve developed preferential treatment for this app in comparison to Apple Music, as an example. 

Spotify leverages an abundance of user data in order to accumulate user preferences for different forms of audio, of which can then be used to recommend audio in the forms of mixes, playlists and podcast suggestions. Using Discover Weekly as an example, it is estimated that the average user that interacts with this playlist is around 2X more engaged than the users that don’t, indicative of a preference for data-driven curated content suggestions. In the 2021 Invest Like the Best Podcast, Ek outlined the fact that he was always hesitant to discard any data since Spotify’s inception, despite pushes from employees. At the time this could’ve occurred without blinking twice, however looking at how technology has evolved since then, specifically with ML and AI, it is great that he didn’t. You can see how data has been incorporated into Spotify’s products by taking a second to ponder how exactly they’ve changed with respect to time. Years ago playlists may have been generic and separated by genre or artist, now if two users open up their Hip Hop mixes, as an example, they are likely to have a completely different set of songs recommended to them.

Challenges arise when a similar approach is taken to Podcasting. From a time point of view, the error of consumption is much higher. If I listen to a bad three minute song, the repercussions of this decision or recommendation are much lower in comparison to the substantially larger time investment that is required for one to immerse themselves within a podcast. This is where the Podz acquisition comes into play. In essence the now-umbrella company leverages ML/AI to create an audio news feed of different 60 second clips, allowing consumers to browse new podcasts in an easily digestible manner. In a great Not Boring Article about Podz, Packy outlined the fact that Instagram reinvented Facebook by providing quality photos on mobile, TikTok reinvented Youtube with immersive mobile video, Twitter reinvented news media with short blurbs of information and now the Spotify+Podz combination may be able to offer a similar value proposition for Podcasting, exciting to say the least. 

Spotify’s growth tactics and reach within the Podcast space do not stop there. A few years ago the company acquired Anchor, an enterprise that has a suite of different tools for podcast creation, distribution and monetization. 

To gauge just how successful this acquisition has been one can look at the 2021 Podcast Wrapped Report numbers, which outlines the fact that a staggering 1.2M podcasts were added to Spotify in 2021, of which 80% were published by independent creators on Anchor! The company also later acquired Megaphone, a podcasting host that allows users to publish, monetize and measure their podcast business, also possessing a breadth of enterprise clients and acting as a supply side software of sorts that routes podcast ad inventory to ad networks. When these two acquisitions were combined alongside the Spotify Audience Network initiative, an exciting value proposition blossomed from its midst. 

In essence, Spotify combined the features of Anchor, i.e. the new abundance of independent and smaller podcasts, with the functionality of Megaphone, i.e. an abundance of enterprise clients and the ability to insert ads into podcasts published on both Spotify and other locations as well (SAI and DAI functionality), to change up the game for podcasting advertising. What Spotify denotes as Strategic Ad insertion (SAI) is essentially the ability for advertisements to actually be successful no matter what the audience type or size may be. Whether one has a podcast to a small group of thirty listeners talking about Japanese contemporary fiction, or if they have a huge following talking about the latest and greatest technology companies, the theoretical ROI on ad placement should still be the same. This creates an interesting flywheel dynamic of which was mentioned in the most recent earnings conference call. As more creators join the platform, the more audiences should grow and the more advertisers will want to join the platform to fill said inventory of both Spotify original and third-party megaphone and anchor created content alike. With all of these moving pieces, when the dest settles you are left with podcasting ad tech stack that is powerful to say the least, with the buy and supply side of the ad network now interconnected within SPAN.

I also am a fan of how Spotify is really upping their value proposition to Podcast Creators. Outside of the ability to create and distribute their podcasts using Spotify, the company’s Open Access Platform is something truly unique in the space. They can not only earn advertising dollars on their content, they also now have additional monetization options such as taking the premium subscription route. This is not only native to content created on the platform, Spotify allows for users that are members of third-party platform’s podcasts to import their membership to and listen to associated content on Spotify (i.e. if I am a member of Motley Fool I can listen to premium pods through the Spotify app). 

The company is also further bolstering the opportunity for advertising through their recent acquisition of Whooshkaa, a company that allows radio broadcasters to turn their existing audio content into on-demand podcast content. In short, this happening allows for more third-party content to be brought into the Audience network, which as a result connects advertiser with another set of audiences. As a side tangent, this also may further enrich Spotify’s ability to continue to take more market share from AM/FM radio, but that is a little more speculative. 

Another top-of-funnel strategy that is likely to reap continuous rewards is the company’s continuous betterment of their exclusive podcast content. As i’m sure most of you are aware, the company has not been shy with the amount of effort they’ve put towards acquiring star-studded Spotify Original or Spotify Exclusive content, or the capital that has been directed at these efforts. The company has acquired Gimlet, a studio that has produced the likes of Reply All, Startup and other popular shows that have garnered large amounts of media attention. The company acquired Paracast, which contains two production studios under its umbrella, of which have created 121+ hit podcasts. In addition, the company acquired The Ringer, a studio founded by Bill Simmons, of which has enormously popular sports and sports culture-centered podcasts. In short, the company has quite evidently beefed up their podcast offerings, a phenomenon I believe showcases how serious they are about this opportunity. Not only can the company leverage pricing power on both the advertising on exclusive content, as an example, or the licensing of in-house created original content, but this is also an enormously useful customer acquisition tool. Using Call Her Daddy as an example, someone may become enamoured with the show, listen to it on Spotify due to the exclusivity arrangement, and then become a premium subscriber or ad-supported MAU as a result. Even Joe Rogan, who has been subject to an extreme amount of criticism/negative publicity of late, has only grown more popular. In Q3’21, he garnered more attention than any other mainstream news program, and google search trends have skyrocketed over the last few weeks. Regardless of your opinion of the man, this is quite evidently a net positive investment for Spotify. 

Sticking with podcasts for just one more moment, Spotify acquired Podsights just last night, an exciting acquisition that will bolster their ad tech platform’s ability to offer insights to ad publishers. Within the official PR the following was mentioned:

Over the past year, we’ve been strengthening Megaphone’s already robust offering—most recently with the acqusition of Whooshka and its broadcast-to-podcast technology—to ensure it’s the best place for podcast publishers to create, monetize, and measure their podcast businesses. And now with the acquisition of Chartable, we will be further enhancing Megaphone’s suite of tools with the integration of Chartable’s audience insights and cutting-edge promotional tools, SmartLinks and SmartPromos. These tools will make it easier for publishers to turn audience insights into action and expand their listenership while ultimately growing their businesses.

Moving on, we should touch upon the company’s acquisition of Betty Labs and Locker Room. Locker Room is essentially an audio-first sports talk platform that lets fans follow different news breaks, interact socially with friends and listen to their favourite commentators LIVE. Putting emphasis on this audio being live is of importance here, specifically since it most likely represents the early instances of potentially much larger future endeavours that Spotify has planned for this space. Despite Clubhouse falling in and out of pop culture’s grace, there is likely still a significant opportunity in this area, particularly when applied to scenarios such as digital concerts, as speculated about earlier. 

As an example, the Fortnite Rift Tour featuring Ariana Grande garnered around 2M views after the fact and 10s of millions of views at the time of occurrence, so speculating here about live audio eventually being intertwined with Spotify’s platform is exciting to say the least. 

Spotify has also started their journey into the Audiobook space with their acquisition of Findaway. The company offers the world’s largest audiobook catalog through their AudioEngine segment, Findaway Voices which allows for audiobooks to be created, distributed to different seller platforms (audible etc.) and monetized allowing creators to keep 80% of their royalties, Publisher Services which offers access to every audiobook reseller around the world and more. In essence, this catalog will allow for Spotify to gain access to one of the widest possible arrays of audiobooks in the world that can be then used to give listeners an additional audio experience on the Spotify app and will also intertwine the company with another avenue of creators, both equally important occurrences. 

Lastly, as I alluded to earlier with the digitization of the automobile and how this is likely to result in heightened instances of streaming, at least in the developed world, Spotify has also directed efforts at offering consumers an alternative through the release of the Car Thing. 

In short, this piece of technology is able to gift even the oldest of automobile with car-play-esque functionality, again directed at taking more of the four-hour-a-day audio consumption share from the likes of radio. 

With all of these musings in mind, I hope I was able to convey the sheer volume of efforts Spotify has on the go right now, not only to make an interesting user experience in music, but also with podcasts and audio as well. 

4.0 How Spotify Makes $$$ 

Spotify generates two main forms of Revenue: Ad-Supported Revenue and Premium Membership Revenue. The latter is generated through Spotify’s sales of display, audio and video advertising delivered through music and podcast mediums and are usually sold on a cost-per-thousand basis. The company also generates money through different advertising exchanges and platforms to distribute ad inventory for purchase. Premium Membership Revenue is more straightforward, with Spotify getting paid by consumers for different membership options, with US options and associated price points outlined below: 

Getting from the top to the bottom line is much more difficult however, specifically since there are a series of complicated arrangements that exist between Spotify and a series of intermediaries. More specifically, Spotify is required to pay out royalties to a host of different parties depending on where they are located within the music value chain. Two pieces were instrumental in my understanding of this topic. The first was Sleepwell’s Music Streaming Royalties 101 and the second was Patient Capital’s Slide Deck, I highly recommend giving both a read. I will be summarizing the associated information the best I can but feel free to go straight to the source if these explanations are not sufficient. 

The first thing one needs to understand is that a song can be split into two components, the composition, i.e. if music were translated into its written form (attributable to the publishing industry) and the master, i.e. the recording of said song after it has been produced (attributable to the recorded music industry). The publishing constituents will receive two sets of royalties in exchange for the use of the composition: performance royalties (paid every time music is performed in a public setting) and mechanical royalties (every time music is reproduced through a physical medium). Upon receipt of either of these royalties, cuts will be distributed to the collection agency or performance rights organization, the publisher and the songwriter. The recorded music constituents receive royalties each time a song is streamed and cuts are distributed to labels/distributors, depending on if you’re a signed or indie artist, producers and managers and finally, the performer. If you would like a more in-depth explanation regarding the nuances of these relationships I encourage you to read the aforementioned sources, however, for the sake of brevity, I have stuck to a more analytical approach. More specifically, as Spotify receives paid-subscription revenue, this is pooled together and then distributed to related parties on a per-stream basis. I have outlined the percentages that gets kept by the company themselves as well as the percentage distributed to other parties, for both the scenario where the artist is signed with a label, and for the scenario where they are independent. Please note that these are ballpark estimates and are not accurate to the exact basis point:

Looking at each of these scenarios, you may have noticed the fact that the artist receives a much smaller piece of the pie when they are signed with a label in comparison to when they are independent. As such, a discussion regarding the nature of these relationships is worthwhile. Researching this dynamic I kept coming back to this verse from one of my favourite songs, The Devil Wears a Suit and Tie by Colter Wall. 

…

I heard him howlin' as he passed me by, and he said

I know you I know you, young man, I know you by the state of your hands

You're a six string picker, just as I... I am

Let me learn ya some I know a few turns to make all the girls dance

Don't you know the Devil wears a suit and tie, I saw him driving down the sixty one in early July,

White as a cotton field, and sharp as a knife, I heard him howlin' as he passed me by

Foolish foolish was I, damn my foolish eyes

Cause that man's lessons had a price, oh sweet price

My sweet soul, everlasting

My very own, Eternal light

The song details an experience a young musician had with the Devil, wherein he sold his soul in exchange for learning the songs that would make all the girls dance. Related back to this research piece, i’m sure you’ve heard many a story from artists outlining how they’ve had to sell their souls to labels in order to make their dreams a reality. Although there is most definitely a case for the labels striking relationships that are more fair to the artist, there is more to the story than that. Labels operate in a very similar way to Venture Capital Firms, where their businesses are reliant on a small amount of out-sized returns in order to remain profitable. Circling back to the aforementioned UMG podcast, mentioned within was the fact that only approximately 10% of the artists that sign with a label actually recoup their initial investment. In a Chris Dixon article a similar story is outlined for VC firms, with data from 1985 onwards outlining the fact that approximately 6% of the investments drove around 60% of the returns.  For the artists that do make it big, this deal does often times end up being unfair, however, for the artists that don’t make it big, they got a shot to follow their dream and oftentimes had the help of substantial amounts of resources to do just that, so the same can’t really be said. With over 60,000 new songs uploaded to Spotify each day, labels still have a value proposition in the industry that is not going away anytime soon. Outside of labels owning a large amount of back catalog music that Spotify require for their library, labels also offer artists their abundant marketing, outreach and PR resources, their connections etc. which on paper don’t seem like much, but at the end of the day could be the difference between them standing out in within the expanding abyss or not. 

Before moving on, one should also note the fact that the company doesn’t distinguish between Revenue generated by audio type, or the costs associated with said audio type. In essence, this means that the labels are likely getting a piece of the pie when said pie is generated by podcast consumption (as an example). I believe this is a component of the company’s business model that will have to change in the coming years, especially as the company starts capitalizing on the all things audio opportunity.

5.0 Financial Analysis 

Please note that I used a 1.13 EUR to USD conversion factor within this analysis. 

Income Statement 

Revenue

Spotify’s Revenue came in at approximately $9.67B for 2021, representing a 23% increase on a YoY basis. The change in this value over the last few years can be seen outlined below: 

The company still derives the majority of their Revenue from the sale of Premium Memberships, with the Revenue associated with this constituent increasing approximately 19% YoY. However, ad-related revenue increased significantly for FY’21 at 62% YoY, now representing 12.5% of Total Revenue: 

With the SPAN (Spotify Audience Network) initiative amongst others, it will be imperative for Top-Line to see bigger contributions from Ad-Supported Revenue if a bull thesis is to remain intact (more on that later). Lastly, the proportions of Revenue attributable to various international locations has remained relatively consistent over the years and is another metric investors should consistently monitor going forwards: 

Cost of Revenue

COR increased at a nearly identical rate to Top-Line at 21% YoY, coming in at approximately $7.077B. The change in this Metric itself and as a % of Total Revenues can be seen outlined below: 

The change in the primary constituents, i.e. COR attributable to Premium and Ad-Supported business segments can be seen outlined below: 

Put simply, we are starting to see some Cost Efficiencies exhibited in the Premium business segment, as a result of more favourable terms being struck between Spotify and labels, whereas Ad-Supported has remained relatively constant over the years, increasing ever so slightly YoY as a result of SPAN activity and slightly altered royalty arrangements. 

Operating Expenses

Operating Expenses increased 8% on a YoY basis, coming in at $2.497B, as outlined below: 

OPEX has remained largely fixed on a relative basis, oscillating between the 26-30% range with respect to Total Revenue, a phenomenon that translates to OPEX’s constituents, relatively speaking, as outlined below: 

In my eyes, OPEX is where it is needs to be (particularly R&D and S&M) to ensure consistent growth and the addition of new platform features, all whilst maintaining slight profitability on an Operating Income basis. 

Margins and Profitability 

Starting off with Gross Profit, the company achieved approximately $2.6B in Gross Profit, increasing 29% YoY. Gross Margins are the highest they’ve ever been on an annual basis, coming in at 27% for 2021, as outlined below: 

The change in this metric’s two constituents, Premium and Ad-Supported Gross margins, can be seen outlined below: 

Both Premium Gross Profit Margins and Ad-Supported Gross Profit Margins improved YoY, coming in at 31% and 10% respectively. As Spotify starts to leverage the ad-tech platform they have built, I believe ad-supported gross margins are likely to improve in a big way given the high-margin nature of the advertising on their original and exclusive content. I also believe there is room for improvement in Premium GP margins, especially as Spotify gains the upper hand on their label relationships, but also from pricing power as well. I will touch on that more within the Thesis Section of this report. 

The change in the company’s Operating Income, Net Income and EBITDA as well as their associated margins can be seen outlined below: 

As previously alluded to, Spotify achieved profitability on an Operating Level for the first time on a full-year basis for FY’21, although I am hesitant to say this continues to expand in the positive direction in the coming years given their growth, acquisition and expansion activities, it is most definitely a net-positive overall. The company is also on the edge of Net Income Profitability and is slightly profitable as gauged by EBITDA measures.

Balance Sheet

The structure of the company’s assets can be seen outlined below: 

Assets are slightly skewed in the liquid direction, consisting predominantly of $2.7B in Cash and Equivalents, followed thereafter by Short Term Investments and Trade/Receivables. Long Term Assets are predominantly composed of Long Term Assets, Goodwill, Lease ROU Assets and Property/Equipment, in order of descending magnitude. The structure of liabilities can be seen outlined below: 

Liabilities are slightly mainly liquid, with Current Liabilities consisting mainly of Accrued Expenses, Payables and Deferred Revenue, in descending order.
