Long Term Liabilities are primarily composed of Exchangeable Notes and Lease Liabilities. Overall Spotify has a thought-out balance sheet that is healthy and free of any warning signs/red flags. 

Cash Flow Statement

The change in Spotify’s various Cash Flows over the last several fiscal years can be seen outlined below: 

CFO increased approximately 39.4% on a YoY basis, coming in at approximately $408M for the year. CFI was approximately $(211)M attributable primarily to the sales/maturities of investment offset mainly by the purchase of short term investments and cash used for business combinations. CFF was approximately $1.4B, attributable almost entirely to the proceeds from the issuance of Exchangeable Notes. The company’s FCF and FCF Margin can be seen outlined below: 

The company is slightly FCF positive having generated relatively consistent FCF over the last few years. As always, as a gauge of sorts, this metric less SBC can be seen outlined below: 

In short, the company’s FCF is relatively minuscule relative to their top-line. As such, I anticipate that the issuance of additional stock or debt will coincide accordingly with any further acquisition activity or related expansionary/strategic efforts. As a shareholder, I believe Daniel Ek is extremely capable and and has shown an aptitude for strategically allocating capital in a direction that aligns with Spotify’s vision to remain a dominant force in the audio industry.

6.0 Key Performance Indicators 

The most important metrics to track in order to gauge the overall health of the Spotify business as a whole are MAUs, Ad-Supported MAUs, Premium Subscribers and Premium ARPU. Starting off with MAUs, these values increased 18% YoY, coming in at approximately 406M: 

Although growth is slightly tapering off, I have no problem underwriting low to mid teen MAU growth for the next five or so years. We are also starting to see noticeable progress made in Spotify’s International Expansion, with the company’s two most penetrated end markets (North America and Europe) gradually losing share to both Latin America and the Rest of the World: 

The amount of Premium Subscribers has been steadily rising, increasing 16% YoY coming in at approximately 180M paid subs as the company expands premium presence internationally, as outlined below: 

Being that as it may, Premium ARPU has decreased over the years as a result of the popularity of the aforementioned bundle or student plans, as reflected below: 

Moving on, Ad-Supported MAUs on the other hand are showing commendable growth, with a 27% YoY increase, coming in at approximately 253M. 

Additional Insights can be drawn when looking at Premium Subs and Ad-Supported MAUs as % of Total MAUs. Premium Subs, relatively speaking, have remained consistent whereas Ad-Supported MAUs as a % of Total MAUs have started to make a resurgence back to 2016 levels: 

Lastly, being that ARPU is calculated as an average of quarterly ARPU values, we can zoom out and view this from an annual POV by taking the quotient of Premium/Ad-Supported Revenue and associated users. As previously alluded to, Premium ARPU has been on a downtrend and is likely to exhibit similar behaviour unless Spotify exerts more pricing-power centered decisions, Ad-Supported ARPU on the other hand has improved slightly over the last few years. 

Spotify’s grandiose visions of being heavily reliant on ad-related revenue are directly tied to these metrics. With the audio consumption of their users starting to include more podcasts, the ad-developments associated with SPAN and the leveraging of the abundance of user-data that can be bolstered to create extremely effective ad-targeting, I believe ARPU in this area should steadily increase, and in order for Spotify to reach the height of their ambitions it will need to. 

7.0 Thesis

My thesis for holding Spotify is threefold. First I believe audio has been significantly under monetized and similar to its video and video-game counterparts will start to realize its full potential through Spotify’s International Expansion, Focus on Ads and Exertion of Pricing Power. Second, after studying how Spotify is connected to Record Labels I believe they are beginning to have the upper hand in this relationship and will potentially be able to leverage their position in order to improve the health of both their Gross Margins and Bottom Line. Third, I believe Spotify will continue to exert dominance in the Audio Industry as a whole and with a strategically-aligned and focused management team should be able to continue to wane competitive forces. 

Starting with Audio and circling back to Matthew Ball’s Audio Opportunity piece, when we compare the aforementioned revenues attributable to the audio industry as a whole, with those of video and video games, there is an evident stark contrast: 

All three industries have experience rapid digitization but audio has not reached the revenues reached in the late 90s again. How do these levels get reached again? I have mentioned the advertising opportunity, which I believe as share continues to get taken from radio and as ad dollars get diverted to podcasting etc., will only grow as a percentage of total Revenue. International Expansion should also be taken into consideration. With the rapid rise of smartphones, exhibiting a proportional relationship to MAU growth, there is still significant opportunities for Spotify to capture value in Emerging Markets using 2020 Smartphone Penetration values as a yardstick: 

As these regions continue to get access to technology, become banked and as audio continues to intertwine itself with global pop culture, there is a long runway ahead for this opportunity. Lastly, Spotify has yet to test its luck exerting pricing power. Using Netflix as an example, the company has raised prices of its membership in developed markets such as UCAN (Canada and the US) as outlined below by The Science of Hitting (highly recommend subbing to his Substack): 

In doing so Netflix has been able to extract more value from developed markets and has not deterred customers in the process due to the value proposition of their platform as a whole. Spotify has had consistent premium membership prices in developed markets despite an ever-improving content offering on the platform. In the coming years I would like to see Spotify take a similar strategy to Netflix in order to negate the downtrend of Premium ARPU and I find it highly likely that they do just that. 

Moving on, I believe Spotify should be able to negotiate more favourable agreements with labels. In reference to the distribution of premium memberships discussed earlier, Spotify shares premium membership revenue with labels no matter the user’s usage habits, a problematic occurrence when one thinks about the rise of Podcasting consumption overall. Looking at the percentage of UMG, WMG and SMG’s Music Revenues attributable to streaming (the dominant record labels) we can see that they are becoming heavily reliant on streaming as a whole as the years have gone on: 

Spotify on the other hand, though still heavily reliant on back-catalogue and the other music controlled by labels, has decreased the amount of streams attributable to label content over the last few years: 

As more independent music takes off, as labels’ reliance on Spotify for revenues only increases, I believe Spotify will, at the very least, be able to negotiate agreements so that they are only sharing music-related revenue with labels, an enticing prospect to say the least and something that should help Spotify’s business health as a whole. 

Finally, I believe Spotify’s positioning relative to incumbents is extremely favourable and is likely to result in a winner take-most situation for the company. Not only does the company have a more engaged user base as alluded to earlier, but they also benefit from having more listeners in different audio segments, i.e. music and podcasting (as previously discussed the company recently surpassed Apple’s podcast listeners in the States). In addition the company also benefits from a management teams with levels of skin in the game and a focus on the audio experience as a whole that I believe cannot be replicated by Big Tech. Using both company and Edison Research estimates data we can then compare the amount of premium subscribers attributable to each company: 

The above numbers of competitors should be taken as ballpark estimates, however, Spotify quite clearly is dominant and I believe they will only be widening this gap in the coming years. In addition, as a shareholder, I believe the bet that Spotify captures the audio opportunity is largely contingent on management’s ability to execute and convert vision into reality. With both Ek and co-founder Lorenzton having significant beneficial ownership of the company, as outlined below, I believe management is directly aligned with shareholder interests heading into the coming years. 

8.0 Conclusion

In short, Spotify is on a quest to capture the opportunity provided by an industry that is rapidly expanding in all directions. With an impressive breadth of technology that is currently unmatched within the industry, I believe the future is quite bright, and I will continue to stick by my assertion that Spotify is one of the most under-appreciated investing opportunities available in public equities today. Thank you for reading my research.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, subscribe and share!

Share

Subscribe now

If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

Leave a comment

item.title: Crowdstrike ($CRWD)
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to MT Capital Research! If you’re new, join a group of 4050 Informed Investors who receive frequent reports on the World’s most interesting Tech Companies by subscribing below: 

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an in-depth analysis on CrowdStrike Holdings, Inc. Within I will discuss the main tailwinds the company aims to benefit from and give a general overview on what one should understand about Cybersecurity in general. In addition, I will delve into more company-specific information, analyzing and breaking down their technology, how they make money, their most recent financials and discussing some KPIs and growth levers that the company aims to utilize going forwards. The format of this research, similar to my past reports, can be seen outlined below. Please feel free to skip ahead to any sections that you feel are most useful: 

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Industry and Opportunity

3.0 Technology 

4.0 How Crowdstrike makes $$$

5.0 Financial Analysis

6.0 Key Performance Indicators

7.0 Competitive Landscape, Valuation and Discussion

8.0 Conclusion

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitute for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investment. 

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content and analysis, give me a follow on Twitter: 

Follow Me!

With all of that out of the way, let’s get started. 

1.0 Introduction 

The rise of the internet, though astounding and world-changing, has resulted in the growth of impending tail risks, phenomena where unchecked vulnerability and fragility may result in the harm of corporations and individuals alike. The internet exists as a gateway to endless arrays of information, entertainment sources, connections with fellow members of our species and now, more times than not, presents itself as one of the most common mediums for interaction between corporation and consumer. With businesses intertwining their processes with an online world, breaches to their connected infrastructure not only pose a risk to their processes, infrastructure and technology, but also to the people that use them. When delving into the plethora of high-profile security breaches, one may recall instances like the 2017 Equifax data breach, where attackers exfiltrated hundreds of millions of customer records from the credit company, or the 2019/2020 SolarWinds Orion product breach, an occurrence that left the data, networks and systems of thousands of customers, ranging from Fortune 500 entities to Government Agencies, at the mercy of said hackers. There is an ever-increasing need for companies to create technology and services that help protect our digital world from the looming risk of security breaches and Crowdstrike offers itself as a shining light amongst darkness. Put simply, Crowdstrike provides technology that primarily protects an Enterprise’s Endpoints, with additional modules aimed at shielding Companies’ Cloud Workloads. We will delve further into the technical specifics of the company’s products in later sections, but for now it is important to become familiar with the Crowdstrike Falcon Platform, of which contains a series of security modules, each providing functionality related but not limited to corporate workload security, vulnerability management, managed security services, IT operations management, threat intelligence services, identity protection and log management, etc. 

With this brief overview in mind, let’s delve deeper into the Cybersecurity space as a whole and analyze the main tailwinds the company aims to leverage within their operations and growth initiatives. 

2.0 Background and Opportunity 

The main area of Cybersecurity that one should familiarize themselves with in order to gain a heightened understanding of Crowdstrike’s operations is Endpoint Security. According to Gartner, a fully functional Endpoint Protection Platform should possess the following features: 

  • Prevent and protect against security threats that include malware, malware-free or fireless exploits. 

  • The ability to exert some form of control (allow/block) software, scripts or processes

  • The ability to detect and prevent threats using behavioural analysis of device activity, application and user data

  • Facilities to investigate security incidents further, and or obtain guidance for remediation when an exploit potentially evades protective controls

Crowdstrike’s Falcon Platform and the associated modules contain therein mesh undeniably to satisfy each of the above criteria and I encourage you to revisit these points at different stages of the report to verify this assertion for yourself. Before delving deeper into the importance of these features we must first understand what an endpoint is. Put simply, an endpoint is any piece of hardware that connects to a network, with an example being the laptop computer you connect to your workplace’s network with. These devices will then interact with the Edge, a buzzword that I'm sure many of you have come across of late. The edge is an intermediary point between the endpoint device and either the cloud/physical database hardware, of which is commonly encompassed by/denoted as the company’s data centers. Edge devices are the network gateway that facilitates interactions between the two aforementioned entities.

​​When one takes into consideration the above oversimplified diagram, it is clear that through the exploitation of various types of endpoint devices, malicious actors could gain access to the company’s highly sensitive infrastructure. The most common technique to either compromise or exploit an endpoint device is malware (i.e. malicious software). There are 8 common forms of malware, of which can be seen outlined and shortly described below: 

  1. Adware: Unwanted, spam-like and malicious advertising that continually pop up and may result in additional malware being downloaded by the user through inadvertent interaction with said ads

  2. Fileless malware: malware that doesn’t use executable files to infect devices but rather leverages RAM to avoid detection 

  3. Virus: Malware that is attached to files, executes once said file is launched and encrypts, corrupts or moves data 

  4. Worm: malware that replicates itself and spreads from device to device throughout a network 

  5. Trojan: a program that appears to be legitimate but is in fact malicious, able to spread similarly to a Virus or Worm

  6. Bots: Malware that performs an automated task without requiring any interaction, can quickly infect devices creating a botnet that can then be leveraged by hackers

  7. Ransomware: Malware that encrypts a device’s data and holds said data until ransom is paid 

  8. Spyware: malware that infiltrates a device and monitors the activities of the associated user

With these definitions in mind, it is clear that the primary objective of an endpoint protection is the ability to negate the potential harmful effects of the wide array of aforementioned malware and (malware/file)-less attacks. We will delve into how Crowdstrike is able to successfully appease the criteria Gartner sets for EPPs, but for now, it is worth going over the general opportunity that Crowdstrike has in front of it. First off cybersecurity is an issue that is omnipresent within our global landscape and is a phenomena that companies will have to deal with likely for decades to come. According to a study performed by the Ponemon Institute, approximately 68% of organizations have experienced one or more endpoint attacks that successfully compromised data or their IT infrastructure [3]. Delving deeper, ransomware, one of the most commonly used forms of malware, has been used in cyber-attacks affecting 47% of SMBs (small to medium businesses) and 54% of larger organizations (1,000-5000+ employees) [4]. Endpoint breaches are not only increasing in frequency but are also becoming more destructive to resources as well, with IBM estimating that the average large-company data breach costs approximately $4.27M and a successful endpoint attack somewhere in the $7.1-$8.94M range, on average [5]. Secondly, digital transformation, though essential to sustained growth in our day and age, is likely increasing the vulnerability of the modern enterprise. Within legacy network infrastructure it was common for protection methods to encompass endpoints, various on-site users, servers, applications etc. Now this perimeter expanded, a phenomena that has obviously been aided by heightened adoption of various technologies, and spurred by the emergence of the pandemic, now must encircle new cloud applications, remote employees, mobile devices, hybrid cloud environments etc, as outlined below: 

In general the more endpoints that enter the trusted perimeter of a corporation, the more data that is sensitive/mission-critical in nature ends up being stored on said endpoints, thus the more capable the endpoint protection must be. An additional phenomena that should be accounted for is the rise of Zero-Trust architecture. Traditional perimeter network security, of which I have alluded to above, focuses on keeping attackers from breaching, but is vulnerable to devices that have already made their within and operate inside. Traditional tech such as VPNs, SIEMs, access controls, firewalls etc. build layers around the perimeter but have higher susceptibility to attacks. Zero Trust on the other hand is more secure and allows for interesting infrastructure modifications to be made. Working in the opposite manner, the architecture assumes the network has been compromised and thus constantly challenges users to verify that they are trustworthy. This architecture removes the need for the perimeter and doesn’t require server resources to be centralized, a design phenomenon that allows servers to become endpoints in themselves. Muji from Hyperrgrowth, in his excellent Flavors of Security Post, which I highly recommend reading if you want a heightened understanding of Cybersecurity, outlines this fact nicely:

“Zero Trust means NO PERIMETER, and hence, no EDGE gateways needed. Your server resources no longer need to be centralized, and can be scattered across any environment. What was edge compute becomes just another server or service. Every server becomes just another endpoint - so your network essentially becomes endpoint-to-endpoint. This layout dovetails nicely with using external SaaS services and cloud infrastructure, as those are just more endpoints. User devices will now talk directly to biz op services and database systems, regardless of where those live. Endpoint security becomes critical, and it must be layered directly with network security.”

The move towards Zero-Trust is not just a Silicon Valley buzzword. Rather, the United States government is also pushing for agencies to adopt Zero-Trust after a May 2021 executive order was signed in order to bolster the federal government’s cybersecurity [7]. Taking all of these points into consideration, it becomes clear that Endpoint Security has and will likely to become even more paramount to Modern Companies in the coming decade.

Zooming out, digital transformations are likely to continue to become more and more cloud-based, a phenomenon that will benefit companies with Cloud-native security solutions that have been enlisted to protect rapidly expanding breadths of endpoints. To correctly size up this assertion a recent CIO survey performed by Morgan Stanley estimates that approximately 25% of application workloads resided in the Public Cloud in Q4’21, with the value anticipated to reach 44% by 2024, an estimation I feel is likely understating the magnitude of this directional opportunity: 

In addition, Cybersecurity remains situated in a highly defensible position, of which is unlikely to be severely affected by macroeconomic conditions ranging from rate hikes to wage inflation, being that is it of such huge importance to the wellbeing of corporations. More specifically, Security Projects remain the least likely of IT projects to get cut, according to surveyed CIOs: 

Lastly, it is worth discussing Crowdstrike’s TAM, a figure that they anticipate to be accurately represented as $54.8B in 2022, of which is expected to grow at a 2-yr CAGR of 11% and reach $67.1B by 2024.  As I mentioned above, there is also a growing phenomenon of moving workloads to the clouds, and thus a larger need for Cloud Security solutions. Within a recent investor presentation, Crowdstrike outlined the fact that Cloud Security is likely not being allocated enough of total IT budgets, a happening that is likely to change as further cloud adoption occurs. Out of the $106.4B in total Cloud Spend that occurred in 2020, as estimated by the International Data Corporation, only 1.1% of this budget was directed at Cloud Security solutions, or $1.2B. If one takes the IDC suggestion for Cloud Security spend as a % of Total IT Budgets, a recommended 5-10%, and use these estimates in conjunction with the $217.7B 2023 Estimates for Cloud Spend, we’d arrive at a $12.4B opportunity using only 5.7% of the average IT budget. 

Regardless of whether these estimates will be 100% accurate or not, it is clear that there is a humongous opportunity for Crowdstrike to cater towards companies in a digitally transformative age, excel with the provision of Endpoint Security Solutions, and benefit from the overall acceptance of Cybersecurity as a whole. I have barely scratched the surface here, however, I hope I was able to convey a sliver of the magnitude of the opportunity in front of Crowdstrike before we move on to breaking down the company’s technology.

3.0 Technology 

In order to get a deeper understanding of Crowdstrike as a company, we must split up their technology into some easily digestible segments, of which can be seen outlined below and described in detail within this section:

Taking a bottoms-up approach to the above figure, we can start our analysis of the general functionality of Crowdstrike’s tech at Endpoints. As previously discussed, Endpoints range from workstations to mobile devices, to the multitude of different hardware possibilities encompassed within the IoT. In order for any cybersecurity offering to then work, a Lightweight Agent must be installed on the Endpoint that requires protection, i.e. a form of software that takes up almost negligible amounts of storage space in the grand scheme of things. The key differentiating factor between how Crowdstrike deploys their agents in comparison to the majority of competitors is the fact that only a single intelligent agent is required, working in conjunction with all of the company’s various capabilities. On the opposite end of the spectrum, legacy vendors usually require endpoints to install a different agent for each associated use-case, a burdensome happening that is net-negative with regards to both performance, UX, storage etc. At this point you may be wondering what exactly the agents on these endpoints do. In essence, these agents capture, analyze and relay data gathered from the various workflows of the endpoint, to other components of the security system. Kernel and user-mode modules go one step further with said data, consistently analyzing it and leveraging the power of local-situation models in order to dictate whether or not preventative/reparative actions are required for any threats an endpoint may face. As mentioned, data is relayed to other components of the security system for further analysis. The first component of note is Threat Graph, a cloud-delivered graph database. Graph databases are essentially a unique technique-driven manner of both storing and retrieving data from databases, with individual records being stored as nodes that are connected via vertices, representing a relationship between a set of unique occurrences, highlighting potential similarities/connections between attempted breaches that can be then used for preventative analysis, as examples. This tech segment also has additional features ranging from AI analysis, of which identifies new threats in real time, a search engine that allows threat responders to get info they need quickly, API functionality that allows threat graph to be integrated with workflows and more. 

These data techniques/functionality are further bolstered when one views them in conjunction with both Falcon XDR and Humio. Starting off with the former, this platform functionality was announced in October of this year and essentially extends the company’s current EDR (Endpoint Detection and Response) capabilities. In essence, this functionality will leverage usage data it is receiving from various endpoints and act on potential threats in real-time before they become costly breaches. XDR (Extended Detection and Response) takes it one step further, ingesting an array of telemetry (i.e. data from a wide variety of communication sources such as IaaS and SaaS data sources), which, when combined with AI and ML techniques, can be used to both expedite and extend preventative action across the security stack. Moving over to the latter, Humio is a platform that was acquired by Crowdstrike, of which offers industry-leading log management, market-leading data compression techniques, useful and expedient search capabilities, which then results in a higher degree of observability across security teams. When one thinks about the fact that on average, a typical endpoint generates approximately 100 Gb of unfiltered system event data per day, as well as the fact that a modern corporation will contain thousands of endpoints, the ability to compress data in an effective manner and leverage it for preventative analysis will be extremely valuable to say the least. Falcon Fusion works to automate complex workflows, leveraging the power of the cloud in order to provide machine guided remediation and accelerated response times, allowing security teams to handle both the expanding complexity and attack surface of their associated enterprise. As an example, if a certain endpoint attack/usage occurrence were to occur, Falcon Fusion can be used to trigger a workflow rather than requiring a traditional manual/monotonous process. Further illustration of this tech in action can be seen outlined below: 

With all of these platform components in mind, we can now delve into Crowdstrike’s modules, of which can be thought of as cloud offerings that give customers differing functionality, depending on the security niche they would like protection/services for. Crowdstrike has modules contained within the following subcategories: Endpoint Security, Cloud Security, Managed Services, Security & IT Operations, Threat Intelligence, Identity Protection, Long Management and Crowd XDR. A brief description of the modules contained within each subcategory can be seen outlined below. 

Endpoint Security 

Securecircle: Fuelled by an acquisition completed in November of 2021, this module helps to bolster the company’s zero trust functionality, allowing for encryption to occur on data going towards, at use or moving away from endpoints. 

Device Control: USBs are devices commonly used in many enterprise environments but pose the risk of being used to bring malware into an organization or leak data out of it. With this module security teams can track and analyze USB usage, monitor file transfers, enforce company policies, and can be combined with other module functionality for EDR analysis. 

Firewall Management: This module allows for teams to create, enforce and maintain firewall rules across multiple OS environments, leverage templates to create new rules, identify and act on firewall threats and anomalies, leverage logging and compliance capabilities etc. 

Next-Gen Antivirus: Enterprises can utilize this module for its AI/ML ransomware and malware detection capabilities, behaviour based IOAs to stop file-less and malware-free attacks, isolate malicious files if they’ve made their way onto the endpoint, remediation of artifacts left on endpoints from attacks etc. 

EDR: This module allows security teams to simplify detection and resolution, facilitating the identification of attacker behaviour, workflow acceleration with MITRE attack, plan response actions, perform Zero Trust assessments etc. 

Cloud Security 

Cloud Runtime Protection:  This module gives a complete overview and heightened visibility into an enterprise’s cloud workloads, container events and metadata in order to secure the entire cloud-native stack and associated workloads, all while supporting CI/CD workloads to meet the requirements of Dev-Ops performance. 

Cloud Discovery: Aimed at improving IT hygiene, organizations can leverage this module to maintain a close watch over computers, applications and different accounts being used within their cloud environment. An interesting overview of this module in action can be seen below: 

Cloud Security Posture Management: This module can be used as a single point of truth by organizations, viewing all cloud resources and deployments, security configurations, networking information etc. in order to manage, monitor and protect these entities from a single resource, reducing the metaphorical attack surface as a result. 

Managed Services

Turnkey Solution: This generalized offering combines the effectiveness of the company’s EPP functionality with their dedicated team of security professionals to offer customers an effective security solution no matter the complexity, or lack thereof, of their security infrastructure at the moment. 

Threat Hunting: Crowdstrike takes a three-pronged approach to threat hunting, leveraging human capital through a team of individuals that provide their services to the associated enterprise, an abundance of data and associated analytics in order to pinpoint and negate any threats a company may face. 

Security and IT Operations

File Integrity: This FIM (File Integrity Management) module allows enterprises to monitor important file, folders and registries, track associated data and leverage other intelligence/analytical tools. 

Vulnerability Management: This module is aimed at reducing the complexity and improving the efficiency of SecOps, providing a series of tools and assessments ranging from ExPRT ratings that show risk levels and weak points in systems, give recommended patch remediations during/after attacks etc. 

IT Hygiene: This module monitors and inventories systems, application usage and user account usage in order to give insights into who is on an enterprise’s network, what applications they are running, where and how privileged accounts are being accessed, etc. 

Forensics: This module can be used by teams to streamline point-in-time and historic forensic triage data that can be used for analysis and investigation of cybersecurity incidents. 

Threat Intelligence

Malware Analysis: This module performs analysis on threats, both evasive and unknown alike, bolsters threat intelligence and delivers instances of compromises that can then be acted upon, allowing for teams to accurately gauge and improve their defences. 

Malware Search: Crowdstrike amasses approximately 300TB or 6 trillion cybersecurity events a week. Through this module customers can search through all of this malware data, both metadata and binary content alike, of which can be used to strengthen analysis. 

Threat Intelligence: Falcon X integrates threat intelligence into EPP and uses this to provide analysis and insight into the capabilities, sources etc. of the attacks. Premium options are also available if enterprises desire services ranging from analyst reports to threat research. 

Situational Awareness: This module allows for enterprises to monitor and act on the risks associated with hidden webpages, dark-web esque pages etc. In essence, this software expands reach into different IRC Channels, phishing domains, messaging apps in order to identify business and reputational risks that may be emerging from leaked credentials etc. 

Identity Protection 

Zero Trust Security: Adhering to the NIST 800-207 standards, this module provides ZT security and associated analytics based upon continuous verification, blast-radius reduction (i.e. if breaches do occur) and automated collection/response principles. 

Identity Threat Protection: This module is focused on how an enterprise deals with and protects against identity-based attacks, providing visibility into identity access of various cloud solutions, identifications and risk scoring analysis of cloud and on-prem identities as well as lateral movement detection that analyzes traffic attributable to different accounts or users. 

Misc. 

We have already delved into the Humio and EDR functionality of the Falcon Platform, of which are technically contained within the Log Management/Crowd XDR module sections. The last piece of functionality that is worth touching upon, in my opinion, is the Crowdstrike Store. Existing as a SaaS marketplace of different cybersecurity apps for enterprises, teams can download different pieces of technology contained within categories ranging from Cloud Security to Zero Trust, as outlined below: 

With this brief description of the various functionalities and inner mechanisms of the Falcon Platform in mind, let’s start to take a look at how exactly Crowdstrike makes money off of all of these offerings. 

4.0 How Crowdstrike makes $$$

Crowdstrike’s business model is straightforward and easy to digest. The company makes money in two primary manners, the sale of subscription plans to customers as well as from their professional services business segment. Starting off with the former, Crowdstrike offers customers access to four pricing tiers: Falcon Pro, Falcon Enterprise, Falcon Premium and Falcon Complete, as outlined below: 

Each of these component’s base price and module access can be seen above, with customers then having the option to add additional features/functionality through the platform’s other modules, endpoints etc. to their plan as they go along their cybersecurity journey, if desired. Moving on to the latter, Professional Services revenue is derived through either hourly rate or fixed contracts, retainer agreements or one-time arrangements for services ranging from forensic and malware analysis, consulting/advisory services, incident response management etc. In essence Professional Services derives revenue from enterprises that desire to benefit from Crowdstrike’s human capital and the related functionality that comes with that. 

Before moving on, it is important that we understand the general functionality of Crowdstrike’s Sales tactics. Similar to many other SaaS counterparts, Crowdstrike leverages what is known as a Land and Expand Sales Strategy, of which can be seen outlined in an oversimplified form below: 

In essence, Crowdstrike’s primary objective is to continually have a stream of new customers knocking at their door, of which can then be converted into customers that leverage a select few modules, which can then be later converted into valuable customers that utilize 4+ modules and have respectable Annual Contract Values associated with them. In addition, the existence of the company’s Professional Services business segment compliments this strategy quite nicely, existing as a means for Crowdstrike to latch onto a customer with the provision of these services, aiming to eventually convert them into a source of recurring Subscription Revenue. 

5.0 Financial Analysis 

Within this section I will be delving into the company’s most recent Income Statement, Balance Sheet and Cash Flow Statement, as reported for Q3 FY’22. 

Income Statement

Revenue

For the nine months ended Q3 FY’22, of which I will denote as FY’22* for the remainder of this report section, Crowdstrike reported approximately $1.02B in Revenue, representing a 67% increase in comparison to the nine months ended Q3 FY’21. FY’22* Revenue in comparison to previous full Fiscal Years can be seen outlined below: 

As the above outlines, FY’22* revenue already exceed FY’21 by a considerable margin. This sustained Top-Line growth was primarily driven by a 70.37% increase in Subscription-based Revenue YoY, in comparison to the 34.32% YoY increase in Professional Services Revenue. Being that as it may, and previously alluded to when we discussed how Crowdstrike makes money and their associated sales model, Professional Services play an important role “landing and expanding”, seeing as this relationship often results in modules being subscribed to as a result. Over the last few fiscal years, Subscription Revenue has become almost the sole constituent of Total Revenues, an encouraging factor given that subscriptions oftentimes converted into a reliable and abundant source of Annual Recurring Revenue (ARR).

Cost of Revenue

Cost of Revenue, of which consists primarily of the costs of hosting the company’s cloud services, SBC and salaries related to associated employees, came in at approximately $271M for FY’22*, representing a 66% increase YoY, increasing relatively in-line with its Revenue Counterpart. Being that as it may, COR as a % of Total Revenue has decreased noticeably since FY’17 and has started to level off in comparison to FY’21, an encouraging sign, and largely indicative of the company’s heightened efficiencies despite the substantial amounts of scale Crowdstrike has added since then: 

Similar phenomena can be observed when viewing COR attributable to the Subscription and Professional Services as a % of Total Revenue, as outlined below: 

Operating Expenses

Similar to the Cost of Revenue, Operating Expenses increased at a near identical rate to Total Revenue, coming in at $869M for FY’22*, representing a 66% increase YoY. 

Delving deeper, looking at OPEX and its constituents relative to Total Revenue gives us a sense of how Crowdstrike is performing under the hood. S&M, R&D and G&A expenses relative to Top Line can be seen outlined below: 

Some relatively self-explanatory conclusions can be drawn from the above, particularly in the efficiencies we’re seeing in the company’s sales efforts as they scale. One can ponder whether or not the red-hot industry in cybersecurity as well as word-of-mouth phenomena between large industry clients and their peers using Crowdstrike’s services have aided in the reduction of relative sales efforts but regardless, operational efficiencies in these areas are evident. R&D as a % of Total Revenue has remained relatively stagnant over the last few fiscal years at approximately 24-26%, values I believe are substantiated given the constant tweaks and new features that will need to be added to the Falcon Platform if they truly desire to be the one-stop-shop Cloud Cybersecurity offering. 

Margins and Profitability 

In order to gauge the company’s profitability, we can take a look at the change in their Gross Profit, Operating Income, Net Income and EBITDA. Starting off with Gross Profit and associated Gross Profit Margins, these values are extremely high and indicative of a largely successful SaaS business model. Remaining constant for FY’22* in comparison to FY’21, I don’t find it unlikely that these margins continue to expand into the high 70s - low 80s in the coming years: 

Delving deeper, looking at Crowdstrike’s business segments and their associated GP margin profiles, it is quite evident the nature of these segments is fundamentally different. The company will continue to leverage Subscriptions as the fundamental growth and value creation lever, whereas Professional Services can be thought of as a hook so to speak, aimed at getting customers stuck within the Crowdstrike ecosystem on the Subscription side while remaining largely break-even/operating at a slight loss itself, as exhibited by each of these segment’s GPs outlined below: 

Moving along, the company is not profitable as gauged by Operating and Net Income and EBITDA metrics, as well as their associated margins. The company is directing substantial capital at adding new technological features, expanding into international waters as well as maintaining a commendable sales presence. The bottom-line is not deteriorating in any meaningful manner therefore this does not appear to be an issue at the moment. 

One should note that the deviation between Net Income and Operating Income and associated margins for FY’22* is attributable to a one-time increase in the provision for income taxes of approximately, which came in at approximately $59M, linked to the tax costs associated with the intellectual property related to the Humio acquisition. 

Balance Sheet 

The structure of Crowdstrike’s assets, as of Q3 FY’22, can be seen outlined below: 

Crowdstrike’s assets are predominantly liquid, consisting mainly of Cash and Cash Equivalents (approximately $1.9B) followed by Accounts Receivable, Deferred Contract Acquisition Costs and Prepaid Expenses. Long Term Assets on the other hand, consist predominantly of Goodwill, Property and Equipment and Intangible Assets. The structure of the company’s liabilities can be seen outlined below: 

Current Liabilities are predominantly comprised of Deferred Revenue (approximately $1B) and Accrued Expenses whereas Long Term Liabilities are mainly in the form of Long-Term Debt ($740M), Non-Current Deferred Revenue and Deferred Lease Liabilities. In short, with ample amounts of cash and no red flags regarding the company’s debt position, I don’t foresee the company’s balance sheet being a source of hindrance going forwards, an encouraging factor given the acquisition-heavy nature of the industry in general (potential source for Crowdstrike’s large cash position), something Crowdstrike has comfortable with judging by their recent activity.  

Cash Flow Statement 

The change in the company’s Cash from Operations, Investing and Financing over the course of the last few fiscal years can be seen outlined below: 

As the company matures they are evidently generating substantially more operating cash flow as they scale, with FY’22* CFO already exceeding its FY’21A counterpart, coming in at $415M. CFI came in at an outflow of approximately $(471)M attributable primarily to Business Acquisitions and the purchase of Property, Plant and Equipment. CFF came in at approximately $46.35M, attributable primarily to proceeds from the issuance of stock from the exercise of options and through the employee purchase plan. 

The change in the company’s FCF can be seen outlined below: 

So far in FY’22, the company has generated approximately $314.5M in FCF with a FCF margin of approximately 31%, relatively in-line to what was seen in FY’21. For the sake of further illustration, I took a look at FCF if adjustments were not made to CFO for Share-based compensation, of which can be seen outlined below: 

Despite SBC as a % of Revenue increasing, the company still has very respectable FCF and associated FCF margin without these adjustments taken into consideration. In short, the company’s strong FCF is an encouraging phenomenon that is likely to have spurious effects in the coming years.

6.0 Key Performance Indicators 

We have delved into Crowdstrike’s financials, however, looking at a few key indicators outside of these metrics gives additional insight into how Crowdstrike is performing. Starting off with the number of Subscription Customers, this value is evidently indicative of the overall success of company’s business model, given that a constant stream of subscribers will drive recurring revenues. With FY’22* Subscription Customers increasing already 48.4% in comparison to FY’21, Crowdstrike is evidently growing this base with relative ease, as outlined below: 

With a growing subscriber base, the company’s Annual Recurring Revenue (ARR) will evidently benefit. With a very impressive $1.514B in FY’22* ARR, a 44% increase in comparison to FY’21, this value is likely to continue to expand and drive meaningful value creation in the years to come: 

Interconnected is the company’s Remaining Performance Obligation of $1.9B, of which approximately 72% ($1.368B) is expected to be recognized in the next 12 months (Q3 FY’22 and onwards) and the remaining 28% ($532M) in 13-36 months, a metric that highlights a baseline for FY’23 Revenue generation to be expected.

We can also take a look at the company’s Implied Annual Contract Value, which is essentially their ARR divided by the number of subscription customers, of which can be seen outlined below: 

Although we are seeing a slight downtrend in these values, I believe this is largely reflective of Crowdstrike starting to find footing in contracts associated with smaller businesses, something I view as largely net-positive.

In addition, the company’s Dollar-Based Net Retention Rate (DBNRR), i.e. the measure of the expansion in the company’s subscriptions over a 12 month period, highlights the stickiness of the Falcon Platform, pointing towards the fact that customers are spending approximately 25% more on average in the most recent reporting period in comparison to the one prior: 

These phenomena can be corroborated further when one looks at the growth in the number of Customers with 4+ modules, and more recently tracked, the number of customers with 5+ and 6+ modules: 

As Crowdstrike continues to add new modules that are deemed essential in their use to the functionality of an enterprise’s cybersecurity, and as customers get more intertwined with the platform as a whole, we are likely to see continued module adoption, and thus increases in ARR as a result.

Lastly, Crowdstrike’s expansionary efforts have been focused quite heavily on obtaining a respectable international presence. As the below figure outlines, the company is reducing their Geographic concentration risk and making some progress expanding into EMA and APAC regions, despite FY’21 and FY’22* geographic distributions remaining largely identical. 

7.0 Competitive Landscape, Valuation and Discussion 

As i’m sure most of you are aware, Gartner Magic Quadrants are thrown around tech research a lot, particularly since they reflect a culmination of sorts, delving deep into the power dynamics of the constituents of a particular market. When I was performing my research for this article I stumbled across magic quadrants for the Endpoint Security Markets in both 2016 and 2021, of which when viewed alongside one another show just how fast this market has evolved in five years: 

Although the leaders of the industry have largely remained the same, i.e. with Broadcom (Symantec), Trend Micro and McAfee still ranking high according to Gartner, the fact that Microsoft, SentinelOne and Crowdstrike now rank higher/in-line with other incumbents, points towards a technological trend that all of these players are capitalizing upon. As I mentioned earlier there is now quite an evident move towards Cloud Infrastructure, a phenomenon that Cloud Security must align with. Legacy vendors are falling behind for this very reason, unable to keep up with the growing plethora of cloud-enabled/compatible workloads and endpoints that need to be protected. Looking at a SentinelOne-generated Endpoint Security market share diagram, it is clear that there is an abundance of value to still be obtained: 

Between Broadcom, Trend Micro’s Apex and McAfee Enterprise Cloud Offerings, it is clear when looking at user reviews that these companies, although they have moved towards the cloud, are struggling to succeed in a similar manner then they were able to with on-prem solutions. McAfee, despite being one of the first legacy operators to recognize this trend, does not instill confidence in me in their technological capabilities. Not only did McAfee sell their Enterprise segment to a PE firm, but their tech cannot keep up. With centricity around on-prem and local machine deliveries, oftentimes requiring endpoint downtime to install and update software, burdensome sensor CPU usage and more, the associated UX and functionality is inferior to the Falcon Platform. Symantec (Broadcom) solutions require multiple agents which themselves require multiple management consoles, and essentially mandate opt-in into their EDR and DeepSight intelligence modules in order for users to be able to derive any intelligence/response capabilities out of their tech. Trend Micro users suffer from similar drawbacks, with deep-dives into user reviews reflecting the fact that these technologies and their reliance on multiple agents across different environments are dreadfully burdensome on performance: 

In my opinion, two of the largest sources of competition are and will continue to be SentinelOne and Microsoft. Starting off with former, Sentinel One is one of the youngest next-generation AV and endpoint protection centered companies there is today. With rapid customer growth, a product line that has been toted as best in-class and ever-improving fundamentals, there has been a plethora of conversation regarding the competitive threat the company poses. Delving deeper into a side-by-side comparison, and starting off with the fundamentals, despite showing a higher Revenue CAGR from FY’20A to FY’22* (the first 9 months of 2021), i.e. 44.41% in comparison to 28.46%, Crowdstrike is operating with a Top-Line that is almost 10X the size of Sentinel One’s, all while bolstering superior Gross Margins, more efficient S&M efforts as gauged by S&M relative to Revenue etc., much better Operating and FCF Margins and higher-magnitude KPIs, as outlined by the table below: 

In addition, SentinelOne, despite having a respectable DBNRR, has a much lower ACV in comparison to its counterpart. Analysts have been quick to showcase the growth in the company’s customer base, however, one must understand the fact that the company evidently caters towards a series of enterprises with a significant proportion of them being SMBs. As such, if ACV were to remain relatively low they will need to maintain a steady cadence of net customer additions to extract a similar level of value from this base as Crowdstrike. An additional titbit of analysis would be to compare the same metrics for the Fiscal Year prior to when Crowdstrike filed their S-1 (June 6th, 2019), to Sentinel One’s (June 21st, 2021). 

Again Crowdstrike operated at approximately 3X the scale, while exhibiting healthier Gross, Operating and FCF Margins, albeit having less customers at a similar point in their roadmap. In my mind, I would be more comfortable holding Crowdstrike at a slower growth rate (still a likely 40% Top-Line CAGR in the coming years) due to the higher-performance financials they are able to exhibit. 

Moving on, SentinelOne may be exhibiting slight superiority when it comes to the product side of things. As we have previously discussed, Crowdstrike leverages modules, a strategy that packets different functionality into different add-ons so to speak that customers can opt into, if desired. SentinelOne, on the other hand, offers one fully integrated solution, of which is more affordable (hence the high # of customers with a lower ACV in comparison to Crowdstrike). Despite Crowdstrike’s platform possessing the ability to pinpoint a virus and “quarantine” it, as an example, the complete associated response and thus the key elimination of the threat oftentimes takes hours. On the other hand, Sentinel One combines their EPP and EDR capabilities into one XDR-solution, of which leverages AI that is capable of identifying and eliminating threats in fully autonomous manner, oftentimes in seconds, in comparison to the more analyst-driven and tedious solution with Crowdstrike. An article written by Convequity goes even deeper into the nuances of this head-to-head comparison, such as SentinelOne’s product scoring a better MITRE Evaluation rating, and should be read if you want a full knowledge base regarding this subject. A general overview of the key differences can be seen outlined below: 

Lastly, one can ponder whether or not SentinelOne has last-mover advantage, i.e. the phenomenon of whether or not the company can use the shortcomings of Crowdstrike’s platform to their advantage. 

Moving on to Microsoft. This powerhouse of a company has not only cemented themselves as a staple of the Cloud Infrastructure space, they have also become a significant player with regards to Endpoint Protection and other areas of Cybersecurity. The company has committed $20B to be spent over the course of the next five years to deliver more advanced cybersecurity tools, has over 650,000 different clients, recently reported $15B in revenue in this business segment, of which represents a Net Add of approximately $4.7B on the year. On the opposite end of the spectrum, the company has also been subject to some scrutiny due to the cybersecurity breaches that effected their own infrastructure over the course of 2021. I have a hard time betting against Microsoft. Taking excel as an example, this piece of software has become the most popular programming language in the world, a phenomenon that may not be testament to its existence as a best in-class product, despite its usefulness, but rather their ability to consistently intertwine themselves with the modern enterprise. As such, I find it highly likely that the company is able to leverage their network, so to speak, to become of the most prevalent players in the Endpoint Security and Cybersecurity space as a whole, seeing as they are one of the few vendors that have offerings for multiple end-markets. Being that as it may, only time will tell. 

In addition, private markets are starting to see an extreme bump in activity. In comparison to 2016, the number of VC backed Cybersecurity deals has almost tripled, as outlined below: 

Regardless of whether or not ideal macroeconomic conditions have spurred easy access to capital, or if the tailwinds in the sector as a whole has resulted in more interesting parties trying to get their piece of the pie, it is worth taking note of, especially since more than an estimated $20B flew into these startups last year. 

Of additional note, and something I don’t see many analysts discussing when it comes to the competitive dynamics of the industry, and Crowdstrike’s position within it, is the company’s CEO George Kurtz. Not only does the man posses almost 3 decades of experience within the cybersecurity industry, having excelled in former powerhouses of the legacy variety, i.e. McAfee, he also demonstrates a clear and deep understanding of the customer-first mentality that is required both to obtain and retain customers in a very competitive marketplace. As an example, when the company IPO’d in 2019, instead of celebrating the monumental achievement, he decided to spend the next 100 days meeting with 100 of the company’s clients. Kurtz was adamant that [15]: 

"Everything comes down to retention rates, and we have extremely high retention rates," he said.  "I learned if you take care of the client, everything else takes care of itself, we'll do whatever it takes to make a customer happy. I can't promise perfection, but I can promise my response. And my response is to make sure the problem is solved and the customer is happy."

Looking at the company’s continual expanding ARR and DBNRR metrics, it is evident that this customer-first approach has been successful and will likely continue to be a driving factor between Crowdstrike’s growth in the future alongside stellar product functionality. 

Outside of Endpoint Security, Cybersecurity exists as an industry with an abundance of high-quality businesses that are catering toward different use-cases and end markets. One of the first questions one may encounter is how exactly does Crowdstrike compare against these entities valuation-wise? Starting off with Top-Line valuations relative to 2020A-2023E Revenue CAGR, Crowdstrike stands out as one of the highest valued and fastest-growing companies as outlined below: 

Although one may Crowdstrike as trading at a premium relative to top-line, if we look at P/FCF (LTM) it paints a different story, with Crowdstrike displaying a middle of the pack multiple and actually generating FCF in comparison to high-growth counterparts.

Moving on to bottom-line metrics, Crowdstrike also exhibits very healthy and positive (something a fair chunk of competitors cannot bolster) previously reported and anticipated EBIT levels in comparison to peers as outlined below: 

Lastly, when one looks at previous consensus estimates vs. what Crowdstrike has actually reported since IPO, the company has consistently beaten estimates by approximately 4-10%, as outlined below: 

I have been on a tangent here for quite some time now so I believe it is best that I summarize all of these ideas into a conclusive statement of sorts, of which I believe will be able to successfully encompass most of the factors an investor should consider when delving into Crowdstrike. First off the Endpoint Security Market is ripe for disruption. With legacy players still possessing substantial marketshare despite having inferior tech, there is a ton of opportunity for Crowdstrike to continue to grow in the future. Being that as it may, there are developments that should be paid attention to. SentinelOne is a fast growing company that is arguably addressing the shortcomings of Crowdstrike’s technology and Microsoft is leveraging an abundance of enterprise connections to gain a significant portion of market share. In addition, there are Private-Market players and substantial VC funding flowing around that will likely result in competitive forces outside of these publicly traded counterparts. With all of that in mind, we can take Crowdstrike’s heavy focus on customer satisfaction, capable but potentially not best-in-class tech, and arrive at the conclusion that they are likely to end up in neither a winner take-all or winner take most scenario, but rather grow in a considerable manner alongside its peers. I have no problem underwriting a sustained 30% top-line CAGR for at least 5 years and with ever-improving margins it is likely Crowdstrike generates significant value for shareholders in the periods to come. Crowdstrike’s metrics show no sign of waning to competitive pressures, therefore, for the time being I will stand by these assertions until the numbers prove me otherwise. Despite not being a shareholder at the moment Crowdstrike served itself as an excellent entry point into the ecosystem for me and I will be monitoring the company alongside additional developments in the coming quarters. 

8.0 Conclusion

In summary, Crowdstrike presents itself as one of the forefront contenders for capitalizing on happenings within an industry ripe for disruption. With capable tech, great financials and no sign of slowing down anytime soon, Crowdstrike is a great company. I hope this research served as a capable starting point to your evaluation of Crowdstrike and Cybersecurity as a whole.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, subscribe and share!

Subscribe now

Share

If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

item.title: Roblox ($RBLX)
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to MT Capital Research! If you’re new, join a group of 3800 Informed Investors who receive weekly reports on the World’s Most Interesting Tech companies by subscribing below: 

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an in-depth analysis on Roblox Corporation. Within I will delve into the main tailwinds the company aims to benefit from in the future, both in the short and long term, break down their technology and platform, discuss what makes it so unique, and lay out how the company makes money. In addition, I will give an overview of the company’s most recent financials, discuss some KPIs that investors should keep on top of and discuss some key happenings that may be indicative of future performance. The format of this research can be seen outlined below, feel free to skip ahead to the sections you will find most useful: 

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Opportunity 

3.0 Technology 

4.0 How Roblox makes $$$ 

5.0 Financial Analysis

6.0 Key Performance Indicators

7.0 Valuation

8.0 Discussion

9.0 Conclusion 

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitute for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investment. 

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content and analysis, give me a follow on Twitter: 

Follow Me!

With all of that out of the way, let’s get started. 

1.0 Introduction 

In a 2021 Acquired Podcast, Ho Nam, Managing Director of Altos Ventures, outlined an interesting dichotomy of the Fox and the Hedgehog, a discussion that was originally brought forwards in the renowned book Good to Great by Jim Collins. Delving deeper, the fox is often described as a crafty being with flashy habits and a sleek demeanour, whereas the hedgehog is a simpler creature, sticking to a set of purposes/principles, usually coming out on top when the two clash. Applied to the world of tech, and nicely outlined in an Altos Ventures blog post, despite the fact that fox style-CEOs may be better with acquiring funding, networking etc. hedgehogs on the other hand are able to measure and track everything about their business, often demonstrating deep levels of knowledge and expertise. Leveraging this single-minded mentality may be risky at times, however, it is often a toolset that allows a company to survive the many peaks and troughs of being a fast-moving company. David Baszucki and his late co-founder Erik Cassel, demonstrated a hedgehog mentality in both the creation and the continual operation of Roblox. The pair originally worked together in the late 1980s on a physics simulation engine known as Interactive Physics, a tool that was geared at helping students gain heightened understandings of the science, despite later being acquired by MSC Software in 1998 for more industrial purposes. Post-acquisition the pair bounced around, eventually coming back together in 2004 when DynaBlocks, the early prototype of Roblox was being worked on. Taking the origin stories of these ventures, and pairing them with the general definition for the hedgehog mentality, it is clear when one starts to delve into the technology, operations and mission of Roblox as a whole, that the mission of the founders was to create a memorable and enjoyable platform experience for children, one that not only immerses them in an interactive social landscape, but also teaches them skills ranging from basic commerce principals, to learning how to program in order to develop Roblox games. The Roblox platform is arguably one of the first instances of a Metaverse that has been completely immersed in pop culture and exists as three main components: Roblox Client, an application that allows for users to explore and play games within 3D digital worlds; Roblox Studio, a toolset that allows for users to develop, create and publish their own 3D experiences and content; and Roblox Cloud, the infrastructure powers the aforementioned platform and functionality. This company is still driven by the same hedgehog that it was co-founded by; arguably one of the main driving factors between past success, platform innovations, and likely a major contributing factor between the company’s continual future success.

With this brief description of Roblox in mind, let’s delve deeper into the main tailwinds and technological happenings that the company aims to benefit from within their operations and growth initiatives. 

2.0 Opportunity 

In order to understand the opportunity in front of Roblox it is important that we understand the scale of Gaming as a whole. According to Limelight Network’s 2021 State of Online Gaming report, gamers spent, on average, approximately 8 hours and 27 minutes a week playing games, with the average hours per week split into each geographical cohort outlined below: 

Although Roblox’s platform is multi-device compatible, an important feature that caters towards the wide plethora of different use cases, there is a clear trend in the user behavior demonstrating a preference for mobile gaming across different gamer skillsets: 

Delving deeper, Mobile Gaming saw strong growth in 2021. There was an approximate $16B growth in Worldwide Mobile Game Consumer Spend, as well as an increase in Mobile Game Downloads, a commendable feat given gaming-positive tailwinds that emerged at the beginning of the pandemic:

In 2021, Roblox was able to capitalize off of these trends very well, ranking strong amongst its cohorts as gauged by Worldwide Download and Consumer Spend rankings: 

In addition, there has been a clear change in Global Gaming Revenue distribution by source over the last decade, a phenomenon that may highlight the recognition of the effectiveness of a key component of Roblox’s business model. More specifically, Roblox and many other games provide users with in-game currency, of which they can use to unlock additional functionality, customize their characters etc. When comparing the % of of Gaming Revenue from In-Game Purchases to the % of Revenue from Premium Games at the start of decade to the end of the decade, it is evident companies and game developers have changed their monetization models towards in-game purchases, a phenomenon that is likely to continue to result in a user comfortability with Roblox’s business model.

The ability to continue to benefit from positive tailwinds will be imperative to Roblox’s continual success. They have evidently experienced a net positive from the aforementioned trends, however they are still focused on expanding their reach. As an example, and looking at Mobile Spend, the company has mentioned explicitly that they are looking for interactive advertising methods that can be used to drive Average Bookings Per Daily User in the future, with David Baszucki, the CEO of Roblox voicing clear optimism with regards to this opportunity in the company’s most recent earnings call [4]: 

“Advertising is an enormous opportunity. And at the same time, our vision for advertising is immersive. It's native. It's around high-quality experiences.

And over time, we'll be working on rolling out the standards around this, how this is supported globally. We do think there's an interesting and big future and at the same time, a very high-quality branded advertising-type future. So super, super optimistic about that.”

With App Annie estimating that total Mobile Ad Spend, as an example, reached approximately $240B in 2021, it is exciting to think about the amount of ad spend that one of the most popular mobile games in the world would be able to capitalize upon.

Lastly, I think it is worth touching upon the amount of Metaverse related-activity we’ve seen of late, a phenomenon I believe is likely to benefit Roblox. This buzzword has taken off, with the amount of mentions in SEC filings in 2021 demonstrating its spread into tech-culture: 

But what exactly is the Metaverse? In a 2020 blog post, Matthew Ball outlines quite an elegant definition that has formed a foundation for the framework I view these developments with. More specifically, the Metaverse can be described as a digital “jacked-in” internet, one that portrays a virtual reality/world of sorts that users would like to spend their time within, similar to sci-fi movie stand-outs such as the Matrix or Ready Player One. Ball continues to say that: 

“The Metaverse is a massively scaled and interoperable network of real-time rendered 3D virtual worlds which can be experienced synchronously and persistently by an effectively unlimited number of users with an individual sense of presence, and with continuity of data, such as identity, history, entitlements, objects, communications and payments.” 

When one analyzes Roblox it is clear that their platform fits this definition almost identically. When a user connects with the Roblox platform they are exposed to a 3D virtual world, one that contains a wide array of different games and activities, a stunning amount of users that can be interacted with if desired, of which have been hard-pressed to stop growing in number since the company’s inception, a sense of presence with the ability for a user to customize their avatar in an almost endless amount of ways, and an in-game economy of sorts that allows for transactions to occur etc. With Metaverse-related ETFs being released, heightened media attention and a continuous desire for unique digital experiences, I believe Roblox is likely to continually benefit from these happenings. 

In summary and despite the fact that I pinpointed my attention largely on mobile-game tailwinds, since I feel these are some the biggest opportunities the company can capitalize upon, Roblox has a clear opportunity in front of it with the growing screentime dedicated to video games, the general acceptance of in-game monetization game models that users have become comfortable with/expect, the amount of potential value to be extracted from in-game advertising, as well as the thirst for metaverse-level virtual immersion. 

Despite barely scratching the surface here, let’s build atop this foundation and start to break down Roblox’s technology. 

3.0 Technology 

As previously discussed, the three main components of the Roblox Platform are the Roblox Client, the Roblox Studio and Roblox Cloud. Each of these components will be broken down within this section. 

Roblox Client 

Roblox’s technology, much like other multiplayer video games, relies on a client-server model. In essence, this is a distributed application structure that spreads out the game’s various workloads across the entities that provide the service, i.e. servers, and the requesters of said service, i.e. clients. Applied to Roblox, the clients in this case would be the players, using their different devices, as outlined below, and the server would be the entity that allows for said clients to render the Roblox Universe. This functionality is how so many people can render an online universe in the same way no matter where they are in the world. 

Splitting things back up into the aforementioned generalized pairing of clients and servers, this design architecture is hugely important for performance, especially when millions of users are trying to connect with Roblox’s services. More specifically, clients essentially handle resource-intensive code such as rendering visual effects, which frees up the server to handle game-states etc. In summary, the Roblox client is the tool users leverage to connect to the Roblox universe, which is designed in a way to be as efficient as possible with resources. 

Roblox Studio 

The Roblox Studio is essentially a 3D development platform that is free to download on associated Mac or Windows devices. Importantly, this ecosystem operates as an open sandbox of sorts, where users can leverage templates and other pre-built functionality in order to start to create expansive virtual terrains contained within a game. 

The Roblox Studio is intertwined with the Lua programming language, of which users can leverage to create scripts that give their games sets of instructions ranging from how many health points to give players, whether or not the world rains molten lava on occasion, and basically anything else you can put your mind to. To cement all ramblings, a illustrative TechInsider video demonstrating how one can make a simple Roblox Game can be seen outlined below: 

There are a few points I would like to relay here, particularly regarding the dev-friendly nature of publishing games in the Roblox universe. First off, once a code-base has been created, it works seamlessly across every platform that Roblox supports, whether it be on a mobile device, computer, video game consoles or VR. Developers can then leverage the power of the social ecosystem omnipresent within Roblox, potentially allowing for their games to be put in front of millions of users through the achievement of virality, as well rest easy on the fact that engagement is likely to not be an issue given that billions of user engagement hours occur on the platform each month. In addition, games, once published, are intertwined with Roblox’s cloud infrastructure, which put simply, removes the complexity from maintaining multiplayer functionality, performing in-game updates or monetizing the content, if desired. Lastly, I think it is worth stressing the expansive array of information that new developers can immerse themselves in, a clear sign that the company evidently intends Roblox Studio to be both functional but also possess a learning curve that is approachable enough for an interested child. As an example, Roblox offers full tutorials to Learn Roblox Studio ranging from those covering the basics, delving deeper into coding using lua, and mastering how to manipulate visuals in-game.  

Roblox Cloud 

In essence, the Roblox cloud includes the services and infrastructure that powers the company’s platform. The cloud was a relatively new addition to infrastructure; an engineering choice that was made in 2017 in response to the fact that their dedicated servers at the time were unable to keep up, struggling with resource waste as a result of the company’s reliance on manual workflows and in-house tooling, all attempting to satisfy the needs of millions of users. In response to these challenges, Roblox leveraged the services of Hashicorp, a cloud infrastructure services provider, that essentially containerized the company’s game engine, upgraded their CPU to a Linux 64-bit version, and leveraged the Nomad platform to run double the workload on the same hardware, save money on windows licensing, and migrate application deployments from on-premise to in the cloud with AWS. Now, with user growth that has been hard pressed to slow down, the company can rest easy on the fact that their infrastructure will be able to keep up with the demands of modernity.  

With all of this information in mind, the Roblox platform comes together and offers users a series of value propositions, of which drive engagement and make Roblox a truly unique virtual experience. These key characteristics can be seen outlined below: 

Starting off with Identity, users can uniquely express themselves within the Roblox universe through their Avatars. Said avatars are customizable in a wide variety of ways and are the form at which the user exists in all of the Roblox games. An interesting visual depicting the evolution of these avatars can be seen outlined below: 

Much like other multiplayer games, users can interact and play with their Friends. The main mechanism of interaction would be through Roblox Chat, of which allows users to communicate with other players. An additional feature of this functionality are the parental controls, which allow a guardian to dictate whom they can interact with on the platform. When considering the fact that the company’s primary demographic is the younger generation, this is an important Safety Feature, and is one amongst many. 

These experiences, at the moment, are evidently engaging, and depending on the game, scenario or user, may be considered Immersive. Being that as it may, the company is focused on increasing the level of immersion, of which will be a key component to making Roblox a heightened Metaverse experience. More specifically, Roblox games can be played through a VR medium, with options ranging from a Burger Cooking Game, to entries such as Laser VR and Paranormica.  Staying on the topic of compatible devices, the fact that the company supports users from all devices, whether that be those using Mac computers, to others trying to play on a playstation or android phone, promotes low-friction enjoyment, of which can occur anywhere in the world. Although cross-platform functionality is becoming more normalized in blockbuster game titles, there are still many instances where one’s gameplay experience is restricted to their console, which may exist as a deteriorative factor for user engagement, therefore I believe the above functionality is absolutely essential to the overall health of Roblox’s platform. At this point, I’ve already mentioned the fact that there are a vast array of games available to play on the platform, but the magnitude of these values are continually expanding, and quite astounding when analyzed. As of early January, it was estimated that there are over 40M games available to play on the platform, representing a true Variety of Content. Lastly, Roblox has a fully functioning economy that exists within its universe. More specifically, users can pay for certain components of games etc. within Roblox and developers can get paid out in in-game currency. This will be delved into in more depth in the next section, however, the economy is a key component to driving user and dev engagement and also pushing the company’s business forward. In summary, these features are all what make Roblox so special, and when viewed alongside the previously outlined Ball-criteria for a Metaverse, look pretty similar don’t they? 

Now that we understand the company’s platform, how developers can create games for it, and the infrastructure that powers it, let’s take a look at how exactly Roblox makes money. 

4.0 How Roblox makes $$$
