Companies have already started to complete Security Token Offerings (STOs), i.e. a process that allows individuals to obtain equity in the company on the blockchain, and there are some exciting opportunities for investments that were predominantly illiquid in the past (commercial real estate, private companies) now being made available to traders via STOs. Out of all the crypto applications, I am most hopeful in the ability for security tokens to democratize investing, providing the little guy access to portfolio allocations that were previously only available to institutions. 

With all of these discussions in mind I would like for you to draw a few conclusions. First the activity in crypto is both stunning and, judging by the level of adoption and intertwinement with social trends and culture, may be hear to stay for the long run. In addition, and as previously asserted, the applications are vast and I have barely scratched the surface with regards to the amount of de-fi technology currently being circulated. Coinbase aims to be the logical first step for all things crypto. With a market-leading brand, a strict adherence to regulatory guidelines and requirements, top-notch security, an ability to act as a trusted custodian for crypto assets, and easy-to-use and functional technology, the company has definitely cemented itself at the forefront of the industry. Now that we know a little bit more about the activity in the crypto space, let’s start to break down Coinbase’s technology and see where they fit therein. 

3.0 Platform 

Coinbase’s platform can be split into three unique and distinct components according to the demographic that they are geared towards. More specifically, Coinbase has technology separated into Retail, Institutions and Ecosystem categories. Functionality contained within each cohort will be analyzed within this section. 

Retail

The main functionality of the retail-geared segment of the platform is, arguably,  to buy and sell cryptocurrencies, of which we can contain under the Invest umbrella. Investors can use either their web browser or the mobile app to purchase a variety of cryptocurrency assets. There are over 100 listed on the Coinbase platform and a snippet of the associated asset directory can be seen outlined below:

The company supports a multitude of different trading preferences, whether that be utilizing supported fiat currencies to purchase crypto or crypto itself to purchase other forms of crypto assets. In addition, Coinbase offers retail investors the options to either act as custodian of their assets or to leverage the Coinbase Wallet functionality, which, in essence, allows for a user to exert full control over their wallets. Put simply, all assets purchased on the platform, whether they bitcoin or NFTs (as examples) will be made available to said wallet, which the user can then use to interact with all varieties of decentralized applications, if desired. In addition, users have the ability to utilize the Coinbase Card, which is in essence a branded VISA card that connects with one’s Coinbase account, in order to Spend with crypto or fiat and receive crypto rewards back for each purchase. 

This functionality is currently available for customers in the UK and various regions situated across Europe,  however, there is a waitlist available for customers within all US States, spare Hawaii. Users also have access to Send/Receive functionality which allows for any of the aforementioned crypto assets available on the Coinbase platform to be sent or received through transfers made between wallet addresses, phone numbers or email (if said communication method has a Coinbase account associated with it). Coinbase also supports on-chain or off-chain sends, with the former being free and much more expedient in comparison to its counterpart. 

Moving along to the Save and Stake functionality, this is where having some form of crypto presence gets interesting. With the former, users are able to earn yield off of their crypto assets and through other processes, if desired. Starting off with stablecoins, i.e. tokens that are pegged to the dollar, investors can earn approximately 2% APY holding DAI in their account or 0.15% APY using USDC. If this isn’t intriguing enough, users have the option to lend their crypto through Ce-Fi (Centralized Finance) or De-Fi processes, earning approximately 4% APY with the latter or  anywhere from 2-7% APY using De-Fi protocols such as Compoundv2 or Aav, depending on what stablecoin is used for the lending itself. Lastly, users have the option to obtain a loan against their crypto holdings. In other words, individuals can borrow up to $1,000,000 against their bitcoin balance. Switching gears to the latter, staking can be described as a process where users lock up crypto holdings in order to obtain rewards or earn interest. In essence, certain protocols such as Tezos reward participants for validating blockchain transactions with their staked holdings and providing some form of reward/compensation accordingly.

Institutions 

The functionality of Coinbase’s technology doesn’t stop at Retail. The company is evidently focused on becoming, as outlined within their S-1, the “one-stop shop” for institutions that are looking to gain exposure to the Crypto Economy. Starting off with the ability to Invest, Coinbase offers institutional clients access to one of the most liquid crypto spot exchanges in the world, as well as a host of different functionality ranging from market data, API access and analytics to order routing capabilities that allow entities to get the best prices on trades possible. Outside of the ability to Send and Receive and Stake, which functions in a similar manner for Institutions as it does for Retail, Coinbase’s storage capabilities are what have the highest value proposition in this customer segment, in my opinion. Cryptocurrencies have a uniquely inherent security risk that has proven a source of hesitancy for institutions to consider them as investments, i.e. they are accessible anywhere, which proves to be a double edged sword as they are thus able to be stolen from anywhere.  Coinbase leverages cold storage, which in essence is a process by where cryptocurrency is stored offline, ensuring that the various on-chain addresses of institutions are not accessible by hackers via traditional means. Custody is both insured and regulated by SOC 1 Type II and SOC 2 Type II financial and security audits as well as able to be fully integrated with the company’s aforementioned trading functionality. The last feature worth noting are the credit offerings Coinbase gears at institutions. Outside of the traditional access to liquidity for hedging etc., the company offers post-trade credit, i.e. fund advancement that allows eligible customers to trade on credit rather than waiting for funds to settle a few days later. 

Launched earlier this year, Coinbase also gears a fully integrated product offering at institutional clients, Coinbase prime. This solution provides secure custody, an advanced trading platform and prime services that allow for the easy management of crypto assets, as outlined by the product release video below: 

In summary, Coinbase’s institutional offerings are leveraged by the biggest funds, financial institutions and corporations in the world and with their expansive feature offering is likely to remain a strong presence in this area. 

Ecosystem

Outside of catering towards both Retail and Institutional Investors alike, Coinbase directs substantial efforts at the betterment of the crypto ecosystem as a whole. Starting off with their Earn functionality, Coinbase provides crypto developers/technology creators with access to the millions of individuals on their platform to spread awareness. In essence, users that watch a video, download an app or complete a task to learn more about an asset will receive a set amount of that asset in exchange for their time. Moving on, Coinbase’s main, developer-friendly offering that I believe warrants bullishness over is Coinbase Cloud. Labelled as an effort to become the “AWS of Crypto” this offering offers developers a series of APIs and infrastructure to create decentralized applications, accept crypto payments, gain insights off of trading data, create infrastructure for staking and more. The seven main branches of Coinbase Cloud can be seen outlined below and despite no numbers being disclosed with regards to the amount of revenues attributable to the offering, the Cloud has approximately $30B+ assets staked across more than 25 protocols and 60,000 nodes to support all of the services on applicable networks, indicative of impressive size given the infancy of the offering: 

Lastly, in a blog post made earlier in the year, CEO Brian Armstrong indicated that the company was amidst plans to launch a crypto app store of sorts, of which offers access to third-party developed products. Armstrong was adamant that the crypto economy is still in its early stages, and that with an expansive ecosystem there is likely to be a wide variety of defi centered applications built on the crypto rails, so to speak [10]. Drawing the following euphemism to how Apple didn’t build every app made for the iPhone, but rather made it open to third-party developers, it is exciting to think about the amount of value that could be extracted from an app-store centered around providing easy access to crypto centered tech. 

Now that we have a better understand of what Coinbase offers, let’s take a look at how exactly they make money from all of it. 

4.0 How Coinbase makes $$$$

Coinbase’s sources of Revenue, and thus how they make money from their platform, can be split into two distinct components, Transaction Revenue and Subscription and Services Revenue. The former encompasses fees charged to users for either Investing in, Sending, Receiving or Spending (using the Coinbase Visa Card). For Investing, Coinbase charges Retail Traders anywhere from 1-2.5% per transaction whereas on the Institutional Level the Exchange operates using a maker or taker model, charging individuals anywhere from 0.04% to 0.50% depending on the volume of the transaction. Using the Coinbase Visa Card is free for each transaction, however, if one makes any ATM withdrawals, there is a 2.5% fee. Moving over to the latter, this value encompasses four main components, i.e. subscription/services revenue associated with Store, Stake, Distribute and Build products. For Store Coinbase earns Custodial Fee Revenue which is dictated based upon the value of assets held in the company’s cold storage solution. For Stake, Coinbase charges a 25% commission for any staking rewards that are obtained using crypto held on Coinbase.  Through Distribute, i.e. the Earn for learning functionality, Coinbase takes a commission based on the value and the amount of the crypto asset that has been distributed to customers. Lastly, Coinbase charges customers Licensing fees for any services that me leveraging within the aforementioned Build Offerings. 

Now that we have a better understanding of how Coinbase makes money, let’s delve deeper into their financials.

5.0 Financial Analysis

This section will delve into the key components of Coinbase’s most recent Income Statement, Balance Sheet and Cash Flow Statement and make conclusions regarding the information contained therein accordingly. 

Income Statement

Revenue

Coinbase’s Revenue for Q3’21 came in at approximately $1.3B, representing a 316% increase on a YoY basis. This value’s change relative to previous reporting periods can be seen outlined in the following figure: 

This value, evidently largely contingent on the activity in the crypto realm, which peaked in the first half of the year, is still showing strong growth in comparison to 2019 and 2020. Total Revenue, as previously mentioned, consists of three main components, Transaction Revenue, Subscription Revenue and Other Revenue. The percentage distribution of Total Revenue attributable to each of these sources can be seen outlined below: 

Coinbase evidently makes the majority of their money through Transaction Fees, with Q3’21 revenue attributing 83% of its total value to this segment. Being that as it may, the company is directing efforts at reducing this concentration risk, and Subscription and Services Revenue was the highest it has been since 2019, coming in at 11% of Total Revenue for the quarter. With the continued focus on Coinbase Cloud and other subscription offerings, it is exciting to think about where this value may be in the future. Delving deeper into each segment, the percentage of Total Transaction Revenue attributable to Retail and Institutional activity and how it is changed over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

Over the last few quarters Retail investors have accounted for approximately 94%+ of Coinbase’s Total Transaction Revenues. This is evidently largely attributable to the company’s fee structure, of which is much higher in the 1-2.5% range for Retail in comparison to the 0.04%-0.5% for Institutions. As such, investors should be focused on monitoring the retail-side of the company’s business since it is the largest value creator. Lastly, the percentage of Subscription and Services Revenue attributable to each segment can be seen outlined below, evidently highlighting the fact that Coinbase has been and will likely continue to extract the majority of the value in this area from both Blockchain Rewards and Custodial Fees: 

Expenses

Coinbase’s Operating Expenses increased approximately 377% on a YoY basis, coming in at approximately $1.02B, increasing at a slightly higher rate to that of its Revenue counterpart but still indicative of the company’s ability to maintain profitability while keeping expenses in check within a relatively fixed range. The change in Total OPEX as well as OPEX as a % of Total Revenue can be seen outlined below: 

As previously mentioned, OPEX as distributed by segment maintains a relatively fixed/stagnant nature. The only notable increase was that of Sales and Marketing of which has been ramping up as a % of Total OPEX over the last few quarters, increasing approximately 780% YoY. The change in this percentage distribution can be seen outlined below: 

Margins and Profitability 

The change in Coinbase’s profitability measures, as dictated by the change in the company’s Operating Income, Net Income and EBITDA, as well as associated margins can be seen outlined below: 

As the above table outlines, since Q1’19, the company has been maintaining a strong degree of profitability and respectable associated margins all while growing at a pace/scale that markets have very rarely seen before. 

Balance Sheet

The structure of Coinbase’s Assets can be seen outlined below: 

Coinbase’s assets are very liquid, with 86% of Total Assets being current, of which consist primarily of Cash and Equivalents and Customer Custodial Funds. Long Term Assets are primarily composed of Crypto Assets held, Other Assets and Goodwill. The structure of the company’s liabilities can be seen outlined below: 

Liabilities are predominantly liquid as a result of approximately $9B of custodial funds due to customers. Long Term Liabilities are mainly in the form of Long Term Debt. Overall the company has a strong balance sheet. If we take out Custodial related metrics from both Assets and Liabilities the company would have approximately $10B in assets with $6.3B being cash and approximately $5M in Long Term Liabilities, a very respectable position heading into the coming quarters.

Cash Flow Statement 

The change in the company’s Cash from Operations, Investing and Financing over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

CFO came in at approximately $342M for the quarter, attributable to the company’s Net Income, SBC, Crypto Asset Payments for Expenses and Impairment Expenses, offset mainly by Crypto Assets received as revenue, deferred income taxes and realized gains on crypto assets. CFI was negative at approximately $(307)M, attributable to investments made in securities and loans originated. CFF was positive at approximately $1.96B, attributable primarily to the Issuance of Debt. The change in the company’s FCF and FCF margin can be seen outlined below: 

In summary, when the company’s ability to remain cash flow positive is combined with their continually growing top and bottom lines as well as a strong balance sheet, Coinbase is in a good place going forwards. 

6.0 Key Performance Indicators

In order to gain a deeper insight into how Coinbase’s business is performing we can take a look at some KPIs. Starting off with Verified Users, i.e. the amount of individuals, whether they align with retail or institutions, that have obtained a Coinbase account. Coinbase continues to show steady growth in their number of users despite crypto volatility, as outlined below: 

Equally as important are the number of Monthly Transacting Users (MTUs), i.e. a person that interacted with a Coinbase product within the last 28 days, which although peaking in amidst the Crypto Mania in Q2 are still strong and have increased more than threefold in comparison to the same period last year: 

Of additional note is the amount of Assets on Coinbase on Platform. This metric allows investors to gauge the amount of USD and crypto assets that are held in wallets on the platform (both in a custodial sense and otherwise) and also represents the opportunity the company has to use said assets within variety of subscription settings. The change in this value can be seen outlined below: 

To put the scale of the Amount of Assets held on the platform into perspective, it is useful looking at the Assets on Platform as a % of Total Crypto Market Capitalization. As Coinbase continues to add new products and assets onto their platform it is likely that their strong ecosystem continues to grow: 

With approximately $255B on the assets on the platform as of September 30th, and with Total Crypto Market Capitalization on that same date being approximately $1.905T, Assets on the Platform represent approximately 13% of Total Crypto Market Cap, an impressive that shows Coinbase’s ability to continue to have a stronger presence within an extremely fast moving niche. 

Moving on, Trading Volume has remained commendable for Q3, although decreasing in comparison to the two previous reporting periods of this year, activity is still strong as outlined below: 

Delving deeper, the percentage of Total Trading Volume attributable to both Retail and Institutional Investors can be seen outlined below: 

As is quite evident, Coinbase’s Trading Volume is becoming more and more attributable to Institutional activity as the quarters go on. Although this makes sense, since these entities are trading with sums of cash much larger than their counterparts, an interesting phenomenon arises here. More specifically, despite being trumped by Institutions in terms of volume, Retail is the largest source of the company’s revenue given how transaction fee structures are set up. As such, retail centered product offerings will inevitably be of a greater value add to the company’s top line despite the increased institutional activity seen of late. Additionally, it is important to understand the concentration in asset holdings attributable to Bitcoin and Ethereum as well as other cryptos: 

From 2019 to the first 9 months of the year there has been an evident reduction in the Bitcoin centricity on the platform. Although it is still the most popularly held crypto asset on Coinbase, there has been an evident surge in Ethereum holdings as well as reasonable holdings in the “Other” crypto assets category, which should hypothetically improve as Coinbase continues to onboard new assets. 

Also of note is the geographic concentration in Coinbase’s Revenue, i.e. the amount of their Revenue attributable to the United States and Internationally, of which can be seen outlined below for 2019, 2020 and the first nine months of 2021 below: 

The amount of Revenue attributable to the US in comparison to the rest of the World can has increased slightly since 2019, now slightly over 80%, thus investors should be monitoring activity in this region closely seeing as it is crucial to the company’s success. 

Lastly, there is no doubt that Coinbase’s price action is correlated with that of Crypto in general. To illustrate this fact, looking at the return of Bitcoin overlaid with the return of Coinbase, measured since May, there are evident similarities in the peaks and troughs of how both assets have traded, thus cementing the fact that one will have to be diligent in monitoring the success of the crypto space in general since Coinbase will evidently behave proportionally: 

7.0 Competition 

There is no doubt that Coinbase operates within an environment that is ripe with competition, both in comparison to other exchange/broker counterparts and crypto-related businesses. Starting off with the former, Coinbase’s NTM top-line valuation relative to 2020A-2023E Top-Line CAGR can be seen analyzed below for a series of publicly traded brokers and exchanges: 

Coinbase is expected to show the highest Revenue Growth during that period and is valued very reasonably with a NTM EV/Rev of 7.1X, second to SCHW at 5.18. Coinbase’s extremely high Revenue CAGR can be attributed to the ~5.76X increase in Revenues that is expected from FY’20 to FY’21 and estimates for FY’23 may be low if the crypto space continues to see the activity of the last few years. Moving on to profitability, a comparison of top-line growth relative to NTM EV/EBITDA multiples can be seen outlined below:

As is evident, a similar story is told to that of the above image’s predecessor and one can reasonably conclude that Coinbase’s valuation is very healthy given its growth and ability to maintain profitability on an EBITDA level in a similar, if not better, manner to its peers.

Coinbase should also be compared with some of its fintech counterparts. We can start off with the NTM EV/Revenue vs 2020A-2023E Revenue Growth seen outlined below: 

Again COIN is showing best in-class Revenue growth for the period examined and very respectable NTM top-line multiple. The company is also anticipated to have top-notch EBIT over the next few years, of which trumps most of its counterparts in scale as outlined below: 

Delving deeper, we can also compare Coinbase with some companies that have more similar operations to those previously compared above, i.e. with deep ties to crypto. An Hayden-Capital modified table below leveraging data from a study FTX by the Generalist gives a general sense below of where Coinbase is valued relative to its peers: 

Though valuation is important, it is also imperative that the trading volume on Coinbase demonstrates continued strength. Although Coinbase is evidently focused on branching out internationally, competition is strong in this area and they are evidently behind some of their counterparts. This assertion is corroborated when analyzing Spot Volumes. Both 24h normalized data (sorted by volume) from Coingecko for exchanges across the globe and monthly data from Nomics demonstrate that although Coinbase has a respectable International position they are not the top dog in this area: 

Moving over to the United States however paints a different story. Being that the company derives the majority of their Revenues from the US it will be imperative that they continue to maintain their dominance in this region. Coinbase’s leading position in the US is corroborated by both 24h data from Coingecko and Monthly Data from Nomics as outlined below: 

8.0 Coinbase Ventures 

This entity is, in essence, Coinbase’s internal investment division that directs investments at privately held crypto companies. This arm, in my opinion, cements Coinbase as a call-option on Crypto so to speak. Not only does an investor gain exposure to one of the most popular exchanges in the world, but also a series of of fast moving crypto companies as well. Although the company may have been aided by an ideal macroeconomic environment, Coinbase Ventures has seen increased activity in the number of investments they have participated in as well as an appreciation in the carrying amount recorded at the end of their most recent reporting periods, of which can be seen outlined below: 

At a Carrying Amount of approximately $270M, this metric has increased more than fivefold since the end of Q1 this year. If you look at a track record of past investments, i.e. allocations to OpenSea, Dapper Labs, StarkWare and Taxbit, all of which have reached unicorn status, it is exciting to think about what the future holds in store for this fund. If you are curious, I have attached screenshots of information regarding the company’s 141 investments within the pdf below:

Coin Ventures
768KB ∙ PDF File
Read now
Read now

9.0 Closing Thoughts 

We have discussed at length Coinbase’s competition, however, I would like to ponder a few points before moving on to my final thoughts on Coinbase as an investment. Starting off with centralized vs. decentralized exchange argument, many would like to tout that a DEX will eventually come and take Coinbase’s lunch, so to speak, which I believe is unlikely to be the case. In the United States, we already understand that Coinbase leads the way in this region and the company’s Spot Trading Volume clearly trumps any decentralized exchange, with Uniswamp being its closest competitor. Unless one is the custodian of their wallet, Centralized Exchanges essentially function by holding the crypto purchased on the platform within a wallet managed by the exchanged (centralized). Decentralized Exchanges differ in the fact that users maintain full control over their wallets, with wallets interacting with each other to trade crypto rather than relying upon the exchange as the middle man. As such DEXs result in two main advantages, security in the fact the one’s crypto is not in danger of being compromised when it is held by the exchange and sovereignty given the fact that users have control over their wallets. Being that as it may, Coinbase will still likely remain the logical first step for most Retail Investors (a phenomenon that is corroborated by Spot Trading Volume in the US) due to its inherent simplicity and ease of access. Though many proponents of defi would like to argue otherwise, managing your own wallet and buying and selling crypto through a DEX is an order of magnitude more difficult for the layman, a factor which I believe adds an extra layer of friction to switching from a centralized to a decentralized exchange. In addition, Coinbase’s platform has never actually sustained a breach or been hacked. User accounts have been exploited through phishing scams, however, the company’s platform itself is extremely secure and for this reason alone is trusted by the biggest institutions in the world for crypto custodianship. For these reasons I feel like the centralized vs. decentralized exchange argument doesn’t have much merit when applied to Coinbase. 

In addition, Coinbase must also must fare well against apps like Cash App and Robinhood. Using Cash App as a point of comparison, the app had almost double the amount of downloads in November than Coinbase. 

I think Coinbase differentiates itself well from other Fintech companies in the sheer volume of crypto offerings. With Cash App for example, the company suffers from being overshadowed by the Bitcoin Maximalism of Block’s (Square) Jack Dorsey. The company is even working on their own decentralized exchange, an effort I believe will prove futile if they are not able to expand their crypto offerings. If we look at the Coinbase’s Trading Volume Distribution by Crypto Asset, as previously discussed, there is a clear behavior trend in Coinbase’s users away from solely investing in Bitcoin to investments in Ethereum and Other Crypto Assets like Solana which have demonstrated benefits in terms of developer capabilities and transaction speeds, feats which Digital Gold is just not capable of. As such, I believe Retail Investors that truly want exposure to all avenues of the Crypto Space are likely to turn to Coinbase for these reasons alone. 

Lastly, Coinbase is putting substantial efforts into differentiating the main drivers of their business. Mentioned earlier the company has evidently acknowledged the fact that their company is heavily reliant on Transaction Revenues. Although this concentration has been reducing slightly over the years, it is still extremely high. Generating meaningful subscription/services revenue is the logical direction and Coinbase is evidently focused on this area, especially given their acquisition-fueled Coinbase Cloud activity of late. The company has also rolled out Coinbase One, a product which for $29.99/month offers individuals zero trading fees, access to 24/7 support, and up to $1M in an investment protection of sorts. These efforts and other future ones like it will most definitely improve the health of Coinbase’s business and platform as a whole going forwards. 

10.0 Conclusion 

In summary, despite not being long Coinbase, I recognize the value proposition here. My main concern is with the company’s evident correlation to the behaviour of the crypto space in general, a worry that I will not be able to get over until I have completed more research into Web 3.0 as a whole. Being that as it may, Coinbase is valued reasonably, has top-tier management, has clear dominance in the US, is adding new products and crypto assets to their product suite and platform, and are no doubt focused on ironing out the kinks in their operations. As such, I believe Coinbase warrants the attention of investors. This research should have provided you with a great starting point for considering the company as a portfolio allocation and I thank you for reading it. Happy Holidays. 

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, comment below and share!

Share

If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

item.title: Airbnb Inc. ($ABNB)
item.description: Disrupting Travel One Air Mattress at a Time
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to MT Capital Research! If you’re new, join a group of 3093 Informed Investors who receive weekly research reports on the World’s Most Interesting Tech Companies by subscribing below: 

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing a deep-dive on Airbnb Inc. Within I will discuss the main trends and tailwinds the company aims to benefit from, detail their platform offerings and services as well as breakdown the inherent value proposition that the company directs at both hosts and guests alike. In addition, time will be spent analyzing the company’s most recent earnings report and performing an in-depth comparison of the company’s competition, where they fit within the world’s everchanging travel habits and discussing some positive and risk factors alike that both current and potential investors should be wary of. The format of this research, as always, can be seen outlined below. Feel free to skip ahead to the sections that provide you with the most value 

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Opportunity and Tailwinds

3.0 Platform 

4.0 How Airbnb makes $$$

5.0 Financial Analysis 

6.0 Key Performance Indicators 

7.0 Valuation and Competition 

8.0 Closing Thoughts

9.0 Conclusion 

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as substitute for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investment. 

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content, follow my Twitter below: 

Follow Me!

With all of that considered, let’s start delving into Airbnb

1.0 Introduction 

Airbnb Inc., which I will denote as Airbnb for the remainder of this report for the sake of simplicity, operates an end-to-end travel platform which, in essence, is focused on creating a world where travel is made more enjoyable and accessible to all. The company’s services range from connecting travelers with owners in order to rent out shared spaces, private rooms or an entire property for themselves, supporting stays in duration anywhere from a few days to a few months, if desired. In addition, the company offers experiences, a series of in-person or online activities hosted by local experts that allow guests to participate in unique activities, of which act as an immersion of sorts into a local culture. The company, founded in 2007 and initially referred to as AirBed & Breakfast, started off as a way for now-CEO Brian Cheskey and his co-founder to pay their rent. Offering air mattresses to individuals that were looking to attend nearby conferences in San Francisco but who could not afford or locate a reasonable hotel, the corporation has transformed the very manner in which many conduct their travel, now existing as a multi-billion dollar disruptive icon of sorts. 

With this brief description of the company in mind, let’s take a look at the main opportunities and tailwinds the company aims to leverage both within the current operations and future growth initiatives. 

2.0 Opportunity and Tailwinds

Before delving into a more broad discussion of current trends that are evidently in Airbnb's favor, it is worth breaking down what the company deems to be both their Serviceable Addressable Market (SAM) and Total Addressable Market (TAM). The former, of which the company believes they are directing full efforts at today can be split into two main components, as outlined by the image below: 

Short-Term stays, which can be defined as a trip with a duration under 28 days, are associated with a SAM of approximately $1.2T (in-house estimate based upon trip duration, ADR, i.e. the revenue earned per trip divided by the duration of the trip, etc.) whereas Experiences and Attractions, or in other words typical tourist spend related to activities associated with travel/excursion, is estimated to have approximately a $300B SAM, resulting in Airbnb’s total SAM adding up to approximately $1.5T. Moving over to the company’s TAM, the company breaks this opportunity down into three main components, as outlined by the image below: 

Starting off with Incremental Short-Term Stays, the company estimates that there is an additional $600B to be potentially extracted from the growth in this area, as corroborated by the 3.5% CAGR that the World Travel and Tourism Council expects to see between 2019 and 2030 [2]. Moving on to Long Term Stays, the company estimates that they will be able to address both the Global Apartment Market and approximately 10% of the Residential Rental Market, resulting in approximately $200B in value. Lastly, the company combines estimates of $1.1T for Non-Tourist Recreational Spend to arrive at a TAM of approximately $3.4T. Although these estimates for both SAM and TAM may appear ludicrous to some, it is important to gauge where the Travel and Hospitality Industry fits within the concept of a Global Economy. Before the emergence of the pandemic, a phenomenon that evidently reaped disastrous consequences on the industry as a whole, the sheer size of Travel and Tourism was astonishing, a feat that is likely to continue as our world moves towards a heightened sense of normalcy. More specifically, Travel and Tourism accounted for nearly 25% of all new jobs created around the world, 10% of all existing jobs and approximately 10.5% of Global Gross Domestic Product [3]. With these numbers in mind, it is an exciting prospect to consider the amount of success Airbnb may be able to reap from targeting an ever-expanding target market. 

Moving on, it is worth discussing some notable tailwinds, no matter how abstract they may seem to be, that may have a tangible effect on Airbnb’s future success. The first is Airbnb’s transition into a verb. This phenomenon can be loosely described as an occurrence by where a brand transitions into a commonly used word; with notable examples ranging from companies/products such as Uber, PayPal, Bandaid, Tupperware, Jacuzzi, Google and many more. Airbnb is no different, now existing as a verb for many that refers to the simple act of renting a place to stay, cementing its brand as a unique moat in itself. In addition, the rise of Airbnb has evidently been a positive benefactor from the rise of the “Experience Economy”. In the late 90’s, James Gilmore and company coined this expression in a renowned study that analyzed how the transformation of a commodity, into a good or service, and finally into an experience, is often associated with heightened economic value at the latter end of the process, as outlined by the flow diagram below: 

As an example, a study performed by PCMA analyzed the fact that since 2016 (excluding pandemic-affected years) US consumers were spending more time and money at restaurants and bars in comparison to down at the commodity level, i.e. at grocery stores, corroborating our previously made assertions of the aforementioned value chain [5]. Moving over to the Travel and Hospitality Industry, I believe Airbnb offers customers, oftentimes, a more differentiated experience in comparison to hotels, a phenomenon that funny enough, often doesn’t come with a premium price tag in comparison to its counterpart. Taking a step back for a second, it is worth pondering why this is for a second. More specifically, when one thinks of a hotel, a differentiated experience does not usually come to mind. As an example, visions of grandiose may be pushed aside for recollections of a bed with plain white sheets, a bathroom that feels gross no matter how many times you think its been cleaned, and complimentary breakfasts that leave much to be desired, or maybe I just haven’t stayed at the right hotels. These memories aren’t by happenstance, with major hotel industry players carefully constructing experiences that no matter the geographic location are remarkably similar. As an example, Holiday Inn has become a hotel chain that most in the Western World are familiar with, particularly due to their impressive uniformity from location to location. The hotel chain first originated in the year 1952, inspired by Kemmon Wilson on a family trip to Washington DC. At the time, hotels were sparse to say the least, often offering non-memorable experiences, even charging Kemmon extra money for his five children [6]. This trip left so much to be desired that Wilson came back an inspired man and decided to try to reinvent the way lodging operated by constructing approximately 400 different motels, each within a day’s drive of each other, across the country. These ideas can be thought of the gold standard that hotels operate according to today, with each holiday inn containing rooms measuring approximately 12 x 26 ft (including the bathroom), possessing telephones, televisions and ice machines, an on-premise restaurant and possessing child-friendly ideals. 

Flash forward a few decades later, this uniformity has spread far and wide may be one of the main reasons Airbnb has, and should continue to, reap large amounts of success. In other words, Airbnb may be the primary location where one goes for a unique experience. On the company’s website they declare that their mission is to create a world where anyone can belong anywhere, which though idealistic and cheesy is hard to disprove. Airbnb’s offer a gateway into a culture or location that hotels simply cannot, and as such the company has become an essential component of the what it means for many to have a good trip nowadays. 

Not only does Airbnb appeal to the traveler, i.e. the guest side of the transaction, it is also offers a real value proposition to the host. The rise in popularity of Airbnb with those looking to rent out a room within or their entire house/apartment may have directly arisen due to the spread of the “Gig Economy”. This phenomenon can be loosely defined as a more flexible way of making end meets outside of the traditional 9-5. Whether that be with actively freelancing, engaging in side hustles such as driving an Uber, being a personal shopper with Instacart, or delivering meals with Doordash, this behavior has become very noticeable. In addition, with Upwork outlining the fact that approximately 36% of the total American workforce performs freelance work, it is evident that technology is fundamentally altering what is possible and the ways in which people can make money. Applied to Airbnb, it is no surprise that individuals have benefitted from the ability to earn income from renting out their properties, a feat that is likely to continue into the future. The very idea for Airbnb stemmed from the willingness to do just that. More specifically, Brian Chesky and his co-founding partner Joe Gebbia decided to charge a few individuals that were in town for a local conference to stay on air mattresses in their apartment, an effort made in order to help pay their rent why they envisioned new business ideas. Little did they know, the air mattresses in their apartment was the multi-billion dollar business idea in itself. As such, the gig economy is quite evidently in the both the DNA of the founders and the company itself, and is likely to continue to aid Airbnb in strengthening its two-sided marketplace’s presence in various geographies across the globe. 

Now that we have a better understanding of the factors Airbnb aims to benefit from and the opportunities in front of them, let’s break down the company’s platform. 

3.0 Platform 

Creating a two-sided marketplace capable of flourishing is challenging to say the least, drawing eerie similarities to a casualty dilemma we’ve all heard at some point in our lives: what comes first, the chicken or the egg? Airbnb, in its early stages suffered from this dilemma, needing to both cater towards travelers and hosts with their technology and grow accordingly. This phenomenon can be labeled as a “lopsided marketplace” so to speak, with the number of travelers greatly exceeding the number of hosts on the platform, as illustrated below: 

You may be wondering how Airbnb successfully grew their platform with this situation in mind, i.e. how were they able to satisfy the demand of travelers by onboarding new hosts in an expedient manner. This can all be boiled down into a simple network effect: as more hosts list on the company’s platform, the more options that are available for the travelers themselves, thus increasing the attractiveness for guests; and as more guests join the platform, the more attractive it is for hosts to list their property seeing as their is a plethora of available customers. With this full-circle network effect in mind, it is no wonder Airbnb has been and will continue to be able to scale across the globe with ease. In comparison to traditional Travel and Hospitality Entities, it is vastly easier for the company to scale, since they can use word of mouth and the aforementioned network effects to penetrate a market that would otherwise require Millions in Real Estate investments for typical legacy hotel operators. Getting back to business, it is of undoubtable importance that we are able to understand both the functionality of both the Guest and Host sides of Airbnb’s technology. 

Guests

The guest-directed side of Airbnb’s platform can be split into two unique components, Stays and Experiences. Stays can be searched for directly on Airbnb’s website or mobile app and are easily navigable with the company’s clean UI. As an example, if one were looking to stay in Toronto from December 25th-28th with themselves and another they would be able to specify this criteria in the search bar and would be directed to a list of Stays accordingly: 

Once one arrives at a place they are interested in they can then view the specifics of the location, read reviews from past guests and delve into the costs associated with the stay. In addition, Airbnb adds a social aspect to this side of their platform through the provision of Wishlist functionality. In essence this allows for travelers to keep track of their favorite locations, share experiences with friends or family and collaboratively plan, if interested. Moving on to Experiences Airbnb offers customers a variety of one-of-a-kind activities hosted by experts within regions across the world. These experiences can be enjoyed in conjunction with a Stay or as their own separate entity and when viewed alongside Airbnb’s self-proclaimed ability to help individuals “belong anywhere” evidently add a layer of cultural immersion that would not be present on the platform otherwise. Similar to Stays, Experiences can be browsed by date of occurrence, category (i.e. cooking, pottery etc.) or location, as outlined below: 

Hosts 

With a similar UI to that of the guest-directed side of the platform, Airbnb makes it quite easy for an owner to host either a room within or their entire house, apartment etc. After making an account, listing on Airbnb is a ten-step process that consists primarily specifying what type of place will be hosted, how much space guests will have (i.e. entire, shared etc.), the location, specifying how many people are welcome, listing any amenities, posting pictures etc. Once the place is listed, hosts can then leverage a series of additional features that ranges from dynamic pricing assistance (i.e. price adjustments that can be made to the space depending on the demand, time of the year etc.), choosing when their listed place is available for rent with the application/website’s interactive calendar and leveraging feedback ranging from guest reviews or suggestions from the platform themselves to improve the performance of the listing. 

Before delving into how exactly the company makes money, it is worth touching on the subtle intricacies that make Airbnb’s platform as functional and user-friendly as it is. First off, both Airbnb’s website and mobile application operate with the three-click rule in mind. This guideline, of which Chesky mentions within a jampacked episode of Blitzscaling (highly recommend if you would like to get inside the brain of one of the founders) was originally set forth by Steve Jobs to Apple Engineers, by where he wanted the iPod interface to be designed in a way that music was at most three clicks away on the device, no matter where the user was located [8].

Applied to Airbnb, the founders wanted guests to be at most three clicks away from a booking a stay at any time. 

This effort was made with an evident focus on reducing the friction associated with using the platform and did not stop there. In 2008, when the company was founded, Fintech was not where it is today. Amidst a financial crisis there was not sufficient capital being directed at creating a multitude of scalable payment solutions. As such, PayPal dominated this space and was the go-to provider for most online commerce operators. Although Airbnb could’ve easily partnered with this behemoth at the time, they decided to take the road less travelled. More specifically, the founders feared that redirecting users from their website to a Paypal page in order to process the payment for a stay would greatly friction, a happening that they could not afford if they were to differentiate themselves from the booking experience of a hotel. As such, the founders (Nathan Blecharcyzk in particular) decided to build payment-processing capabilities in house, a feat that was extremely challenging on a technical level but one that resulted in a customer experience that increased in quality by orders of magnitude being that customers could now pay directly on the company’s website without being redirected. Friction-reducing functionality is further exacerbated when looking at features ranging from the company’s on-platform messaging services, i.e. the ability for hosts and guests to communicate directly on the application, as outlined below, being able to access important details about a stay on-app such as key code combinations, etc. 

In summary, Airbnb design choices were and still are made with an utmost focus on a clean experience. To the layman this may not seem important, but increasing the ease at which the customer is able to use the platform to its intended consequence is of irreplaceable value and offers a tangible benefit in comparison to competitors. 

Lastly, the ability for Airbnb’s platform to scale so effectively is directly rooted in their trust-based review system. When comparing Airbnb with typical Travel and Hospitality Entities, the company differs in the fact that instead of having a one-sided business model that is vertically integrated and is very asset heavy, they have a community-based model that splits the economics being generated between the various stakeholders that are connected throughout the platform. In order for this business model to be functional it relies on trust. Airbnb supports both sides of their marketplace, thus a review system is applied to both hosts and guest. Existing as a five-star system, guests can see the average rating of a host and read reviews of individuals that have previously stayed with the host. 

On the opposite end of the spectrum, hosts can see the ratings of guests in order to pinpoint whether or not these individuals have been responsible, respectful etc. In addition hosts are incentivized to get good reviews since better ranked individuals are placed higher within the hierarchy of search results of a particular location and one can eventually reach SuperHost status that result from the completion of well-received 100 hosted nights and a high guest response rate, of which results in the following benefits: 

Now that we understand how Airbnb’s platform functions, let’s take a look at how exactly the company makes money from it. 

4.0 How Airbnb makes $$$

In the previous section we discussed the nature of Airbnb’s two-sided marketplace, particularly how it is predominantly populated by individuals on the guest side of things rather than its host counterpart. In conjunction with leveraging network effects to combat this dilemma, Airbnb also structures their business model in a very host-friendly manner. More specifically, on each stay that is generated through the company’s platform Airbnb only takes 3% of the Total Transaction Value, which in essence covers the cost of processing the payment itself. Airbnb makes the majority of their money on the guest-side of the transaction, charging guests a service fee that is anywhere between 5-15% of the Total Transaction Value. Being that their is no shortage of potential guests on the company’s platform, this strategy makes a whole lot of sense. In order to cement these points home, a useful visual outlining a hypothetical transaction and where the guest and host fits in accordingly can be seen outlined below: 

Now that we have a better understanding of how Airbnb makes money, let’s take a look at their most recent earnings report and perform an analysis on the contents within accordingly. 

5.0 Financial Analysis

This section will be spent analyzing the key components of Airbnb’s most recent Income Statement, Balance Sheet and Cash Flow Statement and drawing conclusions based upon the values contained therein. 

Income Statement

Revenue 

Airbnb’s Revenue came in at approximately $2.24B for the quarter, representing a 67% increase YoY, however since these are favorable comps due to the affect of the pandemic, we will also examine the percentage increase relative to Q3’19, which was 36%. The change in this value with respect to time can be seen outlined below: 

As is quite evident, Q3  is usually the strongest reporting quarter for Airbnb. Being that as it may, this metric has recovered and grown respectively relative to 2019, indicating that Airbnb’s operations have recovered from the impacts of the pandemic and have regained their footing on the steady growth trajectory they were on prior.  

Costs and Expenses

Airbnb combines their Cost of Revenues (COR) and Operating Expenses into this Cost and Expenses metric. Starting off with COR, this value primarily contains the costs associated with payment processing (i.e. merchant fees, chargebacks etc.), followed by the costs to host the platform and of software. Indicative of Airbnb’s ability to scale while reducing costs in the process is the fact that COR increased 37% and 1% in comparison to the same periods in 2020 and 2019, respectively, in comparison to Revenue values that increased at a higher tape. The change in COR and COR as a % of Total Revenue can be seen outlined below: 

Moving over to Operating Expenses, the company has been controlling expenses well, with OPEX increasing 54% on a YoY basis and decreasing approximately 3% since the same period in 2019. In addition, OPEX relative to Revenue came in at an all-time low, an encouraging fact despite OPEX usually inevitably increasing in the first half of most years: 

This value consists of four main components, Operations and Support, Product and Development Costs, Sales and Marketing and General and Administrative Expenses. The change in these values relative to Revenue can be seen outlined below: 

As the table outlines, all of these values decreased relative to Revenue in comparison to Q3’19 values, again encouraging given the fact that the company has added scale since then. The main values I will be monitoring going forwards are S&M and Product and Development seeing as the former is relatively indicative of the company’s ability to scale primarily on their network effects, which management evidently touts on a quite consistent basis and the former highlights the amount of effort being directed at improvements made with the platform, which hasn’t been an issue in the near-term given the company added approximately 150 new upgrades this year. Lastly, as summary, Costs and Expenses relative to Revenue is at an all-time low of approximately 62% in comparison to 69% last year and 86% the year prior. 

Margins and Profitability 

In order to gauge Airbnb’s profitability, the company’s Operating Income, Net Income and Adjusted EBITDA can be seen outlined in the following table: 

Operating Income totaled approximately $852M, increasing 103% YoY and 266% since Q3’19. Net Income came in at $833M, increasing 280% YoY an 213% since 2019 whereas Adjusted EBITDA came in at approximately $1.1B, increasing 120% YoY and 252% since 2019, respectively. Looking at Operating Income, Net Income and Adjusted EBITDA margins further corroborates the fact that the company is moving towards sustained profitability: 

Although seasonality is of course a factor, the magnitude and margins of these metrics has been the best this Q3 in comparison to previous the same reporting period in previous years. Looking forward, it would be ideal for Airbnb to achieve slight profitability on an Operating and Net Income measures in reporting periods where seasonality is a factor. 

Balance Sheet 

The structure of Airbnb’s assets as of Q3’21 can be seen outlined below: 

The company’s assets are predominantly liquid as gauged by the % of Total Assets attributable to the Current Variety and consist mainly of Cash and Cash Equivalents, Funds Receivable and Funds held on behalf of customers (as part of the payment processing process) and Marketable Securities. Long Term Assets on the other hand consist mainly of Goodwill, Intangible Assets and Operating Lease Assets. The structure of Airbnb’s liabilities can be seen outlined below: 

Liabilities are also mainly liquid with current Liabilities consisting mainly of Accrued Expenses and Funds Payable whereas Long Term Liabilities are mainly in the form of Long-term debt and Operating Lease Liabilities. In summary the company has a healthy balance, one whose liquidity aligns well with the company’s manageable cash burn rate needed to fund growth going forwards. 

Cash Flow Statement 

The change in the company’s Cash Provided by Operating, Investing and Financing Activities over the course of the last several quarters can be seen outlined below: 

Coming in at approximately $1.7B for the quarter, CFO has been showing evident improvements when compared to both Q3’20 and Q3’19, attributable to the company’s diligent cost and expense controls while they have both recovered from the pandemic and continued on their growth trajectory. CFI came in at approximately $(170)M for Q3’21, attributable to investments being made in Market and Equity Securities. CFF was approximately $(2.3)B for the quarter, aligning itself with the financing activities that are usually carried out during Q3. The change in the company’s FCF and FCF margin over the course of the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

FCF and FCF margin for Q3’21 came in at approximately $517M and 23% respectively, again improving over the same reporting period in previous years. In my opinion the company is likely to maintain a positive FCF situation even in periods where seasonality has negative impacts, which makes Airbnb very enticing going forwards with their ability to self-sustain operations. 

Now that we’ve taken a closer look at Airbnb’s financials, let’s delve into some Key Performance Indicators that will give us an additional sense of how the company is performing. 

6.0 Key Performance Indicators

Airbnb labels two main metrics as their Key Performance Indicators, the number of Nights and Experiences booked on the platform as well as the Gross Booking Value. The former, which represents the sum of the total number of nights booked for Stays and the number of seats booked for Experiences and how this has changed on a yearly basis can be seen outlined below:  

The number of Nights and Experiences booked with the platform has already increased 18% for the nine months ended Q3’21 (2021*) in comparison to 2020, however this value is likely to fall short from its 2019 counterpart heading into the end of the year. Moving over to the latter, the change in GBV for the first nine months of 2021 relative to previous years can be seen outlined below: 

With a GBV of approximately $35.6B thus far in 2021, this metric has already improved 49% YoY and is only 6% short of the 2019 total, indicating that GBV is likely to exceed its 2019 counterpart by a reasonable amount heading into the end of the year. You may be wondering how Airbnb has been able to recover GBV at a much higher rate than the Number of Nights and Experiences booked. When looking at the GBV per Night and Experience booked, it is clear that the company has been extracting heightened value from each booking occurring on their platform in comparison to previous years: 

Explained more elegantly by Dave Stepehenson, the CFO of Airbnb, in their most recent conference call, is the fact that European and North American markets have recovered in a faster manner to their Asia and Latin American counterparts, which has driven up the ADR (Average Daily Rate) and consequently the average GBV per night and experience booked as well. In addition, with consumer preferences changing as a result of the heightened degree of technologically-enabled work freedom that emerged as a result of the pandemic, the company is starting to see increased amounts of non-urban whole home and larger home rentals, which has helped to increase the rates as well. In summary, the activity in Airbnb’s platform is starting to show signs of a full recovery, albeit not out of the clear yet with the emergence of the omnicron variant. Being that as it may, heightened ADRs, which management anticipates are likely to remain as such in the coming quarters is likely to assist top-line growth in the short term. 

7.0 Valuation and Competition 

In order to get a better sense of where Airbnb fits in amongst their competition, we will be comparing a series of metrics for the company and its peers. Starting off with Top-Line Growth, a comparison of projected 2020A-2023E Revenue CAGR relative to NTM EV/Revenue multiples for Airbnb and company can be seen compared by the following figure and the table containing the associated data: 

As is quite obvious, most of Airbnb’s counterparts are expecting to grow Revenue in between 2020-2023 at an approximately 40% CAGR, however, Airbnb is valued the richest in terms of a forward valuation multiple in comparison to companies like Booking.com and Expedia that trump it in scale and are still growing at a similar rate. Moving on to profitability, a table outlining EBIT values from 2020-2023 for the same companies can be seen outlined below: 

Although it is net positive that Airbnb is expected to generate meaningful EBIT in the company years, these values are lesser in magnitude to that of Booking and Expedia. Moving over to Operating and Free Cash Flow Margins, Airbnb’s metrics have been arguably slightly better for Airbnb in comparison Booking for the last two reporting periods, and noticeably better than Expedia for the same time frame.

Delving deeper, Airbnb’s main source of competition, in my opinion, lies in the existence of Expedia and Booking. Performing a high-level comparison on important metrics associated with each company’s platform, as outlined below, results in knowledge of the fact that Airbnb’s GBV is a little more than a third of the size of both Expedia’s and Bookings, as outlined by the table below: 

Being that as it may, Airbnb seems to have revamped outside of the pandemic-induced slump at a much faster rate than its counterparts, when looking at the percentage of pre-covid revenue achieved in the first 9 months of 2021. Although the company is evidently benefited from tailwinds in their ADR, this is still encouraging to see. Moving on, in a recent interview, Chesky mentioned that the pandemic gave the company an interesting opportunity, i.e. insight into how they can operate their business 0 marketing spend, a CMO’s dream so to speak. In short, these occurrences gave them an interesting test-case which has resulted in, when flashing forward to the most recent quarter, the company evidently possessing a heightened faith in the strength of their network effects and their ability to spur organic growth, seeing as a reasonable pace of reacceleration to sales and marketing spend has been commendable. Airbnb’s Marketing Spend has evidently improved, as seen by the comparison relative to Revenue below: 

Taken with a grain of salt, this figure paints the picture that Airbnb is able to sustain Top-Line Growth with lower sales and marketing spend, an encouraging factor. A similar tale is told when viewing the company’s marketing expenses relative to gross profits, as the figure below highlights: 

Booking no longer reports Brand Marketing as a separate value in their filings, therefore it is not possible to calculate applicable Sales and Marketing (i.e. Brand Marketing + Sales and Other Expenses) for more recent reporting periods, however, this comparison is still useful. More specifically, in the 2017-2019 period Booking was evidently able to yield more efficient marketing results on a GP basis in comparison to Airbnb. This is evidently due to how the company’s operate their businesses, i.e. how Airbnb keeps most costs on the guest side of the transaction in order to make the experience for individual hosts as pleasant as possible. It is positive to see Airbnb making more efficient use of marketing relative to GP in the first 9 months of this year however it remains to be seen how they will be able extract more GP per dollar of GBV without seriously decreasing host satisfaction (i.e. they would have to increase their take on this side of transaction which may not result in the smoothest host experience).  It is also worth noting that Booking stated that their brand marketing has gone up significantly as a result of pandemic induced headwinds and the fact that they have stopped reporting the exact value makes one wonder whether or not they are still within reasonable distance of their pre-pandemic efficiencies. This would be a comparison I’d be very curious to see given how much quicker Airbnb recovered post-covid relative to their GBV and the diligent cost controls they’ve implemented since then as well. 

Before moving on to final discussions, it is worth looking at the progression of Airbnb in their early years of operation in comparison to Booking. Inspired by a great post by traveltech media made prior to Airbnb’s IPO, looking at Gross Bookings for 6 of each company’s earliest reporting periods, i.e.  2009 to the first 9 months of 2015 for Booking and 2016 to the first 9 months of 2021 for Airbnb, respectively, yields some astonishing results that may be indicative of Airbnb’s potential future direction. This comparison of Gross Bookings can be seen outlined below: 

As is quite evident, when one puts the effects of the pandemic aside, the company appears to be on a remarkably similar early trajectory and seems to have gotten back on track to this path of late. If we zoom out (i.e up until the Full Year 2019 Reporting Period for Booking), this would yield some great results for Airbnb if the same correlation is continued: 

A similar story correlation can be observed with Revenue, if one is so inclined. Moving along, this story gets more interesting when we look at EBITDA, behavior which started off looking remarkably different but has vastly improved over the last 9 months and is likely to continue as Airbnb continues to scale with a very marketing-light approach that they now realize they can sustain: 

In summary, there is no doubt that Airbnb is valued richly to its competition. Displaying projected top-line growth that is in-line with its peers, improving marketing efficiencies that are likely to be approaching the effectiveness of Booking’s, improving EBITDA prospects and remarkably similar GBV behavior to its Booking counterpart, there is a lot to ponder here. An investment in Airbnb is likely to come alongside a belief that the company will be able to maintain their popularity to drive sustainable GBV growth over the next decade while also maintaining profitability through strict expense controls. I lean on the side of optimism and do believe Airbnb will be able to achieve this, however, I do understand that an investment here comes with a price tag. As we have seen throughout history, the world’s best brands are usually valued at a premium, however, this comes with much higher scrutiny and with the market behavior of late, Airbnb will need to execute to perfection if they wish to keep trading at this kind of valuation, in my opinion.

8.0 Closing Thoughts

Now that we’ve satisfied the GARP crowd with the acknowledgement of Airbnb’s valuation and potential shortcomings with regards to size in comparison to their peers, (don’t throw your napkin math at me after this), let’s delve deeper into what I believe is one of Airbnb’s greatest strengths, their anti-fragility.  This term, coined by Nassim Taleb, refers to a property of systems to gain or thrive from the presence of external stressors, noise, chaos etc. In other words, applied to companies, I'd like to define the phenomenon as an enterprise that is able to survive and potentially excel from events that could be classified as problematic, or even worse, catastrophic. In 2020 we were shocked with an event that not many saw coming, a pandemic that fundamentally altered the way humanity functioned, an occurrence that saw borders close and the travel and hospitality industry completely decimated in the span of a few weeks. Airbnb in particular suffered, experiencing more cancellations than total bookings shortly after the emergence of the virus and later laying off 25%+ of their workforce in response to the stresses the business saw.

 Although this behavior doesn’t exemplify the company thriving under pressure, looking back now at how well the company has gotten back on track, how fast they’ve rebounded their GBV relative to their peers and their evident nimbleness, I was and am still very impressed on how the company has executed and continues to adapt. As an example and as mentioned earlier, technology is fundamentally altering the way the world is functioning, and the working habits of many professionals are adapting to the digital age. Aligning themselves perfectly with this trend, the company has seen notable growth in their long-term stays, with over 45% of total nights booked on the platform in Q3’21 being at least 7 days in length. Not only does this represent a great opportunity to expand both their SAM/TAM (i.e. the move towards longer form travel) but it also highlights management’s ability to cater towards the dynamic needs of guests in general. The pandemic gave investors great insight into how Airbnb can function in arguably the worst situation a hospitality business could operate with, and they seemed to have passed with flying colors. 

Looking forward, many would like to tout the risks associated with regulations as one of the main headwinds for Airbnb. Though true, Airbnb’s organization operates almost as an aggregator of splinter cells, relying on individuals situated across the globe to function. The company attributes no more than a percent (plus or minus a few basis points) of Revenue to more than one city. Therefore, regardless of what the regulatory situation may be in that locale, the outcome is not likely to have substantial impacts on either the company’s top or bottom lines regardless. Cities have also seemed to switch their tune up regarding Airbnb (spare New York City’s hard fought battle regarding the nature of short-term rentals that doesn’t seem to ever want to end). More specifically with the local economic activity of cities faltering during the pandemic as a result of decreased tourism and travel activity, many started to rethink their opinions regarding the presence of Airbnb, especially seeing as how it can bring individuals into regions that would normally not see increased activity from hotels. I am by no means an expert on policy, however, in my opinion, Airbnb operates as a net positive, and I don’t see opinions surrounding that assertion turning for the worst anytime soon. Lastly, the company has stated that their Active Listings have grown each quarter this year (I wish they would disclose the growth rate), after 2019-2020 Listing numbers remained relatively flat. The number of listings will continue to be one of the biggest risks going forwards, specifically since the phenomenon of demand with their platform is much easier to come across than supply, respectively. As such, transaction economics (i.e. how Airbnb makes most of their money through platform fees charged to guests) will continue to be a direct line between host satisfaction and resultant listing supply. With the majority of the hosts being individuals (close to 90%) this structure is likely to keep them content and with the ability for a side hustle, gig economy role or form of economic empowerment, whatever you would like to call it, available for the taking with hosting on Airbnb, supply should not be an issue, however, this will need to be monitored.

My closing thoughts are as follows. I do believe Airbnb can sustain meaningful growth going forwards and the company is evidently moving in the right direction with how their business is operating under the hood. Airbnb’s brand and their existence as the go-to-location for all things unique in the travel realm should continue to exist uninterrupted, especially when judging how Chesky and company are still intertwined with the direction the corporation is headed. Being founder-led is a cliche that we have all come across, however I believe Airbnb’s management is top notch and is likely to continue executing to the tee. That being said Airbnb is not a company you can set and forget, in my opinion. With approximately half of the GBV of its competitors and a much higher multiple, investors will need to continually monitor execution to ensure valuation compression doesn’t occur after faltering results.

9.0 Conclusion

In conclusion, there is no doubt that Airbnb has fundamentally altered the very manner in which travel is conducted. Becoming intertwined with pop culture and existing as a verb that transcends generations are all essential ingredients to cult brands, and Airbnb possesses them. Not without risks, I have outlined some key comparative points and discussion items that I believe offer a great starting point for considering Airbnb as an investment, or not. With that, I will bid you farewell. Thank you for reading my research.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, comment below and share!

Share

If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

item.title: Monday.com ($MNDY)
item.description: Making the Worst Day a Better Day
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to MT Capital Research! If you’re new, join a group of 2988 Informed Investors who receive weekly research reports on the World’s Most Interesting Tech Companies by subscribing below: 

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an in-depth deep-dive on Monday.com. Within I will discuss a series of tailwinds as well as limitations with current project/task management software that the company aims to both benefit from and resolve with their own offerings. In addition, I will spend time breaking down the functionality of the company’s platform, perform analysis on their most recent earnings report and discuss a series of factors, both positive and risk-based alike that current and potential investors should be wary of. The format of this research, broken down into each respective section, can be seen outlined below. Feel free to skip ahead to the sections that you will find most interesting:

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Opportunity

3.0 Technology 

4.0 How Monday makes $$$

5.0 Financial Analysis

6.0 Key Performance Indicators 

7.0 Valuation

8.0 Final Thoughts

9.0 Conclusion

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitute for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investment. 

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content, follow my Twitter below: 

Follow Me

With all of that considered, let’s start delving into Monday.com

1.0 Introduction

Monday.com, which I will denote as Monday for the remainder of this report for the sake of simplicity, can be most easily described as a developer of enterprise-geared software applications within the US, Europe, the Middle East and other International Locations. Monday denotes their platform the “Work Operating System”, consisting of building blocks that can be used by any member of an organization, no matter their technical aptitude, in order to spur meaningful value creation and insight generation, and to allow employees to create custom-built software applications and work management tools. The companies secondary offerings, so to speak, include product solutions for marketing, CRM, project management, business development, consulting and more. Through each of these offerings the company aims to accelerate digital adoption, increase efficiencies and productivity, and unify disparate departments situated across a company. 

With this brief summary in mind,  let’s delve into the opportunities that Monday aims to capitalize upon. 

2.0 Opportunity 

Monday believes that their opportunity is rooted in a series of trends stemming from a shift in the very fabric of the way work is conducted. Delving into the specifics, the three main tailwinds the company aims to benefit from can be seen outlined within the image below: 

Starting off with the Digitization of Work, many believe that we’re amidst a paradigm shift where blinding technological innovation is transforming the modern enterprise into companies that have real presence in the digital realm. Our world, as of right now, has seen three Industrial Revolutions. The first leveraged water and steam power, mechanizing human productivity in an exponential manner. The second utilized electric power to spur mass production. The third can be denoted as the knowledge revolution, moving individuals from factory settings into office environments, made possible by an ever abundant supply of information and automation of the monotonous. The fourth revolution, of which has not been completed, may blur the lines between the physical, digital and biological, spurred by the prowess of digital technologies ranging from artificial intelligence, IoT, energy storage and quantum computing. Putting numbers to these assertions, the IDC estimates that over 65% of Global Domestic Product will be digitized by the end of 2022, of which represents a total opportunity for digital transformation spend of approximately $6.8T [2]. We have seen this transformation spend change sentiment, albeit spurred by the emergence of a global pandemic that accelerated adoption in a manner that would’ve taken years longer otherwise. As an example, organizations have shown an increased willingness to adopt remote work, as seen by an increase in the amount of remote-oriented business that anticipate their workforce to remain fully remote in the years to come, a trend that will result in proportional digital adoption and technological reliance as as a result: 

In addition, the pandemic increased the rate at which organizations leveraged software to manage their businesses and conduct daily operations, as outlined by the increased utilization in various corporate-oriented software offerings gauged by the figure below:

Heightened adoption of software may be a direct response to the Increased Need for Organizational Agility. More specifically, a study performed by MIT identified that firms that prioritized agility were able to grow revenues at a 37% higher rate and generate 30% higher profit in comparison to non-agile counterparts [4]. In addition, a recent OliverWyman survey determined that despite nearly 90% of CIOs indicating that agility was important, only 26% of these individuals identified their processes as agile themselves. Software is essential to businesses trying to exceed in the modern era, and as such increased adoption of various digital tools is likely to only increase in organizations looking to gain an edge in an everchanging world. Connecting numbers to these assertions, a study performed by SnowSoftware indicates that approximately 73% of the IT Leaders contained within large corporations studied reported that they are now running anywhere from 100 to 1000 SaaS applications across their network, a steady increase over the last 12 months In addition, outside of staffing, IT managers expect to continue to direct a substantial amount of any additional budgets at the SaaS offerings their organizations require to remain functional, highlighting that an Increased Reliance on Software is here to stay: 

Thus, in summary, there is an evident opportunity for Monday to benefit from the increasing digitization of the workforce, the recognition of the importance of agility, as well as the undeniable velocity of software adoption.
