With these factors in mind, Monday estimates that their 2020 TAM was approximately $56.1B, a value that they anticipate to grow at a CAGR of 12% and reach approximately $87.6B. This estimate spans across Monday’s use-case markets, of which can be seen summarized below: 

  • Project Management ($4B)

  • Collaborative Applications ($21.7B)

  • Sales Force Productivity Management ($11.5B)

  • Software Change and Process Management ($4.6B)

  • Marketing Campaign Management ($14.3B)

The beauty of Monday’s software is their ability to serve many verticals. It is therefore not out of the realm of possibilities that the company can expand their reach into new avenues proportionally to time, especially since their software can spur value creation in organizations present within any industry.

Moving on, it is worth discussing the limitations to current software-based approaches, of which Monday aims to solve with their offerings. Starting off with Software Architecture, these constraints are in essence specifications that enable developers to formalize a set of rules that a piece of software should respect and be designed or manipulated in accordance to. Though important from a design perspective, a lot of project/task management software has been created in order to standardize a repetitive set of workflows, a phenomenon that restricts its ease-of-use as a result, forcing employees to adapt their work flows to match how said software solves problems. Also of note is a complexity tradeoff of sorts that individuals are often faced with, i.e. whether to utilize complex software to cater towards difficult tasks or to leverage a software with a high ease-of-use and fill in the gaps between functionality and desired output with additional tools. We have seen companies such as Palantir have enormous success in the software realm, offering developers tools that are able to connect unthinkable amounts of data and extract value from said data through an easy-to-use platform. Monday aims to have similar success, creating a point of truth that can be used to manage a variety enterprise complexities. 

Almost everyone that has operated within a large corporation understands how disjointed processes can be. Not only is there a separation between the structure and workflows of different departments, there also exists a disparity between the software solutions utilized therein as well. More specifically, software caters towards specific functions ranging from sales to engineering and research and development, and as such leads to the creation of siloes, a phenomenon that essentially represents the inability for cross-department work to occur, seeing as things like data, business intelligence processes etc. are not accessible by all:

As the digitization of processes continued, the stack of technology and the complexity contained therein is only getting growing larger, a phenomenon that is harming workplace communication in the process. New communication tools such as Slack, Zoom, or Facebook Workplace are common avenues where employees can interact, plan out projects etc., however, these platforms are often not where the employees get work done, creating a disparity between execution and collaboration. To represent this numerically, a study performed by Quantified Communications estimates that businesses with more than 100 employees spend more than 17 hours a week clarifying unclear messages, objectives and actions, representing a frequently occurring and costly set of mistakes [6].  As such, software that allows for both communication with team members and the completion of projects/processes therein is essential to the functionality of a healthy team.

Lastly, modern software solutions fail to cater towards the automation and integration requirements of the modern enterprise. Starting off with the former, software tools often lack the functionality needed to automate repetitive tasks that many face on a daily basis. Monday’s software aims to automate the boring stuff, allowing workers to focus on higher-level tasks that create more value for their company as a result. Moving on to the latter, modern software often requires code to connect the various point solutions or custom built applications that exist within a company. The technical aptitude required to interconnect these moving pieces creates additional siloes, forcing users to leverage software regardless of whether or not it is an optimal solution. Monday’s software aims to put no-code/low-code functionality in the hands of all, a prospect that should improve transparency, integration and openness across a company. 

With all of these factors in mind, we are now ready to break down Monday’s technology and get to the bottom of how they aim to be THE software of an enterprise.

3.0 Technology 

In order to understand the value proposition of Monday’s SaaS offering, we must be able to comprehend the different facets of what the company denotes as their Work OS. The Work OS, described simply, relies on an inherent modularity, of which leverages no-code and low-code functionality for individuals to build solutions. With these solutions in place, employees can then create solutions ranging from applications to project management tools, all on top of the aforementioned building blocks, but more on that later. The key components of the Work OS can be seen described in detail below. 

Boards: This aspect of the Work OS can be thought of the foundations of the Monday Platform, seeing as they are often where a lot of the product functionality is built on top of. More specifically, a board can be thought of as a schema-less database that allows users to organize tasks, campaigns, schedules and more, as outlined by the following:

A board will consist of two main components, Columns and Items. The former is relatively self-explanatory, representing data points ranging from work assignments, status and priority levels, file attachments and more. The latter can be thought of as a row on the board, and can represent essentially any task, deliverable etc., like a component of the Iteration 4 task outlined in the image above. Once the board has been completed, Monday offers a series of Views. This functionality allows for a board’s contents to be manipulated or displayed in a manner that suits their needs. For example, a Sales Pipeline board can be transformed into a Gantt Chart in order to gauge when certain milestones are occurring, as outlined below: 

Boards also have built-in support for Forms. More specifically, individuals can create a custom board, share a form with their end-users or clients, and receive the responses to said form that will then get entered into the board as new items. Use-cases evidently range from IT ticketing to inventory or order management. 

Monday prides themselves on their ability to automate a variety of processes involving their boards. This functionality is reliant on what the company calls “automation recipes”, which are essentially are pre-defined combinations of triggers and actions. Delving deeper, a trigger is essentially an event that the individual specifies will spur an action, whereas the action itself is what occurs as a result of said trigger. Users have the ability to access Monday’s Automation Center, of which consists of a series of prebuilt automations that can be applied to boards: 

The aforementioned goes hand in hand with what Monday denotes as Integrations. More specifically, integrations allow for boards created with the company’s software to connect directly to external tools, spurring exchanges of data and insights and reducing the prevalence of siloes within an organization as a result. Monday supports integrations with approximately 40 different tools ranging from Microsoft Teams to Excel and Slack. Integrations can also be tied directly into automations. Example use-cases include notifying a user and creating a new item within a board if a Stripe Payment is received, automatically scheduling zoom calls if an action-item is completed and more. 

Lastly, Monday is evidently focused on reducing the frictions associated with using their boards through the provision of Ready-Made Templates. This feature is essentially a set of boards that have been pre-created for a variety of use-cases and industries ranging from Marketing and Project Management to Manufacturing and Real Estate: 

We now understand the basic building blocks of Monday’s Software, i.e. Boards. Being that as it may, the company’s offerings do not stop there. Individuals can create Dashboards, of which help facilitate workflows and stay up to date with what is happening within a hypothetical multitude of boards. Creating a dashboard is straightforward. All an individual needs to do is add a dashboard from their Monday homepage, as outlined below, specify whether the dashboard is public or private, pick the boards that will be encompassed within and add pre-built widgets that display specific information from the boards within the dashboard. 

Widgets include the ability to uniquely display data contained within a board through various graphical displays, various timelines that allow for pm-related endeavors to be tracked etc., as outlined by the example dashboard below: 

Taking this one-step further, Monday also offers additional functionality to developers. More specifically, Monday supports the ability for developers to create custom dashboard widgets, board views, automations, applications and integrations for custom workflows using code, which can then be accessed by any team members, as described in the short video below: 

Individuals can also access applications that others have created via the app marketplace, with a select few of the hundreds of applications available within showcased by the following image:

Another notable feature of Monday’s Software are Workspaces. In essence, this feature is aimed at reducing the headaches and chaos that usually comes with managing tasks and workloads as team sizes grow. Workspaces provide accounts with a hierarchy of organization that allow boards, applications, dashboards etc. for different departments, teams or projects to all be managed from one central location: 

Monday also facilitates the use of their technology outside of the office through their Mobile Application, available for both android and iOS devices. Capabilities contained within range from viewing boards, checking timelines, accessing their work for the day through the My Work tab and more. This mobile offering is suitable for industries that require individuals to work in the field and communicate with other members of their team in the office, i.e. in construction or manufacturing. 

In addition, a recent and very important addition to the Monday ecosystem is Workdocs.  Put simply, this functionality can be thought of as a Google Docs of sorts, of which possesses heightened capabilities. The functionality of this part of the Monday Ecosystem can be split into three main components, Collaborate where multiple team members can co-edit and work in real time,  Connect which links a document to the a team’s to Monday’s project management tools, data visualization, widget and applications, as examples, and Execute which encompasses the ability for components of a document to be turned into action items that span across a variety of workflows. An example of each of these processes can be seen outlined below: 

In order to set in stone what we have learned above, let’s take a look at some key highlights from a case-study that details the benefits that the NHL reaped from utilizing Monday’s software, i.e. how the organization saved on average approximately 4-weeks for their development cycles. With many developers situated across the globe, the Senior Director of the organization detailed the fact that they were struggling keeping multiple teams across different time zones on track, of which lead to unwanted consequences ranging from unclear prioritization and organizational siloes to a lack of roadmap insight. Onboarding all teams involved with development onto Monday gave immediate visibility as to what everyone was working on, the urgency of different deadlines etc. 

After seeing the immediate benefits of using the platform with their development efforts, the Senior Director decided to use Monday for more. More specifically, they created custom built applications such as one that interacted with SurveyMonkey to store Stanley Cup Requests on a certain board, track where the Stanley Cup is currently at (i.e. a dynamic view of the schedule) and launch automated workflows accordingly, and even track customer engagement on various components of their website and social media presence through Monday dashboards, as outlined below: 

With all of this mind, it is clear that Monday’s software has an evident value proposition, as well as the ability to become an essential component of an enterprise’s work flows as it gets integrated with more and more processes with respect to time. Before moving on, it is relevant to discuss the development efforts Monday has put into creating their own Business Intelligence tool, of which they created from scratch and denote as “Big Brain”. This in-house tool is made accessible to every employee of the company and essentially aggregates the data collected by over 200M events per day, then allowing for insights to be drawn, KPIs and dashboards to be generated and data-oriented product improvements to be constantly made. This BI tool helps Monday improve their product in a manner that is both quick-to-market and high quality and will likely be a tool that helps the company continually prosper. To put things into perspective, the company bolstered, near the end of 2017, that they had over 1B stored events, as outlined below: 

The company now logs, on average, 1B events every 5 days, a feat that took them over 3 years to achieve in their infancy and successfully illustrates the rapid rate of acceleration the company has been able to foster. The company is executing well at scale and a continued focus on leveraging data to improve their product will only improve the usefulness of their ecosystem with time.

Now that we have an understanding of what Monday’s technology does, let’s delve into how exactly the company makes money from this SaaS. 

4.0 How Monday makes $$$

The manner in which Monday makes money from their platform is quite easy to digest. More specifically, the company offers five different subscription plans that businesses can partake in to get access to Monday’s Platform. These subscriptions exist in either a monthly or yearly variety (with yearly offering a 18% discount in comparison to its counterpart), and are priced on a per seat basis, dependent on the amount of features that the business would like to leverage. A high level overview of each subscription plan can be seen below: 

With these pricing tiers in mind, let’s take a look at the company’s recent earnings to gauge their overall financial health.

5.0 Financial Analysis

Within this section of the report I will delve into Monday’s most recent Income Statement, Balance Sheet update and Cash Flow Statement and make comments regarding the overall health of the information contained therein. 

Income Statement

Revenue 

Monday’s Revenue for Q3’21 came in at approximately $83M, representing a 94.9% increase on a YoY basis. The change in this value with respect to the previous quarters can be seen outlined below: 

This increase is attributable primarily by a strong expansion in the size of their customer base as well as improvements made to the amount of value the company is able to extract from their existing customers. We will discuss the specifics of certain intertwined KPIs in later sections but it is worth noting the company’s updated guidance for Full Year 2021 anticipates approximately $300-301M in Revenue, of which represents 86% YoY Growth and commendable strong Q4 performance. These projections demonstrate that the company’s strong trajectory isn’t going anywhere anytime soon and the fact that Monday is continuing to accelerate in an environment that has seen many pandemic beneficiaries flounder of late. 

Cost of Revenue

The change in Monday’s Cost of Revenue (COR) can be seen outlined by the following figure: 

COR for the quarter came in at approximately $10.2M, representing a 61.3% increase on a YoY basis. The above figure is testament to the cost-effective nature of Monday’s business. More specifically, looking at the change in Revenue from Q1’20 to Q3’21 this value has changed by 160% in comparison to the 122% increase in COR during the same time frame. With expenses controlled and the high-gross profit nature of the company in general, this phenomenon is likely to lead to nice bottom line health as the company continues to scale efficiently, as corroborated by the decrease in COR as a % of Total Revenue outlined below: 

Operating Expenses

The change in Monday’s Operating Expenses (OPEX) can be seen represented below: 

Coming in at approximately $102M for the quarter and increasing approximately 32.7% on a YoY basis, it is positive to see Total OPEX decelerate relative to the growth in Revenues. Being that as it may, as a % of Total Revenue OPEX is still very high, as outlined below: 

The change in Total OPEX was primarily driven by a 57% increase in R&D Expenses, 16.5% increase in S&M and 129% increase in G&A, coming in at ~$20M, ~$67M and ~$15M, respectively. Delving deeper and starting off with R&D, Revenue growth has outpaced this investment and has remained relatively consistent as a % of Total Revenue over the last few quarters, as outlined below: 

Realistically, the company should continue to invest into this area in order to develop new product features that serve as differentiating factors between itself and other enterprise management software. Moving on to S&M, this value remains the largest constituent of OPEX and is arguably the driving factor behind the company’s growth. Although there were evident YoY improvements as gauged by S&M as a % of Total Revenue, attributable to efficiencies in their abilities to scale marketing directed at companies and enterprises with more than 10 customers, there is still a long way to go in order to maintain growth with the hopes of eventually obtaining profitability. 

Lastly, G&A expenses increased very slightly YoY, increasing as a % of Total Revenue as well, attributable to the heightened costs that are associated with becoming a public company. 

Margins and Profitability

In order to gauge the company’s profitability, the change in their Gross Profit, Net Income and Operating Income can be seen outlined below: 

Gross Profit came in at approximately $73M for the quarter, increasing at a 101% rate on a YoY basis, a benefit of the company’s increased cost controls. Both Operating and Net Loss moved slightly closer to positive territory on a YoY basis, coming in at approximately $(29.2) and $(28.9)M respectively. The change in the company’s Gross, Operating and Net Margins can be seen outlined below: 

As the above figure illustrates, the company’s Gross Profit Margins are ridiculously high, even when compared against other high-flying SaaS counterparts, having consistently improved over the last few quarters coming in at approximately 88% for Q3. Both Net and Operating Margins improved slightly at approximately (35)%, however these values are indicative of profitability still being lengths away. In summary, the company’s strong top-line and high GP are definitely exciting, however expenses will continue to send the bottom line into negative territory as S&M continues to be a driving factor in the company’s growth. 

Balance Sheet

The structure of Monday’s Assets can be seen outlined below:

The company’s Assets are very liquid, consisting predominantly of Current Assets, of which are made up almost entirely by Cash and Cash Equivalents. Long Term Assets on the other hand consist mainly of Property and Equipment. The structure of Monday’s Liabilities on the other hand can be seen outlined below:

The company’s liabilities are mainly current, consisting primarily of Deferred Revenue, followed by Accrued Expenses and Accounts Payable. Long Term Liabilities consist of Other Liabilities and are essentially negligible. In summary, Monday is strapped with cash, a phenomenon that can be attributed to their recent IPO, of which is likely to assist with their expansionary efforts and operations support for the next few quarters without additional raises, at the very least.

Cash Flow Statement 

The company’s Cash from Operations, Financing and Investing can be seen outlined below:

CFO was approximately $3.8M, the first instance in the company’s history that they achieved a positive Operational Cash Flow, attributable primarily to Accrued Expenses, Deferred Revenue and SBC, offset by prepaid expenses, accounts payable, and accounts receivable. CFI came in at approximately $6.4M, attributable mainly to changes in Short Term Deposits, offset by Purchases of Property and Equipment. CFF was $(1.9)M attributable mainly to the receipt of a tax advance related to option exercises offset by the repayment of a revolving credit facility. The change in the company’s FCF and associated FCF margin can be seen outlined below:

Monday achieved their first instance of positive FCF this quarter at approximately $0.8M and an FCF margin of 0.96% , despite approximately $3M in CAPEX. Though not gargantuan, it is encouraging to see Monday step into positive FCF territory especially when judging all the growth plans management currently has underway.

6.0 Key Performance Indicators

Outside of traditional financial metrics evaluated earlier, it will be important to understand a few select Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) in order to gain further insight as to how Monday is performing. Starting off with Net Dollar Retention Rate, this metric allows for us to track the quotient of Current Period ARR to Previous Period ARR, which if greater than 100%, is indicative of an expansion in the amount of revenue attributable to Monday’s existing customer base. In other words, this metric highlights the company’s ability to generate more revenue from customers they already have. The change in this value over the last the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

Focusing on NDRR for clients with more than 10 users is important seeing as the company directs the bulk of their S&M at the acquisition of these clients. This value has evidently improved lately, coming in at 130% for Q3. NDRR is also improving when calculated for all customers, as highlighted below: 

Sticking with the theme of analyzing how efficient S&M efforts are at obtaining customers with more than $50,000 in ARR, Paid Customers that meet that criteria recorded in Q3 and in previous quarters can be seen outlined below: 

Increasing 231% on a YoY basis and coming in at 613 for Q3’21, these efforts are evidently reaping benefits, with the Net Adds (i.e. the difference between the number of paid customers meeting the aforementioned criteria in the current period and the previous period) displaying healthy upward trajectory as well: 

Before moving on, it is worth discussing the company’s marketing efficiencies. Many tout that Monday is very inefficient with their marketing spend, which to me, shows an evident inability on analysts’ parts to understand the company’s business model and be able to back up their assertions with numerical evidence. I believe Monday is efficient with their S&M despite this value being a large part of OPEX. Starting off, we can calculate the company’s approximate Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC) utilizing data that is present within their F-1 (this will be applicable to the Q1’21 period but should not have changed too drastically to Q3’21. I will provide updates on my twitter if more up to data is made available). The number of new customers added in Q1’21 can be seen outlined below: 

Using the above net-add, we can then divide total S&M spend in this quarter by the total number of customers added to get the average CAC, as outlined below:

Now that we have the CAC, we can now calculate the ARPC that can be expected for the entire year using Q1’21 data. This value can be calculated by dividing total revenue for the period by the Average Number of Customers ((Customers at Beginning of Q1’21 + Customers at End of Q1’21)/2) and multiplying this value by four to get its annual counterpart, as outlined below:

Using these values we can then calculate the payback period for obtaining a new customer, which is essentially the CAC divided by the Annual ARPC, as outlined below:

This Payback Period is in the middle of the pack of a multitude of SaaS counterparts and is very healthy given the company’s growth trajectory. With all of these metrics in mind it can be concluded that Monday is steadily increasing their customers, increasing the overall stickiness of their product and leveraging efficient S&M tactics (if Q1’21 efficiencies have been maintained) to make this growth all happen. 

7.0 Valuation

Before delving deeply into the competitive landscape and the main concerns I have with making an investment in this company, it is worth touching on where the company is valued relative to some of its publicly traded peers. Starting off with top-line growth, valuation of some enterprise management software on a EV/NTM basis relative to their 2020A-2023E Revenue CAGR can be seen outlined below: 

Out of all its enterprise management counterparts, MNDY does display the highest rate of projected Revenue Growth from 2020A-2023E, with a CAGR of approximately 55%. Despite that fact, the company is valued richly with a NTM EV/Revenue multiple of approximately 39. Being that as it may, ASAN and TEAM do have much higher valuation premiums despite bolstering slower growth during the same time frame. Looking at NTM EV/GP vs. 2020A-2023E CAGR (%), a similar story is painted, with MNDY’s NTM EV/GP multiple of approximately 39 : 

It is also worth noting Monday’s projected ability to achieve profitability on an EBIT basis. These values relative to its peers can be seen outlined below: 

With all of these factors considered it can be concluded that the company is displaying best-in class top-line growth over the course of the next few years, however, they are valued richly on both a NTM EV/GP and EV/Revenue basis with no sign of profitability in sight. As such, caution may be warranted given the market’s tendency of late to compress richly valued SaaS stocks despite their exciting growth prospects.

 8.0 Final Thoughts 

Before delving deeper into the main risks I am pondering with regards to MNDY, it is worth discussing the company’s expansion plans. As previously mentioned, the company extracts the majority of their Revenues from successful sales efforts directed at enterprise clients (i.e. clients with more than 10 users). The company was adamant in their most recent conference call that they intend to continue to hire more enterprise-class sales people, an endeavor that they hope will continue to fuel the growth trajectory they have been able to maintain as of right now. These plans can be corroborated when looking at revealera data, of which shows a continually high number of MNDY job openings, as outlined below: 

When one thinks about their efficient S&M spend and respectable payback period, the prospect of expansion and hiring more capable sales people is most definitely exciting. When considered alongside the company’s top-notch gross margins (in comparison to industry peers), the recent achievement of a positive FCF margin for the first time, and improving Operating Margins, growth is likely to continue to yield better outcomes. A comparison of Monday’s Metrics with publicly traded counterparts for their 7 most recent reporting periods can be seen outlined below: 

As you can see, when comparing the MNDY with its peers, GMs in the most recent quarter were second to only ASAN, with FCF and Operating Margins showing superiority to ASAN and SMAR. MSFT and TEAM are evidently far superior, but they also have a more dominant presence in the project/task management industry and in MSFT’s case are one of the largest companies in the world with amazing fundamentals. Although this doesn’t take into consideration private competition such as Trello, Airtable etc., MNDY is in a favorable fundamental position that will likely help them excel as they continue to penetrate into market. In addition, to gauge the company’s culture and CEO approval, we can compare each of these company’s GlassDoor Ratings. Although this is not a foolproof comparison due to the disparity in the number of reviews left for each company, it gives a general sense that MNDY benefits from top-notch culture and management as outlined by the measures below: 

Moving over to the negative side of the spectrum. The biggest concern I have with Monday, outside of the glaring risk in the company’s valuation, is their ability to penetrate a very saturated market. Delving deeper, if we take a look at data published by InvestiAnalyst on Twitter (check out the linked analysis if you want a detailed ASAN vs. MNDY comparison) the project/task manager space is evidently dominated by Jira and Microsoft Teams, as gauged by a survey of CIOs of large corporations below: 

According to this data, over 54% of CIOs surveyed were utilizing some form of Microsoft related-product with 34% utilizing Jira Work Management. Although these values are not entirely representative of the exact market share that each of these companies/technologies possesses, Microsoft and Jira are the clear leaders of this space, a phenomenon I believe will make it relatively difficult for smaller players to gain major market share at their expense. Reading a Not-Boring piece on Excel earlier this week, I believe the project/task management vendor software space can draw lessons from the historical lifespan of various spreadsheet software. Looking at the success of Excel, this software benefited enormously from the growth of Windows in general, becoming dominant in the late 90s as the OS gained popularity. 

After nearly 40 years, Excel is still a clear leader, an occurrence that isn’t rooted in the software’s best-in class features or bells and whistles, but rather, indicative of how Microsoft has taken the world by storm, cementing the Office Suite as the logical first step for almost all processes conducted within the modern workspace. Getting more applicable to our analysis, it makes sense that Teams was the most popular surveyed application given its proximity to other Suite Apps. As of June 2021, there are over 1B users of Microsoft Office Suite, a statistic that I believe points towards Teams continued success in the team management space. To play devil’s advocate, many will mention the recent release of Workdocs and how this could act further improve the stickiness of Monday’s platform, giving users more of a reason to conduct almost all of their processes directly within the platform. Though ambitious, I am hesitant to believe this will result in a tangible increase in Monday’s market share. As an example, Google Suite has over 6 million paying businesses that are reliant on its services/applications, a value that will unlikely experience meaningful churn as a result of customers preferring Monday’s work docs. Speaking more anecdotally now, in my own short professional experience, I have utilized multiple different software to manage my own and my team’s workflows, and switching from one to the other (i.e. from Smartsheets to Microsoft teams/planners) was relatively painless and did not leave a void in my day-to-day. This can obviously vary from one person but a little personal flavor doesn’t hurt here.  In short, I cannot get myself to pay such a high multiple for a SaaS company I feel is largely undifferentiated within their space, no matter how fast they are growing. 

9.0 Conclusion

In summary, Monday offers itself up as an interesting opportunity. With easy-to-use and functional technology, real-world use-cases that have helped major enterprises improve efficiencies and fast-paced growth, there is a lot to like. On the other hand, the company’s valuation and their place within a software niche I believe will be difficult to shakeup in a major way will make me stay way from Monday as a portfolio allocation. Regardless, this research offers a starting point for considering Monday as an investment and I hope that it was of use to you. Thank you for reading.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, comment below and share!

Share

If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

item.title: Marqeta Inc. ($MQ)
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to MT Capital Research! If you’re new, join a group of 2850 Informed Investors who receive weekly research reports on the World’s Most Interesting Tech Companies by subscribing below:

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an in-depth analysis on Marqeta Inc. Within I will discuss the key trends and tailwinds the company aims to benefit from within their operations and growth initiatives, break down the products they offer their clients and how said products function, as well as outline the manner in which the company makes money. In addition, I will discuss some key points from the company’s most recent earnings report and delve into what I feel are some important happenings, both positive developments and risk factors alike, to keep in mind when considering Marqeta as a potential portfolio allocation. The format of this research, as per usual, can be seen outlined below. Feel free to skip ahead to the sections that add the most value to your research 

1.0 Introduction

2.0 Opportunity 

3.0 Product Breakdown 

4.0 How Marqeta makes $$$ and Value Proposition

5.0 Financial Analysis

6.0 Key Performance Indicators

7.0 Valuation

8.0 Closing Thoughts

9.0 Conclusion

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitute for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investment.

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content follow my Twitter below: 

Follow Me

With all of that considered, let’s start delving deeper into Marqeta Inc.

1.0 Introduction 

Marqeta Inc., of which I will denote as MQ for the remainder of this report, in essence, has created and operates a modern card issuing platform, of which aims to provide a variety of different businesses the ability to create a unique and potentially innovative payment experience for both their customers and end users. The company’s cloud-based, open application programming interface (API) platform allows for card issuing and transaction processing services to be incorporated directly within or on the outskirts of the processes of developers, product managers and entrepreneurs.  The company’s value proposition is simple and easy to digest. More specifically, the company’s tech helps facilitate a variety of different use-cases within some of the most well-known corporations worldwide. These include the ability for modern card issuing to cater towards Doordash’s operations, i.e. enabling the transfer of money from the account of the app users to the driver purchasing the food; moving money from an Affirm or Klarna BNPL card directly to the merchant; or modern card issuing for Square’s Cash App, allowing for peer-to-peer transfers to be directly reflected on user debit cards.

Now that we have a general understanding of what MQ does and what they offer their clients, let’s take a look at some key opportunities that the company hopes to use to their advantage within their processes. 

2.0 Opportunity

According to a 2020 Nilson Report, of which detailed the sheer enormity of network transactions that occur worldwide, approximately 468 billion transactions for goods and services attributable to Global Network Cards occurred that year [2]. These network transactions are heavily reliant on a complex ecosystem, a statement that doesn’t sufficiently relay the sheer vastness of parties involved with each transaction. More specifically, a typical transaction has ties to Banks, both of the Issuing and Acquiring variety, Acquirer and Issuer Processors and card networks such as the prominent fintech rails, Mastercard and Visa. A helpful illustrative diagram of the anatomy of a transaction can be seen outlined below:

With the functionality of a transaction in mind, it is time we delve deeper into the disparity between the Acquirer and the Issuer sides of the transactions. Over the last decade, there has been noticeable innovation on the Acquirer side of the transaction, however, the same cannot be said about its counterpart. This phenomenon is corroborated when looking at the difference between the presence of acquiring banks and issuer processors, with 300+ acquiring banks existing in the United States but only 200 Issuer Processors present Globally. Issuer Processors, which are essentially entities that connect with networks and an issuing bank to provide a system of record, manage the issuance of cards, communicate with settlement entities and authorize transactions, have seen relatively lackluster amounts of innovation, traditionally existing as legacy operators. MQ aims to change this, simplifying and creating a democratized issuing process that extends its reach beyond the scope of physical card issuance into a realm that facilitates digital commerce, mobile wallets and cross-border transactions. We will delve into the technical specifics of these products in later sections, however, for now, we should focus on some key trends that the company aims to leverage within their operations. Each of these trends can be seen outlined in the image below and will be described in detail thereafter:

The Rise of Digital Payments has taken the world by storm and is likely to continue to expand in a proportional manner to that of its e-commerce counterpart. To put things into perspective, Retail Commerce Sales are expected to reach a staggering $6.4T by the end of 2026 with approximately 22% of Total Sales expected to be a result of e-commerce [4], as outlined below:

In addition, a 2020 study performed by Euromonitor anticipates that approximately 46% of Total Global Transaction Volume is likely to occur via an electronic payment medium, up from the 31% that was measured in 2017 [5].  These projections, though they may not come into fruition with to-the-decimal precision, are indicative of high velocity adoption of digital payments worldwide, a prospect that is likely to increase the Total Payment Volume that goes through MQ’s platform as a result. 

Moving on, payments are no longer disjointed from applications. More specifically, there has been an evident Convergence of Software and Payments of late, a prospect that is likely to continue. Put simply, our payment methods have now been intertwined in a seamless manner with many of the applications we use on a regular basis, whether it be with through ride sharing or digital marketplaces, as examples. Historically payments were split between those that were card-based or non-card based (i.e. alternative payments). Card Payments traditionally occurred at a point of sale with a customer paying for goods/services, whereas non-card payments were often used to facilitate bank transfers or cross-border interactions, as examples. In a world that is becoming ever-digitized and ever-complex, software companies are starting to partner with payment companies in order to ensure they are able to cater toward their end-users preferences, i.e. with card or alternative payments. A recent study performed by SafetyPay estimates that over three billion people worldwide do not have access to credit cards and two billion do not have access to bank accounts as well as the fact that 39% of e-commerce transactions occurring in 2020 happening via alternative digital payments [6]. As such, technology companies that are able to cater towards these use-cases are likely to thrive in the future.  

In 1988 Joseph Pine and James Gilmore first coined the “experience economy”, a term that refers to the need for companies or marketers to create memorable events for consumers, whereby said memory extends from an associated product or service [7]. Providing notable experiences are almost always associated with a pricing premium, a heuristic that is outlined well by the following image: 

The Growth of the Experience Economy is driven by the creation of memorable digital experiences, being that almost every aspect of our lives whether it be driving, getting groceries, interacting with banking services etc. is incorporated with these mediums. As such, Software Developers face a staggering amount of pressure to create compelling technology, a process that is made exponentially easier through the provision of open APIs. MQ enables the experience economy by giving developers the tools they need to embedded payments into their applications or products with negligible friction, a process that would’ve otherwise been reliant on a select group of legacy institutions able to provide similar services in the past. 

With the rise of the digitized processes, as well as a spread of technology into every facet of modern life, of which saw accelerated adoption as a result of the spread of the pandemic, individuals are becoming increasingly comfortable relying on technology companies for payment, banking and other financial services. Traditionally banks had a stronghold over the customer experience, seeing as they were the only institutions able to provide the services they did. Flash forward to today, open banking has become common, i.e. banks opening their services to third party channels and allowing customers to access services through alternative parties, as highlighted by the image below [9]: 

Last but not least, there has been a threefold happening that should be taken note of, i.e. The Rise of Globalization, the Gig Economy and Open Data. First off, the interconnectedness of our world and the need for commerce processes to cater towards various emerging markets and the complex tax and regulatory infrastructure has created a dire need for agile payment methods. Secondly, the Gig Economy is changing the manner in which work is being done. I have harped on this at lengths within my Upwork and Fiverr deep-dives, however, with a growing number of individuals engaging in gig work ranging from driving ubers to becoming personal shoppers, traditional bi-weekly payment methods are no longer suitable for these situations. Lastly, whether you like it or not, data is becoming the most valuable commodity in the world and is fundamentally altering archaic industries, enhancing the manner in which business analytics are conducted. Take Upstart for example, a company that leverages millions of data points to do away with the FICO score and underwrite a higher number of loans all while mitigating credit risk, data is useful to say the least. With all of these ramblings in mind, companies require a scalable and reliable platform that is able to meet the growing payment requirements of the modern business. 

To put a stamp on things, Nilson estimates that approximately $6.7T in transaction volume went through US issuers in 2020. With MQ having a TPV of approximately $60.1B in 2020, the company has less than 1% penetration into this total transaction opportunity as of right now, a proposition that they hope to capitalize on in the coming years. With these facts in mind, let’s move on to taking a look at MQ’s technology and the associated functionality of their products.

3.0 Technology 

The manner in which clients access the MQ platform can be simplified and represented by the following image: 

In essence a client whether it be a Doordash or Square of the world will leverage the capabilities of MQ’s platform, of which will interact with a series of issuing banks, card networks and card vendors in order to provide the client with a solution to their diverse payment requirements. Delving into the specifics, developers can access the technological capabilities through either various APIs or through webhooks, which are in essence a method of altering or augmenting an application with custom call-backs. These APIs and webhooks connect directly to the three main components of MQ’s platform, MQ Issuing, MQ Processing and Settlement and MQ Applications, all of which are intertwined with cloud-based infrastructure that aligns with modern dev-op requirements. In order to understand the true capabilities of the company’s technology, we will be delving into each of the three platform components below.

MQ Issuing

This component of MQ’s platform, in essence, is a multi-faceted approach to supporting card programs of multiple varieties. The company offers the ability to issue physical, virtual and tokenized cards as well as a series of different fulfillment services, of which can be seen summarized in the image below: 

Building and Testing Cards is made easy with MQ’s platform. Customers are able to create their card product, set up funding sources, cardholders and cards and then start simulating mock transactions within a sandbox of sorts to truly understand the functionality. Developers can then Configure Cards with open APIs, meaning that they can define the specific attributes of the cards they wish to issue. More specifically, it can be decided whether the cards will be compatible with ATM, point of sale or online use-cases as well as their various verification requirements, whether that be through physical presence, address or postal codes. Options are also given for single-use cards that terminate after the single transaction they are intended for or multi-use cards that expire at a pre-specified date. Clients also have a series of choices with regards to the customization of their cards. These include but are not limited to choosing a custom logo design, carrier, signature and graphics that help convey the desired messaging of the company’s brand. The components of physical cards can be chosen as well, i.e. whether or not they have a magnetic stripe, are NFC-compatible or Visa/MC chip-enabled. MQ cards are also easily integrated with digital wallets by way of tokenization. Tokenization is essentially where the company de-identifies sensitive cardholder data by converting it into strings of randomly generated numbers known as tokens. This process allows for mobile apps to be integrated with MQ endpoints in order to request, store and provide the ability to store MQ-issued cards in digital wallets ranging from Apple to Google Pay, an exciting prospect when one considers the sheer volume of users of this tech. The MQ platform also allows for the Management of Card Programs, functionality where devs can manage activation, physical card ordering and fulfillment, card suspension and lost/stolen card reporting and much more. All of these features are accessible through the MQ card management dashboard, of which is outlined below: 

Also of note is how MQ cards can be embedded within customer applications. Normally if a company desired to add this functionality to one of their products they would have had to go through the process of ensuring their tech was compliant to Payment Card Industry Data standards (PCI DSS), a set of guidelines that are in place to ensure that any companies handling payment information maintain a secure environment. With MQ, the company has created widgets that allow cardholders to activate cards and set PINs within web and mobile apps all while embedded sensitive data is kept PCI compliant, a unique value proposition to say the least. Lastly, MQ gives full capabilities to set up primary constituents of card functionality such as Primary Account Numbers, Personal Identification Numbers, CVC codes and more, allowing developers to validate their programs easily before launch. Once ready, cards can be Instantly Issued, attributable to the fact that MQ has a series of bank partnerships and direct integrations with Visa and Mastercard card networks.  

MQ Processing and Settlement

A general overview of the MQ’s processing related features, of which are applicable to payments made with the physical, virtual or tokenized cards they have issued can be seen outlined below: 

Processing transactions in a secure manner is made possible with MQ’s arsenal of technological capabilities. Secure Authentication for physical cards occurs through either a PIN or signature verification whereas digital card counterparts users are authenticated using either address verification, card verification values or 3D secure methods. Businesses and the developers contained therein then have the ability to approve transactions based upon pre-specified rules, all occurring in real time. More specifically, clients can specify rules such spending limits per merchant, amount per spend, frequency of spend, start and times of transitions and much more, providing a Customized Card Experience that the client is comfortable with from the beginning. An exemplary process can be seen outlined in the following image: 

Moving on, MQ’s cards and platform offers flexibility in funding the accounts associated with a card. Standard funding models requires the company to preload funds into an individual’s account and maintain sufficient balances for each cardholder’s transaction, a tedious process that requires one to be on top of ensuring no accounts or under or over funded. MQ simplifies this process through the provision of JIT (Just-in-Time) Funding, a process that funds an account in real time. Developers can configure an endpoint within their application that receives and responds to JIT funding requests and upon approval (i.e. based upon the aforementioned criteria) MQ will move funds from the client’s funding source into their customer’s account. MQ also supports complex transactions. More specifically, if users would like to engage in a dual-message transaction such as giving a server a tip after a meal has been paid for, MQ handles the receipt of clearing files from the associated payment network, processes the transaction and communicates that the transaction has been completed back to the payment network, i.e. Accurate Transaction Clearing. 

MQ supports an additional layer of functionality with processing payments through the intertwinement of said processing with Real-Time Notifications. MQ webhooks can be used to relay information to end-users depending on various processing events. Example use-cases include providing customers with a notification once their food delivery has been paid for saying that their order will arrive shortly or setting up notifications on product returns to ensure the client is able to apply credit back to an account in an expedient manner, to name a few. Lastly, MQ ensures their processes are data-analysis/cleaning friendly through the provision of Reconciliation Acceleration. Through a subset of JIT processes, i.e. if a customer is using Gateway JIT for card funding, developers can insert metadata into transactions, such as a booking ids to assist with the creation of transaction records. 

 MQ Applications 

Outside of the general functionality behind issuing cards and processing the payments made with these cards, customers can utilize a series of applications, all contained within the dashboard, to gain a series of insights surrounding all facets of the payment lifecycle. These applications can be seen listed below: 

Starting off with Developer Tools, MQ offers three main categories of tools that they can use to foster a productive payment ecosystem within their application. These include the Sandbox, the API explorer and the Community of which allow developers to prototype, gain technical insights on product capabilities and interact with engineers in a productive environment. Program Administration allows for clients to manage card program funds, monitor cardholder statistics and generate a variety of reports if desired. MQ ensures risk management is a priority and allows customers to tweak the rules of a decisioning engine, of which approves or declines transactions in real-time, providing a layer of Fraud Protection. In the event where transactions that go through need to be disputed or reviewed, MQ provides Case Management through a series of API endpoints that help clients submit and track chargebacks and then send push notifications to the overseer when updates have been received from the card network. Lastly, customers can leverage a series of Compliance and Reporting and Data Intelligence capabilities through the MQ dashboard of which allow individuals to monitor and review reports that are adherent to anti-money laundering and BSA regulations as well use data to gain insights regarding factors ranging from chargebacks to card activities using the transaction data associated with a card program. 

With all of this functionality in mind, we now understand the technological capabilities of MQ’s platform. Used by the developers of some of the largest companies in the world, spanning across Fintech to the Experience Economy, there is no doubt that what MQ has created is adored. In order to cement what we have discussed in this section, let’s take a look at how MQ was able to assist DoorDash with their unique payment needs, as an example. 

With DoorDash, restaurants are now able to expand their customer base, while the customers themselves are able to choose from a variety of local cuisines, all from one convenient application, simplifying the takeout process by orders of magnitude. These capabilities were made possible by MQ’s technology, of which allowed for DoorDash to pay restaurants at their POS, all while keeping a firm focus on fraud mitigation. Delving deeper, DoorDash required the quick issuance of “red cards”, of which allowed for their drivers to purchase customer’s food from restaurants in an expedient manner. The company also required a high level of control over each transaction, the ability to manage fraud using JIT transactions, and a reliable card issuance platform that could be used in fast-paced circumstances as DoorDash scaled across the nation. Not only was MQ able to help the company gain insight over transactions and leverage data to help restaurants learn more about their customer’s delivery preferences, but they were also able to cater towards the time-sensitive nature of purchases and deliveries made on the platform. 

It is quite evident that MQ’s dynamic technology platform helps fast-moving companies incorporate payments into their processes in a manner that would not be possible using legacy infrastructure. With these facts in mind, let’s jump over to how MQ makes money from all of this.

4.0 How MQ makes $$$ and Value Proposition

As outlined above MQ primarily derives revenue from two main sources, Interchange Fees and Processing Services. Starting with the former, the company generates the majority of their money from a usage-based model, of which essentially equates to Interchange fees being generated by card transaction volumes that go through their platform. In order to understand how MQ fits in within a traditional bank, the diagram below outlines a typical interchange transaction and the portion of the interchange fee that gets distributed to each party involved: 

Square in the above diagram represents the issuer (could’ve been DoorDash or Instacart for example but Square was chosen) and receives 80bps, V/MA i.e. the card networks receive 25bps, MQ receives 20bps and SuttonBank, i.e. the primary bank that MQ bank has entered into a prepaid card agreement with, receives approximately 3bps. This diagram, created by James Ho, does a good job of illustrating the different pieces of the pie that are required to conduct an MQ-involved transaction. Moving on, the company also generates revenue from, albeit a much smaller chunk of their total revenue, Processing Services of which include fees charged for processing services, fraud monitoring capabilities, tokenization services, and other “add-on” features, for the lack of a better term. 

With all of these facts considered, we can now delve into what I perceive MQ’s value proposition is to their customers. In essence, MQ offers companies the ability to create unique card programs all while avoiding the need for tedious interactions with a traditional bank. The archaic processes of old would typically see a company interacting with an institution, of which would act as both the card issuer and issuing bank. MQ’s technology on the other essentially dismantles this entire process, separating the creation of cards and the authentication required in order to create said cards, enabling companies to create complex card programs in an expedient manner. This dismantling can be seen outlined below: 

With all of these factors in mind, MQ offers exposure to some of the fastest growing fintech companies in the world by providing them services that are indispensable, but more on that later. Now that we better understand how MQ makes money, let’s take a look at their financials. 

5.0 Financial Analysis

Within this section we will delve into the Income Statement, Balance Sheet and Cash Flow Statement of MQ in order to derive a better sense of how the company is performing up to and including Q3’21 earnings. 

Income Statement

Revenue

MQ’s Total Net Revenue for Q3’21 came in at approximately $132M, representing an increase of 56% on a YoY basis. How this value has changed over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

Total Net Revenue consists of two primary constituents, Platform Services Revenue and Other Services Revenue. The former came in at $126M for the quarter with the latter being measured at $5M, representing a 55% and 90.77% change on a YoY basis, respectively. The distribution of Total Revenue to each of these sources can be seen outlined below: 

As is quite evident, Platform Services Revenue is the main manner in which MQ generates Revenue. Although Other Services Revenue has increased its contribution to Total Revenue, this increase has been a result of higher activity within MQ’s ecosystem and thus the proportional rise in card fulfillment services that has come with it. This value is unlikely to ever become more than 10% of the aforementioned total. Of additional note is how the constituents of Platform Services Revenue has changed. The change in percent distribution attributable to Net Interchange Fees and Processing/Other Fees (fees charged to customers if their payment volume falls below a threshold or if users use payment cards at teller machines) can be seen outlined below: 

Although Processing and Other Fees increased at 73% in comparison to the 51% increase in Net Interchange Fees, the proportion of Platform Services Revenue attributable to each source is likely to remain stagnant as the quarters go on, as the above figure demonstrates the steady-state nature of this distribution. 

Cost of Revenue

MQ’s Cost of Revenue (COR) was approximately $72M for Q3’21, increasing at a slower tape to that of its Total Net Revenue counterpart with the 48% YoY change. COR’s change over the course of the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

COR contains two main components, Card Network Fees and Issuing Bank Fees, followed by a smaller contribution from Other costs. The former is essentially a predetermined percentage of the company's Total Payment Volume (TPV) that they must direct at the Card Networks for as compensation for routed transactions. The latter on the other hand is compensation for the issuance of cards to customers and the sponsoring of card programs with card networks and similar to its counterparts are charged as a % of TPV. With these fees in mind, Card Network Fees increased 47% YoY and Issuing Bank Fees increased 29% and Other Costs increased 97%. The distribution by source of Total COR can be seen outlined below: 

Card Network Fees will remain the largest source of COR going forwards, specifically because of the way Issuing Bank Fees are structured. More specifically, MQ has an agreement with Sutton Bank based on volume tiers, which essentially equates to the fact that MQ will pay the bank less as processing volumes grow. Moving on, driving down Total COR as a % of Total Net Revenue will be imperative to MQ scaling efficiently. How this has changed over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

This value has shown improvements on a YoY basis and will be important to monitor going forwards to ensure MQ is maintaining their high Gross Profit profile and not sizing up at an unsustainable rate.

Operating Expenses

The change in MQ’s Total Operating Expenses can be seen outlined below: 

Total OPEX came in at approximately $105M for the quarter, increasing ~121%. This increase was due to the increase in the two primary constituents of this metric, i.e. Total Compensation Benefits and Other Operating Expenses, of which increased 112% and 155% respectively. Total Compensation Benefits includes things like salaries, bonuses and SBC and is likely to remain the largest component of OPEX going forwards, whereas Other Operating Expenses consists of things ranging from technology costs to marketing and advertising costs. The distribution of Total OPEX attributable to the two main constituents can be seen outlined below: 

As outlined above, Total Compensation Benefits have remained 70%+ of Total OPEX for a few quarters now. One should note that the proportion of Total Compensation Benefits attributable to SBC has been steadily creeping up as a result of the IPO and and fees related to stock options/RSUs but nonetheless should be monitored to ensure that it doesn’t elevate OPEX artificially in the coming quarters: 

Two additional notes should be made regarding OPEX. The first is the relative ease at which the company sustains operations with very little marketing spend. This can obviously be chalked up to Revenue Concentration, of which we will touch upon in the next section, however one can ponder whether organic marketing, i.e. the word of how MQ caters towards some of the most unique companies in the world, may spread and increase their customer base despite continually low marketing spend. 

Lastly, there is no doubt that Total OPEX as a % of Total Revenue is high, as outlined below. Although MQ deems this as a necessary evil given their expansionary plans and need to retain talent via SBC, it will need to be controlled in the future if the company ever aims to see profitability: 

Margins and Profitability

In order to gauge MQ’s profitability, the company’s Gross Profit, Operating and Net Income and Adjusted EBITDA and how these values have changed over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

Gross Profit came in at approximately $59M for Q3’21, a 67% increase YoY, increasing at a faster tape to Revenues as a result of good cost controls. Both Operating and Net Income came in at approximately $(46)M for the quarter, increasing as a result of the expansionary efforts reflected in the company’s OPEX. Adjusted EBITDA came in at $(5)M, displaying the company’s lack of profitability even with the effect of business expansion and non-recurring items taken out of consideration. The change in the company’s margins can be seen outlined below: 

Margins tell a similar tale to what was discussed above. Of note is the company’s steady Gross Margin profile in the high 30% - mid 40% range, coming in at 45% for Q3’21. Investors should watch to ensure GP stays strong while the bottom-line does not deteriorate in any meaningful manner. 

Balance Sheet 

The structure of MQ’s Asset Position can be seen outlined below: 

MQ’s assets are very liquid with Current Assets consisting predominantly of Cash and Cash Equivalents, followed by Marketable Securities. Long Term Assets on the other hand consist mainly of property and equipment and operating lease assets. The structure of MQ’s liabilities can be seen outlined below:

Current Liabilities are the main constituent of MQ’s Total Liabilities, consisting mainly of Accrued Expenses and Revenue Share Payable, which in essence is an agreement MQ makes to share a percentage of Interchange Fees with clients if they reach a certain volume threshold. Long Term Liabilities on the other hand consist mainly of Operating Lease Liabilities. In summary MQ has a tank of a balance sheet and is likely to be able to support growth initiatives in the coming quarters with ease, at the very least. 

Cash Flow Statement 

 For the sake of gauging where MQ is at with respect to their Cash Flows, the change in the company’s Cash from Operations, Investing and Financing can be seen outlined below: 

MQ’s CFO came in at approximately $(4.5)M for the quarter, entering into a negative territory as a result of the company’s Net Loss and Network Incentive Receivables, offset primarily by SBC and accrued expenses/liabilities. CFI came in at approximately $(305)M as a result of the company’s purchase of marketable securities, of which was offset primarily by maturities of marketable securities. CFF was ~$(9)M for Q3 as a result of the repurchase of common stock. The change in MQ’s FCF and associated FCF margin can be seen outlined below: 

MQ’s FCF came in at approximately $(5.6)M for the quarter, a 142% decrease YoY, with FCF margin measured at approximately (4)% as a result. FCF is not something to be worried about given the company’s cash position going forwards and their reasonable capex requirements. Overall FCF does not appear to be a source of hindrance at the moment. 

6.0 Key Performance Indicators 

In order to gain some additional insights as to how MQ is performing it is imperative we look at a few metrics that can be deemed the company’s Key Performance Indicators. Starting off with TPV, this value is evidently important as it gauges the amount of activity the company has going through their platform. Increasing 59.8% and coming at approximately $27.6B, the company is evidently seeing sustained growth in their ecosystem, as outlined below: 

The next thing to monitor is the company’s take rate. As outlined earlier, the company can usually expect a 20bps take rate (i.e. amount of TPV they can convert to revenue via interchange fees). When looking at the 9-month value for Take Rate, it slightly improved, as outlined below, as a result of Sutton Bank lowering Interchange Fees as a result of MQ hitting a certain volume tier. 

Of additional note is the company’s Revenue Concentration. Though heavily touched upon by analysts at the moment, it is important for new investors to understand that a lot of the company’s Revenue is attributable to Square. Although the company is aware of this, it is worth monitoring to determine whether or not MQ’s relationships with other big firms are mitigating said risk, i.e. if a non-Square entity is starting to generate meaningful value for MQ. The change over the last few quarters can be seen below: 

Also of importance is MQ’s Processing Concentration. More specifically, MQ settles a large portion of funds directed through their ecosystem through Sutton Bank, as displayed by the figure below: 

Outside of the health of the Fintech industry in general, Revenue and Processing Concentration are evidently MQ’s two biggest tail risks and as such should be monitored to ensure that crucial partnerships do not deteriorate. 

7.0 Valuation

Before I make final comments on the company, it is worth touching where MQ’s valuation is with respect to its peers. In my opinion, since MQ is in stages of infancy, I believe we can gain the most insight when we compare the NTM EV/Rev multiples vs. 2020A-2023E Revenue CAGR for some popular fintech companies, of which can be seen outlined below: 

Out of all the companies compared, MQ bolsters a reasonable but still relatively high NTM EV/Revenue Multiple (at the time of writing) while also showing middle of the pack 2020A-2023E Revenue Growth at approximately 44%. It is also worth noting the ability for these companies to generate profits on an EBIT level. Thus, a comparison of 2020A-2023E projections can be seen outlined below: 

With these two points of comparisons in mind, one can draw the conclusion that MQ is valued relatively richly relative to their projected top-line growth amongst their peers and that profitability on the EBIT level doesn’t appear to be in site within the next few years unlike the majority of its counterparts. 

7.0 Closing Thoughts 

The best way to think of an investment in MQ, in my opinion, is as a call option on Modern Fintech. First and foremost and as I have stated earlier, the company is in its infancy of catering towards some extremely large enterprises. With expansionary efforts underway, of which are corroborated when looking at the steady increase in MQ job openings displayed by revealera data, it is exciting to think of the improvements the company can continue to make on the issuing side of the payment ecosystem with a strengthened workforce: 

Getting down to the details, we can now look at the services that MQ powers and the exposure to the many behemoths that an allocation to this company gets you. Starting off with the BNPL space, there has been undeniable growth in this area of late. Whether a product of a low-interest rate environment or not, these alternative payment methods do not appear to be going anywhere anytime soon. For reference, the number of BNPL downloads, as measured on a quarterly basis, can be seen outlined below: 

Marqeta has relationships with the biggest BNPL companies in the world having partnered and worked with Klarna, Afterpay (in the Australia and New Zealand markets), Affirm, Sezzle and Zip, providing each of these companies with unique and dynamic card-issuing services to cater towards their customer’s needs. To get a little more speculative, I am excited about MQ’s relationship with Affirm, especially when looking at the rocket-fueled trajectory the company has been on of late. In a recent conference call, MQ confirmed that they were partnering with Affirm on their Debit+ effort, as seen quote from Jason Gardner, CEO of MQ, from their most recent CC quote below [14]: 

“Yeah, I can confirm that we are powering Affirm's Debit+ card. I can't comment any more beyond that until it's in market, but Affirm has been a great partner of Marqeta for many years, and continuing that partnership with the Debit+ card.”

The debit+ will be the first debit card available in the US that has BNPL services tied directly to it, functionality that would not have been possible without MQ’s tech. Getting more speculative here, Affirm’s partnerships with the biggest merchants in the world, specifically Amazon may help MQ reduce their Revenue Concentration risk going forwards and offer a serious long term value proposition. More specifically, Amazon announced yesterday that they will stop accepting visa credit cards that have been issued in the UK. If this action, for whatever reason, were to replicate itself in the US, there would be an obvious opportunity for Affirm to fill a very real void in this space, allowing for MQ, by association to issue cards to fill said void. Regardless of whether or not this happens, MQ is acting as a fundamental layer within the BNPL space that cannot be dispensed with. Therefore if you are bullish on BNPL, I would say you are bullish MQ by association. 

Card applications don’t stop there. We already understand how MQ can help fuel the processes of Experience Economy companies, so now let’s take a look at another red-hot industry, cryptocurrency. Digging into the technological applications, MQ’s instant issuance system allows for card programs to be deployed directly into digital wallets with its network integration, direct deposit and ACH functionality, helping foster cryptocurrency-centered digital banking experiences. As of today, MQ has allowed companies such as Coinbase, Bakkt and Shakepay roll out visa debit cards that allow for customers to spend crypto at point of sale. Delving deeper, Coinbase has been gaining noticeable steam and is catching up to Cash App, on a user satisfaction basis in the United States, as outlined below: 

When looking at Cardify’s recent cryptocurrency report, of which outlines cryptocurrency deposits as a % of Total Retail Investment Deposits, it is quite clear that the adoption of cryptocurrency is very real, at least on the Retail side of things: 

With these factors in mind, I consider MQ’s ability to cater towards the modern crypto enterprise and the spending habits of the customers contained therein a hedge of sorts against MQ’s Revenue Concentration risk, seeing as it is not out of the realm of possibilities that de-fi continues to sink its teeth into modern payments, increasing the rate at which Coinbase (as an example) users would like to pay for goods and services using crypto, and thus requiring MQ tech as a result.

Lastly, before concluding this research I feel obligated to discuss the biggest source of potential headwinds for both MQ and Modern Fintech in general, the Durbin Amendment.

To spare you a law-induced nap, the Durbin Amendment, of which is part of the 2010 Dodd-Frank Law, is in essence a piece of regulation that lowers the interchange fees that merchants are obligated to pay banks when a purchase is made using a debit card. However, like many regulations, there exists a loophole around said amendment, of which has beenexploited by Fintech companies in full. More specifically, the Durbin Amendment exempts financial institutions with less than $10B in Assets. What this equates to can be best described in basis points, with Durbin-exempt banks being able to charge 80-105bps + $0.15-$0.20 as a transaction fee whereas Banks with more than $10B in assets are restricted to charging 21cents + 5bps per transaction. This loophole resulted in something astonishing, Fintech companies were able to cater towards the payment requirements of areas such as SMBs by partnering with Durbin-exempt banks, extracting more value from these niches than big banks could hope to. MQ is no different, seeing as they only contract Issuing Banks that are exempt, in order to maximize their interchange fees. Say what you want about the US government, but they aren’t one to let businesses get away with a free lunch so to speak for very long. Regardless, it is worth noting that this loophole could close at any time, and both MQ and its clients/counterparts Interchange Fees could be materially affected.

9.0 Conclusion

In summary, MQ represents an opportunity to get exposure to all avenues of fast-moving Modern Fintech ranging from BNPL to Crypto as well as to members of the Experience Economy, ranging from DoorDash to Instacart. This company provides an indispensable service within each of these ecosystems and as such should be a consideration if you are a fan modern card issuing solutions in any capacity. Though not without its risks, the company’s valuation as well as potential regulation surrounding the Durbin Amendment are all headwinds the company will have to navigate with top notch execution. Regardless, MQ is an enticing story and definitely worth having on your watch list. Thank you for reading my research.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, comment below and share!

Share

If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

item.title: Matterport Inc. ($MTTR)
item.description: Building Virtual Cities One Brick at a Time
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to MT Capital Research! If you’re new, join a group of 2725 Informed Investors who receive weekly research reports on the World’s Most Interesting Tech Companies by subscribing below:

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an in-depth analysis on Matterport Inc. Within I will discuss key trends, both technological and otherwise, that the company aims to leverage within their operations, break down their product suite and its associated functionality, as well as outline the manner in which the company extracts Revenue from their Clients. In addition, I will perform a financial analysis on the company’s most recent Q3’21 Earnings as well discuss some key positive developments and risk factors that I believe both current and potential investors should be wary of when considering Matterport as an investment. The format of my research, as per usual, can be seen outlined below, please feel free to skip ahead to the sections that you feel are most important:

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Opportunity and Value Proposition

3.0 Connection to VR

4.0 Technology Breakdown

5.0 How Matterport makes $$$

6.0 Financial Analysis

7.0 Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)

8.0 Valuation 

9.0 Final Thoughts

10.0 Conclusion

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitute for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investment.

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content and analysis, give me a follow on Twitter: 

Follow Me!

With all of that out of the way, let’s get started.

1.0 Introduction

Matterport Inc., of which I will denote as Matterport for the remainder of this report, can be most easily described as a company that is focused on digitizing and indexing the “built world”.  The company offers clients the ability to create Matterport Digital Twins, of which are 3D representations of an area or building that can be edited, tweaked, represented and captured within their product suite; Matterport Capture, an application that supports the use of 3D, 360 degree and iPhone Cameras in order to capture the depth, imagery and other data points associated with a space; Matterport Workshop, an application that allows additional details and features to be added to spaces; Matterport VR, i.e. the functionality that allows for customers to experience VR in conjunction with models and Matterport Showcase, an application available for audiences to explore and view spaces in their completed formats. 

Now that we have a better understanding of what the company does and what they offer customers, let’s take a look at some trends and opportunities the company aims to benefit from within their growth strategies and overall operations. 

2.0 Opportunity and Value Proposition

Oftentimes, looking at what the companies deem is their Total Addressable or Total Serviceable Market is exaggerated to say the least. Matterport’s classification of their opportunity is no different, however, it is useful to gloss over in order to understand the vastness of the use-cases that their technology can be applied to, as well as where their industry is with respect to complete digitization. Before delving into the specifics, we must first become familiar with what Matterport deems as a “Space”.
