This term, in essence, represents a room, an entire building, or an area contained therein that has been captured by one continuous scan and is then reconstructed digitally, using captured imagery and spatial data [2]. A Managed Space would then be a Space, as described above, that has been scanned and managed on Matterport’s platform.  As such, the company could theoretically manage an amount of spaces that greatly exceeds the number of buildings situated within their Total Addressable Market. With these definitions in mind, the company estimates, as of March 2021, that their Total Serviceable Market is approximately 1.3B spaces worldwide. With the company having a sub 5% penetration in this area at the moment, i.e. having only converted 5% of available spaces into managed ones, there is evidently room for improvement as the company expands their reach outside of the real estate, travel and hospitality sectors into other end markets that include retail, insurance and repair, facility management and more.  Moving on to the Total Addressable Market, the company estimates that with approximately 4 billion buildings and 20 billion associated spaces situated across the globe, resulting in an approximately $240B Market Opportunity. Although the company is evidently amidst stages of infancy, they lack no ambition in extracting as much value as they can from their Target Market.

Besides the glaring opportunity to increase the rate of digital adoption in archaic industries such as Real Estate and Insurance Claim Analysis (more on how Matterport enables this in later sections) I believe the company’s technology intersects very well with the activity we have within and surrounding the “Metaverse” of late. The Metaverse, a term that has roots within Science Fiction, can be most easily defined as a version of the internet that is, in essence, a manifestation of actual reality. This construct, which many shrugged off years ago is starting to gain traction, particularly with Facebook’s recent name change to “Meta” and Microsoft’s announcement of their intent to facilitate metaverse interactions within the Microsoft Cloud and Microsoft Teams ecosystems, cementing the fact that some of the world’s biggest corporations are taking these developments seriously.

The Metaverse, and its ability to exist as a fully synchronous experience and functioning economy is powerful to say the least. One can imagine a organic universe that can be tapped into if desired, of which contains digital items, assets, environments and ecosystems ripe for the taking. Matterport and its ability to transform the physical into the digital, turning bricks into bits, will be able to aid in the creation of this vision, a proposition that is likely to result in an enormous opportunity for value creation. This is more than mere speculation, especially considering that Matterport has already partnered with Facebook in the past, working with Facebook AI to combine their spatial data sets with the training of embodied agents. With best-in-class technology, Matterport is likely to assist some of the world’s largest companies with the creation of digital spaces in an unparalleled manner. 

Matterport isn’t just able to facilitate to the creation of an increasingly complex digital world, it is also leverages a series of partnerships to maximize their opportunity to cater towards almost every stage of a physical property’s lifecycle. These stages can be seen outlined in the image below. For the sake of clarity, I broke down an example partnership in each of these avenues to illustrate the wide net of capabilities the company possesses as well as the many streams of organic growth opportunities they’re exposing themselves to.

Design: Matterport has partnered with Autodesk in order to integrate with BIM 360, a prospect that will allow teams integrated with the Autodesk ecosystem to access digital twins of their job sites, further enhancing their design capabilities as a result [5]. 

Build: Procore, one of the most used construction software in the world, offers customers a single point of truth to manage construction drawings and associated documentation. Matterport integrates with the Procore dashboard, facilitating streamlined RFIs and digital property walk-throughs and demonstrations as a result [6].  

Promote: Businesses/Developers are able to publish a 3D virtual walkthrough of their property on Google Street View by publishing their Matterport spaces on the platform. In addition, Zillow has partnered with Matterport to allow customers to create a 3D home tour when listing their property through their service [7]. 

Insure: Matterport has partnered with Verisk, an Insurance Software provider that, with matterport integration, allows for 3D diagrams of loss sites to be created, eliminating the need for property professionals to manually sketch these diagrams to assist the claims process [8].

Repair: In connection with Guidewire’s Donan Add-on for ClaimCenter, Matterport 3D Scans can be directly access from claim files, allowing for insures to automate product liability decisions, reducing the need for field inspections to occur and allowing for repair processes to be expedited accordingly. 

With all of these factors in mind, Matterport has no issue catering towards Retail, Real Estate, Travel, Construction, Corporate, Industrial, Commercial and Hospitality End Markets, leveraging the aforementioned partnerships to capture as much of their opportunity as possible. In summary, with the staggering amount of spaces that exist worldwide, the bolstering pace of technological immersion as well as Matterport’s multi-faceted use-cases, the company is evidently setting itself up for success. Now that we have a better understanding of what Matterport estimates their TSM and TAM to be, how they may fit in within fast-paced Metaverse activity, and the variety of use-cases they can cater towards, let’s now take a look at what products and services the company offers their customers. 

3.0 Connection to VR 

Although the opportunities outlined above, particularly within the Metaverse may appear to be ambitious, the activity Matterport has produced within the VR realm is far from speculative and is most definitely worth noting. Matterport was founded in 2011, a time when VR had not picked up too much steam. Despite that fact, the company was still dedicated to enabling the 3D capture of the physical world in a manner that had never been done before. Two years into their campaign to greatly increase the ease at which 3D captures of spaces could occur (in comparison to the traditional process of legacy systems that were monotonous to say the least), Oculus, a company that would later be acquired by Facebook and gain notable notoriety across the tech world, released their first laptop-connected virtual reality headset, as outlined below:

Matterport, busy with their own ambitions, noticed immediately and decided to get a devkit shortly after the release of the original Oculus. According to Matt Bell, the co-founder of Matterport, this occurrence resulted in an unexpected synergy between their technologies. Matterport had been working to create a technology that would capture the physical world and represent it digitally whereas Oculus had created a technology that allowed for these digital worlds to be viewed in 3D, acting as a teleporter of sorts to the digital realm [10]. For the sake of illustration, an excerpt of the first demo Matterport created custom-made for VR viewing can be seen outlined below:

Flash forward a few months and Matterport continued to launch efforts at capturing the VR opportunity, creating their own dedicated team to find an end-to-end process for Matterport digital twins to be seamlessly tailored to VR. This effort was successful, with Matterport designing the ability to turn 3D content into VR content, with the company providing users with free access to these capabilities in between 2016-2017 to encourage adoption. Today, accessing VR capabilities through the Matterport platform has never been easier, with the ability for spaces to be viewed directly through Oculus Web Browsers, as outlined below:

There has been tremendous excitement surrounding the VR space of late and for good reason with both the Annual Unit Sales and Cumulative Installed Base projected to grow steadily up until 2024, as outlined below: 

Regardless of what you may think about VR, this technology has real-world use-cases that are just starting to come into fruition within multiple industries and adoption is unlikely to slow down in the coming years. When combining Matterport’s digital twins with the ability to view them in a completely immersive manner, the company is directing efforts at building a Google for the physical world, or in other words the capabilities for one to search and explore almost any physical location across the Globe seamlessly. It is exciting to say the least.

4.0 Technology Breakdown

Put simply, Matterport and their associated technology platform allows for spatial data to be collected from a variety of capture devices in order to take a building that exists in the physical realm and transform it into a digital entity. By creating a navigable, dimensionally accurate and photorealistic digital twin, Matterport subscribers are then able to extract information and insights that were previously unavailable through traditional mediums. The company’s platform is spurred by two main driving factors, of which can be seen outlined by the image below: 

The first, and arguably the most important factor that one must be aware of when considering Matterport’s platform is their ability to bring buildings that were offline, online. When one thinks about the Real Estate industry in general, visions of blinding technological innovation do not usually come to mind. More specifically, the manner in which some RE operations are usually conducted are archaic to say the least. Before Matterport, if a customer desired to assess their building or space, they would have had to either conduct an in-person site visit, or rely on some form of CAD software that usually leaves much to be desired in terms of the accuracy of the space. With Matterport’s platform on the other hand things have changed, scrapping the need for site visits or for floor plans or photographs to be used to extract insights. The process of digital incorporation starts simply, with customers scanning their space with different technologies, ranging from LiDar to 3D and 360 degree cameras to smartphones. Each form of technology Matterport allows spaces to be scanned within can be seen outlined in further detail below.

Matterport Pro2: The Matterport Pro 2, of which can be seen outlined below, is the company’s proprietary 3-D camera that allows for buildings up to 500,000 SF (square feet) in size to be scanned with a high degree of precision. 

360 cameras: Despite having designed their own hardware, as described above, the company supports almost all 360 degree cameras available on the market today. These options are more inexpensive than their counterpart, allowing for buildings of a smaller scale to be mapped digitally with ease. 

LEICA BLK360: Matterport supports the use of this Lidar device and is able to leverage their platform’s AI capabilities in conjunction with these devices in order to construct digital twins with an extremely high degree of accuracy. This option is ideal for Architectural Professionals that require an extremely accurate digital twin.

Smartphone Capture: Lastly, through Matterport’s mobile application, the company facilitates the creation of digital twins utilizing the capture capabilities of either iPhone or Android Devices.

Once the space has been captured by any of the above devices, the spatial data is then incorporated into Matterport’s expansive data library, cementing their true existence as a data company. To date, the company has captured over 10 billion+ SF (Square Feet) of space, amounting to more than 3 billion unique data points. These data points are then utilized to create amazingly accurate 3D twins, of which exhibit vibrance, dimensional accuracy and the characteristics of the area that would not be visible within a CAD drawing or a photograph. Transforming data into a digital twin is made possible by Matterport Cortex. This AI-powered engine takes in data, of which consists of information regarding geometries, fixtures and conditions etc. and applies Spatial Indexing to different points in order to create the space. More specifically, this process consists of deep-learning, dynamic 3D reconstruction, computer vision and advanced image processing in order to acquire the necessary amount of detail needed for the 3D Twin.  Starting off with Deep Learning, Matterport leverages their neural network data architecture in order to compare each 3D model against the millions of datapoints provided by aggregated information obtained from various buildings, spaces and comments from the thousands of subscribers leveraging Matterport’s platform. These capabilities allow for building configurations and environments to be created with notable consistency. Dynamic 3D reconstruction is the process by where 2D visuals and static images are transformed into a 3D representation of the space. More specifically, real-time spatial alignment algorithms work alongside the company’s deep learning processes reliant on millions of data points to create a previews of the model in progress, all in real time. Cortex also relies upon computer vision, which in essence leverages a series of features to enhance the value of different digital twins. Features include adding measurements to different objects or components of a room, the creation of custom videos and walkthroughs as well as object and face recognition.

Lastly, the company has a series of photography algorithms that ensure the digital twin is not just a computerized model, but is of professional grade quality. These algorithms include dynamic tone mapping, saturation adjustments and more, all allowing for high quality 3D image capture to occur with the press of a button. With all of this functionality in mind, it is evident that these proprietary solutions offer an interesting value proposition to Matterport’s clients, of which would be difficult to replicate via an in-house development effort. Similar to other AI/ML centered companies, the bigger Matterport’s dataset gets, the better their technology is likely to become and the more enticing it becomes for both customers and developers to leverage Matterport’s services and product suite. With all of these factors in mind, we now understand the Matterport Capture offering and the technology behind it. Once an individual creates their digital twin, they are then able to edit, customize, add additional details to and share their space, using Matterport Workshop.  Additional features contained within the workshop include the ability to create a highlight reel of the space, add Mattertags which are essentially labels that convey additional information, label rooms print 4K quality photos of different areas and more.

Matterport then gears two offerings at individuals that are aimed at viewing the digital twins they have created. The first is the Matterport Showcase App, of which allows for the individual and a chosen audience to view the space in its final format. This functionality allows for the space to be explored in walkthrough mode, dollhouse view or floor plan mode, can be sent via email, text or viewed through social media, and can be leveraged to explore created spaces offline, if desired. 

In addition, the showcase app supports the ability for individuals to experience the digital twin in virtual reality. Customers can download Matterport VR, pair with either a Cardboard or Oculus VR device, launch the showcase application through Web Virtual Reality functionality, then walk through and experience the space as if one were actually there. When considering the commonality of in-person site visits, the ability to convey this visuospatial information via VR mediums is powerful and may fundamentally alter the manner in which information regarding spaces is shared in the near future.

Moving on, Matterport distinguishes itself as more than just a technology company, creating an ecosystem centered around their products. Firstly, Matterport provides access to both Software Development Kits (SDKs) and Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) to developers, thus making it possible for engineers to build applications, experiences and workflows using Matterport functionality. In addition, the company has made a third-party software marketplace containing Matterport software add-ons available to their clients.

This marketplace includes the likes of WP Matterport Shortcode, a Wordpress plugin that allows Matteport digital twins to be shown on a website, TruePlan for Xactimate, an add-on that reduces the need for manual sketching measurements/loss calculations and Rela, a marketing solution for listings, as examples. When viewed alongside Matteport’s immense technological capabilities, the ability to integrate the tech with custom-built solutions and additional features, this evidently increases product stickiness as a whole. 

Now that we have a better understanding of how exactly Matterport’s technology functions, the additional features they offer clients and the ecosystem they have continuously foster, let’s take a look at how exactly they make money from it. 

5.0 How Matterport makes $$$

Matterport fuels their business through four main revenue sources, each of which can be seen outlined below by the following image: 

Starting off with Subscription Revenue, the company derives the bulk of their revenue from this source. More specifically, Matterport gears subscriptions at use-cases involving either a single user looking to create digital twins for a few spaces using their iPhone, to a business that would like to do much more with Matterport technology. The pricing, capabilities, amount of users and the number of active spaces (spaces that can be edited, shared and published at a given time) and some key features of each of Matterport’s standard subscription plans, the Free, Starter, Professional and Business plans respectively, can be seen outlined by the images below: 

Matterport’s business model also possesses inherent flexibility, allowing for the company to tailor custom subscription structures to large enterprises if the aforementioned are not satisfactory.  Moving on, Matterport makes money through the offering of data license solutions to their customers. In essence, License Revenue is revenue generated from customers that wish to leverage the vast array of digital twin data they have within their possession. Although this revenue source is not substantial at the moment, one can ponder the opportunities that may be over the horizon if metaverse-oriented companies wish to add virtual space datapoints into their processes. 

Denoted as Product Revenue, Matterport earns money by charging customers for their capture technology that obtains the data necessary to transform images into digital twins. The company primarily derives value in this area through the sale of their Pro2 camera, of which retails for the price of $2,795 (at the time of writing) [19]. In addition, in order to provide optionality to their customers, Matterport sells capture devices manufactured by third parties, marking up the cost of these items accordingly before their sale. Product Revenue is the second largest constituent of Total Revenue following its Subscription Revenue counterpart and is likely to continue to act as a customer acquisition tool of sorts. More specifically, if one is seeking out a capture device, becoming acquainted with the Matterport platform and subscription service as a result is the logical next step.

Lastly, the company also earns money through the provision of professional services. Although Matterport’s capture technology and associated ecosystem is straightforward and relatively easy to become accustomed to, some customers, particularly if they are working on a larger project, may require assistance from Matterport. Encompassed within Services Revenue, the company charges clients for scheduling and performing a professional scan of their property. This process is expedient, with a 72-hour gold standard being set for when the customer will receive their finalized 3D digital twin after the scheduled appointment has been completed.

In summary, Matterport amalgamates a variety of different revenue sources in order to create a full experiential solution centered around their technology. More specifically, the company is able to generate recurring revenue through their subscriptions and data licensing, and one-time revenue from the sale of their hardware and services. The combination of the aforementioned creates a relatively diverse business model with an interesting value proposition.  

Now that we know how Matterport makes money, let’s take a look at their financials and make some insights regarding the overall health and functionality of their business accordingly. 

6.0 Financial Analysis 

Within this section we will be taking a look at the company’s Income Statement, Balance Sheet and Cash Flow Statements up to and including their most recent earnings release for Q3’21. Let’s delve deeper now shall we. 

Income Statement

Revenue

Matterport’s Revenue for Q3’21 came in at approximately $27.7M, an increase of 10.29%  on a YoY basis. The change in this value with respect to the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

This value can be split into four primary constituents, i.e. Revenue attributable to Subscriptions, Licensing, Services and Products. The change in the distribution of Total Revenues attributable to each of these components can be seen outlined below: 

As is to be expected, Matterport derives the majority of their Revenue from Subscriptions, followed closely behind by Product Revenue, with approximately 57% of Total Revenue attributable to the former and ~31% to the latter. With the relatively one-off nature of hardware sales in mind, it is evident that Subscription Revenue will be an important part of Matterport’s growth going forwards. With these values increasing 36.12% on a YoY basis in comparison to the 4.28% increase in Product Revenue, it is quite evident that the company is executing on this growth plan well and will likely continue to reap the benefits of heightened recurring revenues going forwards. It is also worth noting the behavior of the two less noticeable Revenue sources, License Revenue and Services Revenue and how these values have changed. Starting with License Revenue, this metric decreased approximately 96% on a YoY basis, only accounting for 0.43% of Total Revenues. Matterport’s management was adamant that this value will likely to remain low in the upcoming quarter, due to the sporadic manner in which these transactions occur/are recognized. Being that as it may, hope in this area is not lost, with the company noting in their ER call that they intend to close a relatively substantial license revenue agreement with a client that is recurring in nature and will thus be recognized in the Subscription segment. Moving on, Services Revenue saw a 41% increase on a YoY basis as a result of heightened activity with in-app purchases and capturing services, accounting for ~12% of Total Revenues for the quarter. 

Cost of Revenue 

The change in Matterport’s Cost of Revenue (COR) can be seen outlined by the image below: 

Coming in at approximately $13.5M for the quarter, COR increased approximately 34.6% on a YoY basis in comparison to the ~10.3% YoY increase in Total Revenues. In order to better understand the root causes of this increase, COR by Revenue Segment and its change over the last couple of quarters can be seen outlined below: 

Subscription CORs increased 31.1% on a YoY, less than their respective Revenue increase. Services COR increased 42% in comparison to a 41% increase than its Revenue counterpart as a result of the labor costs associated with conducting in-person scans using third-party technicians. Lastly, Product COR increased 36% on a YoY basis despite its Revenue contributions remaining relatively stagnant YoY, hence the increase in Total COR as a proportion of Total Revenues, of which is reflected in figure below:

This increase can be attributed to the company expediting materials in order to meet customer demand as well as the overall increase in material costs that almost every industry has experienced of late. Investors should monitor this value to ensure cost controls are prioritized. 

Operating Expenses 

The change in Matterport’s Total Operating Expenses (OPEX) can be seen outlined below: 

Total OPEX came in at approximately $59M for the quarter, increasing 324% on a YoY basis. A breakdown of Total OPEX by segment, ie. the OPEX attributable to R&D and SG&A respectively can be seen outlined below: 

As per usual, SG&A expenses were the main constituents of Total OPEX, increasing 343% on a YoY basis. This increase was a result of both the company’s continued efforts decreased at Sales and Marketing efforts as well as the increased headcount they incurred in their G&A organization, of which was a result of becoming a publicly traded company. Although R&D became a smaller constituent of Total OPEX YoY, this value still increased 275% on a YoY basis as a result of planned investments being made in department headcount, of which should result in heightened product development efforts going forwards. For the sake of illustration, Total OPEX as a percentage of Total Revenues can be seen outlined below: 

Although the increase in these values was largely to be expected, when thinking of the scaling efforts Matterport has underway, Total OPEX as a % of Total Revenues is obviously very high and is not ideal for the longevity of the company. Going forward this value should be monitored, especially when considered alongside continued S&M spend. More specifically, if the company continues to ramp up S&M efforts while bolstering mediocre growth in revenues, similar to what was seen this quarter, I would deem that problematic. 

Profitability Measures 

In order to gauge the company’s profitability, Matterport’s Gross Profit, Operating Income and Net Income and how these values have changed of late can be seen outlined below: 

GP, coming in at approximately $14M for the quarter, decreased 6% YoY as a result of the higher COR discussed earlier. Net Income and Operating Income both decreased significantly, coming in at $(44)M and $(168)M for the quarter, respectively. The change in Net Income was primarily driven by the change in the fair value of warrants liabilities and contingent earn-out liability, i.e. one-time items associated with the company going public. Moving on, the increase in Operating Loss YoY was a result of previously outlined OPEX increases and should continue to be monitored going forwards. The change in the company’s Gross Profit, Net Income (adjusted this quarter to account for non-recurring items, all other quarters non-adjusted) and Operating Margins can be seen outlined below: 

The company’s Gross Margins decreased slightly QoQ from the 60% range to ~51%. Operating Margin came in at (160)% and Adjusted Net Income Margin came in at (5)%. These values are indicative of the relatively high GP-nature of the company’s business, a positive sign if they are able to scale Revenue more going forwards with a continued focus on recurring revenue streams. In addition, Matterport is far from profitability and is likely to sacrifice the health of their bottom line to achieve growth goals going forwards.

Balance Sheet

The structure of Matterport’s Asset Position can be seen outlined below:

Matterport’s assets are relatively liquid, with Current Assets consisting primarily of Cash and Cash Equivalents, Short Term Investments. Long Term Assets primarily constant of Long Term Investments. The structure of Matterport’s Liabilities can be seen outlined below:

The company’s Liabilities are very illiquid with Current Liabilities that are basically negligible in nature consisting of accounts payable primarily. Long Term Assets on the other hand consist primarily of earn-out liabilities and public/private warrant liabilities, i.e. liabilities associated with going public. In summary, Matterport’s balance sheet does not appear to be problematic for the time being given the ample liquidity that has arisen from going public. Therefore, the ability to sustain efforts for a few upcoming quarters without an additional cap raise is likely.

Cash Flow Statement 

In order to understand where Matterport is at with respect to their Cash from Operations, Investing and Financing, the change in these various cash flows on a quarterly basis can be seen below: 

CFO for the quarter came in at approximately $(18.5)M attributable primarily to the company’s Net Loss, of which was offset mainly by SBC and change in the fair value of warrants and earn-out liabilities. CFF came in at $594M for the quarter, attributable to the proceeds seen from going public. CFI was $(469)M, attributable to a large cash outflow directed at the purchase of investments. The change in Matterport’s quarterly FCF can be seen outlined below: 

FCF was $(18.5)M for Q3’21. With the one off-nature of many expenses in the company’s Net Income this quarter, as well as the fact that they are relatively non-intensive when it comes to capital expenditures, this value is likely to return to slightly less negative territory, allowing for the to continue to direct efforts at growth and expansion in the coming quarters. Given the cash on hand, the company’s FCF doesn’t appear to be problematic at the moment.

Now that we have a better understanding of Matterport’s Financials, let’s look at some Key Performance Indicators that shine additional light as to how the company is performing.

7.0 Key Performance Indicators

The first and arguably one of the most important KPIs for Matterport is the number of subscribers on the platform. This metric measures the number of users that have created a Matterport account during the respective reporting time period. The change in Total Subscribers can be seen outlined below: 

Increasing 116% YoY and coming in at approximately 439,000 at the end of Q3’21, these values are evidently increasing as the time goes on, a positive sign as it is indicative of the amount of activity in Matterport’s ecosystem. Being that as it may, for the longevity of Matterport’s business in general it will be even more imperative for the company to be able to monetize subscriptions. The amount of Paid Subscribers as well as the portion of Paid Subscribers with respect to Total Subscribers and its change over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

Despite seeing a rapid growth in Total Subscribers YoY, Paid Subscribers increased in a more lackluster fashion, coming in 53,000 paid subs and increasing 35% YoY, relatively in-line with the increase in Subscription Revenue over all. Also telling is the fact that Paid Subscribers as a % of Total Subscribers has been decreasing over the last few quarters, which may be telling of potential struggles Matterport is having with monetizing subs. Although more data is needed to draw a definitive conclusion on these happenings, it is worrisome given the fact that the company will need to rely on Subscription Revenues to fuel future growth. Not only is generating new subscribers important but extracting more value from existing subs is imperative to Matterport’s trajectory. This value, as measured by the Net Dollar Retention Rate, shows how much more Revenue users present in last year’s reporting cohort generated this year, and its change can be seen outlined below: 

This value is likely to remain bumpy in the future quarters as factors such as churn have an impact, however, Q3’21’s Net Dollar Expansion Rate of 114% is indicative of slight YoY increases in the amount of ecosystem activity attributable to existing subs. Another metric that may help gauge the ability for Matterport to generate value from subs, although the company does not officially report it, is the Average Revenue Per Paid Subscriber, which can be seen outlined below: 

Although changing in an unimpressive manner over the last few quarters, investors should continue to monitor this value, as it should ideally increase over time as Matterport focuses on acquiring subscribers in the higher priced tiers. The last metric of note is the Amount of Spaces Under Management, of which measures the amount of rooms, buildings or distinct areas that have been scanned on the Matterport platform can be seen outlined below: 

Increasing 62% on a YoY basis and coming in at approximately 6.2M spaces on the platform as of Q3’21, it is evident that Matterport is seeing higher penetration into their TAM and TSM that include billions of spaces. 

With all of these metrics in mind a simple conclusion can be drawn, of which in my eyes is a double-edged sword of sorts. More specifically, the company is evidently seeing increased activity on their platform, as gauged by the amount of subscribers as well as the number of spaces under management, with both values increasing respectively YoY. Being that as it may, the company has not been able to monetize this growth to a level which I believe should be expected of a company that is so richly valued. The company is directing substantial capital at increasing R&D and S&M efforts so this might change, however, in my opinion, Matterport needs to have a more enticing reason for subs to go paid and stay there if they want to keep growing.

With these KPIs in mind, let’s take what we know about the company so far and examine it’s valuation to draw a better conclusion.

8.0 Valuation 

There is no doubt that Matterport is valued richly, a proposition that may be problematic in the face of potentially faltering execution. Delving into the specifics, we can get a better sense of where Matterport is at with respect to their Metaverse-oriented competition by comparing the Next Twelve Month EV/Rev Multiple with forecasted Revenue Growth (2020A-2023E) as seen outlined below:  

As displayed above, despite Matterport showing almost best-in-class Revenue Growth for the forecast period (second to SNAP) they are valued the richest on a NTM EV/Rev basis. With the fact that the company is displaying difficulty converting new subscribers into paid counterparts, I have difficulty seeing the company achieving their projected 45% 3-year revenue CAGR and thus I find it hard to stomach a NTM EV/Revenue multiple of 39 when the company only displayed approximately 30% YoY Revenue growth. As we have seen of late, if companies are not executing to perfection, valuation multiples are being compressed in a big way, and I fear Matterport may fall victim to that sometime soon. When performing a similar comparison with EV/NTM GP multiples, a similar conclusion can be drawn: 

Lastly, if we look at the EBIT projections for some metaverse oriented companies there is likely no sign of profitability in sight for Matterport, especially given their expansionary efforts. 

With all of these facts considered, I would much prefer to expose myself to a NVDA for example, as it is a company that is likely to power, literally, much of the Metaverse activity in the coming years while also maintaining a more reasonable valuation, steady revenue growth and profitability on a EBIT level. 

9.0 Final Thoughts 

Before making closing remarks it is worth touching on a few positives. The first is the company’s expansionary efforts, of which they touched upon in their most recent CC and which has evidently been a priority of the company over the last few months, as displayed by Revelera job opening data: 

With these expansionary efforts the company may develop S&M strength that helps them acquire more paid subscribers etc. Another thing to take note of is Matterport’s recent launch of 3D capture (for free) to more than a billion android devices. This launch may potentially act as a source of organic marketing by allowing individuals to onboard to their platform by using their device’s inherent hardware and associated camera app. When considering the fact that android devices maintain 70% of total cellphone market share, it is an interesting growth proposition to say the least: 

Lastly, the company is evidently doing the right things when it comes to partnerships. More specifically Matterport announced partnerships with the likes of PTC Vuforia an augmented software offering designed to provide training in immersive 3d environments, SIMLAB a company focused on the digitization of design/construction processes and increased activities with Meta AI Research, which is developing AI systems analyzing the physical/virtual worlds. All of these partnerships are likely to expand the use-cases of Matterport’s technology as well as help to spur adoption across industries. 

Now to get a little more speculative, I would like to discuss the trajectory of where I think Matterport will end up down the road. More specifically, I find it likely that Matterport ends up as a buy-out candidate, especially when considering the activity that the likes of Google, Facebook and Microsoft are displaying within the metaverse. Meta’s activity (formerly Facebook) is evidently the most notable, I mean it isn’t every day a trillion dollar changes the name of their business to encompass a gamble they’re making on the future trajectory of the world. Matterport would evidently add value here by enabling the creation of of photorealistic spaces within the metaverse. There are a lot of potential directions this could go, but, seeing a deal I would have never envisioned happening yesterday, it affirms my hunch that big corporations are willing to engage in partnerships to make this vision a reality. More specifically, Microsoft and Meta announced that they plan on integrating their enterprise offerings, Teams and Workplace, allowing for individuals to access content from both ecosystems without the need to switch between different apps. If these two behemoths are willing to partner, I see no reason for Matterport not to pay a bigger role in their ambitions going forwards.

Out of all the aforementioned companies, I believe Google’s activities in this realm intersect the best with Matterport’s capabilities. More specifically, I believe Matterport’s Digital Spaces mesh perfectly with the company’s Google Maps offering. This proposition isn’t too far fetched, especially when considering the amount of AR-related features Google has been launching of late as well as the recent effort on Matterport’s end to integrate with the Android Ecosystem.

With all of these speculations in mind, I think the assertion that a buyout occurring in the future is not made out of lunacy, but time will if this hunch is corroborated. At the very least, shareholders can be content at the fact that the company is uniquely positioned to benefit from both previously outlined technological tailwinds as well as heightened attention of highly successful corporations occurring because of their unique product offering.

10.0 Conclusion 

With the increasing digitization of the world spreading rampantly, and Matterport’s truly unique capabilities, the company offers itself as an interesting opportunity. Being that as it may, the company’s valuation, slowing growth and execution that doesn’t make my jaw drop will have me sit this one out for the time being. I hope this research served as a good entry point to all things Matterport. Thank you for reading.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, comment below and share!

Share

If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

item.title: dLocal Ltd. ($DLO)
item.description: Turning Chaos into Order in Emerging Markets
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to MT Capital Research! If you’re new, join a group of 2370 Informed Investors who receive weekly reports on the World’s Most Interesting Tech Companies by subscribing below:

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an in-depth analysis on DLO. Within I will be discussing the main trends and macroeconomic happenings the company aims to leverage within their operations, break down their products and outline in detail how the company makes money. In addition, I will analyze the company’s financials and outline the key factors, both positive and risk-based alike, that I believe investors should be wary of when considering DLO as a potential portfolio allocation. The format of my research, like always, can be seen outlined below. Please feel free to skip ahead to the sections that you feel will be the most helpful to your process: 

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Opportunity 

3.0 What dLocal Offers Merchants

4.0 How dLocal makes $$$

5.0 Trajectory of the Company (So Far)

6.0 Financial Analysis

7.0 Key Performance Metrics

8.0 Competition and Valuation

9.0 Why I’m Long and Risks I’m Focused On

10.0 Conclusion 

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitute for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investment. 

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content and analysis, give me a follow on Twitter: 

Follow Me

With all of that out of the way, let’s get started. 

1.0 Introduction 

In essence, dLocal can be defined as a company that is focused on redefining the manner in which payments are conducted in emerging markets. Through the company’s direct API payment platform, dLocal aims to connect a multitude of different global enterprises with billions of customers concentrated across a variety of developing economies. The company caters towards enterprises that operate in various industries, ranging from SaaS, shared economy and marketplaces, online retail, travel and tourism and financial services and provides functionality including but not limited to accepting payments, sending payouts and settling funds. dLocal’s products help merchants navigate complicated foreign payment landscapes, improving acceptance and conversion rates, reducing friction, preventing fraud and improving the seamlessness of interacting with one’s customers, all while abiding by everchanging local laws/regulations. 

Now that we have a brief understanding of what exactly the company does, let’s take a look at some key trends and opportunities that the company aims to leverage within their operations and growth initiatives.

2.0 Opportunity 

In a world that is becoming driven by interactions that occur within the digital realm, as well as the increasing prevalence of individuals engaging with e-commerce mediums, there are a series of trends that are worth noting, as well as some disparity in said trends that have arisen globally. The main items that dLocal aims to capitalize on within their business can be seen outlined below: 

Starting off with The Rise of the Digital Economy and E-Commerce, technology has evidently changed the manner in which most of us conduct our daily lives. With the growing rate at which individuals are able to access the internet, and the increased smartphone penetration that has occurred over the last few years, as outlined below, the manner in which consumer and merchant interact is changing. 

The primary benefactor of these changes arguably has been and will continue to be e-commerce. To put things into perspective, of the approximately $4T in retail sales that occurred in 2020, almost 18% of these were a result of e-commerce [3], a value which is expected to surpass 21% in 2024. In addition, a growing interconnectedness between entities and countries situated across the word, i.e. the phenomenon of globalization, has only been spurred by technology. To back up this assertion, the EMI estimates that over the last two decades there has been an approximate 6% growth in World trade. In addition, Bloomberg estimates that 50%+ of said retail trade is attributable to emerging market sources. In essence, these regions are becoming increasingly important within a more interconnected World. Not only is technology spurring higher rates of engagement between developed and developing countries, it is also giving certain demographics access to goods and services that were previously unavailable to them. For some additional background, the amount of middle class individuals in Emerging Markets greatly trumped those in developed countries, with 679M middle class households measured in the former in comparison to 176M in the latter [4]. This demographic has historically been very involved with retail trade and more recently, e-commerce interactions. When coupled with the staggering GDP growth that is anticipated to occur in Emerging Markets vs. Developed Markets, i.e. how their GDP Growth CAGR Forecast for 2020-2025 is anticipated to be 4.9%, almost 3X the size of developed nations CAGR during the same time frame, there is evidently a surplus of value ripe for the taking in the e-commerce realm, as well as for the companies that help facilitate transactions. While that sounds all fine and dandy, there are a series of struggles that exist with offering solutions for the aforementioned individuals. Despite the massive size of Global Network Card systems, of which facilitated approximately $477B in purchase transactions for goods and services in 2020 [5], there are key differences in the ability of legacy payment methods to cater towards the shopping habits of those within the US and Europe, and those situated Internationally. For the sake of illustration, it is quite clear that in the US both credit and debit cards are both widely held and utilized. According to a recent Nielsen Report, it was estimated that almost 82.2% and 71.7% of the adult population within the United States held debit or credit cards, respectively [6]. The companies that provide these instruments, though successful in highly developed regions, have struggled expanding their reach Internationally . This assertion is corroborated further when looking at the fact that banking penetration often falls below 20% in several emerging markets, with inhabitants of these regions preferring to use cash-payment systems, digital wallets or transfers. In other words, members of these regions often leverage local payment methods rather than alternatives with international capabilities/functionality, with over 83% of total e-commerce expenditure in 15 developing regions occurring through the medium of the former, as surveyed by AMI [7].  An outline of some interesting payment statistics within global markets, more specifically the sources of aggregate e-commerce payment volumes, can be seen outlined within the table below:

With the above values in mind, there is an evident opportunity for solutions that are compatible with local payment methods. For the sake of further illustration, the amount of cross-border e-commerce transactions that occur as a percentage of total e-commerce transactions, as gauged by the survey of three developed and three emerging markets, the two tables can be compared below:

Heavily populated Emerging Markets, as judged by the above figures, show evident room for improvement in terms of the amount of cross-border transactions that occur in these regions. As an example, Brazil shows only 6% of transactions occurring cross-border, despite having one of the highest e-commerce growth rates in the world. Poor penetration in these areas may be a result of the complexities that arise from making payments in these regions. Associated transactions require strict adherence to challenging frameworks, volatile FX exchange rates, relationships with local institutions, and technological capabilities that facilitate transaction settlements while abiding by different tax and regulatory environments simultaneously. As such, these multi-faceted processes pose real challenge to merchants, evidently presenting themselves as a tedious and difficult task to complete in-house. There are very few businesses that can offer merchants this functionality in an effective and cost-efficient manner, presenting an evident opportunity for dLocal to capitalize on. In summary, with the growth of e-commerce, increasing rate of individuals who desire to interact with merchants and bolstering fast growth in certain regions around the world, there exists a real need for payment systems to be able to function within these environments. dLocal and its technology aims to be the company that benefits from these tailwinds, building solutions that cater towards both local and cross-border payment needs and building themselves a very impressive moat while doing it. 

With all of these happenings in mind, let’s take a closer look at what exactly dLocal’s products offer clients. 

3.0 What dLocal Offers Merchants

dLocal targets businesses through what they denote as their “One D-Local” model. In essence, this represents the company’s go-to-market strategy, and contains their associated technology, intellectual property, and a variety of business functionality/capabilities. Clients can gain access to all of this functionality, encompassed within the dLocal platform, through the use of a single API and are billed for its use through a single contract, but more on that later. In order to understand what dLocal offers their clients, which in the company’s case are Global Enterprise Merchants, we must first split their offerings into those centered around the facilitation of Pay-in and Pay-out and Marketplace processes. These processes represent, in my opinion, the bulk of dLocal’s technology value proposition and as such should be the primary focus of analysis. All other functionality can be thought of as icing on top of the company’s proverbial cake, and will be broken down in the latter parts of this section. Pay-In processes can be loosely defined as a instances by where dLocal assists Global Merchants with getting paid whereas Pay-Out processes on the other hand sees dLocal assisting merchants with making payments online in a safe and expedient manner. Marketplace allows for marketplace sellers, of which are intertwined with an ecommerce platform/company’s network, to accept local cards and payment methods directly through their platform.  The technological enablement of these processes is centered around dLocal being able to navigate a complex environment of regulations and decipher a complex web of systems that lacks uniformity when moving from region to region. Being that dLocal facilitates interaction between consumer and merchant in approximately 30 different countries, the company’s technology allows merchants to rest easy on the fact that their platform: 

  • Adheres to local regulatory and tax requirements

  • Focuses on offering end-user transparency and security

  • Mitigates inherent fraud risk 

  • Provides the ability to leverage transaction data to gain valuable insights

  • Provides the opportunity for the interaction between Global Merchant and local emerging market partners 

With this functionality in mind, let’s take a closer look at the Pay Ins, Pay Outs and Marketplace processes, respectively. 

Pay-In

dLocal assists Global Merchants with accepting payments in different emerging countries, supporting local payment methods commonly used within each region. These methods include but are not limited to both international and local credit cards, bank transfers, cash payments, direct debit and the use of different e-wallets. Pay-In functionality, as provided by dLocal’s API, can be split into three main segments, each of which can be seen outlined in further detail below. 

Credit Card Payments

dLocal allows companies to accept credit cards, both of the international and local variety all while maintaining a focus on PCI compliance. This compliance standard is mandated by credit card companies in order to uphold a high degree of security within transactions [8]. In order to reduce the friction associated with Merchants accepting credit cards, merchants can either interact with dLocal on exchange payment on a server to server basis, or, if they are not PCI compliant, they can leverage the company’s Smart Field technology. More specifically, Smart Fields are essentially an iframe that can be incorporated with a merchant’s website that is adherent to PCI standards.

Installments

Merchants also have the option of accepting payments with installments. Similar to BNPL functionality I have outlined in-depth in previous deep-dives, the Merchant receives the full amount they are owed at settlement (from dLocal) and then dLocal will be responsible for ensuring they are repaid in full from the consumer. This no-risk process (for Merchants) has benefits ranging from boosting average order value, decreasing purchasing friction and much more. 

Alternate Payment Methods

As previously mentioned, APM dLocal supports transaction methods that range from Bank Transfers to Cash Payments. These constituents differ dependent on the country they are contained within. If you wish to see the exact payment methods dLocal supports in approximately 30 different emerging countries, I have included a link to the associated documentation below [10]. If not, take my word for the fact that dLocal has their bases covered in these regions. 

With all of these factors in mind and for the sake of understanding where dLocal fits within a typical Pay-In transaction, let’s take a look at a hypothetical interaction between consumer and global merchant, of which can be seen outlined below: 

Pay-Out

This subset of dLocal’s functionality essentially allows for the partners of merchants to be paid in their local currency. dLocal leverages their connection with over 200 banks spread across emerging markets to pay partners, all while avoiding extra taxes and fees typically associated with foreign currency conversion, and bolstering an expedient settlement time of 24-48 hours, a breath of fresh air when compared to legacy infrastructure. A schematic of the traditional Pay-Out process can be seen outlined below: 

Marketplace

As previously touched upon, dLocal facilitates global e-commerce processes for interested merchants by accepting payments from customers contained within emerging markets and then paying associated marketplace sellers that are oftentimes situated across the globe. An exemplary Marketplace transaction enabled by dLocal can be seen outlined within the following image: 

With arguably the largest cohorts of dLocal’s value proposition in mind, we can now move on to the other technological capabilities of the company as a whole. These extra titbits of functionality can be listed as follows: Fraud Prevention, Direct Issuing and Integration, each of which can be seen outlined below. 

Fraud Prevention

dLocal offers a holistic approach to risk and fraud management, providing flexible solutions that can be incorporated with the aforementioned payment functionalities outlined above. The company offers merchants three solutions to select from, of which cater towards different needs. These solutions are Smart Defense, Defense Manager and Chargeback Guarantee. 

Smart Defense 

dLocal provides merchants access to a host of AI/ML models that are able to track and score payment transactions. AI/ML models leverage a multitude of data points, i.e. the millions of transactions that occur within dLocal’s network and across merchants situated across various industries. As such, merchants that utilize Smart Defense are then able to pinpoint suspicious transactions, improving their ability to detect fraud and increase approval rates as a result, essentially automating fraud protection as a result.  

Defense Manager

This Fraud Prevention constituent is aimed at merchants that already have their own fraud prevention in-house. This segment can essentially be thought of as an extension of Smart Defense, i.e. rather than automating the majority of the fraud recognition merchants are provided access to an intuitive administrator dashboard, of which gives greater control over transaction approval and rejection. 

Chargeback Guarantee

Through Chargeback Guarantee, dLocal provides merchants a completely managed fraud prevention system, in exchange for a fixed rate. The company absorbs all of the headaches and problems associated with risk management processes, guaranteeing merchants free fraudulent chargebacks if they arise during transactions. 

Direct Issuing

With dLocal’s Direct Issuing functionality, merchants are able to create e-wallets that behave similarly to bank accounts for their consumers as well as issue prepaid cards that are associated with their brand. With both physical and virtual brand-related cards able to be issued, associated users will then be able to spend the funds on services, products, groceries, withdrawal funds from ATMs, pay their bills and even send money to their peers, all in their locally denominated currency. Similarly to previously outlined technological capabilities, all of this can be done utilizing dLocal’s API. Additional functionality includes the ability for merchants to re-issue cards when expired or block their use if stolen and instantly credit funds to branded cards (in comparison to dreadfully long traditional settlement times). If you think about the variety of instances that require merchants to pay their supply-side user base such as drivers and freelancers in local currency, this functionality definitely has wide use-cases associated with it. 

Integration 

Lastly, and arguably an interesting addition to the company’s value proposition, dLocal supports integration with merchant ecosystems that include Shopify, Lightspeed (for Mexican Merchants), and Tienda Nube (Argentinian-based SME SaaS platform). When considering the sheer size GMV that occurs within each of these ecosystems, dLocal evidently will be able to generate substantial amounts of LTV through this functionality. In addition, dLocal is able to be integrated with merchants that support Google Pay on their platform. Though second tier to Apple Pay, Google Pay has approximately 150M users worldwide [11], and dLocal’s compatibility with this payment method will be another spurring factor for reducing friction associated with merchants conducting global e-commerce processes. 

Now that we have a better understanding of what dLocal offers merchants, let’s take a look at how exactly they make money from it. 

4.0 How dLocal makes $$$

As previously mentioned, the company prides itself on having created an easily digestible business model, which the company denotes as the “One dLocal model”. This model essentially contains one technology platform, of which encompasses the aforementioned functionality outlined within the previous section and can be accessed all through one API, earning money through one contract between dLocal and the associated merchant. This simplicity is corroborated when digging deeper into how a merchant creates a relationship with the company. More specifically when a merchant is looking to leverage dLocal’s technology, the primary route of contact will be to reach out to the company’s sales team, detail certain aspects of their business, both operational and otherwise, as well as specify the solution they wish to use (pay-ins, pay-outs or direct issuing). An example contact form can be seen outlined below:

Based upon this information an arrangement can then be honed between dLocal and the merchant. Once this relationship has been formed and customers have had time to familiarize themselves with the platform, dLocal primarily earns money through fees they charge merchants for cross-border and local payment transactions executed within associated emerging markets. 

These fees are unique to each use-case but either occur as a fixed percentage or fixed fee per each transaction. In addition, the company charges FX conversion service fees for cross-border payments. Lastly, dLocal charges Merchant Discount Rate (MDR) fees to customers for any services they provide, these include fees for leveraging the company’s fraud/risk-mitigation and tax/regulatory abidance functionality as well as processing and settlement fees, to name a few.  

Now that we have a better understanding of how dLocal makes money, let’s take a look at some key milestones that the company can bolster across their relatively short lifespan so far, since I believe it is indicative of potential early stages of hypergrowth.

5.0 Trajectory of the Company (So Far) 

6.0 Financial Analysis 

In order to get a better understanding of where the company is at financially, I will be analyzing their Income Statement, Balance Sheet and Cash Flow Statement up to and including Q2’21. It is worth noting that the company recently released preliminary results for Q3’21, as such I have taken the lower extreme of these values (since the company reported certain metrics in ranges) and included them in my analysis where applicable.

Income Statement

Revenue

dLocal’s revenue came in at approximately $59M for Q2’21, representing a 186% increase on a YoY basis. Taking into consideration the company’s preliminary revenue results for Q3’21, dLocal is expecting to report $67M for the upcoming period, of which would represent a 117% increase YoY. The change in these values over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

The company’s Revenue can be split into two components, Transaction Revenues and Other Revenues. As previously discussed, the former represents money the company makes on transaction fees (either as a fixed percentage or fixed fee) whereas the latter represents fees charged to merchants for setup, fraud/risk management and other services provided. The percentage of Revenue attributable to each of these constituents for Q2’21, in comparison to Q2’20, can be seen outlined below: 

As you can see, Transaction Revenue became a larger percentage of Total Revenue as a whole for Q2’21 in comparison to Q2’20. With the company’s High Revenue Retention, transaction fees will continue to be the main manner in which the company generates top-line growth, especially as ecosystem GMV continues to grow. Other Revenue can be thought of as compensation for maintaining a commendable customer experience and will likely never be a material source of growth going forwards. Moving on, the amount of the company’s revenue attributable to both Existing Merchants (merchants that had recognized revenue both this reporting period and the same reporting period last year) and New Merchants and how this has changed over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

As outlined above, the company evidently derives a large portion of their revenue from existing partners. Being that dLocal has relationships with some of the largest merchants in the world, this will likely continue to be the case, especially when viewed alongside their sticky product and relatively sparse competition.  New Merchants will continue to be a driver of business growth, however when looking at the company’s Net Revenue Retention (NRR) it becomes clear why I have made my previous assertion: 

Being that NRR is Prior Period Revenue divided by Current Period Revenue these values are extremely impressive. For the sake of clarity, prior period revenue is essentially FY’19 Revenue (as an example) attributable to all merchants whereas current period revenue is FY’20 revenue attributable to the same merchants used to calculate prior period revenue. These values are in-line, if not better, than some of the stickiest SaaS products out there and will undoubtedly earn dLocal it’s high valuation, but more on that later. Regardless, with NRR expected to come in for Q3’21 in the 170-180% range, showcasing the likely stability in revenue generation to be expected in quarters to come as well as overall customer contentment. Lastly, it is worth noting the geographic concentration in the company’s revenue. 

As the above figures illustrate, LatAm Revenue has become a larger constituent of Total Revenue YoY, increasing from 84% of Revenues to 91%. This is likely to remain the case when considering the fact that approximately 50% of the markets dLocal is available within are situated in Latin America, some of the regions that are experiencing the highest growth in e-commerce activity in the world. Although I believe this exposure will be net positive to the trajectory of the company, investors will have to monitor macroeconomic conditions in this region in order to clip any tail risk. 

Cost of Revenues

The change in the company’s Cost of Revenues (COR) over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

Coming in at approximately $25M for Q2’21, these values increased 176% YoY in comparison to a 186% YoY increase in Revenues. COR as a % of Total Revenue and how this metric has changed can be seen below: 

As a percentage of Total Revenues, COR has stagnated at approximately the 40-43% range over the last few quarters. Largely consisting of fees that the dLocal leverages for their tech’s inherent functionality, i.e. fees owed to banks, local payment method providers etc., as well as hosting expenses for their platform, salaries of employees and amortization costs of in-house software, these values have increased relative to dLocal’s scale. With Payment Processing Costs being approximately 94% of the company’s Total COR, it is evident that this value will be the primary constituent of COR as dLocal continues to operate and expand into new emerging markets, likely to increase proportionally relative to GMV going forwards. 

Operating Expenses 

The change in dLocal’s Operating Expenses can be seen outlined below: 

This value came in at approximately $15M for the quarter, increasing 302% on a YoY basis. Total Operating Expenses as a percentage of Total Revenue increased proportionally as well: 

The three main constituents of Total Operating Expenses as well as their YoY Change and relationship to Total Revenue can be seen outlined in the table below: 

As the above table outlines, Total Operating Expenses and the increase YoY was largely driven by the increase in General and Administrative Expenses. This 405% YoY increase was a result, primarily, of costs associated with the company’s secondary portion of their IPO as well as an increase in salaries due to the fact that they doubled their headcount YoY. In Q2’20 G&A expenses were approximately 13% of Total Revenues in comparison to 23% in Q2’21. It is reasonable to conclude that Total OPEX is likely to approach sub 20% of Total Revenues as the company’s operations continue to hone and as one-off expenses are removed from the sum of the whole, however, for now, the increase in Total OPEX is not problematic and is occurring a result of an increase in business scale and going public. 

Margins and Profitability

In order to gauge the company’s profitability, let’s take a look at dLocal’s Gross Profit and Net Income and how these values have changed over the last few quarters: 

Gross Profit increased 193% on a YoY basis, compared to the 142% and 139% increases in Operating Profit and Net Income, respectively. These values are encouraging given the company’s 186% increase in Revenues and high degree of expenses directed at expansion. The company’s Gross Profit, Operating and Net Income margins can be seen outlined below: 

Although COR has increased relative to dLocal’s penetration into different emerging markets, Gross Profit Margin is likely to remain in the 50-60% range going forwards, high when compared to counterparts in the Fintech industry. Operating and Net Income Margins are indicative of the company’s ability to maintain profitability while also bolstering a high degree of growth, and is something not many companies at similar stages can showcase. 

Balance Sheet

The structure of dLocal’s assets, as of Q2’21, can be seen outlined below:

The company’s assets are very liquid, consisting almost entirely of Cash and Cash Equivalents and Trade/Other Receivables. Long Term Assets consist predominantly of Intangible Assets. dLocal’s Liabilities on the other hand can be broken down as follows:

The company’s Current Liabilities consist predominantly of Trade and Other Payables whereas Long Term Liabilities can be linked to Lease Liabilities, mainly. With these descriptions in mind, it is evident that the company has ample liquidity and a healthy balance sheet to support operations going forwards. When combined with dLocal’s recent secondary offering, it is likely the company will be able to support operations without additional equity/debt raises in the near future. 

Cash Flow Statement

In order to gauge where the company is at with respect to their various Cash Flows, Cash from Operations, Investing and Financing for 1H’21, compared  can be seen outlined below:

CFO for the first half of 2021 came in at approximately $40M, attributable primarily to the company’s Net Income, with the main positive adjustments being made for SBC (reasonably low at 5% of Total Revenue), Amortization of Intangible Assets, offset by Other Operating Losses. CFI came in as an outflow of ~$(35)M mainly attributable to acquisitions of intangible assets, offset by the acquisition of FVPL. Lastly, CFF came in at ~$150M linked mainly to proceeds from the issuance of shares and the IPO. The company’s FCF the same period can be seen outlined below:

7.0 Key Performance Metrics 

The first and arguably the most important metric to pay attention to is the company’s GMV (referred to as TPV in filings). This metric essentially represents the value of all payments processed through dLocal’s platform and can be used to gauge the overall wellbeing of the company’s merchant partners, the inherent satisfaction of these entities and the individuals they serve as well as the scale of the company’s business as a whole. The change in GPV over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

GMV has evidently been accelerating at a rapid pace, judging by the fact that Q2’21 GMV, coming in at approximately $1.46B increased 319% on a YoY basis and Q3’21 GMV is expected to grow 211% and come in at approximately $1.78B.  Though largely contingent on e-commerce activity within emerging markets, I do not anticipate this value to slow down anytime soon. Moving on, as with any payment processing company, analyzing take rate is imperative to understanding how much value the company can extract from their transactions. The change in this metric over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

The company’s take-rate came in at approximately 4.05% for Q2’21 and based upon expected values for GMV and Revenues, is likely to come in at approximately 3.8% in Q3’21. You may be asking yourself why this has been decreasing slightly over the last few quarters. One must understand the fact that the company has pricing tiers set with their largest merchants. What this means is that as the merchants transact at higher volumes in emerging markets, take rate will usually decrease as per the agreement between dLocal and merchant. As such, when looking at dLocal’s high NRR, take rate is likely to remain in the high 3% to low 4% range for the near future given where their large merchant partners are with respect to their contracts. When comparing this take rate with typical credit card companies (upper end of their processing fee ranges), dLocal obviously extracts more value from their GMV, an encouraging fact given the infancy of the company’s growth trajectory: 

Lastly, it is important to understand the company’s NRR and just how high this value is relative to its peers. For the sake of comparison, I decided to look at dLocal’s NRR relative to competition (Global-E Online in particular) and some of the highest-performing SaaS companies in the world. Although dLocal and the latter are in different industries, the top-performers in this cohort have very high product stickiness and have sustained impressive price action and high multiples for an extended period of time now. This comparison can be seen outlined by the following figure: 

It will be important for investors to monitor this value to ensure it remains best-in-class in comparison to industry peers and highly valued technology company counterparts. At 175% this value is indicative of extremely high product satisfaction and the stickiness of dLocal’s platform as a whole. 

8.0 Competition and Valuation 

The biggest source of competition for dLocal is in my opinion, Global-E Online Ltd., of which I will denote as GLBE for the sake of brevity. GLBE, similarly to dLocal, is focused on helping merchants expand into and conduct e-commerce processes in emerging markets. However, GLBE, unlike dLocal, attempts to cast a wider net over this opportunity and suffers as a result, in my opinion. More specifically, GLBE generates Revenue from two business segments, Service Fees and Fulfillment Revenue. Service Fees, much like dLocal, are fees generated as a percentage of GMV, charged to merchants as compensation for processing payments/transactions in different locales. Fulfillment Revenue on the other hand is generated through the company’s offerings of shipping and handling services for merchants in various emerging markets. As outlined below, the company derives a large part of their Revenue from Fulfillment Services, with 63% of Total Revenues being attributable to this source in 2020. This percentage distribution has remained relatively constant over the last few years: 

Digging more into the specifics, and starting to delve in the key differences with the both companies, both dLocal and GLBE have seen tremendous top-line growth as exhibited by similar growth trajectories outlined below: 

As previously asserted, GLBE’s split-focus between payments and fulfillment starts to degrade overall business wellbeing when one looks at other parts of the company’s Income Statement. More specifically, the low gross-profit nature of fulfillment revenues in general can be pinpointed as one of the main reasons for the discrepancies between the two company’s gross profit below: 

As outlined above, dLocal displayed GP that was approximately 50%+ better than its counterpart for Q2’21. Moving on, there is also an extreme contrast each of the company’s various profitability measures, i.e. Operating Profit and Net Income. The differences can be seen outlined below: 

As is quite obvious, despite both of these entities exhibiting strong top-line growth and high-velocity scale expansion dLocal has been able to maintain a focus on profitability whereas GLBE has not. Of additional note are the company’s margin profiles, i.e. their Gross Profit, Operating and Net Income Margins, of which can be seen compared below: 

Lastly, dLocal’s and GLBE’s GMVs can be seen compared below: 

Quite evidently, dLocal’s payment centered ecosystem is much larger in scale. When viewed in conjunction with both of these companies take-rates, i.e. dLocal’s take rate in the 3.7-4.2% range and GLBE’s at approximately 6%, I believe dLocal’s incentivizes customers to transact at a higher volume through their platform in comparison to its peer. In summary, the companies have similar top-line trajectories, however, I believe dLocal’s focus on payments as well as much stronger profitability and margin profiles will lead to outperformance in the long-run in comparison to GLBE. 

Moving on to dLocal’s valuation, there is no doubt the company is richly valued.. Various dLocal valuation metrics can be seen outlined below: 

Being that as it may, as many of the top companies in the world, this is for a reason. The company’s strong top-line growth, as exhibited by EV/S vs. 2021E-2022E Revenue CAGR, and how this metric is best in-class relative to its fintech peers as outlined below, is testament to, in my opinion, the strong likelihood that we should see continue to see dLocal prosper in the coming quarters.

9.0 Why I’m Long and Risks I’m Focused On 

dLocal has relationships with some of the largest companies in the world, spanning across a variety of industries, to help them and their merchants (if applicable) expand into select emerging markets. A few name drops can be seen outlined below: 

  • Amazon

  • Shopify

  • Nike

  • DiDi

  • Uber

  • Booking.com

  • Microsoft 

  • Lightspeed

In conjunction with an absurdly high NRR, great top and bottom lines and presence within an industry that has stayed red-hot of late, I have started a position into dLocal. In a world that is becoming ever inter-connected, the sheer volume of the growth in certain emerging markets, and the ability for dLocal’s products to reduce the difficulties associated with expanding e-commerce operations into locations that are vastly different from the west, I believe there is an undeniable value proposition here. I have been wanting exposure to LatAm e-commerce for a while now and I believe this business intersects well with my newfound knowledge of the payment tech industry as well as my desire to increase my allocations toward businesses in high-growth stages quite perfectly. When viewing the fact that dLocal derives the majority of their revenues from activity in the LatAm region, as well as the continued growth that is expected to occur over the next few years, I believe dLocal will be able to leverage their existing relationships with merchants new and old, and conduct higher rates of payment volumes as these entities look to increase their exposure to this region. 

With Latin America bolstering the highest growth of any region (beating out the APAC region for the first time since 2010) as well as the fact that total LatAm e-commerce sales are expected to reach $160B by 2025, growing at a CAGR of 17.15% between the 2021-2025 forecast period, I believe dLocal is well set up to capitalize on the increased payment activity that is likely to need facilitating in the area as a result. With the fact that the company just recently completed a secondary offering at $52/share, as well as their evident and consistent profitability, a rare phenomenon in the fintech industry as a whole, I believe the risk/reward is great here for an excellent company. Lastly, the company has been and will likely continue to be active with expansion into new emerging markets. Yesterday the company, announced that they had entered into Thailand, El Salvador, an effort that will see them reach 93M new consumers, of which had a combined 2020 e-commerce revenue of $26B, as well as offer merchants another reason to expand their e-commerce operations with the help of dLocal’s payment API.

I acknowledge this allocation is not without its risks. The first risk that investors should be aware of is the lockup period that is due to expire  on 11/30/2021. This expiration period usually results in some downwards selling pressure on the stock in the short-term. This phenomenon can be viewed with many high-profile IPOs, with the example of Uber outlined below:

Plenty of other examples can be found on the web if you are curious.
