Although this doesn’t guarantee negative price-action of any kind, it is worth keeping on eye on if you’re looking to start a position in the near term. Lastly, I will be focused on monitoring two additional risks. The first and evidently the most glaring is the valuation of dLocal. With the EV/S multiple like dLocal’s there is usually not a lot of room for error with management’s execution. The company has been doing a great job as of late but regardless any misstep will likely result in multiple compression. The second will be the macroeconomic situations of all the emerging markets that the company is exposed to, particularly LatAm, of which could negatively impact the ability for merchants to conduct business successfully in these regions. As such, I will be continually monitoring all of these factors and changing my thesis if new data points suggest a call for action. 

10.0 Conclusion

Businesses that turn chaos into order are some of my favorite to invest it. Whether it be corporations that turn their companies complex web of data into something tangible that can have value extracted from it, such as Palantir, to companies that that are changing the status quo of how payments are conducted, like Square and Affirm, companies that fulfill a real and untapped need are extremely valuable. With some of the world’s largest merchants and businesses looking to expand their reach across the Globe, many have encountered hindrance as a result of complexities of payment infrastructure in emerging markets. dLocal’s easy-to-use technology, of which can accessed simply from one API, allows merchants to navigate new waters in a way that would have not been possible previously. dLocal is coasting along on some of the largest tailwinds the world has ever seen, i.e. the change in the very fabric of the way retail trade is conducted, via e-commerce, as well as increased Globalization that would not be possible without humanity’s technological prowess, and I will gladly join this company on a potentially fantastic trajectory. Thank you for reading my research.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, comment below and share!

Share

If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

item.title: Square ($SQ) x Afterpay (ASX:$APT)
item.description: The Gorilla Glue between Square's Two Ecosystems.
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to MT Capital Research! If you’re new, join a group of 2300 Informed Investors who receive weekly reports on the World’s Most Interesting Tech Companies by subscribing below:

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an in-depth analysis on Afterpay, the Australian Fintech company that Square announced their plans to acquire earlier this year. This research will be focused on describing the company’s back-story, breaking down their products and services, discussing some key financial metrics and factors that one should be aware of, as well putting my thoughts down on paper regarding how I believe this acquisition helps Square’s business as a whole.

The format of this report, broken down into each respective section, can be seen outlined below. Feel free to skip ahead to the sections that you feel will be most useful:

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Brief History 

3.0 Opportunity and Demographics

4.0 What Afterpay Offers Consumers and Merchants

5.0 How Afterpay makes $$$

6.0 Financial Analysis - FY’21 Earnings

7.0 Key Performance Indicators

8.0 What Afterpay adds to Square

9.0 Conclusion

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitute for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investments. 

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content and analysis, give me a follow on Twitter! 

Follow Me!

With all of that considered, let’s get started. 

1.0 Introduction 

Afterpay, most simply, can be described as a company that connects merchants and consumers, facilitating the use of buy now, pay later (BNPL) services. In essence, these capabilities allow for consumers to buy something now, pay for a percentage of the good/service ticket price at checkout, then pay for the remainder in equal installments over a predetermined repayment period. The company, though with roots in the APAC region (primarily Australia), has strong presence in both the United Kingdom and the United States, creating an interesting value proposition for its users, as well as for Square’s International expansion efforts. 

Now that we know a bit more about what the company offers, let’s take a look at how exactly this company came to be what it is today. 

2.0 Brief History 

Afterpay, envisioned and brought into fruition by young CEO Nick Molnar, the youngest self-made billionaire ever recorded in Australia, has to be one of the most astonishing growth stories in all of the Fintech space.

More specifically, Afterpay went from a consumer-lending startup thought-up at the beginning of 2014, to a company that was acquired by Square at a roughly $30B+ valuation on August 1st of this year. Molnar showed an early affinity for business growth, starting to sell jewelry throughout his time as a university student, as a side-hustle so to speak, eventually becoming the largest seller of jewelry on eBay in Australia. With ambitions to make a name for himself in the finance world,  Molnar sought out to become an analyst within a private equity firm. However, as legend has it, he was encouraged to pursue the jewelry business with the full extent of his time once his then boss found out how successful his endeavors were [3]. With this blessing in mind, Nick decided to launch an Australian web-presence for ice.com, a leading jeweler in America [4], an endeavor that proved to be challenging given the fundamental disconnects that existed between conducting sales for luxury items in-person in comparison to through online mediums. According to Nick, the online front he had created was struggling with conversions, only able to turn one of every 100 website visitors into an actual paying customer [5]. Leveraging his customer demographic’s distrust for credit cards, as well as the ever-growing trend of technologically-enabled instant gratification behavior (Uber, Food Delivery Services, Netflix etc.), Molnar and his then-neighbor Anthony Eisen (co-founder of Afterpay) stumbled upon the idea that is now Afterpay in 2014. The pair moved fast, with 2015 seeing the company enter into a joint venture agreement with Touchcorp, a digital payments system company, obtain their first customer by way of Fashion Group Princess Polly and raise $8M in private equity investment, which would be their only round of private funding. Their first business partner saw immediate success with the company’s BNPL payment methods, bumping their Average Order Value by A$44 and lifting their revenues as a whole by 15% [6]. It was evident that their business model worked and as such, the company decided to go public, listing on the ASX at $1 Per share. Growth efforts continued, eventually resulting in the company hitting 1M customers and over 7,200 merchants by 2017. Since then, the company has expanded into New Zealand, the UK, the US, Canada and currently has plans to expand further into Europe, Spain and Italy [7]. This tale, of which has many similarities to the origin story of Square, highlights a common theme that exists within successful entrepreneurial endeavors, i.e. founders creating a solution to a problem they’ve faced in your own life. Outlined within the Innovation Stack by James McKelvey, the idea for Square, which would inevitably become the company destined to acquire Afterpay, was spurred by a problem McKelvey faced as a small merchant himself. More specifically, when James was trying to sell his hand-made glass project to a customer he was unable to accept credit cards as a form of payment. Capitalizing upon the fact that existing payment systems did not cater towards merchants with small GMVs, McKelvey turned this $2000 lost sale into a $100B+ company by creating payment solutions that were cost-effective, transparent, elegantly designed and easy to use, all aimed at small merchants. Afterpay falls under the same umbrella, solving an issue that Molnar was having with poor sales and capitalizing upon the fact that existing payment methods did not cater towards the spending/financial habits of younger generations (main user cohort of BNPL) in an all-encompassing manner. With both Square and Afterpay connecting merchants and consumers, I couldn’t think of a better addition to the company’s roster, but more on that later. 

For now, let’s take a look at some key trends and happenings that the company intends to benefit from as well as the main demographics they will be catering towards with their product offerings. 

3.0 Opportunity and Demographics

Afterpay undoubtedly has an enormous opportunity in front of them, mainly as a result of the staggering activity that we have seen in the Buy Now Pay Later (BNPL) space. This opportunity, in my opinion, has arisen as a result of the following phenomenon: the rise of e-commerce, an increasing disregard/acceptance of traditional credit card payment systems as well as an associated and proportional increase in trust that many are placing in new-age financial institutions. 

Starting with the rise of e-commerce, there is no doubt that pandemic-induced tailwinds help to spur the adoption of this shopping medium globally. Despite that fact, these trends don’t appear to be going anywhere anytime soon. By 2026 Total Retail Commerce Sales are expected to reach a staggering $6.388T, with the total percentage of retail sales occurring through e-commerce mediums being exacerbated proportionally as a result, expected to reach 21.8%, respectively. The change in these actual values and projections can be seen outlined below:

With these factors in mind, it is evident that payment methods that align with e-commerce processes will be increasingly valuable as use cases continue to evolve. A report conducted by WorldPay, one of the largest payment technology companies in the world, paints a telling picture of where the payment method landscape may end up. More specifically, BNPL was estimated to be the payment method behind approximately 2% of all associated transactions in 2020, and is expected to reach approximately 4% by the end of 2023 [9]. You may be wondering why exactly BNPL has seen such rapid growth, and why it is not anticipated to slow down anytime soon. First-off there has been an ever-increasing prevalence of individuals trusting intermediaries with their financial data, and thus leveraging non-legacy banking systems to cater towards their financial needs. This phenomenon and the change in the relationship between consumer and associated institution, i.e. an open banking systems, can be seen outlined by the image below:

As such, the Fintech Companies and other institutions providing payment methods that would’ve otherwise not been possible decades prior have seen increases in user engagement activity. Secondly, a growing distrust of credit cards may be another spurring factor behind previous and future BNPL growth. With the average credit card debt in the United States coming in at approximately $6,270 [11]  as well as an ever increasing knowledge of the potentially disastrous effects that compounding can have when it acts against you, many are seeking out alternative means of purchasing goods/services that they feel are more transparent. Not only a phenomenon in the United States, this assertion is corroborated further when looking at credit card behavior in Australia, the birthplace of the company and the geographic region that will likely continue to be a large part of Afterpay’s success. More specifically, Personal Credit Cards outstanding in the Country have been on a continuous decline since 2015, despite continuous growth in Retail Sales during the same time frame: 

With these growth trends in mind, we can now analyze the spending habits and demographics the company aims to cater towards. Afterpay’s opportunity at hand is largely contingent on their ability to capitalize upon both the spending habits and the behaviours associated with the demographics of BNPL users in general. Starting off with spending habits , the values attributable to United States citizens, as gauged by the 2020A Retail Spend, by Business Category, can be seen outlined below [14]

With the assumptions that BNPL can cater towards the above types of businesses, this would represent a Total Serviceable Opportunity of approximately 20.08% of Total United States Retail Sales, a value of which I believe largely underestimates the opportunity in front of Afterpay. More specifically, I see no reason for BNPL not to be applied to purchases made within the Auto, Food and Beverage Industries going forwards, a prospect that would increase the size of the Total Serviceable Market in the US alone by a considerable amount. Being that 2020 saw a decrease in the amount of money individuals were directing at Food and Auto expenditures, I have used 2019 values, as outlined below to paint a better picture of what the Afterpay’s TSM were to look like if BNPL were to venture into these areas:

Applied to the Afterpay’s presence within other regions such as Australia and the UK, it is evident that the prospects of using BNPL in the majority of one’s common purchase settings are quite bright. Moving on to the demographics,  the two largest cohorts by gender and by age mix, according to Cardify’s most recent BNPL report, that leverage BNPL transactions can be seen outlined below:

As outlined above, the majority of Afterpay’s consumers, per Cardify will be females in the 19-34 range. With the company’s strong focus on partnering with trendy brands ranging from Revolve to Fenty and Asos, as well as their understanding of the disregard these individuals have for traditional credit systems, Afterpay appears to be poised to capitalize on both these spending and demographic trends, particularly of their young customers. The final factor that is worth discussing is the income mix of the constituents that frequent BNPL services. More specifically, the most common BNPL users in the United States are those with Incomes less than $25,000 (24% of their cohort) and those within the $25,000-$50,000 range (40% of their cohort), respectively [16]. As such, Afterpay will need to cater towards the spending habits of these individuals. In order to maximize GMV generation the company will most likely need to ensure frequent and repeat spending with reasonably small Average Order Values (AOV). In summary, Afterpay is poised to capitalize on the aforementioned tailwinds above and will need to maintain a steady focus on expanding into new verticals (i.e. new products/services BNPL can be used for) and catering towards the above demographics in order to create as much LTV as possible for shareholders.

Now that we have a better understanding of what opportunities, trends and individuals Afterpay aims to capitalize upon and cater towards, let’s take a look at the company offers both consumers and merchants.

4.0 What Afterpay Offers Consumers and Merchants

In order to understand Afterpay’s business we must first split their product and services offerings into two unique and distinct components, those directed at Consumers and others directed at Merchants. The company has a unique value proposition aimed at each of these parties, of which allows for the creation and maintenance of a thriving ecosystem containing both buyers and sellers. 

Consumers 

Put simply, consumers are able to extract value from Afterpay by leveraging the following functionality: convenient payment method, spending tracking and budgeting, and online marketplace. Each of these components creates a sticky customer experience and brand recognition that stands out within the BNPL space, of which can be seen broken down in further detail below.

Convenient Payment Method

The first and arguably one of the most important pieces of the Afterpay Consumer story is how convenient paying with the platform is. More specifically, consumers can execute a payment with Afterpay either through the merchant’s platform as follows [17]:

  1. Add the product you wish to purchase to your cart

  2. Select Afterpay as the payment method at checkout

  3. Login/create your Afterpay account, of which is approved instantly

  4. Complete Purchase. The total owed is then split into four payments, payable over two weeks, across the company’s inherent six-week repayment term. 

If that process seemed simple to you, it’s because it is. More specifically, the manner in which the company provides consumers with access to credit is impressive to say the least. Traditional means of obtaining credit are usually littered with FICO scores, i.e. a rating system  that has been used traditionally to gauge whether credit should be provided to an individual. The FICO system measures how much credit a consumer has, how much of said credit is being used and how often they’ve been able to pay what they owe on time. Therefore, associated application processes are usually tedious. It is therefore evident that Afterpay, as a credit-based payment method, reduces the friction associated with a transaction as a whole in quite a tangible manner. On a side note, Afterpay mitigates some of their credit risk concerns by limiting the amount of credit they issue a consumer on each purchase. More specifically, total credit provided to consumers is usually less than $3000. As an example, when I signed up for Afterpay for the sake of due diligence, I was allotted approximately $600 to be able to spend. The rate at which the total credit made available to me would then increase as time goes on, contingent on my ability to pay back past purchases. The transparency of repayment is a notable spurring factor to creating repeat customers. The four stage process occurs as follows: One instalment at the time of purchase and 3 installments spread across every two weeks of the 6 week term [19]. 

Spending Tracking and Budgeting 

Afterpay’s consumer-directed functionality is focused on maintaining a high degree of freedom and flexibility. More specifically, through the company’s website or app consumers can: 

  • Check their spend limit

  • Reschedule their payments (Afterpay allows for customers to reschedule up to three payment dates per year, shifting them up to five days with each update)

  • Choose how much they pay (although the company has a typical four-instalment repayment process, customers can choose to pay off more or all of their outstanding purchase balance ahead of schedule)

Afterpay’s platform also organizes all purchases under the payment schedule app. An example of this dashboard, from my makeshift Afterpay account, can be seen outlined below:

Online Marketplace

Afterpay is also focused on providing a unique shopping experience to their consumers. More specifically, their platform aggregates a variety of different deals, brands and product categories/themes ranging those sourced from local businesses to others that are focused on maintaining a high degree of sustainability, as examples. A portion of Afterpay’s United States website can be seen below for the sake of illustration. This website, to me represents a great front for consumers and merchants to connect seamlessly, an undeniable value proposition to both parties and the ecosystem as a whole, but more on that later.

Merchants 

Besides providing consumers with a very useful payment method, Afterpay offers merchants an undeniable value proposition as well. When Merchants add Afterpay to their payment options, they’re not only able to provide a more customizable shopping experience, but are also able to reduce the friction associated with purchasing their products, as well as engage in an organic customer acquisition strategy of sorts. Some tangible benefits to allowing Afterpay payments can, per data aggregated over the last few years by the company, can be seen outlined below [22]: 

  • Higher Conversion: On average, Afterpay partners see a 22%+ increase in their cart conversions, as well as higher rates of repeat buying

  • New Customers: Afterpay Merchants, on average report that 30% of the consumers directed at their business via Afterpay are new to their brand entirely

  • Larger Orders: Impressively, Merchants see up to a 40% increase in the AOV of consumer purchases made through Afterpay on their platform 

These benefits are corroborated further when looking at a survey of over a thousand Afterpay-acquainted merchants, of which reported tangible improvements in important metrics, as outlined below:

Integrating with Afterpay is almost risk-free for a merchant. More specifically, companies that partner with the service get paid upfront, i.e. they don’t have to wait for the BNPL loan to get repaid before they receive what they are owed for each purchase. In addition, Afterpay takes on the transaction risk, i.e. the risks associated with chargebacks and fraud, aimed at helping merchants focus on essential business processes rather than the minute details. Lastly, merchants can leverage a series of reporting functionality such as receiving daily settlement reports, where the transactional data contained within can be used to verify orders etc. 

Important is the fact that the integration with Afterpay is seamless. Getting the ball rolling is as simple as filling out a form on Afterpay’s website, as outlined below. Also of note is the fact that Afterpay supports a host of e-commerce and POS providers. The company also offers bespoke solutions for businesses that are equipped with their own developers, indicative of the fact that the company is focused on reducing friction of the integration process.

Lastly, Afterpay created an extra layer of value for Merchants with the addition of Afterpay Ads:

Merchants will be able to extract additional value from the platform by launching ads using a proposed pay-per-performance model. This functionality will allow for businesses to promote deals, products and collections, paying only when an individual engages with the ad. This low-risk opportunity for marketing efforts when coupled with the fact that Afterpay’s Shop Directory generates more than one million referrals per day globally will undoubtedly help businesses grow.

Now that we have a better understanding of what Afterpay offers both consumer and merchant, let’s take a look at how exactly they make money from all of it. 

5.0 How Afterpay makes $$$

Similar to their product/service offering, Afterpay makes money from their interactions with both Consumers and Merchants, each of which can be seen broken down into more detail below. 

Consumers

Although Afterpay plainly states within their help center that their service is free, i.e. meaning that there are no upfront fees charged or any interest incurred, the company makes money from this business segment through late fees associated with the issuance of their BNPL loans. Unlike credit cards with their deceptive late fees and charges, Afterpay’s late fees are crystal clear, with customers being charged $10 if their payment is not processed on or before the due date, and a further $7 being charged subsequently for each week that the balance continues to go unpaid. These fees will then continue until a maximum of 25% of the total order value has been charged to the consumer [26].  

Merchants

Put simply, Afterpay makes money from merchants in a similar manner to other payment processing services, charging merchants for each transaction that occurs through their platform. The company’s fee structure, per their merchant agreement [27], can be seen summarized simply below: 

  • $0.30 flat fee per transaction

  • 4%-6% of the total order value 

For the sake of illustration, let’s take a look at a hypothetical transaction that occurs through Afterpay. Assuming a $250 purchase made by a customer through Afterpay as well as a 5% of order value plus the $0.30 flat fee owed to Afterpay from the merchant, the result can be seen outlined by the following flow diagram:

Afterpay then receives the money they are owed from the BNPL loan they issued to the customer after the six week repayment process has been completed. Afterpay taking on the credit risk of the transaction, i.e. how the merchant gets paid instantly (minus Afterpay’s cut), greatly reduces the friction associated with onboarding the payment method into a merchant’s payment , of which will undoubtedly help merchant growth in the coming quarters continue to thrive. 

6.0 Financial Analysis - FY’21 Earnings

On August 25th, Afterpay released their FY’21 Annual Report. In order to gain insight on how the company is performing, I will be taking a look at some key components of the company’s Income Statement, Balance Sheet and Cash Flow Statements and making a few conclusions and comments based upon the information contained therein. It should be noted that Afterpay, being the Australian company they are, reported their FY’21 earnings in Australian dollars. As such, I converted these values to USD based upon a 1AUD=0.74USD conversion rate I obtained at the time of writing. With all of these factors in mind, let’s dig deeper into Afterpay’s financials. 

Income Statement 

Revenue:

Afterpay’s FY’21 Total Revenue accelerated an impressive 89.54% on a YoY basis, coming in at approximately $684M. The change in this value over the course of the last few fiscal years can be seen outlined below:

The two primary constituents of the company’s Total Revenue are Revenue attributable to Afterpay, Pay Now and Other, respectively. As previously outlined in discussions regarding how Afterpay makes money, Afterpay Revenue is primarily derived from payment processing fees, i.e. the difference between what consumers pay for an item and what the merchant receives from Afterpay. Afterpay also sees slight contributions to their Revenues from late fees, of which is recognized by the Other Revenues metric. Pay Now Revenue is essentially revenue the company generates from facilitating transactions from existing consumers to different forms service model providers. Put simply, this Revenue source can essentially be thought of as referral fees generated through Afterpay’s connections to different entities. The distribution of Total Revenue between Revenue attributable to Afterpay, Other and Pay Now, as well as how this has changed over the last few years, can be seen outlined below:

The above figure highlights the fact that Afterpay’s main source of Revenue will be from merchants, followed closely behind by Other Revenue (late fees). Pay Now revenue as a percentage of Total Revenue has been steadily declining over the last few years. This fact is further corroborated when looking at the fact that management stopped operating their European e-services business unit last year. Therefore, this phenomenon is likely to continue in the coming years as Afterpay continues to focus on their main business strengths. An important revenue-related metric that investors should continue to monitor is Late Fees as a percentage of Afterpay Revenue. This value provides a reference point for gauging how much Revenue is derived from merchants and consumers, and its change on a yearly basis can be seen outlined below:

In order to scale their business while maintaining a high degree of engagement on the consumer side of things, Afterpay will need to continue to derive most of their revenue from merchant sources. The above corroborates this focus, albeit late fee charges may be decreasing as a whole as a result of the macroeconomic environment we are in, i.e. how the presence of low interest rates usually correlates with lower instances of credit defaults/repayment issues all around. Regardless, I believe Afterpay’s focus on obtaining the bulk of their revenue from merchants leads to a healthy business model all around, especially since merchants are very willing to accept a payment processing fee tradeoff for increased AOV, order frequency and higher customer influx.

Cost of Revenue

The company’s Cost of Revenues increased ~85.8% on a YoY basis, coming in at approximately ~$185M for FY’21. The change in these values over the last few fiscal years as well as how they’ve changed with respect to Total Revenues and Afterpay’s Gross Merchandise Value (GMV), can be seen outlined below:

Cost of Revenues and their associated YoY increase was largely spurred by the heightened processing and variables costs associated with increased GMV activity and ecosystem growth. When looking at how these values have changed relative to both Total Revenues and Total GMV, especially how COR has stagnated at sub 30% and 1.2% of each of these metrics, it is evident that Afterpay is scaling with efficiency.

Operating Expenses

Afterpay’s Total Operating Expenses (OPEX) increased approximately 104% on a YoY basis, coming in at ~$221M for FY’21. The change in this value with respect to the last few FY reporting periods can be seen below:

Total OPEX consists of two main components, Marketing Expenses and Other Operating Expenses. The proportion of Total OPEX attributable to each of these sources and how this has changed of late is outlined below:

As the image above clearly depicts, Marketing Expenses are becoming a larger percentage of OPEX as the fiscal years go on. These expenses are primarily attributable to a series of brand awareness campaigns that the company rolled out over the last 12 months, consisting of the Pay Better campaign, customer acquisition efforts and a series of investments directed at both partnerships and visual merchandising. An example star-studded advertisement from the Pay Better campaign can be seen outlined below:

Other OPEX on the other hand primarily consists of costs associated with various business departments ranging from compliance to finance, technology costs and customer services teams. Despite the strong GMV and Total Revenue Growth YoY, these values only increased 71%, indicative of operating efficiencies that the company is reaping with newfound scale.

Quite noticeably, Other OPEX has been decreasing steadily as both the company’s Total GMV and Total Revenues have increased, whereas Marketing Expenses have continued to increase, driving the increase in Total OPEX as a result. As a shareholder in Square, the efforts Afterpay is directing continuously growing their merchant and consumer base via marketing efforts is encouraging to say the least. Although the law of diminishing returns may eventually kick in here, I believe the OPEX profile of Afterpay is exactly where it should be for the time being.

Profitability and Margins

In order to deepen our understanding of both the functionality and the profitability of the business as a whole, the change in the Afterpay’s Gross Profit, Operating Income and EBITDA can be seen outlined below: 

The company’s Gross Profit increased a steady 75.11% YoY, a commendable move in contrast to the 78% increase in Total Revenue, i.e. a healthy increase in both GP and Total Revenues highlights the healthy profile of the company’s costs. Operating Income decreased on a YoY basis, coming in at $(122)M, attributable to the company’s increased marketing efforts as well as a ~100% increase in occurring as a result of increased headcounts. EBITDA decreased by 600% on a YoY basis, attributable primarily to the change in the valuation of the company’s minority interest in Clearpay UK (the company’s BNPL interest in the UK) that occurred as a result of the heightened performance the business saw during that period [27]. 

Gross Profit Margins came in at 73% for the quarter, a (1.51)% decrease on a YoY basis. Although GP is high, it is useful to examine the amount of GP the company is able to extract from their GMV, i.e the value they can extract from total payment volume that occurs on their platform. This value and how its changed over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below, and is illustrative of the similarities between Afterpay and a payment processing company. These values are likely to remain in the 3-5% range in the coming quarters:

EBITDA and Operating Margins both decreased significantly, coming in at approximately (13.18)% and (17.77)% for the quarter, respectively. Overall, the measures and margins outlined above are indicative of where the company is at within their roadmap. Given the significant marketing and expansionary efforts that are likely to continue, I do not anticipate significant profitability or margins that reflect that to be incurred anytime soon.

Balance Sheet

The change in the company’s Asset position can be seen outlined below:

Afterpay’s Assets are primarily liquid, with 85% of the company’s position being of the current variety, of which consist mainly of receivables (i.e. the assets that are owed to the company, of which increased proportionally to GMV), followed closely by Cash and Equivalents. Long Term Assets on the other hand consist primarily of Intangible Assets, followed by Deferred Tax Assets. Afterpay’s Liability structure can be outlined as follows:

Current Liabilities are composed mainly of Trades and Other Payables whereas the company’s Long Term Liabilities are attributable almost solely to Borrowings. More specifically, an ~$1B increase in borrowings was attributable to the issuance of Convertible Notes. Overall the company has a healthy balance sheet. The cash position, when gauged alongside the company’s run-rate, should able to sustain $30B+ in GMV, of which points towards a minimum of a year free of equity/debt raises. 

Cash Flow Statement

The change in the company’s Cash from Operations, Investing and Financing over the last few fiscal years can be seen outlined below:

CFO came in negative for the FY’21 at ~$(423)M. This value is attributable to payments made to merchants and suppliers, of which was offset by receipts from customers. CFI was negative for FY’21 at ~$(82)M, attributable primarily to payments for the development of intangible assets, acquisitions and increases in short-term deposits. CFF was positive for FY’21 at $903M, linked mainly to the issuance of Afterpay Convertible Notes, proceeds from borrowings and issuance of shares, offset primarily by the repayment of borrowings and a US ESOP Cash Settlement. Moving on, the change in the company’s FCF and FCF margin can be seen outlined below:

Although FCF has evidently continued to grow into negative territory proportionally to business scale, these increases are for expansionary efforts and with the company’s cash position as well as their newfound position under Square’s umbrella, I do not anticipate FCF to be a source of hindrance going into and finishing FY’22. 

7.0 Key Performance Indicators 

In order to better understand some key drivers of Afterpay’s success, both in the past and in attempt to foresee potential happenings in the future, we must take a look at some KPIs, of which showcase the inner mechanisms and workings of the company’s business as a whole. Starting off with the company’s GMV, this measure allows for shareholders to gauge the activity on the company’s platform, seeing as it measures the total monetary value of sales facilitated through the platform. Increasing 89.73% on a YoY basis and coming in at ~$15.6B for FY’21, the change in this value can be seen outlined below:

Equally important and undoubtedly a driver of GMV growth as a whole is the rate at which Active Customers and Active Merchants have changed. Afterpay’s Active Customers grew 64% on a YoY basis, coming in at ~12M customers for FY’21. Active Merchants accelerated at a faster rate, improving 77% on a YoY basis, recorded as ~73,000 for FY’21. The change in both of these metrics with respect to time can be seen outlined below: 

Another important metric to gauge is the Take Rate, or in other words how much of Afterpay’s total GMV are they able to convert into Revenue. This value has been steady at around 4% for the last few fiscal years, coming in at 3.9% for FY’21, as outlined below:

This metric reaches a higher degree of importance when viewed alongside the growth in the company’s Active Merchants. The growth in both Active Customers and Active Merchants is important, however, being that the company derives the majority of their Revenues from fees charged to merchants for payment processing, as well as the fact that having more Merchants available to take Afterpay as a payment method should increase customer experience as a result, continued merchant acquisition efforts will be imperative to LTV creation. If Afterpay were to be viewed like a traditional payment processing company, the value proposition for merchants becomes very clear. In order to make a clear comparison, I created my own metric, Payment Processing Take Rate. This was calculated by dividing the company’s Afterpay Revenue Less the effects of Late Fees by Total GMV. As such, this allows for the effect of Revenue only generated from Merchants to be examined with respect to GMV. The change in this value can be seen below:

Payment Processing Take Rate compared to the Average Credit Card Processing Fees of networks can be seen outlined below [27]:

This, to me, paints a clear picture. Merchants can onboard onto the company’s platform, increase their customer influx, AOV and order frequency as a result, while Afterpay takes on the credit risk of the BNPL transactions, all while only paying a few hundred more bps in fees in comparison to traditional credit cards, a win-win so it seems. Moving on, the company’s geographic concentration of GMV, Active Customers and Merchants can be seen outlined below:

The first figure clearly depicts that the company’s GMV is primarily attributable to North America and APAC (Australia). Secondly, the majority of the company’s Active Customers are from North America, followed by Australia, however there have been some noticeable growth in customers in the UK (Clearpay) over the last two Fiscal Years. Lastly, as expected given the fact that Afterpay has its roots down under, the majority of the company’s merchants are in Australia, followed by respectable growth in the US and UK. With these factors in mind, we can take a look at the competition that Afterpay will likely face, specifically from Klarna and Affirm, its two most noticeable peers, in my opinion, as measured by GMV, Active Customers and Merchants:

Starting off with Klarna, this powerhouse is likely to remain the biggest source of competition for Afterpay. The company has a remarkably high GMV as well as well as a stunning number of consumers and merchants, and they also have best-in-class customer acquisition, as indicated by data from a recent Cardify report:

Despite the above phenomena, Klarna falls behind Afterpay in terms of web traffic in the United States whereas the opposite is true in the United Kingdom, as outlined below:

With Affirm, although this company is leveraging a combination of retail hype and partnerships with some of the biggest merchants in the United States, Afterpay is likely to remain ahead in this regard. My reasoning for this is based upon the fact that Afterpay will be introduced into the Square/Cash App ecosystem in the near future, of which will undoubtedly bring more eyes onto the platform, particularly since Square has such a loyal consumer base in the US. In addition, although Affirm is leveraging connections and excitement to their advantage, Afterpay still managed to grow FY’21 GMV at a faster rate on a YoY basis (90% vs 79%), despite having almost 2x the GMV to begin with. When viewed alongside the key geographic distributions of Afterpay’s GMV, merchants and consumers, I believe that the best route for success is for Afterpay to maintain their competitive advantage in both the US and Australia. With the company’s best-in class brand recognition I do not anticipate that this will be a hard feat to accomplish: 

Lastly, it is important for shareholders to monitor the amount of credit losses the company incurs. This metric, reported by Afterpay as Gross Loss, highlights Afterpay’s ability to scale while not becoming fragile as an expense in the face of looming credit risk. The fact that the company was able to maintain steady Gross Loss as % of Total Revenue and GMV while expanding more heavily into the US and UK (less mature markets than Australia) is impressive to say the least. The improvement in these values evidently benefit from the current macroeconomic environment, i.e. low interest rates usually lead to less credit defaults all around, therefore it is worth watching this value alongside macroeconomic happenings in the future Fiscal Years to assess Afterpay’s overall health:

8.0 What Afterpay adds to Square

When completing research on Square, I came across an interesting article, one that discusses the tale of Square Wallet, a failed venture in the company’s past that many are not aware of [29].  This app was launched in 2011 and was originally designed to allow customers to quickly pay for purchases with only their smartphone. 

The app, despite having made a partnership with Starbucks at the time, failed to catch on. The root cause of this technology’s failure is still up for debate, however it is clear that this product’s tech stack was not enticing enough to consumers or merchants to result in the abolishment of spending in a traditional manner with one’s credit card.  Being that as it may, this effort, in my eyes, represents the first instance of Square attempting to make a closed payment system. As we all know, Square is the operator of two amazingly successful business segments, the Seller Ecosystem and Cash App. Despite neither of these business segments struggling with growth or finding unique manners to organically acquire customers, there has rarely been a reason or spurring factor to mesh both of these partitions together. This phenomenon can be observed when looking at past investor presentations, particularly with Square stating they are growing two unique ecosystems, a statement that showcases an evident disparity between each segment.

Delving deeper, Square is evidently able to extract value from the merchants involved with the Seller Ecosystem, as well as from consumers that utilize Cash App. Primarily earning revenue from charging Sellers a fee on each transaction made utilizing Square’s tech, as well as from fees directed at individuals that have either sent, spent or invested money using Cash App, it is obvious that Square is able to earn money from either side of a transaction, never both sides. This is where the idea of a closed loop payment system comes in. Loosely defined as a transaction that occurs between the buyer and the seller, with no other middle part involved, this system is a holy grail of sorts within the Fintech industry. Open-loop payment systems, of which most of us interact with on a frequent basis, operate in an opposite manner, facilitating the interaction between consumer and merchant, distributing small percentages of the total transaction by way of fees to different intermediaries. An exemplary open-loop system can be seen outlined below:

Recent efforts corroborate my assertion that Square is working on building a closed-loop payment system, an ambition that, if successful, will provide an opportunity to capture the full payment processing fee pie when a buyer and seller exchange funds. The first is Cash App Pay, a new app feature that will allow for consumers to utilize their Cash App accounts to pay for goods/services at select Square Sellers. This process doesn't require the intermediary payment processing rails to speak (i.e. Mastercard, Visa) and thus is a closed-loop payment system of sorts. The second effort, of which has been the subject of this report, is Square’s metaphorical adoption of Afterpay. To me this represents an obvious way for Square to connect consumers and merchants together in a way that would not be possible before the acquisition, with the dynamics of a BNPL network resulting in spurious and increased interactions between each party. When combined with Cash App, one can ponder the directions that Square is likely to push the app towards alongside Afterpay. The most obvious in my opinion is the intertwinement of Afterpay with Cash App. More specifically, in order to strengthen the engagement with the Square ecosystem as a whole, I see no reason for the company not to allow for repayments of BNPL loans to occur using Cash App. With Cash App having over 40M monthly transacting users and Afterpay having close to 12M Active Consumers and 70,000+ Merchants to shop from, it is exciting to think about the growth increased adoption that will occur when Afterpay’s Network combines with Cash App’s ecosystem. These efforts, when combined, will allow for Afterpay to generate revenue from Afterpay-related Cash App usage, i.e. the repayment of a BNPL loan with Cash App and from transaction fees paid by merchants for each Afterpay transaction. Many have stated that Square may have overpaid for this acquisition, however, when I think about the organic growth that this partnership will cause, I see unfathomable value here.

The second reason that I think this acquisition will have tangible effects on Square’s growth is international expansion. When looking at International Revenue as a % of Total Net Revenue (for Square), this value has managed to remain under 5% over the last few quarters, as outlined below:

When looking at Afterpay’s GMV on the other hand, the company derives approximately 90% of Total GMV, approximately 45% each, from the US and Australia, followed by approximately 10% from the UK. When the two ecosystems intersect it is likely to have a twofold effect. The first will be strengthening Square’s stronghold on the United States. We know from previous discussions that the company trumps both Klarna and Affirm in the US but it is also worth noting that Cash App overshadows its close competitor, Paypal’s Venmo, as corroborated by Google Search Interest below: 

The combination of the two is likely to create an interesting payment-technology landscape in the US. Secondly, Afterpay’s incorporation with the Square ecosystem is likely to further the company’s international efforts, particularly in Australia (since Klarna largely overshadows the presence of Clearpay in the UK this acquisition may have marginal effects in that region). In summary I believe the Afterpay acquisition has a twofold effect on Square as a whole. First, they will be able to leverage the strong Network Effects of Afterpay to gorilla glue their two business segments together. Second, they will be able to expedite International Expansion while also increasing the distance between competitors, both within the BNPL space and beyond within the US. I am truly a fan of this decision to acquire Afterpay.

9.0 Conclusion

In summary, Square is a behemoth of a business that has only been made stronger with the addition of Afterpay into its ecosystem. With a Seller-focused segment that has yet to experience serious competition, Cash App bolstering strong customer adoption and sticky associated use-cases (P2P money transfer, investing and spending) and Afterpay cementing Square as a bank of the future with its exposure to a fast-moving payment method that is taking the world by storm, it is quite easy to be a Square shareholder. So concludes the second part of my Square research. I hope you learned as much about each of its components reading these two pieces as I did writing them. Thank you for reading.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, comment below and share!

Share

If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

item.title: Affirm Holdings, Inc. ($AFRM)
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to MT Capital Research! If you’re new, join a group of 1835 Informed Investors who receive weekly reports on the World’s Most Interesting Tech Companies by subscribing below:

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an in-depth analysis on Affirm Holdings, Inc. where in I will discuss the company’s opportunity and associated value proposition, break down their products and services as well as discuss some key happenings, both positive and risk-based alike, that current and potential investors should be wary of.

The format of this report, broken down into each respective section, can be seen outlined below. As always, feel free to skip ahead to the sections that you feel will be most useful:

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Opportunity

3.0 Products and Services

4.0 How Affirm makes $$$

5.0 Financial Analysis - Q4 FY’21 Earnings

6.0 Key Performance Indicators

7.0 Positive Developments

8.0 Risk Factors

9.0 Conclusion

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitute for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investments.

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content and analysis, give me a follow on Twitter! 

Follow Me!

With all of that considered, let’s get started. 

1.0 Introduction

Affirm Holdings, Inc. of which I will denote as Affirm for the entirety of this report, can be most easily described as a provider of digital and mobile-first commerce solutions, primarily within the United States and Canada.  The company’s inherent payment network, of which connects (through partnerships) to origination banks, provides customers with a unique opportunity to pay for a purchased item over a period ranging from 1-60 months. The company has integrated thousands of merchants ranging from small businesses to large enterprise brands across varieties of industries on its platform, and has created a web and mobile-based ecosystem that offers interesting value propositions to both consumers and businesses.

Now that we have a rough understanding of what Affirm does and offers customers, let’s take a look at the value propositions that the company aims to capitalize upon in the years to come. 

2.0 Opportunity 

In order to understand the solutions Affirm provides customers via their products, we must first understand the underlying themes, trends and problems the company aims to both capitalize on and address, respectively. The first and arguably the most important happening that the company aims to align their offerings with, and benefit from in general, is the rapid rise of e-commerce. A report conducted by Insider Intelligence highlights the sheer breadth of global e-commerce, with the 2021 global retail e-commerce sales expected to come in at approximately $4.9T, as outlined below:

Despite this value’s enormity, when looked at from the perspective of a % of total retail sales, e-commerce is still only anticipated to account for 20% of all retail sales transactions. Despite having accelerated at a breakneck pace from 2019 to 2020, these values, to me, are illustrative of a continued opportunity for growth. With almost every business starting or maintaining an e-commerce presence, combined with some key demographic happenings and behaviours, continued growth appears to be inevitable. In 2021 alone it was estimated that cohorts within younger generations, particularly Gen Z and Millennials, conduct almost 65% of their total shopping online, with 34% of their total purchases being conducted through mobile-app mediums. In short, the future looks bright for products that facilitate and encourage e-commerce purchases. 

Anyone who has followed the Fintech industry as of late understands the activity we have seen in the Buy Now Pay Later (BNPL) space. BNPL can be defined, loosely, as POS instalment loans that allow customers to purchase products and then pay for them at a later date. Customers typically make an upfront payment towards the item and then pay for the rest of the balance in an equal number of predetermined instalments [3]. This payment method is expanding rapidly, a happening which intersects perfectly with the rapid rise of e-commerce. Of the total global e-commerce transactions, 2.1% were estimated to be attributable to BNPL sources, with this value expected to reach 4% by 2024 [4].  When considering the sheer magnitude of the GMV (Gross Merchandise Volume) that would result from 2-4% of global e-commerce transactions occurring via BNPL mediums, this is an exciting prospect.

Affirm also aims to capitalize on the lack of transparency within the financial services and payment industry. This effort, to me, aligns very well with some of the core lessons that were prevalent within the Innovation Stack by James McKelvey. The book, though largely a tale centered around the rise of Square Inc., one of the largest Fintech companies in the world, told a similar tale of the lack of transparency within the aforementioned industries. More specifically, a large part of Square’s success can be attributed to their product offerings catering to underserved individuals, those of which were largely overlooked by some of the largest corporations in the world. By building products that had no hidden fees, pleasant user experiences and were not associated with strict terms, conditions or lock-in periods/contracts, Square excelled. Moving back to Affirm, the company aims to capitalize on similar issues and accelerate their business accordingly.  Differing is the fact that the company is trying to repair the issues that consumers have with standard debit and credit cards. To put things into perspective, in the latter half of 2020 it was estimated that consumers had paid $104B in late charges for the Trailing Twelve Months (TTM) a value that had increased 11% from 2018 and almost 29% from 2013 [5].  In addition, it was estimated that Americans owe nearly $806B in credit card debt across 500M unique credit cards [6]. With the nature of credit cards in general, and how there is almost an incentivization of sorts to let debt compound against you by way of only making minimum payments, there exists an evident need for payment methods that don’t generate revenue at the expense of the individual’s financial wellbeing. 

A telling survey paints a potential picture for the direction the Financial Services Industry may be heading. More specifically, a 2020 Fintech study performed by PWC showcased the increasing rate at which Americans are trusting technology companies with their financial data, as well as the fact that individuals are more likely than ever to purchase financial products from said technology companies instead of legacy financial institutions [8]. Lastly, the merchant is often left out of the payment solution equation. With the cost of customer acquisitions increasing on all ends, and retention being a nightmare of sorts that merchants commonly try to solve with promotions, aggressive sales, and expensive digital marketing campaigns, there is an untapped avenue for solutions that help merchants direct an influx of new customers their way. As such, tech companies that are able to provide sustainable, scalable and fair financial solutions to underserved consumers and merchants may be at the forefront of an enormous revolution in the payments space. Affirm and its associated BNPL solutions aim to be that company.

Now that we have an understanding of the opportunity and the problems Affirm aims to capitalize upon, let’s take a look at the products and services they offer both consumers and merchants. 

3.0 Products and Services

As previously mentioned, Affirm caters towards both consumers and merchants. As such, product offerings will be split into each of these segments accordingly, and comments will be made discussing the manner in which they fit together to create Affirm’s unique network. 

Consumers

The main consumer-centered features and functionality of Affirm’s product can be seen outlined below: 

Checkout: Consumers, when they are shopping with approved merchants, have the option to choose Affirm as a payment method, similar to how they would choose PayPal or credit/debit card at checkout via traditional mediums. Checking out with Affirm is a simple and easy to digest process. For the sake of analytical clarity, lets navigate through an illustrative example of using Affirm to complete a purchase through a hypothetical merchant. The first stage of the process consists of the consumer selecting Affirm at checkout on the associated website, then prompting entrance of a phone number for secure log-in/sign-up purposes, as outlined below: 

Next, the consumer enters some Personal Identification Information ranging from their address to SSN in order to gauge whether or not they are eligible for an Affirm loan: 

Lastly, the customer will then be shown a series of payment plan options, all of which have different repayment time periods, interest rates (either 0% or a fixed rate each month that doesn’t compound) etc., and then will be able to complete their purchase using Affirm: 

Virtual Card: This product is essentially a unique, BNPL-integrated, debit card so to speak, one in which only exists in the world of bits. In essence, consumers can apply for a loan of a fixed amount, either through the Affirm application or on Affirm’s website, which on approval, gets loaded onto a one-time-use visa debit card. 

This product, which is an evident example of ingenuity and smart ecosystem growth tactics, allows for consumers to use Affirm-branded functionality with merchants that have not fully integrated with the Affirm system themselves. Upon the completion of their purchase with the virtual card, consumers would then pay back the amount spent in a similar manner to loans originated with the product’s Checkout functionality. 

Affirm App and Marketplace: Within the Affirm App consumers are offered deals and discounts, based upon their shopping habits, shown new brands and popular storefronts, as well as given the option to browse merchants within different niches. 

Aimed at keeping customers engaged within the application ecosystem, consumers can navigate and view affirm-approved merchants within the apparel, automotive, electronics, health and wellness and luxury industries, as examples. In addition, consumers are given the option to exercise greater control over their existing BNPL loans by viewing remaining balances and setting reminder dates in order to avoid missing payments, as outlined below: 

Savings Account: Affirm offers consumers a no-minimum, no-fee, 0.65% APY savings account, all of which can be accessed through either Affirm’s website or app. 

Before moving on to what Affirm offers their Merchants, we must first understand arguably the most important of the company’s value propositions. Despite, to many, seeming only like a company that facilitates alternative payment methods or loans, Affirm labels themselves first and foremost technology company. As a technology company, Affirm has engineered a solution that sets themselves apart from traditional credit underwriting models, allowing them to support an ever growing GMV, originating loans at a breakneck pace while also ensuring they are not becoming fragile in exposure to ever-looming credit default risk. All of this functionality is achieved through their inherent risk model. More specifically, this model, of which relies on a sea of data points, operates at the transaction level rather than relying on standard and outdated credit scores. As such, the company is able to offer attractive financing rates to customers that would have otherwise been turned away by legacy lending systems, while also decreasing the prevalence of delinquencies. In summary, Affirm’s risk model facilitates more loans all while negating risk in the process. And the best part is, the more data points the company receives the better this model will behave, theoretically. 

Merchants 

Despite evidently catering towards their customer base well, Affirm’s platform offers a series of benefits to merchants as well as a seamless onboarding process, of which can be seen outlined below:

  • Choose a Customized Solution: Merchants have the option to choose which BNPL payment option works best for their business. More specifically merchants can choose whether consumers can purchase products with either 0% APR or payment plans with fixed interest installments each month. 

  • Support a variety of Process Mediums: Whether a merchant would like to conduct business via e-commerce, in-store or through tele-sales mediums, Affirm supports these business decisions. Affirm allows for the easy integration within an e-commerce site, encourages signage/displays to be placed in brick and mortar environments that catch the eye of customers and allows for consumers to be served over the phone without the need for the handling of confidential data, respectively. 

  • Mitigate Risk: Affirm helps reduce the risks associated with conducting business. More specifically, the company helps reduce the prevalence of chargebacks and frauds and also ensures that merchants receive payments within 1-3 days of conducting purchases. In other words, despite the merchant offering customers BNPL options, Affirm takes on the risks associated with those transactions, ensuring merchants get paid no matter what. 

Once merchants have been integrated with the Affirm ecosystem, they’re offered a series of technological capabilities that ensure stickiness is maintained to the umpteenth degree. This functionality can be seen outlined below: 

  • Merchant Dashboard: Through Affirm’s Merchant Dashboard, individuals are able to configure their account, view transaction data, manage their account and online storefront and much more. 

  • Analytics: Merchants can optimize their customer acquisition and conversion campaigns by leveraging data to generate key insights. Individuals have the options to see how certain products are performing as well as take a look into the purchasing habits of their customers. 

  • Client Support: Affirm merchants have access to a team of client support specialists of whom help resolve inquiries that can range from resolving account issues to helping with business performance reporting and assisting with new product launches. 

  • Affirm Documentation: Being that Affirm supports the ability to integrate their solutions via APIs and SDKs into individual’s e-commerce websites etc., they have a rich library of dev-friendly documentation that answers any software-engineering related questions that may arise. 

  • Return Management: Through Affirm’s acquisition of Returnly in 2021, the company helps merchants settle product returns in a seamless manner. The company issues a merchant credit immediately upon refund request, of which can be used to purchase a new product instead of waiting days for a traditional refund to be processed. This results in higher customer satisfaction and an increased-rate of purchases/revenue generation made upon issuance of a refund. 

These features help drive conversion at each stage of the customer life-cycle, of which can be seen described in more detail below: 

  • Accelerate Awareness: When a merchant partners with Affirm they then gain access to the company’s network of more than 6M shoppers. Merchants can tap into an avenue of marketing and associated revenue acceleration that would otherwise not be possible via traditional channels. More specifically, merchants can situate a link to their business on Affirm’s high-traffic website, accelerate product launches by being included in Affirm emails to their customer base, tap into organic social media growth and boost awareness by partnering with broad networks of affirm-friendly influencers. 

  • Accelerate Consideration: Affirm’s technology provides tools ranging form prequalification, i.e. showing customers the BNPL loans they would qualify for through a merchant before the checkout process even occurs, and dynamic price messaging, i.e. messages being sent to customers on the app or website mediums that provide details on potential upgrades and bundles that the merchant is offering, all aimed at increasing Average Order Value (AOV). 

  • Accelerate Conversion: Affirm leverages their Adaptive Checkout capabilities in order to spur increased conversions. More specifically, at checkout Affirm’s technology provides a series of payment options that are curated to the user’s profile, an intelligently designed conversion method aimed at giving customers more reasons to say yes to a purchase. 

With all of these factors considered, both revolved around Consumers and Merchants respectively, Affirm paints an interesting value proposition. More specifically, the more engaged customers are with the ecosystem, the better it is for merchants, and vice-versa. This creates an elegant network effect associated with Affirm’s ecosystem, of which can be seen outlined below: 

Now that we have a better understanding of what Affirm offers both consumers and merchants, let’s take a look at how exactly the company makes money from it.

4.0 How Affirm makes $$$

Similar to Affirm’s product offerings, the manner in which Affirm generates Revenue from their business can be split into two segments, Consumers and Merchants. 

Consumers

Affirm primarily makes money within the Consumer segment by way of the issuance of loans. More specifically, Affirm earns interest income on the loans they direct at their customers, of which are originated by their bank partners, Cross River Bank and Celtic Bank, FDIC-insured banks located in the state of New Jersey and Utah, respectively [17].  In essence, the company purchases the loan from their originator banks, paying a fee that is equal to the principal interest of the loan, a fee for each loan purchase and any accrued interest, i.e. the amount of loan interest that has already occurred since inception but that has not been paid back to the borrower. In addition, the originating banks also receive a small performance fee from Affirm when the loan has been fully repaid by the customer. Therefore, put simply, Affirm earns money from the interest generated on these loans, less the accrued expenses, a fee for the loan purchase and the performance fee due upon loan payback. Also worth noting is the fact that Affirm is capable of originating their own loans using associated licenses in both Canada and the United States. This process, although it avoids the aforementioned costs, has only accounted for a small portion of total loans issued over the last few years and is likely to stay that way in the near future. 

Affirm also earns money from consumers through the Virtual Cards segment of their business. More specifically, the company keeps a portion of the interchange fee that occurs whenever a customer utilizes one of these cards in a transaction. In order to fully understand the extent of the company’s moving pieces, how Affirm makes money from Virtual Cards should prove sufficient. Within a Virtual Card transaction, Affirm will underwrite a loan, set the terms (i.e. payback period, APR % etc.). The company will then obtain revenue from a portion of the interchange fee that occurs as a result of the transaction. Affirm will then leverage their connection to an origination bank in order to send a loan to the consumer, which results in Affirm having to purchase said loan from the bank as well as pay the institution an origination fee. The merchant will receive the sum from the bank in the amount of the total purchase value less the fee that Affirm charges merchants per transaction. In addition, Affirm will then collect any interest from the loan depending on what the APR terms are.

Merchants

Affirm earns Revenue in this segment by charging merchants for every transaction that their network, and by association their product/services, helps facilitate. The company doesn’t mention what these fees work out to be in terms as a % of the total transaction value, however, in my opinion, an educated guess would land somewhere in the 2-4% range.

5.0 Financial Analysis - Q4 FY’21 Earnings

The highlights of Affirm’s Q4 FY’21 earnings will be analyzed from this point onwards. Insights will be drawn with regards to the company’s income statement, balance sheet and cash flow statements, respectively. 

Income Statement: 

Revenue

The company’s Total Net Revenue accelerated an impressive 71% on a YoY basis, coming in at ~$262M. The change in this value with respect to previous quarters can be seen outlined below: 

Affirm’s Total Net Revenue can be broken down into two primary constituents, Total Network Revenue, of which includes Merchant Network Revenue and Virtual Card Network Revenue, as well as Revenue generated from the company’s loan activities, which includes Interest Income, Gain on Sales of Loans and Servicing Income. Starting with Total Network Revenue, this value increased 23% on a YoY basis, of which was driven by a 4% YoY growth in Merchant Network Revenue and a 614% YoY Growth in Virtual Card Network Revenue, although the latter is inflated due to favorable comps. The change in Total Network Revenue over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

This metric, evidently showcases the amount of value Merchants find in Affirm’s platform and has been consistently steady, a positive sign when considered alongside the effects of seasonality. Although Virtual Card Network Revenue will likely always be the smaller constituent of Total Network Revenue, it is worth noting the sum of the whole attributable to this segment has been steadily improving over the last few quarters: 

Although the company doesn’t officially report this value, I have summed Interest Income, Gain of Sale on Loans as well as Servicing Income into an all-encompassing value, which I will denote as Loan Revenue, in order to gauge how Affirm’s business segments are performing with respect to each other. The change in this value over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

Increasing 135% on a YoY basis, the increased activity related to Loans was primarily driven by a 268% increase on the Gain on Sale of Loans, followed by a 111% and 60% YoY increase in Interest and Servicing Income, respectively. How these constituents have changed relative to Total Loan Revenue can be seen outlined below: 

Affirm evidently benefited from increased Loan Selling activity, a value that will likely continue to rise proportionally to GMV. Regardless, the company’s primary source of Revenue in this segment will continue to be Interest Income, especially since Affirm will not be able to cater towards every merchant with 0% APR rates. Lastly, the breakdown of Total Revenue into its primary components and how this changed over time can be seen below: 

Thus, it is quite evident that Affirm is first and foremost a company that makes money from loans, followed closely by the money they are able to extract from merchants from both transactions and interchange fees.

Revenue Less Transaction Costs

Acting as a GP of sorts, the company’s Revenue less Transaction Costs is an important gauge of how Affirm is performing. More specifically, looking at Net Revenue less the costs of generating, processing and servicing, preparing for losses etc. associated with said Revenue is an important gauge of the scalability of the company’s business model. This metric is indicative of prosperous activities in my opinion, as outlined by the change in the value below. It should be noted that the negative value incurred in Q3 FY’20 was a result of factoring in higher credit losses as a result of the macroeconomic stressors brought on by the pandemic. 

Operating Expenses

Despite the 71% increase in Total Net Revenue on a YoY basis, the change in Total Operating Expenses exceeded that of its counterpart, increasing 247% Respectively. How this value has changed over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

Despite a portion of this value rising to the proportionally to the an activity increase within Affirm’s ecosystems, a large majority of this OPEX increase occurred as a steep rise in share-based compensation (SBC). SBC as a percentage of Total OPEX and how this relationship has changed over time can be seen outlined below: 

This steep rise in SBC occurred as a result of Affirm’s increase in headcount, which changed from 893 employees to 1,641 employees. Although aligning new employees with the interests of the business via equity is understandable, a 2410% increase in SBC as a result is steep. Regardless, shareholders should keep any eye on this going forwards, especially since the company intends to keep increasing headcount into 2022 [17]. 

Extremely important, and quite frankly amazing, is how the company’s provision for credit losses have changed over the last few quarters. More specifically, their rapid decrease, 191% decrease YoY to be exact,  is testament to the overall effectiveness of Affirm’s risk models. This is ML/AI 101, the more data points the Affirm models get fed, the better they should theoretically perform, an exciting value proposition when one thinks about the rate at which the company is capable of scaling with strong ecosystem growth. 

Moving on, how the company’s Technology and Data Analytics (T&D), General and Administrative (G&A) and Sales and Marketing (S&M) have changed is important to gauge where management’s head is relative to operations. 

The increase in these values on a YoY basis was primarily attributable to the increased headcounts, activities and obligations that come with becoming a publicly traded company. More important, in my opinion, is the change in S&M and T&D relative to total OPEX, as outlined below:

The former’s value has continually increased over the last few quarters.  Being that the general activity of Affirm’s business, particularly their AOV and GMV, is directly reliant on consumer engagement, a headfast continuation of strong marketing efforts will be imperative to sustainable ecosystem growth, thus investors should not be too concerned about this increase. The latter will be essential to being able to increase the amount of GMV in a responsible manner. More specifically, an upmost focus will need to continue to be made on Affirm’s risk models, of which helps ensure Affirm’s provision for Credit losses stay low as a result of lower credit defaults and charge offs. Affirm’s ability to detect fraud ensures sustainable scale and it appears that the company is maintaining a strong focus on this. These efforts are obviously working, and I would like to see this nose to the grindstone focus continue. 

Profitability

In order to gauge the profitability of Affirm, let’s take a look at both the company’s Operating and Net Income and EBITDA as well as their associated margins.  The change in these values over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

The change in associated margins paints largely the same tale, as seen in the following image: 

Quite evidently, Affirm is not profitable by any stretch of the imagination. The company is focused on expanding their business, and with expansion comes expenses. I do not anticipate these values to improve in the coming quarters judging by the extent of the company’s growth initiatives they have underway. 

Balance Sheet

The company’s Asset Position, as of Q4 FY’21 can be seen outlined in the following table:

The company’s assets are reasonably liquid, with Current Assets consisting primarily of Cash and Equivalents and Accounts Receivable. Long Term Assets are mainly in the form of Loans held for Investment (i.e. loans Affirm intends to hold until payoff) and Commercial Agreement Assets. The structure of Affirm’s liabilities can be seen outlined below:

The company’s liabilities are predominantly illiquid, with Current Assets consisting of only small amounts of Accounts payable and Accrued Expenses. Long Term liabilities on the other hand align primarily with the company’s lending operations and Funding Debt. More specifically, the company owes more than a billion dollars to third party entities that purchase loans from originating banks. Affirm utilizes very little of their own equity within their lending operations. More specifically, Affirm is able to handle their large GMV with ease because they leverage funds from third parties in order to satisfy the loan requirements of customers. Taking all of these factors into consideration, the company’s balance sheet aligns well with its operations and doesn’t appear to be a potential source of hindrance going forwards.

Cash Flow Statement 

The change in the company’s Cash Flow from Operations, Investments and Financing, over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below:

CFO was slightly negative at ~$(20)M this quarter, attributable primarily to the company’s Net Loss and Purchase of Loans held for sale, offset by mainly by Proceeds from the sale of loans, SBC, Gain on Sale of Loans and Credit Loss Provisions and accrued expenses. CFF was negative at ~$(178)M for the quarter attributable primarily to the proceeds from funding debt, offset by the repayments of debt funding. CFI was slightly positive at ~$84M, attributable to principal payments and loan servicing activity, offset by purchases and originations of loans. The change in the company’s Free Cash Flow and FCF margin on a quarterly basis can be seen outlined below: 

The company is evidently FCF negative and will likely stay that way judging by their aggressive expansion efforts. With the recent IPO in mind, it doesn’t appear likely that Affirm will require a cap raise to fund operations, at least for the next few quarters, in my opinion.  

6.0 Key Performance Indicators

In order to fully understand how the company is performing, let’s take a look at some key KPIs that can be used to gauge how well the company is performing. The first and arguably the most important gauge of the level of interaction within the company’s ecosystem is GMV. This metric, defined as the total amount of transactions that occur on the platform, net refunds, in my opinion shows how satisfied both Merchants and Consumers are with the platform. With this metric improving on a QoQ basis over the last four quarters as well as the 125% increase YoY, Affirm’s business is evidently accelerating, as outlined below:

The growth in the company’s consumer base can also be honed in on by way of the total number of Active Consumers (consumer with at least one transaction on the platform in the TTM).  The change in this value over the last few quarters can be seen below: 

Increasing 97% on a YoY basis, Affirm is evidently bolstering strong consumer engagement. Although this value is slightly inflated as a result of acquisitions, of which brought an incremental 1.1M customers into the consumer ecosystem, this metric still increased 66% on a YoY basis without this effect taken into account, an impressive feat.
