Active Consumers have also been engaging at a more frequent basis, as measured by Transactions per Active Consumer (amount of purchases made per consumer, on average, over the TTM). The change in this value can be seen outlined below: 

Future consumer engagement and overall health of Affirm’s business will be dictated largely by the amount of merchants they are able to onboard into the ecosystem. The number of the customers merchants increased by 418% on a YoY basis, largely driven by partnerships with Williams Sonoma, Dick’s Sporting Goods, Neiman Marcus and Shop Pay, of which helped to add 23,000 active merchants to the platform. The change in active merchants over the last few quarters can be seen below: 

Lastly, an important metric I will continue to track is how the company is dealing with delinquencies. This, to me, highlights the effectiveness of Affirm’s model to deem the credit-worthiness of customers as well as their ability to scale their loan operations without being vulnerable to customers that cannot pay back what they were loaned. The model, as it gets fed more data points, has been continuously improving, as outlined below. This is an evidently encouraging sign going forwards into an ever-growing Affirm consumer base. 

7.0 Positive Developments

Technological prowess of Affirm aside, I believe the efforts the company is making with regards to building a super-app are astronomical and are most definitely worth taking note of. These happenings, in my opinion, makeup the majority of the value proposition that longs are taking into consideration here with Affirm. Digging into the specifics, the four main points I would like to touch on that can be thought of as additives to the existing capabilities and functionality I outlined earlier in this report, are Returnly, PayBright, Affirm Debit and Affirm Crypto. 

In May of this year Affirm finalized their acquisition of Returnly, a fintech company that focuses on providing consumers with frictionless and seamless return experiences. Returnly treats returns as a transaction of sorts, allowing these occurrences to be processed instantly, providing consumers with quick access to merchant credit in the case where they were not satisfied with the original purchase.  This acquisition not only brought new technological capabilities into the Affirm ecosystem, but brought new consumers and merchants with it, being that Returnly, as of May, serves over 1,800 merchants and has been used by 8M shoppers [20]. In December of 2020, Affirm announced their intent to acquire PayBright, one of Canada’s premier BNPL companies. This acquisition not only represents a great opportunity for Affirm to extend its reach outside of the US but also gives Affirm access to some of the biggest merchants in the world. More specifically, customers have access, through Paybright, to BNPL transactions at Apple, Wayfair, Sephora and more. Although these acquisitions, as of right now have only accounted for an additional 1.85% in GMV as of the end of FY’21, these acquisitions in my eyes are important for two reasons. Firstly, via Returnly, the company increases the stickiness of their ecosystems and reduces the friction associated with making purchases on their platform. There is nothing worse than returning products in the traditional sense of the deed, therefore, customers knowing that purchasing products has now been made risk-free and painless, should help GMV and Total Network Revenue going forwards. Secondly, PayBright is most exciting to me because of their connection to Apple. This tech mega-company is intertwined with almost all of our lives (as I type on this my mac) and the incorporation of BNPL with Apple as a merchant creates an interesting value proposition. With this partnership existing in Canada, one can only imagine the GMV growth that would occur if this partnership were to extend into the US as well. Smart acquisitions like this make a lot of sense for Affirm and it highlights the fact the company is willing to acquire in order to climb higher up the totem pole, so to speak. 

Moving on to some internal developments, the company is evidently working on rolling out products that increase the activity in their ecosystem and stickiness overall. Starting of with the Affirm debit+ card. Customers will be able to use the physical debit card to pay online or in stores. Affirm will them notify the consumer after the transaction has been completed if they are eligible to have said purchase split up and paid back over time. This card operates with a Consumer’s existing checking account, and reduces friction as a result of customers not needing to alter their existing bank relationships. This poses an interesting value proposition to consumers as it has no fees to open or maintain, can split bigger purchases into smaller ones, and can be used anywhere (not just affirm approved merchants), thus penetrating its way into consumer’s everyday in-store spending habits. For merchants, this offers the opportunity to tailor-fit deals and promotions to customers based upon associated purchasing data. 

Moving over to crypto, customers will soon have the ability to purchase different digital currencies utilizing the Affirm app. 

These new product/feature roll-outs most definitely create the feeling that the company is working on building a “Super App”. This fact is only further corroborated when looking at the Apptopia report comparing Affirm with its 4 most prevalent BNPL Peers (Klarna, Afterpay, Zip, Sezzle).  Out of all these companies, Affirm had both the happiest and stickiest users, an exciting proposition judging by the fact that new product features outlined above have not been officially rolled out yet. 

With Affirm’s Net Promoter Score (NPS), an important measure that measures how likely a customer is to recommend the product to a peer, remaining best in-class at 83, Affirm again stands out amongst its competitors, as outlined by the sentiment comparison below, and the new features they are rolling are likely to only increase this phenomenon:

Moving on, Affirm’s partnerships with Shopify, Amazon and Walmart, and Target will be large components of growth going forwards. 

Initiated in July of 2020, the Shopify x Affirm partnership allowed for the e-commerce giant’s merchants to offer BNPL payment options to their consumers, if they desired. Of Affirm’s Active Merchant Base, thousands are attributable to Shopify’s merchants. Not only has this already increased Total Network Revenue and GMV, but when combined with the eventual Affirm Debit+, the company will have made some notable progress on spurring shopping behavior associated with higher frequency and lower AOVs in comparison to the majority of purchases made within their ecosystem today. 

With respect to Amazon, Affirm announced that they had entered into a partnership with the Giant in order to provide customers access to BNPL payment options for orders of more than $50. This partnership, though in its initial stages and only being made available to select customers at the moment, will be an undeniable source of growth for the company. By focusing on higher ticket purchases, Affirm will be able to leverage Amazon’s millions of customers in conjunction with reasonably high AOV to generate large magnitudes of value. 

In addition, although Affirm had already been partners with Walmart since 2019, there were a series of headways that have been made with respect to the magnitude of this arrangement. More specifically, in the latter half of September, Walmart announced that they had done away with their layaway program, replacing it with a BNPL payment option provided by Affirm [26]. The activity that Affirm will see in their ecosystem as a results of these two partnership is sure to generate LTV and a nice bump in their numbers. With Amazon and Walmart possessing a large share of total consumer retail spending by quarter, as well as the fact that BNPL drives higher instances of repeat buying in comparison to spending with a traditional credit card, it is easy to see why so many are excited about Affirm’s growth trajectory. 

Of additional note, Affirm announced yesterday that their BNPL services will be offered by Target to consumers in time for this holiday season. When viewed alongside the Walmart and Amazon partnerships, Affirm now has relationships with 4 out of the Top 6 (although their partnership with Apple is only in Canada) e-commerce merchants in the United States [28]. For reference, the 2020 sales of these giants are outlined below, with Affirm’s partners highlighted accordingly:

In my opinion, these partnerships, as well as the fact that the holiday season is fast approaching, may allow for Affirm to close the gap between themselves and its main competitors, Klarna and Afterpay, however, only time will tell.

Lastly, there is no doubt that Affirm has a star-studded roster for Management. The members that inhabit the top positions of the company have experience in some of the largest institutions in the world, which should help Affirm in the future. I have outlined the largest companies that members of management have worked at in the past and it is impressive to say the least: 

8.0 Risk Factors

The first risk that must be addressed is the saturation in the BNPL space. More specifically, there are companies, particularly with Klarna [30] and Afterpay [31], that dwarf Affirm in scale. Although the company is aiming to address this risk with all of their growth initiatives, shareholders should continue to monitor some key metrics. For the sake of comparison I have outlined some key values, as of their most recent reporting periods that encompassed a full a year, below:

As is quite evident, despite Affirm’s previously outlined higher degree of stickiness and customer satisfaction, the company is largely trumped by its competitors in terms of scale. Notable is Afterpay, which has a higher rate of GMV growth with a magnitude that greatly exceeds that of Affirm’s. Being that as it may, Klarna on the other hand is best-in-class for a reason, with scale that its counterparts can only hope to match. 

Moving over to valuation, there is no doubt that these measures are rich, to say the least. Though relatively understandable given the pace of growth Affirm bolsters, these will evidently be a source of fragility in the future if activity in the BNPL or fast-growing tech space were to ever compress and take multiples with it. EV/Rev multiples with respect to past fiscal years as well as with respect to estimates can be seen outlined below:

In addition, the company is anticipated to remain EBITDA and FCF negative for upcoming fiscal years. When viewed in conjunction with the company’s growth initiatives, it is likely they will need to raise additional capital via equity or debt to continue growing (my guess is in early FY’23).

Of note is the boom in BNPL app downloads and ecosystem activity in general. The velocity of growth in major players has been outstanding, but it makes one wonder how long this is sustainable for. 

More specifically, a report performed by Credit Karma outlined the fact the over 44% of Americans have used BNPL services to buy an item they required, with 34% of those respondents having fallen behind on one or more of these payments  [33]. With the tremendous growth in the GMV of these ecosystems, it is worth worrying whether or not these ecosystems will fold in the face of fragility, of which occurs as a result of an an inflationary environment, i.e. an environment where credit defaults tend to rise. 

Lastly, it is worth noting the concentration risk in Affirm’s merchant base, and thus by association their Total Net Revenue. More specifically, at the end of FY’21 20% of the company’s revenue was attributable to Peloton and 25% of its Total Net Revenue was attributable to its Top 10 merchants [34]. Although the company has been mitigating the prevalence of this risk through new partnerships, the company is fragile in relation to consumer attitudes towards these merchants, and will face deteriorating financials if its merchants were incur decreased activities. Something to keep in mind at the very least. 

9.0 Conclusion

Affirm’s efforts to build a Super App are noteworthy, to put it lightly. When combined with their relationships with top e-commerce retailers, sustained growth and great management, I can see why so many people are long this company. On the other side of the coin, there are risks, mainly with competition and a possible contraction that may occur in both tech multiples and BNPL activity in general. I am neither long nor short (mainly because of my allegiance with Square and Afterpay) however Affirm is a company, in my opinion that is definitely worth the attention. So concludes my research, I hope you learned as much as I did writing it. Thank you for reading.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, comment below and share!

Share

If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

item.title: Square, Inc. ($SQ)
item.description: Foundations of a Behemoth: The Seller Ecosystem and Cash App
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to MT Capital Research! If you’re new, join a group of 1678 Informed Investors who receive weekly reports on the World’s most interesting companies by subscribing below: 

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an in-depth analysis on Square, Inc.; specifically the Square Seller Ecosystem and Cash App. I will be leaving an in-depth discussion regarding the company’s recent acquisition of Afterpay for another issue, being that I believe it deserves a few thousand words of discussion, comparison with competitors and demystification of the enormity of the opportunity it represents for the company. This report will be focused on describing the opportunity, tailwinds and factors Square aims to leverage within their operations and growth initiatives,  as well as breaking down the hosts of products and services they offer their customers. In addition, I will be performing a financial analysis on their most recent earnings report and discussing the value propositions and main positive developments I am focused on and excited about for the future.

The format of this report, broken down by section, is outlined below. Feel free to skip ahead to the parts that you feel will be most useful. 

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Opportunity

3.0 Product Breakdown 

4.0 How Square makes $$$

5.0 Financial Analysis - Q2’21 Earnings

6.0 Key Performance Indicators I am focused on

7.0 The Value I see in Square and Why I’m Long

8.0 Conclusion

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitution for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investments. 

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content and analysis, give me a follow on Twitter! 

Follow Me!

With all of that considered, let’s get started. 

1.0 Introduction

Square, Inc., of which I will denote as Square for the remainder of this report, can be most easily described as a company that creates tools, products and services that enable sellers to accept card payments and conduct a range of business processes ranging from reporting and analytics to executing next-day settlements and leveraging loans to improve their operations. The company designs and sells various hardware products that include but are not limited to the Magstripe Reader, a device that allows for payments to occur with magnetic stripe cards; Square Stand, a device that allows for iPads to be effortlessly converted into a POS solution; and Square terminal, a device that replaces all the functionality of traditional keypad terminals, to name a few. The company also offers software and services ranging from Square Appointments, Square for Retail, Square Online and Square Online Checkout, etc. Of additional note is the fact that the company owns and operates Cash App, a mobile payment service that facilitates P2P (peer-to-peer) transactions, stock and crypto trading, the purchase of goods and services and much more.

Now that we know a bit more about what Square does and what they offer their customers, let’s take a look at the opportunity the company is facing and how they hope to capitalize on it going forwards, both in the coming quarters and years. 

2.0 Opportunity 

Square’s success, as of right now, has been directly reliant on the operation of two unique ecosystems, one surrounding Sellers, and the other surrounding Individuals (the users of Cash App to be more specific).  Even with the recent acquisition of Afterpay, in my opinion, these will remain the company’s two primary focuses, being that BNPL efforts, in my eyes, represent an excellent opportunity for Square to grow Cash App and its associated user base in an expedient and organic manner.

Starting with the Seller Ecosystem Opportunity, Square estimates that the total opportunity in this segment is approximately $85B. This estimate, of which is directly reliant on estimated 20M businesses and $6T in Gross Receipts (business sales that form a basis for taxation), can be split into four distinct and unique sub-categories, of which can be seen outlined below [2]:

Transaction Profit: This value was determined based upon the previously outlined value of $6T in Gross Receipts, multiplying by 0.65 (assuming that 65% of all of these payments were made with credit cards) and then multiplying that value by 0.01 (assuming a 1% transaction margin with respect to total Gross Payment Volume (GPV)).

Software: This value was estimated by selecting targetable businesses reporting less than $100M in Annual Gross Receipts, within applicable industries, and multiplying this value by Square’s annualized software revenue per existing seller by product (three months ending January 2020).

Square Capital: This value was determined by multiplying the total number of small business loans outstanding as of 2019 by the standard revenue rate on these loans of approximately 4-6%. 

Financial Services: This value exists as the combination of Transfer and Square Card opportunities. The Transfer subcomponent was determined by multiplying the Instant Transfer Volume per seller, estimated in 2H '19,  by the 1.5% pricing on volume that Square uses for businesses with less than $250k in Gross Receipts. The Square Card Opportunity was determined by multiplying a multi-faceted estimate for average spend of targetable businesses, multiplied by the number of businesses with less than $20M in Gross Receipts, multiplied by estimated Mastercard Interchange Rates (fee that merchant is required to pay for every transaction).

Square aims to turn this total US Revenue Opportunity of $85B into a $100B counterpart by focusing on medium and long-term strategies. The former includes expansion into international markets as well as the creation/roll-out of new product use-cases, whereas the latter is heavily contingent on an up-market expansion, i.e. the targeting of mid-market and large US Sellers that offer trillions of untapped potential.

The second opportunity that Square must focus on is the Cash App Ecosystem. With $9T in volume the company hopes to address, the three-fold Cash-App opportunity can be seen outlined below:

Sending: This opportunity is the sum of P2P and micro-merchant volume estimates. The P2P estimate is the sum of the monthly P2P volumes per user of Cash App, Zelle and Venmo, whereas the micro-merchant volume is the sum of gross receipts and US Volume of businesses with gross receipts under $250K and informal businesses respectively. 

Spending: This estimate was based upon the sum of US Debit and Credit Spend as calculated by Nielson for 2018. 

Investing: This opportunity is the product of the CoinMetrics total USD Bitcoin Volume from 2019, and Square’s Gross Profit attributable to Bitcoin for FY’19. 

Square aims to further this $60B+ Cash App opportunity with the introduction of new products and use-cases within the associated ecosystem as well as further penetration into markets outside of the United States. When taking all of these estimates, for both ecosystems, into consideration, it is evident that the company’s opportunity does not lack scale or enormity. The direct success of these ecosystems, ambitions and trajectories will be examined in later sections of this report alongside some Key Performance Indicators (KPIs), but for now, let’s take a look at the specifics of the products that brought Square to the dance, so to speak, in the first place.

3.0 Product Breakdown 

Similar to Square’s Total Market Opportunity,  products will be broken down with respect to their distinct ecosystem, i.e. contained within the Seller Ecosystem or Cash App, respectively.

Seller Ecosystem Products

Square’s Seller Ecosystem consists of three unique components, Software, Hardware and Financial Services. A summary of each member of these respective cohorts can be seen outlined below.

Software

Square has four Software Product Categories, of which can be seen outlined in the image below: 

Square Point of Sale Software exists as a customizable POS system, focused on providing customers a realm of functionality with no setup or monthly fees. The software supports business processes of all shapes and sizes, with the ability to be synced with an online store (no-code functionality i.e. can be deployed right away), intertwined with a social media business, used on-the-go by delivery workers and much more. Being that this POS software is outfitted on Square Terminals and Square Stand hardware devices, it powers Brick and Mortar, Multi-location, On the go and Occasional businesses across the United States [3]. Square’s POS software has four unique forms: 

  • Square POS

  • Square Retail

  • Square Restaurant 

  • Square Appointment

Each of these variants has different features that fit their associated business niche like a glove, supporting processes ranging from scheduling and sending invoices to customers, to managing inventory or creating cost reports, respectively. 

Square’s Online offerings offer customers a suite of different services, all of which are designed to help make running an online business easier. All of the company’s online-focused products are illustrated below: 

  • Square Online: Square Online is focused on providing customers a tangible solution for building and maintaining an e-commerce store. In addition, Square Online provides functionality that allows businesses to offer an omni-channel experience to their customers, facilitating different payment methods, shopping styles (i.e. online, delivery, pickup etc.) and integrating seamlessly with Square’s POS systems. In addition, Square Online provides business management services ranging from inventory tracking to SEO optimization for associated websites.

  • Square Online Checkout: This service is a quick and easy way for businesses to get paid online, allowing for the creation of buy buttons and pay links on the checkout page of a website. 

  • Square Virtual Terminal: Customers can utilize this service to transform their computer into a POS system, essentially existing as a virtual card terminal that is capable of issuing receipts, scheduling recurring payments and offering expedient checkout times. 

  • Square Invoices: While using this service, customers can send digital invoices and estimates, accept different payments, track which invoices have been paid or unpaid. Jam packed with tools, individuals are able to leverage different types of custom reporting functionality and cash flow management tools built into the software. 

Square is evidently a developer-friendly company. This assertion is evidently corroborated when looking at the various APIs and SDKs they have made available to those that would like to integrate with their ecosystem in an alternative manner. A description of the two categories of APIs and SDKs the company offers can be written as follows. 

  • Payments: These APIs facilitate a variety of payment processes, ranging from in-person to online or mobile. SDKs ranging from those that integrate with Square’s hardware and a business’ custom POS system, to ones that allow developers to use Square’s payment services on their own e-commerce platform, are all readily available. 

  • Commerce: These APIs allow developers to integrate Square’s business management tools ranging from those that keep track of active subscriptions to ones that are centered around inventory management and loyalty programs, within their own custom built applications. 

Existing as the last sub-category of the company’s software offerings, Square has a series of different customer and business management software tools, all of which exist within the Square Dashboard. This software can essentially be thought of as a hub for all things business intelligence and management, providing quick insights and varieties of reporting capabilities. Within, business owners can track transactions, transfers and invoices as well as leverage analytics functionality that provide actionable data visualization and monitoring that would otherwise only be possible within a spreadsheet.

Hardware

Square has five different hardware products of which are capable of supporting all major and modern payment types, and aimed at sellers in order to provide them with a complete POS experience. These hardware offerings include [6]: 

  • Magstripe Reader

  • Contactless Chip Reader

  • Square Register 

  • Square Terminal 

  • Square Stand

Financial Services

Square better serves their Sellers through the provision of a series of financial services. Before we delve into each product, it is of paramount importance to understand how Square behaves within transactions occurring within their ecosystem. More specifically, Square acts as a merchant of record, a term commonly used in the payments industry to describe the party in the sales transaction whom the cardholder believes they are making a purchase from, and the party in which said cardholder is liable for payment [8].  This role allows for more efficient onboarding of sellers, the provision of transaction data analytics and other useful features. Square has also partnered with transaction processing services, card networks and issuing banks in order to provide sellers with the most expedient and reasonable terms possible. Associated Financial Services can be seen below: 

  • Square Card: The money that a business makes and that goes into a seller’s checking account can be spent directly using the Square Prepaid Debit Card.

  • Instant Transfer: Transfers of up to $10,000 can be initiated and executed from the Square App or Dashboard. 

  • Managed Payments: In exchange for a fee, Sellers can receive payments from customer’s cards via swipe, tap or through online mediums, as examples. 

  • Risk Manager: Square provides customers with access to algorithms that are designed to analyze, spot and block payment fraud and secure business processes as a result. 

Of additional note is the Financial Services that are provided through Square Capital. More specifically, Square Capital provides small business loans to interested parties, of which are sped up and made more pleasant in comparison to traditional loans through the use of their risk management processes, of which helps to facilitate both loan collections and the underwriting itself.

In order to make this process even more efficient, in March of this year, Square announced that their industrial bank, Square Financial Services had completed its charter approval process and was FDIC approved to begin operations. This acquisition allows for Square to maneuver in an increasingly agile manner, and will serve mainly to underwrite and originate loans for Square Capital’s lending product [10]. 

Lastly, Square provides a Payroll-related Financial Service, of which allows for sellers to pay their employees (by connecting to their Square checking account), automate their associated tax filings and manage associated employee benefits, all from one convenient location.

Cash App

Cash App, in essence, is a provider of mobile financial services. Self-proclaiming itself as the easiest way to send, bank, spend and invest [12], the product evidently exists and offers related services through these four categories. A description of the functionality contained therein can be seen outlined below. 

Send

Cash App offers Peer to Peer (P2P) transaction services to customers, allowing for money to be sent between two parties in a relatively expedient manner. A simplified step-by-step process for a money transfer goes something like this: 

  • Open Cash App

  • Enter the amount to be transferred

  • Tap Pay

  • Enter an email, phone number or Cashtag (a CashApp username of sorts)

  • Tap Pay

Bank 

Cash App offers consumers bank-esque features that are inherently useful. More specifically, through the Banking Tab of the application, individuals have the ability to direct-deposit a paycheck to their Cash App account balance, add money from an external bank account or deposit a physical check into the ecosystem. 

Spend

Cash App differentiates itself from other online payment platforms by offering customers access to a customizable debit card, denoted as the Cash Card, of which can be used to spend; with all transactions being drawn against their Cash App balance. This card can be used anywhere ranging from standard brick and mortar locations to at the ATM machine for withdrawals. 

Customers also have the option to add Cash Boosts to their debit transactions. These boosts are essentially discounts that can be used to get 10% of a grocery store purchase, save $5 on a Taco Bell order, save a fixed amount on a Playstation Store purchase, as examples. This boost program should be thought of as a rewards program, of which incentivizes customers to utilize the Cash App ecosystem for their purchases.

Invest

Relatively self-explanatory, the Invest section of the Cash App allows individuals to allocate capital towards stocks, ETFs or bitcoin, with as little as $1. Customers can make investments utilizing the Cash App balance they have, or transfer money directly from a linked debit card or bank account [17] .  This section, to me, represents a good place for beginners to begin their investing journeys, however, being that this section of the Cash App only supports a few hundred stocks, ETFs and only Bitcoin within the crypto realm (Dorsey is likely to remain headstrong on this one), it may not be a feasible solution for seasoned investors. Regardless, this again offers another opportunity for customers to remain fully engaged within the full realm of financial capabilities contained within the Cash App ecosystem. 

Now that we have a better understanding of the full realm of products and services offers their customers, both within the Seller and Cash App ecosystems respectively, let’s take a look at how exactly Square makes money from it. 

4.0 How Square Makes $$$

Seller Ecosystem 

Square’s Seller Revenue can be split into three constituents: Transactions, Services and Subscriptions as well as Hardware. The main manner in which the company makes money from each of these categories can be seen outlined below. 

Transactions

Revenue extracted from Transactions is primarily attributable to Square’s POS and Online software. For Square’s POS-related Software, of which contains Square POS, Retail, Restaurant and Appointment specifically, the company charges sellers a 2.65% fee per in person transaction (in relation to total purchase value) for all major credit cards and a 10 cent fee for every INTERAC chip and pin or tap use [18].  Square’s Online-related Software (Square Online, Square Online Checkout, Square Invoices) makes money slightly differently, charging sellers a 2.9% + 10 cent fee per transaction, as previously outlined.  Square Virtual Terminal turns seller’s computers into fully functional payment terminals capable of accepting both credit and debit cards, with the associated fee structure catering towards both remote in-person use-cases as such. For remote situations (i.e. typed-in transactions) sellers are charged 3.4% + 15 cents per transaction) whereas in-person processing has an identical fee structure to the traditional POS software [19].  It should be noted that Square gives sellers a custom-pricing option if and only if their Revenues exceed $250K. Additionally, all transaction-related services utilized within custom-built applications via APIs / SDKs will have identical cost-structures to those of the counterparts outlined above.

Services and Subscriptions 

Starting off with Square POS Software, these products generate Subscription revenue in addition to their transaction fee revenue counterpart. The associated pricing of each of these products is outlined below: 

  • Square Retail: $60/location.

  • Square Restaurant: Free for one location, $60/month per device per location and $40/month for each additional POS device added.

  • Square Appointment: Free for 1 user, $50/month for 2-5 users, $90/month for 6-11 users.

Although Square’s Online Dashboard is offered to sellers for free, Square Team Management contained within requires a subscription in order to be used to the extent of its capabilities (i.e. to access advanced data analytics etc.). More specifically, the plus tier of Square Team Management costs $35/month/location [20].

The products contained underneath the Financial Services umbrella, of which charge sellers for their use can be seen outlined and described below. 

  • Square Instant Transfer: transfers of up to $10,000 cost 1.5% for each transfer.

  • Square Risk Manager: 6 cents per online transaction monitored.

  • Square Capital: Loans extended to qualified sellers are paid back by Square taking a fixed percentage of each sale the business makes [21].

Hardware 

Square charges sellers a fixed fee for the purchase of each hardware device. The fees associated with each product are as follows [22]: 

  • Magstripe Reader: Free at signup.

  • Contactless Chip Reader: $49.

  • Square Register: Outright price of $799, or $39/month for 24 months.

  • Square Terminal: $299 outright or $27/month for 12 months.

  • Square Stand: $169 outright or $16/month for 12 months.

Cash App 

Square generates revenue from each of the main segments/functionality of Cash App, Send, Spend and Invest.

Send

The manner in which Cash App Spend earns money can be seen outlined below: 

  • Instant Deposit Fee: For each instant deposit, the customer is charged a flat 1.5% fee or the $0.25 minimum if the transaction is small.

  • Credit Card Transfer: Cash App allows for customers to send money from their credit card, in exchange for a 3% fee [23]. 

  • Business Account: Cash app facilitates the transfer of money between customer and businesses, charging the business 2.75% for each payment they receive [24]. 

Spend 

Cash App generates Spend revenue by charging customers for functionality related to the Cash Card, of which can be described as follows: 

  • ATM Fees: Customers are charged $2 for each ATM withdrawal made with their Cash Card.

  • Interchange Fees (transaction fees merchant’s bank account must pay whenever card is used): Square earns interchange fees when individuals use the Cash Card, typically around 0.3%.

Invest

Although Cash App doesn’t generate revenue from customer’s purchasing stocks or ETFs, they do generate revenue when a customer purchases Bitcoin. Cash App charges customers a small fee when they complete a bitcoin trade and being that there is usually a price difference between bitcoin exchanges are quoting and what individuals pay for bitcoin, the company generates additional revenue on the exchange it facilitates [25].

5.0 Financial Analysis - Q2’21 Earnings

Square reported their Q2’21 earnings on August 2nd. Some of the company’s high level highlights, both financial and operational, can be seen outlined below: 

  • Gross Profit of $1.14B, a 91% increase on a YoY basis, with Cash App generating $546M in Gross Profit and the Seller Ecosystem generating $585M, a 91% and 94% YoY increase, respectively. 

  • Adjusted EBITDA of $360M, a 53% increase YoY.

  • Net Income of $204M.

  • A majority stake ownership in Tidal was completed in April.

  • Company announced intention to acquire Afterpay, a deal that is anticipated to close in the early part of 2022.

  • Launched Square Banking in July, an effort aimed at improving the ease at which businesses can manage their cash flows and get more out of their money.

With these highlights in mind, let’s dig a little deeper.

Income Statement 

Revenue

Square’s Revenue for the quarter came in at ~$4.68B, a value that has been hard pressed to decelerate over the last few years. Looking at how Total Revenue has changed on a YoY basis is in my opinion, misleading, mainly due to the constituents this value includes. More specifically, Total Revenue includes the sum of the value of all of the Bitcoin Transactions completed on the platform. As such, in order to better reflect how Square’s business is actually performing, let’s take a look at how Total Revenue, less bitcoin has changed over the last few quarters:

Important is the fact that Square’s business is accelerating regardless of their hard-pressed adoption of cryptocurrencies, particularly within the Cash App Ecosystem. Regardless, Square’s business, based upon Revenue growth, is firing on all cylinders, increasing 87% on a YoY basis. The constituents of this growth, particularly related to Transaction, Services/Subscription and Hardware segments, can be seen outlined below:

The YoY increase of these segments can be seen outlined below:

Despite Hardware being the fastest growing Revenue Segment, Transactions were evidently the largest contributor to Total Revenue, less Bitcoin, and will continue to be a primary generator of long-term value for the company, in my opinion.

In order to gauge the overall performance of each of the two main components of Square’s business as a whole, the change in Seller Ecosystem Revenue and Cash App Revenue over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below:

These values showed strong growth YoY, increasing 81% and 87% on a YoY basis respectively. Testament to the strong engagement with Square’s platform, these values should continue to increase going forwards as a result of the continued digitization of payment processes and continued penetration into businesses outside of the micro and SMB categories. Each of the Seller Ecosystem and Cash App Revenues can be split into different components. These values and how they’ve changed YoY can be seen outlined below: 

These values are indicative of consistent growth in activity within both of Square’s ecosystems. I am most excited about the improvements in the Subscription/Services Revenue attributable to Cash App, of which is attributable to transaction fees for the Cash Card and associated instant deposit. Cash App acting as a closed loop payment system represents an enormous value proposition and the more users that leverage the app as such, the better. Lastly, although the Bitcoin Revenue viewed as Revenue in the traditional sense is misleading, it offers a useful insight into the potential organic growth effects it may have (i.e. people sending bitcoin, buying bitcoin and becoming familiar with the ecosystem etc.). Despite a 211% increase on a YoY basis, there was a noticeable dip QoQ in Bitcoin Revenue. This value is largely correlated with activity in the crypto space, rising and falling in a proportional manner to overall crypto trading volume.

Gross Profit

In comparison to Revenue, Gross Profit may offer a better insight into how Square’s business is performing. More specifically, the breakdown of Gross Profit with respect to the Seller Ecosystem and Cash App can be seen outlined below:

For the sake of illustration, Seller and Cash App as a % of Revenue is illustrated below in order to understand the relationship between Revenue generation and Gross Profit.

It is evident that Cash App, despite being a lower proportion of Total Revenues, Less BTC, is a driver of GP. Square’s marketing efforts as well as the organic growth that the ecosystem sees with continued user activity should continue to drive this further in the coming quarters. It is also worth discussing the strategy at which Square operates their Hardware Segment with respect to Gross Margins. More specifically, Square will sell their hardware at either break-even or a loss in order to spur Ecosystem growth. This is only an example of Square’s intelligent customer and user acquisition strategies that will prove to be important for the creation of LTV.

Cost of Revenue

The company’s Cost of Revenue, Less the Cost of Bitcoin, and its change over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

The change of each COR constituent compared side by side with its Revenue counterpart can be seen outlined in the following table:

Overall COR has increased relative to the size of Square’s business processes, as expected. The increase in Subscription/Services COR, of which occurred at a faster rate than its counterparts is attributable to growth in Cash Card and Instant Deposit activity as well as the costs related to the music streaming services (related to Tidal acquisition) [26]. 

Lastly, COR relative to Total Revenue, Less Bitcoin, has been decreasing steadily over the last few quarters, a sign of efficiency in Square’s processes.

Operating Expenses

Square’s OPEX increased 64% on a YoY basis, coming in at ~$1.017B for the quarter. The breakdown of OPEX into its constituents and their respective YoY change can be seen outlined below:

The proportion of OPEX attributable to each source remained relatively stagnant YoY. Product Development, S&M and G&A, the largest components of OPEX, increased relative to increased personnel/headcount costs, transaction costs, as well as marketing efforts and customer acquisition costs associated with Cash App. respectively. OPEX and its change relative to Revenue (both types) over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below:

OPEX relative to Revenue of both types is reasonably high, however, when digging deeper into what the expenses are attributable to, myself, as a shareholder is content with what management is doing, particularly with the efforts they are directing at Cash App customer acquisition, of which will be an undoubtable spurring factor of continued growth and prosperity.

Margins and Profitability 

The change in the company’s Gross Profit, Net Income, EBITDA and EBIT Margins can be seen outlined below:

Net Income, EBITDA and EBIT Margins are all indicative of Square’s slight profitability, coming in at 4.36%, 4.24% and 3.64% respectively. Gross Profit on the other hand decreased slightly on a YoY and QoQ basis, particularly because of the low GP-margin nature of the Bitcoin segment in general (sub 5% GP). Although this business segment makes up for it with the trading volumes, I believe the illustration below better corroborates the high-margin nature of both the Cash App and Seller ecosystem with the effect of crypto not taken into account: 

Profitability can be gauged further by looking at Net Income and adjusted-EBITDA, GAAP and non-GAAP values respectively:

These values again corroborate a swing in the profitable direction for the company. Although Square is a top-5 bank in the United States with respect to market capitalization, it will be a while until I desire Square behave like those aforementioned counterparts. The company is focused on scale instead of reporting massive profits, and I would like this to continue.

Balance Sheet

The structure of Square’s Assets can be seen outlined below:

Square’s Current Assets are primarily in the form of Cash and Equivalents, Customer Funds, Investments and Settlements and Loans held for sale, in order of descending magnitude.  Long Term Assets are comprised mainly of Long Term Investments, Goodwill, Lease Assets, and Property and Equipment, in decreasing order. The structure of Square’s Liabilities can be seen below:

Current Liabilities primarily consist of Customers Payable, followed by PPP liquidity advances, accrued expenses and settlements payable. Long Term Liabilities on the other hand mainly consist of Long Term Debt. Square’s balance sheet aligns well with their operations and the financial services they provide their customers. With liquidity not being an issue, I do not anticipate Square’s balance sheet to be a source of hindrance going forwards. 

Cash Flows

The change in the company’s Cash from Operations, Investing and Financing over the last few quarters can be seen outlined below:

Cash from Operations came in positive for the quarter at ~$1.93B, with the main constituents being the company’s Net Income, Sale and forgiveness of loans, Customers Payable and SBC (share-based comp), offset primarily by the Purchases of Loans and Settlements Receivable. Cash from Investing was very negative at ~$(775)M as a result of the purchase of Marketable Debt Securities, Purchase of Bitcoin and Purchase of securities with customer funds and Business Combinations, primarily offset by Proceeds from Debt Securities (maturities and sales) and sale of equity investments. Lastly, CFO was ~$396M for Q2, attributable to the proceeds from Senior Notes and PPP Liquidity Facility advances, offset mainly by the Repayments of PPP advances and Payments associated with stock unit vesting.

The change in the company’s Cash Flow can be seen outlined below: 

With Capital Expenditures of ~$30M the company is directing efforts at supporting growth. Square doesn’t have the most abundant FCF but when considering the amount of capital they are directing at growing their ecosystems etc. I am okay with that. The company stated within the 10-Q that they had sufficient capital for at least the next 12 months, thus I would not expect cap raises for the next few quarters.

6.0 Key Performance Indicators I am focused on

Gross Payment Volume: Arguably one of the most important metrics to gauge the overall health of Square’s business is their GPV. This value can be defined as the sum of all card payments processed by sellers (excluding refunds) and Cash App activity (Cash For Business and P2P payments sent from a CC) [27].  Increasing 88% YoY, this metric, in my opinion is reflective of the stickiness of the ecosystem and the progress of the transformative digital payment age that is taking the world by storm:

Seller GPV Mix by Size: Square started off serving micro and SMB-sized businesses, offering payment solutions and a software ecosystem that were truly unique and catered towards individuals that existing payment processors had decided to overlook. Being that as it may, with the omni-channel nature of Square’s software and how this intersects with larger business processes perfectly, as well as the fact that GP is largely driven by the Software Business Segment, GPV activity attributable to larger sellers is paramount to Square’s continued growth. The distribution in GPV and how its changed over the last few quarters can be seen below:

Evidently improving over the last three years, I will continue to look for Square to increase their penetration in the cohorts associated with higher Annualized GPVs going forwards.

Geographic Presence: The company’s penetration into International Markets will be an important part of Square’s growth story going forwards. Mentioning that they had entered into brand awareness campaigns in Countries around the World, ranging from targeting sellers in Australia and Canada to launching in Ireland and Spain, the company is evidently focused on this growth proposition. Afterpay adds significantly to this International Growth story, but more on that another time. Square’s International Revenue has stayed <5% of Total Net Revenue since early ‘20, however, it is encouraging that management is headfast on changing this for the better:

Cash App Weekly and Monthly Active Users: Lastly, given the fact that Cash App is becoming almost 50% of total GP while only being one third of Total Revenue, Less BTC, the activity in this ecosystem is paramount to the company’s ability to generate value for shareholders. With 40M transacting users, and the Q2’21 shareholder letter illustrating the fact that WAU are close to two thirds of total MAUs, reported data is indicative of meaningful customer interaction occurring on the platform on a frequent basis [28] which should only continue with the company dipping their toes into the BNPL waters and continually executing extremely effective customer acquisition and marketing campaigns.

7.0 The Value I see in Square and Why I’m Long

Fool me once shame on you, fool me twice shame on me, or so the old euphemism goes. Applied to Jack Dorsey, I have a hard time believing that starting two multi-billion dollar companies occurs by happenstance. Regardless, with the man’s evident focus on Square in comparison to Twitter, as outlined below, and his uncanny ability to eerily predict the direction of technological trends, I as a shareholder am content and recognize the undoubtable value that the CEO of Square brings to the table. 

My bullishness is centered around three main themes, pertaining to both the Seller Ecosystem and Cash App respectively.

Firstly, the Seller Ecosystem that Square has created, and how it essentially creates an omni-channel experience for customers to complete all of their processes, no matter what medium they are contained within (either in-person or online), instills an essentially irreplaceable value proposition within a business. During my research I came across a CNN Article with Jim McKelvey, the co-founder of Square, wherein he discussed how Square was able to survive Amazon’s competitive onslaught in the early 2010s [28]. He stated that the companies that were able to innovate the entire stack were the ones that were the most difficult to unseat. The stack, in a software engineering sense of the word, contains everything ranging from the databases to the front-end of the software that makes things pleasant to look at and interact with. In the payment-processing world, this refers to catering towards the full realm of experience, from the card-reader to the POS software that is associated with it, and much more. Square’s seller ecosystem, i.e. the beautifully simple UX and capabilities of its software as well as the ease at which it can be integrated with associated hardware, makes Square hard to unseat. Although many would like to tout the looming competition offered by entities like Toast, or Lightspeed, I don’t believe these companies are serious threats against Square. They may have a product that tailors better towards a particular customer segment, however, they lack the fully integrated nature of Square’s ecosystem. In my opinion, this is only made stronger with the recent activities of Square Capital. Creating the financial tools to serve Square’s customers when they need them will only improve stickiness and I am excited to see where the future takes this part of Square’s business. 

Organic Marketing, though typically associated with the Cash App brand, is making its way over to the seller ecosystem as a result of recent company efforts. More specifically, the TikTok x Square partnership announced on Tuesday of this week, represents a huge opportunity to continue to drive GPV and adoption growth in the Seller business segment. Allowing creators to send TikTok users directly to their Square store, the company will be able to leverage the fact that nearly 50% of TikTok’s 1 Billion Active Users have purchased a product after seeing it advertised within the application [29].  Undoubtedly this partnership will result in both higher adoption of Square’s software, but will also offer an unfathomable amount of eyes on their offerings by way of network effects.

Moving on to the Cash App, I believe the acquisition of Tidal is illustrative of the overall strategy I see Square taking with this business segment, and how I believe this will translate into the creation of Long Term Value. On May 4th it was announced that Square had acquired a majority ownership in Tidal, a subscription-based music and video streaming service [31]. To many this was a head-scratcher, did Square really want to test its luck in the music industry? To me, this acquisition made perfect sense, given the obscene amounts of organic marketing and resultant Cash App user-base growth this deal will result in. Cash App has not been shy about its S&M efforts, particularly within the pop-culture realm. More specifically, the likes of Cardi B, Lil Nas X and Megan Thee Stallion have all partnered with Cash App in the past, offering individuals the chance to win cash prizes if they were registered within the app ecosystem. 

With this go-to-market strategy, Square is leveraging the power of social media to get more views on the Cash app product and ecosystem as a whole. When taking into consideration the fact that hip hop industry most definitely has a love affair with the product, with 200+ hip hop songs from varieties of artists mentioning Cash App somewhere within their songs, the Tidal acquisition starts to make a lot of sense [33]. The artist base on the platform, which are a form of business entities in themselves, can both use the product, which Square can obviously benefit from, and then leverage these artists in sales and marketing campaigns in an organically exponential manner that would not be possible with traditional customer acquisition strategies. 

Lastly, the efforts that Square is directing at the closed-loop payment space are, in my opinion, something to be excited about. An open-loop payment system is essentially one that runs on the rails so to speak, i.e. has a functionality that is directly reliant on the card providers, Mastercard and Visa. Reliance requires a share of the pie and as such Square has to direct a percentage of the fee they charge for payment processing back at the rails after processing payments. In a closed-loop system, i.e. the one that Square is trying to build with Cash App, this middle step is skipped altogether, with Square being able to keep the full processing fee pie for themselves when the cardholder and seller exchange funds directly.

For the sake of further illustration, as recently announced, Cash App Pay will allow consumers to pay with their Cash App accounts at participating Square Sellers. Though reliant on the extent to which consumers are willing to forego their credit cards, debit cards etc. to use the cash app ecosystem instead, this poses a very interesting opportunity for Square. When combined with the Afterpay efforts, this proposition is only further strengthened, but more on that in my Afterpay research piece. 

With all of these happenings considered, I am long because of Square’s undeniable value to sellers, the series of efforts they have embarked on in order to continuously spur growth in both of their main business segments and the attempts they are making to benefit from closed-loop payments. It is an exciting time to be part of everything Square is doing.

8.0 Conclusion

Square is at the top of the Fintech industry for a reason. With two strong business segments growing larger by the minute, there is a lot to like. In addition, with the Afterpay acquisition in mind, my opinion and conviction is only strengthened. Subscribe below so you don’t miss my upcoming Afterpay analysis and full Square Thesis.

Subscribe now

So concludes my initial Square Research. I hope this served as a good starting point for learning about the company. Thank you for reading.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, comment below and share!

Share

If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

item.title: Snowflake Inc. ($SNOW)
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the 175 Individuals that have subscribed to my newsletter since the last piece! If you’re new, join a group of 1608 Informed Investors by subscribing below: 

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an in-depth analysis on Snowflake Inc. where in I will discuss the key factors and tailwinds that the company aims to benefit from both within the Big Data space and beyond, as well as break down the company’s product suite’s inherent functionality and delve into its associated value proposition. In addition, I will perform a financial analysis on their most recent earnings, and discuss some positive and negative factors that both bystanders and current investors should be wary of. 

Like previous reports, the format of my research can be seen outlined below.  Please don’t hesitate to skip ahead to the sections that you feel are the most valuable.

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Opportunity 

3.0 Value Proposition 

4.0 Product Breakdown

5.0 How Snowflake makes $$$

6.0 Key Performance Indicators

7.0 Financial Analysis - Q2 FY’22 Earnings Analysis 

8.0 Guidance

9.0 Positive Developments

10.0 Risk Factors 

11.0 Conclusion

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitution for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investments.

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content and analysis, give me a follow on Twitter!

Follow Me!

With that in mind, let’s get started. 

1.0 Introduction

Snowflake Inc., which I will denote as Snowflake for the remainder of this report, can be most easily described as a provider of cloud-based data services. These services are contained within an all-encompassing platform, of which can be classified as a PaaS, or Platform as a Service. Snowflake’s platform, or the Data Cloud so to speak, is an ecosystem that enables customers to aggregate and consolidate data into one single source, of which can then be used as a foundation to complete business analytics processes, create custom-built applications, facilitate artificial intelligence and machine learning insights, and share data and results in a cross-organizational manner. Snowflake’s platform is utilized by entities that are both big and small, as well as situated across various Geographic locations and industries  [2].

We now have a rough understanding of what Snowflake does and what they offer their customers. With this general overview in mind, let’s take a look at the opportunity that Snowflake has in front of it, of which they aim to capitalize upon both with in current operations and within future growth initiatives.

2.0 Opportunity 

Although citing the Total Big Data Market Size as Snowflake’s Total Addressable Market is misleading, it is still of analytical importance as it allows for comparisons to be made between current Big Data activity and associated projections. More specifically, in 2020, it was estimated that the Total Global Big Data Market in 2020 was approximately $130.7B, a value which is expected to grow at a CAGR of 10.2% in between the 2020 and 2026 forecast periods, reaching a Total Value of $234.6B [3]. More company-specific, the size of the global data warehousing market was valued at $21.2B in 2019 and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 10.7% up until 2028, reaching a value of $52.2B . With Snowflake catering towards approximately 5,000 customers as of Q2’21, of which consist of approximately 42.4% of the Fortune 500, it is evident that there is a current demand for Snowflake’s services, especially from some of the world’s biggest corporate spenders [4], of which is likely to translate into future demand within the coming quarters and years. 

Snowflake’s opportunity stems from a series of inter-organizational and multi-industry trends that have arisen alongside the ever growing societal, cultural and corporate prevalence of technology and data in general. Centuries ago, the Industrial Revolution transported individuals away from the farmstead and instead placed them in factories. The widespread mechanization of mankind laid the foundations for the second Industrial Revolution and the inevitable reliance on oil and fossil fuels that came with it. Since then, many would argue that the Knowledge Revolution has been well underway, shifting jobs out of factories into office environments. The technological improvements that made this change possible shuffled the role of the world’s most important commodity away from oil, crowning data in its place. As such, the need for organizations to properly leverage their data has never been greater. This commodity is at the heart of almost every modern process improvement and innovation, with the transformation of data from a fragmented entity into KPIs, insights and precursors for decision making being of undoubtable importance. 

The magnitude of the Big Data opportunity is evident, however, there are a series of additional technological trends that will need to be paid attention to in order for Snowflake to constantly cater towards the infrastructure and consumption habits of the modern enterprise. Firstly, the cloud has arguably become one of the most important components of a corporation’s infrastructure. In 2020, a study performed by Gartner estimated that approximately 83% of Enterprise Workloads were in the cloud, 94% of US enterprises have used or are already using a cloud service, and an estimated 30% of surveyed businesses’ IT budgets are being directed at cloud computing-related expenditures [5].  Secondly, the manner in which technology is being consumed has changed. Gone are the days where rigid licenses or packages can cater towards an organization’s multifaceted needs. This is where the rise of SaaS comes into play, with a utility model of software provision having an evident popularity over the last decade, and for good reason, seeing as it caters towards a business in a fully customizable and unique manner. These trends, when applied to the Big Data industry are quite simple, essentially equating to a need for data warehouse solutions that are compatible with modern cloud infrastructure, as well as customizable in a manner similar to SaaS counterparts. 

With Snowflake’s Cloud-based PaaS business model, the company aims to leverage the aforementioned occurrences to become one of the world’s most valuable companies.

3.0 Value Proposition 

With opportunity comes challenges. Current Data Technologies on the market leave much to be desired, struggling to extract value from current architecture and legacy databases. A 2020 study performed by the Harvard Business Review, by where C-level technology and business executives were surveyed, ranging from those situated at American Express to Johnson and Johnson, yielded some astonishing results. More specifically, 72% of these executives stated they were struggling to build a data-driven culture, 53% stated they were not yet leveraging data as a business asset and 52% said they were falling behind on the data and analytics front [6]. These results are evidently stunning, but where exactly do these data challenges arise from and what do current technologies leave to be desired? 

The main issues that current data warehouse solutions run into, in my opinion, can be stated as follows: 

  • Lack of support for Data Volume and Diversity

  • Poor Cost and Time Effectiveness in both Implementation and Maintenance

  • Burdensome UX

  • Inability to cater towards Geographically diverse Enterprises

The first issue is of extreme importance. Modern enterprises struggle with storing and maintaining massive amounts of data, often suffering from the presence of fragmented data lakes and silos that are not accessible across all corners of an organization. Disparate solutions are often accompanied by data duplication and inefficient processes. This lack of structure becomes a real issue when an organization tries to extract value from large datasets, with disjointed architecture reducing the feasibility of executing time-effective queries. Secondly, trying to develop and maintain data solutions in-house are both capital and time-intensive, resulting in a stagnation of a company’s data efforts as a result.  Lastly, traditional legacy database and big data architecture are often difficult to work with from a user experience standpoint, and do not cater towards the ever-changing geographic residency and data sharing requirements of modern corporations. When coupled with the fact that most institutions' legacy data systems are intertwined with cloud providers in a constrained manner, i.e. only able to run in specific regions, a series of challenges arise when attempting to distribute data and insights across organizations with presence in various locations. 

Snowflake aims to solve all of these aforementioned issues, leveraging their Data Cloud solution in order to reduce the presence of Data Silos, i.e. the presence of data repositories that can only be controlled and accessed by one department, isolated from the rest of an organization. By providing solutions that support data diversity and scalability, bolster a high performance relative to the price paid for the PaaS, and focus on ease-of-use and multi-faceted geographic/cloud requirements, Snowflake’s customers yield a series of benefits, as outlined by the image below: 

Now that we have an understanding of the value proposition Snowflake directs at their clients, let’s roll up our sleeves and try to dissect the company’s product. 

4.0 Product Breakdown 

In simple terms, Snowflake’s product is essentially a fully managed cloud data warehouse.  In order to understand how this product functions, we must first understand how it intersects with a businesses’ processes. As such, let’s take a look at an over-simplified process diagram, of which I have split into three unique and distinct components, outlined below:

Most modern enterprises will ingest large amounts of data on a daily basis. This data, whether it be structured or semi-structured (Snowflake supports both of these well), originates from sources ranging from sensors and legacy databases to APIs and standard files. Data from these aforementioned example sources are then absorbed via ETL or ELT processes. Standing for Extract, Transform, Load or Extract, Load, Transform, respectively, these methods differ in the fact that the former is extracted from data sources, deposited in a staging area and then loaded into a data warehouse whereas the latter transforms the data after it has been loaded. Once the data has been ingested into the Snowflake Lakehouse (contains both Data Warehouses or Data Lakes depending on the transformation process that data has been put through) Data Consumers can execute queries to then derive some sort of operational value from said data, ranging from things such as analytics reporting and custom-built machine learning applications to secure data pooling.

The Snowflake intermediary outlined in the flow diagram above, essentially exists in three unique and distinct layers, of which result in the platform’s distinct functionality: centralized storage, multi-cluster compute and cloud services. The first layer is the company’s cloud storage layer, of which allows clients to store data of both structured and unstructured varieties. Being that this layer is run separately from the compute layer, there is an inherent scalability that would not be possible utilizing typical legacy data storage methods (one can think about the capital expenditures required to purchase and maintain a host of new servers). Within this layer, data ingestion, compression and storage are all fully managed by Snowflake, accessible to users via SQL queries. The second layer, multi-cluster compute, leverages the power of the cloud in order to both execute queries expediently and manage resources effectively. Being that these requests are executed in a massively parallel processing manner, query results are fast and also give clients the option to partition virtual data warehouses in a manner that aligns with their various departments (i.e. virtual data warehouses for accounting, finance etc.). Also important is the fact that users of snowflake can choose how much compute they require (associated with a particular cost) before performing any sort of analysis, leading to cost effectiveness. Lastly, cloud services act as the grease within the cogs of Snowflake's ever-complex machinery, performing tasks ranging from authentication and access control to metadata and infrastructure management. 

All of these features tie into a truly unique product, of which offers a host of benefits to the customers that decide to leverage its power. In order to truly grasp the use-cases, it is imperative that one understands the value proposition of a fully managed data warehouse solution. Corporations, on average, direct extensive amounts of time and capital at the design/creation and management of legacy databases. Snowflake’s PaaS, is a fully managed service and allow for a company’s roster of Data Engineers to re-focus their efforts on higher level tasks and analysis instead of spending a large part of their time on rudimentary and monotonous data warehouse maintenance work. In addition, Data Engineers can also rest assured at the fact that Snowflake’s platform components are spread across multiple data centers in order to ensure availability, ACID compliant, i.e. solutions align with database transactions standards that ensure validity and reduce the prevalence of errors and fail-safe, i.e. data deletions and modifications are fully reversible and modifiable for a period of seven days. These factors, when considered from the perspective of a corporation, lead to an inherent stickiness, i.e. a recognition that the same capabilities and functionality would be difficult to duplicate in-house with similar effectiveness. 

Another factor to consider, is the manner in which Snowflake stays cloud-agnostic. Not only does this lead to Snowflake’s platform being able to exist as an entity that is not overwhelmed by competitive forces, but it also leads to a very developer friendly experience. With support for Google Cloud, Amazon Web Services and Microsoft Azure, Snowflake aligns themselves with the cloud consumption habits of the modern enterprise. Flexera’s 2021 State of the Cloud report corroborate this fact further, finding that 92% of surveyed enterprises leverage a multi-cloud strategy (combination of public cloud services)  whereas 80% utilize a hybrid cloud strategy (mix of on-premises, private cloud and public cloud services) [8]. The fact that Snowflake’s product tailors towards these use-cases should continue to aid with their rate of adoption in the near future. 

Now that we have a better understanding of what Snowflake offers their customers, let’s find out how exactly they make $$ from it.

5.0 How Snowflake makes $$$

As previously mentioned, Snowflake’s PaaS is split into three distinct components, Storage, Compute and Cloud Services, as outlined below:

Snowflake offers their customers four different product editions, each of which contain different features that can be seen outlined below:

Corporate entities can decide to be billed for using Snowflake’s services in an On-Demand or Pre-purchased capacity manner. The description of each can be seen outlined as follows.

On-Demand:

Customers are charged based upon their usage of the distinct layers of the architecture. For Storage services, charges are directed at customers as a monthly fee, and differ depending on the amount of compressed data that is housed on the platform. The average beginning flat rate,  per TB of data stored can be seen outlined below:

Compute and Cloud Services extract revenue from customers using Snowflake Credits. These units of measure are Snowflake’s way of maintaining their inherent cost efficiency, allowing for customers to only pay for the resources they require for their various workflows. The Compute layer of Snowflake’s service utilizes credits and differs depending on the size of the chosen data warehouse. The size of the data warehouses can effectively be thought of as the size of the compute engine that powers query execution, evidently speeding up as the size of the virtual data warehouse increases. A table of the credits consumed per hour (CCPH), based upon the virtual warehouse size can be seen outlined below:

Compute, on average, costs $0.00056 per second, per credit. As an example, if a customer were to leverage a 4XL sized data warehouse for the span of an hour, it would cost approximately $258.05 (3600s x $0.00056 credit/second x 128 credit consumed/hr). As previously mentioned, Snowflake focuses on cost efficiency. By allowing customers to place virtual warehouses on sleep mode, they don’t incur costs when they’re not in use, in comparison to traditional legacy database systems. This phenomenon can be seen illustrated further below:

Outside of utilizing Compute resources to execute custom queries, Snowflake also offers a series of “server-less” features that consume credits on a per second basis in a similar manner.  These features and their inherent capabilities can be seen outlined below: 

  • Snowpipe: Automated feature that allows for data streams to be rapidly ingested

  • Database Replication: Replicate existing data across different regions, both physical and cloud-based

  • Materialized Views Maintenance: Synchronize materialized views (where a query result is stored in a table) with underlying base tables

  • Automatic Clustering: Leverage user-defined cluster keys in order to optimize clustered states

  • Search Optimization Service: Resources can be used efficiently (small virtual data warehouses) in order to speed up point lookups in extremely large data tables

Cloud services, of which ensure that data warehouse solutions are maintained in an end-to-end manner and automatically assigned to a customer’s infrastructure based upon the requirements of their workload. These services usually result in the client not incurring any additional costs, seeing as Snowflake allows for their provision of cloud-related services up to an equivalent cost of the 10% of total Snowflake credits consumed that day, which for the majority of use-cases is more than enough to cover.

Pre-Purchased Capacity: 

Although this billing method is structured differently than its on-demand counterpart, the essence of how a client interacts with the platform, as described above, remains the same. A Pre-Purchase Capacity essentially entails that customer purchase a specific dollar commitment to Snowflake. This dollar amount is determined based upon an evaluation of the company’s data warehouse needs and the associated resource requirements, and is then consumed on a monthly basis. The total is split into a cost for data storage requirements and the Snowflake Credits that will be required for Compute and Cloud Services-related processes. Although On-Demand pricing is more dynamic, Pre-Purchase Capacity is suitable for long-term minded companies, offering more services and lower price guarantees.  

In order to drive the points I've made regarding how Snowflake makes money home, let’s take a look at a hypothetical pricing example to fully understand what a customer will deal with in the real world [14]. 

The company’s data loading requirements can be seen outlined below:

The company’s user requirements can be outlined as follows:

With a 65 TB compressed data storage requirement, the company would be looking at the following pricing:

6.0 Key Performance Indicators 

In order to understand how Snowflake’s business is performing, we must first take a look at some Key Performance Indicators that do a good job at telling investors where the company is at with regards to their growth trajectory and their executional roadmap. The six most important KPIs to Snowflake’s success can be seen outlined below:

Product Revenue: This value is the Revenue attributable to customer’s usage and consumption of Snowflake’s PaaS. More specifically, Product Revenue includes the fees the customer incurs and pays Snowflake for compute, storage and transfer resources. Since Snowflake’s customers can decide when, where and how they interact with the product, on a consumption basis, this metric provides a gauge of the extent to which companies are engaged with the platform. This behavior differs from traditional SaaS business models that receive a monthly payment based upon contract durations and agreements. 

Remaining Performance Obligations (RPOs): This metric reflects the future revenue remaining on contracts that Snowflake has set up between themselves and their customers. Though useful to get a general sense of what to expect from Snowflake in the periods to come, one must remember that customer consumption doesn’t occur on a fixed basis, differing on a case-by-case basis.  

Total Customers: Relatively self-explanatory, total customers reflect the number of unique contracts that Snowflake has on the go. This value doesn’t include the entities that utilize Snowflake in on-demand capacity. 

Net Revenue Retention: Based upon a trailing two measurement period (2 years up to and including the most recent reporting period), this value is calculated by first determining the customers that utilized the platform in the first month of the first year of the measurement period, then dividing the Year Two Product Revenues attributable to these customers by the Year One Product Revenues attributable to the same customers. This value is not only indicative of future prospects but also reflective of the overall satisfaction of Snowflake’s current customer base, being that it gauges whether or not long-form customers are engaging with the platform in a more meaningful manner over time. 

Customers with TTM Revenue > $1M: This value is self explanatory and highlights the relative success at which Snowflake is both scaling their business and obtaining important levels of operating leverage. 

7.0 Financial Analysis - Q2 FY’22 Earnings 

It should be noted that all dollar values mentioned from this point onwards will be in USD. 

Snowflake reported their Q2 FY’22 earnings on August 25th.  The company’s main highlights from the quarter, both financial and operational, can be seen outlined below: 

  • Product Revenue of ~$255M, a 103% increase YoY 

  • Remaining Performance Obligations of $1.5B, a 122% YoY increase

  • 4,990 Total Customers 

  • 169% Net Revenue Retention Rate

  • On a TTM (Trailing Twelve Month) basis 116 customers had Product Revenues greater than $1M 

Snowflake chairman and CEO Frank Slootman made the following comments regarding the company’s Q2 FY’22 performance [15]: 

“Snowflake saw continued momentum in Q2 with triple-digit growth in product revenue, reflecting strength in customer consumption.
