item.title: Palantir ($PLTR)
item.description: Demystifying the World's Most Secretive Company
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the 255 people who have subscribed since my last piece! If you’re new, join a group of 1182 informed investors by subscribing below:

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an analysis on Palantir. Within, I will discuss some key trends and tailwinds that the company will aim to leverage in the coming quarters and following years, attempt to de-mystify the company’s product offerings and services, analyze their financials, and ponder some positive developments and risk factors that I feel are of the utmost importance for current and new shareholders alike to understand.

The format of this report can be seen outlined down below, feel free to skip ahead to the sections that you feel are the most important: 

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Opportunity 

3.0 Value Proposition 

4.0 Product Breakdown

5.0 Business Intricacies

6.0 Q2’21 Financial Analysis

7.0 Guidance

8.0 Positive Developments

9.0 Risk Factors

10.0 Conclusion 

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitution for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investment decisions. 

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on Twitter! 

Follow Me!

Without further ado, let’s get started.

1.0 Introduction

Palantir Technologies Inc. can be most easily described as a company that builds and rolls out software and big-data based platforms for Government Entities and Global Corporate Clients to engage in investigations, operations and analysis. The company offers two unique products, Foundry and Gotham, of which are connected by Apollo, Palantir’s Continuous Delivery System [2]. Gotham, the company’s product offering geared at Government entities, aims to comb through massive datasets, ranging from those provided by sensors to intelligence sources to informants, in order to provide and identify useful patterns, insights and information. The platform also aims to expedite and simplify the handoff process between analysts and operational entities, allowing for individuals to launch responses to threats identified by the software. Palantir Foundry, the product offering aimed at Corporate Individuals, simply stated, is a central OS for a company’s data, which allows for the easy integration and analysis of data in one, easy-to-access location [3].

Now that we have a rough understanding of what the company does, let’s look at the opportunity Palantir has in front of it and aims to target and leverage within their day-to-day operations and growth initiatives. 

2.0 Opportunity 

Big Data, defined as voluminous amounts of unstructured or semi-structured data that is collected over time, of which possesses an inherent velocity, complexity and diversity, represents an enormous opportunity for Palantir to capitalize on going forwards. A Market Study completed by Global Industry Analysts, estimates that that the Big Data Global Market will reach a total value of $235B by 2026, based on the estimation of a total market size of $131B in 2020 and a CAGR of 10.2% in between the 2020 and 2026 forecast period [4].

Palantir splits their market opportunity into two segments, Commercial and Government, both of which hone in on the aforementioned projections above. A description of each can be seen outlined below. It should be noted that I applied a very conservative 5% CAGR to the company’s 2020 TAM projections in order to be more reflective of the current landscape Palantir aims to address in 2021.

Commercial: The modified estimate of the TAM for the Commercial Sector is ~$59B. This projection is based upon a broad approximation of approximately 6,000 companies with more than $500M in yearly revenue as well as an assumed annual contract value for potential customers. Palantir Foundry has a wide range of capabilities and applications including but not limited to data management, application development, security, supply chain management and artificial intelligence etc. [6], and thus a wide arsenal of potential clients. 

Government: The modified estimate of the TAM in the government sector is ~$66B. This projection is based upon estimates surrounding total federal and state expenditures, with 5% of these total budgets being allocated towards software-based spend. The entities contained within this TAM are United States government agencies as well as its allies and other customers that align with liberal democracies [7].  To date, the company has worked with the US Army, Navy and Air Force, US Special Operations Command, Centers for Disease Control, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and many other high profile organizations. Palantir’s penetration in the military sector would not be where it is today if it were not for a 2016 lawsuit, by which Palantir sued the US Army for an unlawful procurement solicitation of the service’s next iteration of DCGS-A that shut the company’s commercial offering out of competition [8]. The judge ruled in favor of Palantir based upon the fact that the federal government is obligated to consider choosing commercially available software before considering building their own functionality in-house. Revenue attributable to the Army has increased noticeably since. Also of note is the manner in which Palantir chooses their Government clients. If potential customers do not align with the idealisms of the United States or Palantir’s culture and mission, such as the Chinese Communist Party for example, they will not be considered. Although this decreases the breadth of the company’s TAM, I believe this will increase the depth and length of contracts with existing Government clients going forwards. 

3.0 Value Proposition 

As stated above, Big Data provides an astonishing opportunity for organizations to better their processes, operations and decision-making as a whole. However, the sheer breadth/size of datasets often appears in conjunction with a host of difficulties that companies will have to dampen in order to derive any meaningful value from their data. The structure of many company’s legacy data systems are disparate to say the least, commonly existing as unique point solutions (i.e. solutions designed to tackle a single problem) or custom applications built on top of fragmented data lakes [9]. These ever-present phenomena often lead to the creation of data silos, i.e. a collection of data that is isolated from and not accessible by other components of a corporation, which is a serious roadblock in front of an entity’s data-driven decision making [10]. This is where Palantir comes in, separating itself from its data broker and data aggregator competitors and cementing its uniqueness in the form of a software company.  More specifically, Palantir creates digital infrastructure for data-driven operations and decision making. Their products, simply put, can be thought of as connective-tissue of sorts, facilitating the intertwinement of an organization’s data, analytics and execution [11]. Palantir turns order into chaos, allowing a company’s data ecosystem to evolve so to speak, as outlined by the image below: 

This is all made possible Palantir’s unique approach, of which can be seen outlined below: 

  1. Create a Central Operating System for Data: Palantir’s Gotham and Foundry software, enables organizations to transform siloed data systems into one single, accessible, unified data asset. Data is represented as unique entities, relationships and decisions rather than just the results of running a program or cells in a spreadsheet and is all accessible through one central location. An example of a OS dashboard in action can be seen outlined below: 

  1. Existing Systems are Augmented, not Displaced: Palantir’s software inherent functionality allows for flexibility that is not commonplace within the data-solution industry. More specifically, companies can integrate their existing solutions into the central OS in order to avoid resource and capital intensive efforts directed at rebuilding infrastructure from scratch. This fact alone allows for Palnatir’s solutions to be easily scaled and generate meaningful/noticeable results in very little time. 

For Government Clients, Palantir’s approach contains an additional layer, which can be summarized as follows: 

  1. Security-Enabled Collaboration: Palantir’s software ensures the complexities of security clearances, inter-organizational boundaries, data sensitivity levels etc. are respected at all times. The company’s technology, of which constructs models from data points, is also in turn able to secure each of these individual pieces of information in a manner that the client so desires. This process maintains safety while also ensuring analytical functionality is not lost along the way. 

In comparison to standard software companies that are cut from the same cloth, relatively speaking, Palantir is headfast on differentiating themselves. This effort is achieved through the focus on creating alpha. 

Most companies leverage software that is commoditized, i.e. a set of standardized tools that help entities keep up with their competitors, never excel beyond them, or in other words, focused on beta generation. Palantir is different, creating a set of solutions that capitalize on resources, find value in data that others would have ignored, and generate insights that help a company stand out amongst the pack. 

The complexity of Palantir’s products are imperative to the longevity of the company as a whole and creates a unique value proposition for investors as well. Essentially this boils down to the buy vs. build debate, where companies are given the choice to either buy Palantir’s software or task in-house developers, consultants and IT professionals to build a product with no effectiveness guarantees at staggering costs.  As such, Palantir represents a no-brainer solution of sorts. 

Now that we have a better understanding of how Palantir aims to provide value within the Data space, let’s do a deep dive on the important specifics of each of their product offerings.

4.0 Product Breakdown

The three main components of Palantir’s Business are Foundry, Gotham and Apollo. Each of these cohorts will be analyzed within this section of this report. 

Palantir’s two software products, Foundry and Gotham, are full-stack (i.e. with a back-end, front-end (graphical user interfaces with a firm focus on UX) and associated interconnectedness ) solutions that focus on aggregating and integrating data and providing frameworks to build knowledge systems. These systems maintain focus on collaboration and spur easy access to hosts of information and analysis. With this simplified description of the software’s’ functionality in mind, let’s dig deeper into Foundry and Gotham.  

Foundry

Simply put, Foundry is data analytics software geared at Palantir’s corporate clients. This software exists in a series of distinct layers, all of which connect to each other and result in Palantir’s unique functionality. The first is the automated data connection layer. In essence it connects the various fragmented, disparate data sources of different structured and unstructured natures into a common, organized arrangement and provides the foundations for which the second and arguably the most important layer, the Ontology, is built upon. An example of hypothetical use case by where a manufacturing company’s various data sources are organized in an easy-to-digest hierarchy/organization, can be seen outlined below:

The second layer, the Ontology, creates a digital twin of the business that is applied to all downstream workflows ranging from search and analysis to operational applications. This should be thought of as an aggregation of sorts, in other words taking the organization’s data, assigning meaning or a function to it, and using that to create standardized building blocks for which all other aspects of the software will come back to. The Ontology also acts as a two-way interface between the company’s aggregated data and the real world, allowing for unique insights to be fed back into the businesses. This ties into the bi-directionality of this layer as a whole, which is a unique functionality of the product. Rather than attempting to rework new data sources into existing foundations, through the Ontology there exists a common framework where new data can automatically make its way into business workflows, an extremely useful proposition and spurring factor of cross-organizational collaboration. The Ontology ties itself into the third and more advanced layer of Foundry, Simulations / AI.  In order to make better decisions, this layer creates models, which are imperative to deriving value out of the data building blocks created in the previous layer. These models can include deep-learning/AI processes or simple rules that adhere to quality/process standards outlined by members of executive teams. Leveraging the connective tissue of foundry, users of the platform can understand the impacts of a decision before they make it. This creates a code-like nature of introducing new business components, i.e. business changes can be rolled out in stages and tested, essentially creating a version of control of sorts within a complex organization. Moving on to the user layer, i.e. the central decision support infrastructure, this area of the software is where users can make inferences regarding active models, utilize low-code/no-code widgets to generate new insights/reports, utilize and build their own “what-if'' statements to complete complex and multifaceted data analysis in very little time. This layer also allows users to connect directly and simply with legacy ERP systems, taking raw data, joining it, making inferences regarding the connections between database tables and more. All in all, if you’ve ever worked with data in any capacity in your professional life, the functionality of Foundry is revolutionary, stunning and simply phenomenal to say the least.  

In order to better understand what I previously outlined above, let’s take a look at a real-world example of how Palantir’s software assisted Scuderia Ferrari.

Formula-One is an undoubtedly complex sport, of which has relied upon data for a very long time. Each car comes outfitted with many sensors that measure performance, reliability and a host of other metrics. During a Formula One race, sensors relay data at up to 1000Hz, amounting to 1000 instances of data being recorded per second. With data volume comes siloed systems, which undoubtedly spurred the Ferrari racing team to seek out the assistance of Palantir Software. Palantir was able to aggregate all of the data into a Central OS, replace existing tools and automate repetitive analyses, and also allow for engineers to test new hypotheses in fast-paced circumstances via simulations and AI models. This functionality was made possible by a central learning loop present within Palantir’s system, of which records the data, decisions made by operators and associated outcomes in order to improve the inherent knowledge base and thus the likelihood of more accurate decisions being made in the future [17]. 

Gotham

Gotham, the first software platform that Palantir built, is a product geared at Government Entities and members of the Intelligence Community (both the United States, Allies and members that align with the democratic interests of the West). Functioning similar to its Foundry counterpart, Gotham is focused on being applied to the most complex and chaotic situations in the world, all while acting on three phases of the decision making cycle: understand, decide and act [19]. The understand phase is similar to that of the data aggregation capabilities of Foundry, but often occurs to a greater extent, with the United States Government as an example having spent hundreds of millions of dollars alone on data-generating sensors within the last few decades. As such Gotham is able to take data sources that would’ve never been viewed in the same realm and joins them within a central OS similar that has hypothetical use cases similar  to something viewed within Spy Movies or Call of Duty missions. 

The decide phase leverages a feedback loop, of which can be seen outlined below:

Gotham presents users with a series of options, of which can be run in conjunction with simulations and AI models in order to arrive at honed-down decisions that have evolved in response to constantly changing data sources. The inherent nature of this stage, i.e. the ability for the results of decision to be fed back into the system as data, is invaluable and allows for AI/ML models to get better as they make their way deeper into an Enterprise’s decision making. Lastly, the Act stage is where Gotham shines in comparison to traditional data analytics platforms. More specifically, Gotham is able to be deployed on the edge, i.e. as a process that is able to execute on hardware devices that are able to process information without streaming or storing data in the cloud [22]. This software, similar to Foundry, also allows for modules (low-code/no-code functionality) to be deployed on the fly during intense situations, shortening the time it takes to gain valuable analytical capabilities. All in all, with Gotham’s ever-improving functionality, connection to the most powerful institutions in the world via long-form contracts and projects, and inherent stickiness that comes with Palantir’s products, it is hard not to like the value creation prospects that this product possesses for the business as a whole.

Apollo

Apollo, can be thought of chocolate chips in the Foundry and Gotham cookie so to speak, powering Palantir’s software, and acting as a continuous delivery system that allows for the company to cater towards their clients many different edge cases. Traditional enterprise SaaS companies often run exclusively in the public cloud, commonly only leveraging services from one cloud provider. Apollo differs in this regard, aligning with the fact that Palantir’s clients are often government entities with astringent cloud security requirements or extremely disconnected environments, such as the likes of military surveillance equipment. The schematic below outlines a simplified process diagram for different edge cases:

With the end-to-end nature of the system, Apollo allows for the seamless integration of new product features, security updates and platform configurations. This is all done with an utmost focus on stability. As a result, Apollo shines past traditional SaaS architecture catering towards all varieties of network topologies and processes higher up the tech stack, such as with AI/ML lifecycle model maintenance.  Global presence also allows Palantir to meet the ever-evolving data residency requirements of their clients. This functionality increases the feature velocity of Gotham and Foundry and also allows for ridiculously fast onboarding times. More specifically, onboarding can occur in a few hours (this would take competitors days or more) and updates can be rolled out to entire fleets of software users up to 41,000 times per week. To me, this is an evident Unit Economic Nirvana. More specifically, Apollo allows Palantir to cater towards an infinite number of clients, all whilst relying upon the same computational requirements, an encouraging factor when one is bullish Palantir’s future. 

All of these factors considered, giant corporations that have traditionally been against SaaS, were enticed to give Foundry or Gotham a gander based upon the aforementioned functionality. With the pandemic inducing business happenings of an urgent nature, Apollo was the functionality that allowed Palantir to cater these clients needs with ease.  

A side note, Palantir is one of the handful of a series of companies (includes the likes of Amazon, Microsoft etc.) that has been authorized to be utilized for Mission Control National Security by the United States DoD [26], a testament to the functionality of Apollo to say the least.

5.0 Business Intricacies 

Palantir primarily drives revenue by passing clients through their unique, three-stage sales cycle. Each stage, though occasionally unpredictable and sporadic, are essential to generating long-term value and have an essential role to play in both customer growth and retention.  

Acquire Phase: Palantir offers access to their platform to their customers, many a time for very low or no cost at all. This acts as a primer of sorts, providing an opportunity for the clients to gauge the effectiveness of the software, and allowing for Palantir to evaluate the intricacies and needs of the customer. By educating entities of the technical capabilities of Foundry or Gotham, Palantir aims to then move the corporations into later sales stages. Any customer that is classified under this section is realizing less than $100k generated within the LTM and are contained within accounts that operate at a loss [27].

Expand Phase: This phase contains efforts made by Palantir directed at bettering their understanding of the exact issues that are commonplace within their client’s business. Clients within this sales stage may generate more than $100k in revenue, however they have poor associated unit economics, more specifically, contribution margin. This metric can be defined as the margin associated with the revenue generated by the unit, less the associated unit variable loss. This essentially means that we are considering only the revenue generated by the software and the costs associated with generating said revenue [28]. 

Scale Phase: This is the part of the sales cycle where unit economics start to become stellar; costs usually decrease, allowing contribution margin to enter into positive territory while the client generates more than $100k in revenue. Improvements are attributable to the fact that clients are usually versed by this stage, able to develop apps on top of or that coincide with Palantir’s software, engage in high-functioning ERP analysis and more. At this stage, Palantir aims to have sunk their teeth enough into the client so that 1) they become a continuous source of operational + management fees and 2) the cost of turning back and trying to develop in-house alternatives to Palantir is providing would be astronomical and not feasible. This last phase is both where the company starts to recognize material revenue, but also where they sign the dotted line on a potential long term source of prosperous ROI [29]. 

It should also be noted that these sales cycles are long-form, i.e. a time commitment ranging anywhere from three quarters of or the entire year, respectively. As such, even though Palantir adds a new client, there may not be any tangible or material revenue revenue recognition for anywhere from ¾ of a year to a full year.

When coupled with the Revenue concentration within the Top 20 clients, it is evident that Palantir will need to maintain good relationships with their existing clients in order to clip their tail. On a positive note, Palantir’s total number of customers (TTM ended Q2’21) was 169, with the company adding 20 new customers. This concentration, when viewed alongside the magnitude of the spend of the US Army and other associated entities, is understandable but should definitely be monitored by investors going forwards.

Profitability and Margins:

8.0 Positive Developments

Not only is Palantir focused on becoming one of the biggest players in the Big Data space, it is also investing in some of the most promising early-stage disruptors on the market today. Palantir’s Investment Commitments, per the company’s most recent 10-Q filing, can be seen outlined by the following table:

It should be noted that the above information pertains to Investments with associated agreement dates made on or completed before July 1st. Additional investments made between July 1st and August 12th (the release of their quarterly filing) can be seen outlined below:

These holdings range from companies designing electrical vertical take-off and landing aircrafts, in the form of Lillium, or a health service provider that leverages AI to create virtual clinic operations for patients, in the form of Babylon Health. 

This strategic decision was not only made to try to generate an ROI with their asset position, but also offers testing grounds for Palantir’s platform. Traditional use-cases within bureaucratized institutions, big businesses etc. are one form of lessons, so to speak, that the company can use to improve their product. The above companies on the other hand operate at a different pace, utilizing Foundry at high-velocities in an attempt to become more disruptive. Despite these companies existing in the form of SPACs to Private Entities, obviously subject to risks ranging from de-SPAC exposure/sentiment to high-pressure/stakes environments attributable to disruption-seeking business models,  the investments pose a win-win situation, in my opinion. Either the company nets a nice profit from a potentially successful investment, or, Foundry becomes better as a result of feedback from use-cases in unique situations. In my book, Palantir appears to be attempting to expose themselves to Positive Black Swans, a proposition of which I am content with. 

Staying with the theme of Black Swans, of the negative variety this time, Palantir’s Gold Purchase, announced earlier this month, has been a big topic of conversation within the investment community.  More specifically, the company, during August 2021, purchased $50.7M on 100-ounce gold bars, of which will be held in a secure third-party facility, and were obtained as a preparation of sorts for a Black Swan Event [36]. The company’s recognition of an increasingly complex world, and the potential negative looming events that come with it, is something I am a big fan of. In the case of an environment with high interest rates, Gold should generate a decent ROI and at the very worst (i.e. other macroeconomic conditions), would act as a store of value / alternative asset holding on the company’s balance sheet.

Palantir’s optionality has to be one of the most important factors to remember when analyzing this company. More specifically, it’s functionality, ranging from data aggregation and analytics to AI/ML deployment, capitalize on some of the most exciting trends that an investor can aim to have exposure to going forwards.  Delving deeper, the most important development, in my opinion, are Palantir’s capabilities with regards to the Edge. Through the inherent functionality of Apollo, and more specifically, Apollo for Edge AI, Palantir is able to offer computational capabilities that would have otherwise required intermediaries had they not developed Edge AI capabilities themselves. Glossing over most of the technical specifics, there are innumerable applications where these capabilities can be applied to.

A powerful use-case was illustrated within Palantir’s most recent investor’s conference call, i.e. the company’s meta-constellation software. This software integrates itself with existing satellites, connecting hundreds of orbital sensors and AI models in order to perform some extremely sensitive and important analysis on problems ranging from crop yields to wildfires. This has also been applied to submarine analysis, leveraged by the US and allies. Palantir’s Edge AI connects with satellite subsystems, integrates AI models with the existing hardware and allows for the rapid reconfigurement of satellites to occur dependent on informational needs by constantly swapping micro AI models back into the system.  The capabilities don’t stop there, when one thinks about the direction our world is going, Edge AI can be applied to Energy Management, Drug Compound Design Analysis, and an ever-developing IoT (Internet of Things) infrastructure. Some of the world’s most prevalent engineering problems, such as Autonomous Driving can and most likely will be solved with Edge AI. Palantir’s software can be applied to vehicle sensors and Edge AI can then be used to detect potential obstacles in the path of the moving vehicle, allowing for seamless FSD [38]. With the Edge Computing Market expected to be worth $61.14B by 2028, growing at a CAGR of 38.4% in between the 2021-2028 forecast period, these use-cases represent an undeniable value proposition [39]. 

Lastly, the company’s increased Sales Effort is a promising proposition for the company’s growth trajectory. In February of this year, Palantir and IBM partnered, allowing the company to expand their sales force while also allowing IBM to increase the ease-of-use associated with their software. This deal provides access to a sales team of more than 2,500, which is quite the increase from Palantir’s previous sales force, which only contained 30 individuals [40]. With Foundry still having a relatively low penetration within Fortune 500 companies and other large entities, it is very exciting to think about the doors that will be opened as a result of this partnership. When viewed in conjunction with Palantir’s unique sales cycle, of which Palantir decreases client risk associated with trying their software out, as well as the inherent stickiness of their products, exponential growth is not out of the question.

9.0 Risk Factors

Palantir, is without a doubt, valued richly. This phenomenon is corroborated when looking at some NTM valuation metrics, i.e. EV/EBIT, EV/EBITDA and EV/Sales as well as LTM multiples such as EV/GP and Price to FCF as outlined by the images below:

Being that as it may, I believe this valuation is warranted when looking at the competitive landscape Palantir faces. More specifically, I have yet to find a company that offers a similar vertically integrated and end-to-end solution for data analysis and ML/AI applications. Lastly, when one considers the fact that management sandbagged guidance, I see no reason for Palantir not to easily excel a 30% Revenue CAGR in the coming years and thus provide a fundamentally-driven case for Palantir to be a multi-bagger from this sideways price action seen over the last few months:

Another risk that has been ever-prevalent and focused on by analysts is Dilution. This phenomenon can be attributed to the company’s high SBC, of which has already been discussed at length throughout this report. The YTD change in the number of Shares Outstanding can be seen outlined below:

Increasing 8.06% in the last 6 months, Total Shares Outstanding will continue to increase as stock option plans get awarded and exercised by existing and incoming employees. Although the SBC is hard to stomach, this dilution will likely eventually come to a halt as the company becomes more established in the years to come. In order to both obtain and retain the world’s best software engineers, product managers and other talent, the company must invest in their employees, and thus these values are necessary associated repercussions. In my opinion, and judging by the prowess and capabilities of their products from an engineering perspective, I would consider this a high ROI, but only time will tell if this continues to be the case. 

Lastly, the mystique that surrounds the company may come back to bite them at times. The fact that they are closely associated with Government and Military Entities, information surrounding their inner workings, specifically with Gotham, is often sparse due to security and confidentiality requirements. They are evidently subject to secondhand scrutiny with regards to the actions of the US military and their allies, particularly since their software is so intertwined with many of their operations. For better or worse, Palantir stands firm in their beliefs and values, as was made abundantly clear in the beginning of their S-1:

“Our software is used to target terrorists and to keep soldiers safe. If we are going to ask someone to put themselves in harm’s way, we believe that we have a duty to give them what they need to do their job. We have chosen sides, and we know that our partners value our commitment. We stand by them when it is convenient, and when it is not.”

Alex Karp, the controversial leader of Palantir, has also been ruthless with his description of his Silicon Valley counterparts, of which has caught some slack over the years. A prime example of this would be another hard-hitting quote from the company’s S-1 [41]:

“The engineering elite of Silicon Valley may know more than most about building software,” Karp wrote. “But they do not know more about how society should be organized or what justice requires. Our company was founded in Silicon Valley. But we seem to share fewer and fewer of the technology sector’s values and commitments.”

The brash and outspoken nature of Karp has upset a lot of individuals, and as a result has put a target on Palantir’s back so to speak by many prominent financial journalism outlets. This phenomenon was on full-display recently when many a hit piece were released, accusing a Palantir software glitch allowing unauthorized personnel to access FBI data.

Although the blame was shifted to the end user (FBI not Palantir) for not properly following access and security controls, I felt this was a prime example of many members of the finance community jumping to conclusions [43].  Regardless, investors should be wary of potential negative spotlight, of which is usually just a byproduct of success. Palantir, in my opinion, offers both their customers and investors more than a traditional tech company, thus it is only natural for competitors and analysts that do not properly understand their technology, value proposition or intricacies to spread misinformation.

10.0 Conclusion

Palantir, to me, represents one of the best investing opportunities I’ve come across in a long time. By casting a wide net on a booming TAM and offering some of the best-engineered products in the Big Data realm, Palantir, in my eyes, is poised to capitalize. This opportunity is not without its risks, and is bound to subject investors to some headaches regarding controversy, SBC and rich valuations. At the end of the day, as a shareholder of Palantir, I believe this risks are worth stomaching for the potential upside this company could see.

Thank you for reading my research.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, comment below and share! If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

item.title: The Original Bark Company ($BARK)
item.description: Making Dog Ownership Fun and Easy, One Box at a Time
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to my newsletter! If you’re new, join a group of 927 informed investors by subscribing below:

Subscribe now

Today I will be completing an analysis on The Original BARK Company. Within, I will break down some key tailwinds and trends that the company benefits from, analyze their product and service offerings, as well as discuss their financials and positive developments/risk factors alike that potential or current investors should be wary of. The format of this report can be seen outlined below. Feel free to skip ahead to sections that you feel are the most valuable. 

1.0 Introduction 

2.0 Opportunity 

3.0 Value Proposition

4.0 Business Breakdown - Product, Platform and Services

5.0 Financial Analysis - Q1 FY’22

6.0 Guidance

7.0 Positive Developments

8.0 Speculative Company Directions

9.0 Risk Factors 

10.0 Conclusion 

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitution for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investments.

If you would like to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on Twitter!

Follow Me

Without further ado, let’s get started.

1.0 Introduction

The Original BARK Company, which I will denote as Bark for the remainder of this report, can be most easily described as a dog-centered company, of which provides products, services and content geared at Man’s best friend. The company leverages its subscription-based business model and Direct-to-Consumer capabilities to provide customers and their pups monthly boxes of premium toys and treats via Barkbox and Super Chewer; health products via Bark Bright; meal plans via Bark Eats as well individual items from via Bark Shop. The company also, through the Commerce side of their business, sells Bark toys and treats, as well as Bark Bright Health and Wellness solutions through retailers and online marketplaces. 

Now that we have a basic understanding of what the company does, let’s look at some key trends and tailwinds that the company aims to leverage in both their operations and growth initiatives going forwards.

2.0 Opportunity 

Some important trends and tailwinds coupled with projections and statistics, as outlined below, represent the foundation for an undoubtedly promising Market Opportunity that Bark is poised to capitalize on: 

Large and Resilient Pet Market: In 2020, Total US Pet Industry Expenditures totaled $103.6B with Pet Food and Treats representing the largest cohort, contributing $42.0B, or 41% to the total value [2]. Estimates for 2021 indicate that growth is anticipated to continue, with Total Industry Expenditures expected to reach ~$110B. Pet-related spend is also very resilient in nature, with values increasing in previous recessionary environments (such as the early 2000s and 2008-2009) as well as during a pandemic-induced Global shock seen in 2020.

Increased Humanization of Pets: Dogs are moving up the hierarchy of many family structures [4]. As such, there has been a proportional increase in the rate at which owners spend on high-quality products for their pets. A study performed by Advantage Solutions estimated that nearly three quarters of American Dog Owners were concerned with the origins of their pet’s food and treats, with an equally high percentage willing to spend more in order to maintain their pet’s health and longevity [5]. With the high-margin nature of these offerings, pet-focused businesses will be able to capitalize on these habits going forwards. 

Increasing Rate of Dog Ownership: A survey performed by the Insurance Information Institute estimated that in 2020 there were over $63.4M households in the United States that owned a dog [6], representing the most popular pet cohort in North America.  With these values continually climbing and work from home trends appearing to become permanent in many industries, Bark will be able to cater towards this ever-growing customer base.

Millennials have the highest rate of dog ownership: In 2020 it was estimated that 76% of 20-38 year old’s own a pet, accounting for 34% of all dog ownership in the US, the largest percent ownership attributable to a generational cohort [7]. With demographic trends increasing the age at which individuals first start families, there is an increasing propensity for dogs to be treated as a first child so to speak, with spending habits corroborating these factors accordingly.

E-Commerce is here to stay: In 2020, largely attributable to pandemic-induced acceleration, e-commerce sales in the United States reached a total of $212B [8]. Pet-centered e-commerce sales contributed to approximately 10% of the aforementioned value. According to an IBISWorld analysis, approximately 30% of Pet-related expenditures were conducted via e-commerce mediums [9]. With Bark’s data-driven and subscription-based approach to generating e-commerce sales, the company’s trajectory appears to be directly aligned with modern shopping habits.

3.0 Value Proposition 

Bark, through their platform and inherent business functionality, aims to provide and create shareholder value with a series of processes and strategies outlined below. 

High Customer Retention: Bark utilizes and leverages data points and customer feedback obtained through social media, email communications and NPS (Net Promoter Score) mediums in order to ensure customer needs are met. High quality products, targeted marketing campaigns, customer service and a simplicity of use that is attributable to the company’s subscription models ensure a high degree of customer retention as exhibited by the company’s low churn rate.

In-house Product Design/Creation: Rather than selling third-party products, Bark strongly believes in creating their own high-quality, themed products.  Not only does this strategy result in a unique brand association not commonly seen within the pet-industry, but it also allows for the company to achieve a higher degree of profitability attainable via higher price points and margins. 

Focus on Personalization and Cross Sales: Bark customizes subscription boxes for hundreds of thousands of customers on a monthly basis. Through the company’s algorithms, they are able to suggest products that align with the dog’s attributes, the dog parent’s specified wants and needs,  as well as the company’s current inventory. The company is also focused on increasing order value via Add-to-Box (ATB) product offerings, of which can be coupled with existing subscriptions. These cross-sales tactics can be leveraged by Bark when new products are introduced into their catalogue, as their existing subscription base ensures scaling can occur efficiently. 

Omnichannel Distribution: Bark is focused on providing customers access to their products through a variety of different mediums, ranging from Direct-to-Consumer focused BarkShop, traditional brick and mortar retailers and other ecommerce platforms such as Amazon. This strategy ensures that all customers' shopping habits, no matter their preference, are met.

4.0 Business Breakdown - Product, Platform and Services

Bark’s product and service offerings can be split into four distinct and unique categories, seen outlined below: 

  • BarkBox

  • Bark Super Chewer

  • Bark Bright

  • Bark Eats

BarkBox: 

This product offering can be most easily described as a monthly, curated and specialized, assortment of themed toys, chews and treats.

Each monthly box contains two toys, two bags of treats and a chew toy, all with a new themed collection every month. This process is aimed at offering products dogs love while also making the monthly process enjoyable and fun for the owner as well. As an example, some recent box themes, ranging from WWE to Space Jam, can be seen outlined below:

The signup process for the BarkBox service is straightforward, consisting of the following steps: 

  • Basic Questions About Dog (Name, Gender)

  • Size Questions (i.e. is dog small, medium, large), allows for products to be sized

  • Dog Breed Specification

  • When is your dog’s birthday (Barkbox helps celebrate it)

  • Dietary Restrictions? I.e. Can your dog not eat chicken, turkey or beef? 

  • Account Specifics

  • Choose Subscription Option (i.e. do you want a 12 month subscription for $23/box, 6 month subscription for $26/box or monthly subscription for $35/month)

  • Add an extra toy to the box for $7/month (30% savings)

  • Shipping Details

These signup stages are transparent and easy to digest, and coincide with Bark’s free shipping policies (to all states except for Hawaii and Alaska), as well as their 100% money-back satisfaction guarantee.

Bark Super Chewer: 

This product offering differs slightly from its BarkBox counterpart, and consists of a monthly box that contains two durable and tough toys (for hard chewing dogs), two bags of treats and two chew toys.

Although these boxes are themed, 100% satisfaction guaranteed, and shipped for free in a similar manner to the regular Barkbox, they are priced slightly differently, with the 12 month subscription coming in at $30/box, 6 month subscription at $35/box and monthly subscription at $45/box. 

Bark Bright: 

Bark Bright is a monthly subscription box that contains a one month supply of Dental Sticks and a one month supply of triple-enzymatic toothpaste, all of which are aimed at improving the oral hygiene and health of dogs. This subscription service offers two pricing options, $30/month for a 6 month plan or $35/month for one month at a time. In comparison to traditional and hard-to-implement dog dental hygiene procedures (i.e. trying to brush their teeth) the chew and toothpaste combo offered by Bark is a more enjoyable experience for both owner and pet, as outlined below:

Bark Eats:

This product offering is Bark’s attempt at making dog food as easy as possible. The subscription process, similar to its other counterparts, is straightforward and consists of three easy-to-digest (no pun intended) steps to subscribe: 

  • Owner specifies important information about their dog, i.e. joint issues, digestive pain etc. 

  • Owner talks with a Wellness Advisor in order to create/build a meal plan, of which contains specialized ingredients fine-tuned to the dog’s medical and wellness needs

  • Bark then delivers the food, contained within 28 pre-packaged daily partitions, aimed at making feeding and portioning seamless

The cost, per month, of Bark Eats starts as low as one dollar per day, and typically ranges anywhere from $30 to $60 per month depending on the size of the dog and their associated dietary needs. With Bark Eats having chicken, turkey, fish food offerings, with different blends geared towards dog age, grain tolerance and dog size, it is evident that the company is focused on ensuring customizable shopping experiences rather than a one-sized fits all approach to the pet product market.

Bark Shop: 

Bark Shop can be thought of as the section of the company’s website that offers access to individual products outside of the traditional subscription offerings. Products available for individual purchase include the likes of themed toys (such as those from the space jam drop), treats and chews and items from Bark Bright such as the enzymatic toothpaste.

Bark Home, available within this section of the company’s platforms, caters towards customers that desire accessories ranging from collars and leashes to dog beds and pet-sized bath robes.

When individual products are coupled with the company’s intense focus on ATB (add-to-box) functionality, i.e. the algorithm-based suggestion of products to customers with existing subscription memberships, it is evident that the company is focused on maximizing value and revenue generation. More specifically, by generating individual sales on top of already recurring revenue, Bark is able to increase the value of average orders (AOV) and shorten the time it takes to introduce/familiarize customers with new product offerings, which is a positive for the longevity of their business.

5.0 Financial Analysis - Q1 FY’22

It should be noted that all dollar values from this point onwards will be represented in USD. 

On August 9th, Bark reported their Q1 FY’22  Earnings. The highlights from that period, financial and operational alike, can be seen outlined below: 

  • Subscription Shipments (quarterly) increased 52.4% YoY, to 3.6M 

  • Q1 FY’22 Revenue of $117.6M, increasing 57.2% YoY

  • Gross Margins of 59.3%

  • Add-to-Box Revenue contributed $7M to its Total Revenue Counterpart, an increase of 174% YoY

  • The company continued to invest in Bark Eats, their fulfillment infrastructure and business technology 

Manish Joneja, CEO of Bark, had the following to say about the company’s performance during the most recent quarter: 

"We are extremely pleased with our strong start to fiscal year 2022. During the quarter, we increased subscription shipments 52% year-over-year, continued to optimize our add-to-box feature across our suite of products, and partnered with iconic brands such as Warner Bros. and The NBA.  We continue to believe our unique value proposition—from our world class Happy and Creative teams to our machine learning capabilities—will have a halo effect on our newer, less discretionary categories such as health and food."

With this brief summary in mind, let’s dive deeper into Bark’s financials.

Income Statement: 

Revenue: 

As previously mentioned, the company’s Revenue for Q1 FY’22 came in at ~$117.6M, representing an increase of 52.4% on a YoY basis. This value, in comparison to its previous year counterparts can be seen outlined by the figure below:

The percent distribution of the company’s revenue, as split between DTC (Direct to Customer) and Commerce sources, can be seen outlined below: 

DTC Revenue sources grew 57% on a YoY basis and was, most evidently, the main driver of total Revenue for the quarter. Management attributes the strong and consistent growth, as exhibited above, to the addition of approximately 280,000 new subscriptions of which helped fuel the delivery of 3.6M shipments to the company’s sub base that is now ~1.9M in size, and growing [21].  Commerce Revenues on the other hand, though the smaller cohort of Total Revenues, grew noticeably as well, increasing by 58.7% on a YoY basis, at $12.2M. The growth in these values was attributable to increased activity at retail partners (Costco, Amazon etc.) as well as activity with new partners such as Lowes [22]. This retail activity is positive, and negates some of the dip in subscription-based purchasing activities that is bound to occur as individuals interact with brick and mortar locations at an increased rate due to re-openings etc. Another metric to consider is the growth of the Average Order Value (AOV), these values increased on a YoY basis by $0.87. Not a huge increase by any means, however it shows Bark’s ability to retain customers while also maintaining pricing, as well the versatility of Bark Play (Bark Bright, Eats and Home aren’t as significant sources of revenues). In summary, these Revenue values, in my eyes, are impressive, especially considering the tough comps Bark had to deal with going into this quarter.

Cost of Revenue: 

Bark’s Cost of Revenue was recorded as $47.8M for the quarter, in comparison to $27.9M at the same time last year, an increase of ~71% YoY.

Although these values were largely due to a proportional increase in the company’s Revenues, they were also affected by an increase in the company’s freight costs (attributable to industry-wide problems) as well as slight deviations in the price of certain materials. These values are not likely to improve within upcoming quarters contained within 2021, and thus should be expected to remain elevated for the time being. 

Operating Expenses: 

The change in Operating Expenses, on a YoY basis can be seen outlined by the following table:

The amount of Total Operating Expenses attributable to General & Administrative Expenses and Advertising and Marketing Expenses, respectively, during the most recent quarter and the same time last year, can be seen outlined below:

Operational Expenses, increasing ~99% on a YoY basis, saw a greater contribution from G&A Expenses this quarter, particularly due to the increased size of the company’s subscription base. When coupled with the heightened shipping costs seen across the US as well as the expansionary efforts the company is embarking on in order to expand their Bark Eats and Bark Bright offerings, it is understandable why G&A contribution grew. These values should remain skewed for the remainder of the year given shipping challenge headwinds. S&M expenses, though lessening their contribution to total OPEX, were skewed due to a YoY increase in CAC (Customer Acquisition Costs) of ~57%. Although some analysts may find this troublesome, if you take a second to digest the fact that comps from last year were heavily damped due to pandemic-induced pressures, this increase doesn’t appear to be too troublesome. Bark is still a relatively new business that is attempting to optimize their marketing funnels, thus patience is warranted in order to let the company iron out their kinks. When coupled with Bark’s continuous efforts to maintain a relationship with their customers, the LTV (long-term-value) of subscriptions and repeat purchasing habits greatly overshadows upfront CACs [23]. 

Profitability and Margins: 

The company’s Gross Profit, EBITDA, EBIT and Net Income Margins, and their change with respect to previous quarters, can be seen outlined by the following:

To further gauge the company’s profitability, Bark’s Net Income and EBITDA will be analyzed, as seen in the following figure:

The company’s gross margins are testament to the vertically integrated nature of Bark as a company. The fact that they have a loyal subscriber base with a low turnover rate, as well as the fact that their products are manufactured and distributed in-house, will be a driver of continued gross margin health going forward. Although the company has high gross margins, margins that took into consideration COGS as well as shipping the products to the customer would be in the low 50% range assuming a $5-$6 fulfillment cost. Though still high, this paints a better picture, in my opinion of the margins associated with just selling the product and without other Operating Expenses considered. On a EBITDA and EBIT Margin basis and Net Income basis, coming in at (9.2)% and (9.91)% and (21.09)% for the quarter respectively, as well as judging by the company’s EBITDA of $(10.82)M and Net Income of $(24.8)M, it is evident that Bark is not profitable. This phenomena is attributable to the fact that the Bark, very clearly, has stated that they are amidst an investment year. The company has been able, in the past, to generate profitability (as seen in 2020) with diligent expense-control procedures. Being that as it may, management has stated that they are focused on growing their Bright and Eats product categories, which requires a proportional increase in staffing and technological investments as a result. If all goes well, Bark will be able to scale their operations at the expense of margins for the next few quarters, of which, in an idealized scenario, could be a significant source of growth in the future. 

Balance Sheet: 

The structure of Bark’s Assets can be seen outlined by the following table:

Bark has a very liquid asset position, consisting primarily of Cash and Cash Equivalents, followed by a reasonable Inventory Position. Long-term Assets are construed of Net Property Plant and Equipment and Intangibles. The company’s Liabilities can be summarized as follows:

Bark’s Current Liabilities consist of Accrued Expenses, Accounts Payable and Deferred Revenue in order of descending magnitude. Long Term Liabilities on the other hand consist mainly of Long Term Debt.

Bark has a very good balance sheet. With a strong and liquid asset position by way of plentiful cash/equivalents, the company will be able to fund growth initiatives (potentially high ROI opportunities) without taking on burdensome debt, an encouraging fact to say the least.

Cash Flows: 

The change in the company’s Cash Flow from Financing, Investing and Operations over the last few quarters is outlined by the following image: 

CFO came in at $(61.87)M for the quarter. In comparison to approximately ~$1.474M at the same time last year. The negative CFO can be attributed, primarily, to Inventory, Accounts Payable and Other liabilities adjustments made to Net Loss. CFI came in slightly negative for the quarter, at $(8.4)M, attributable solely to Capitalized Expenditures. CFF on the other hand came in very positive, at $353.72M, attributable primarily to cash injections from the proceeds of the PIPE Issuance and proceeds from Equity Infusion from Bark’s SPAC reverse-merger.

FCF at $(70.18)M for the quarter, can be attributed to the company’s negative CFO coupled with their Capital Expenditures. Despite the fact that many may tout the benefit of being FCF positive, I believe Bark, when one takes into consideration the use of these cash flows (i.e. in scaling and improving their business) is right where they need to be. If all goes well, the betterment of high-margin business offerings that will generate meaningful revenues will be worth quarters of incurred negative FCF. 

6.0 Guidance 

For the upcoming Q2 FY’22 and for FY’22 as a whole, the company anticipates Total Revenue of $122M and Total Revenue of $516M, respectively. Despite giving no further guidance, the affirmation of values stated within previous quarters is testament to the positive outlook management has on their ability to maintain strong operations will also stamping out headwind pressures. 

7.0 Positive Developments 

The first point I would like to touch on is Bark’s valuation. With their Enterprise Value of ~$980M, their EV is approximately 2.3x LTM Revenues, 2.1x their Total Asset Position and 3.92x their LTM Gross Profit. Although Bark is not as profitable as its peers, judging by where it is at relative to its growth trajectory as well as the consistent compression of EV occurring due to poor price action, there is a lot to like about the R/R at the moment.

Another positive factor that I think is imperative to the continued overall success of Bark as a company is their social media presence. Arguably one of their strongest assets, Bark operates a series of Instagram accounts, a description of which can be seen outlined in the tables and images below [24]:

In this day and age, marketing through attention-economy based platforms such as Instagram are essential to generating organic website traffic and maintaining a steady stream of new subscribers to Bark’s various offerings. With Bark’s unique product offerings, of which are just as enjoyable/fun for the owners as well as their dogs, as well as a higher social media presence in comparison to peers such as Chewy, I am confident in this best-in-class marketing channel being able to generate meaningful conversions for the company.

One must also consider the numerous partnerships that Bark has with humongous brands ranging from the NBA to Universal Studios and Dunkin Donuts. In addition, the company has embarked on a collaboration effort with Netflix, with tangible results expected to be seen at the beginning of next year. These workings will continue to allow BarkBox products to remain in a league of their own when it comes to uniqueness and may open the door for other potentially large partnerships in the future, which when paired with the company’s social media presence, should be successful [26]. 

Moving over to product expansion, Bark Eats, in my opinion, represents a real opportunity for significant revenue, earnings and shareholder value generation.

Bark’s Eats offerings, and their highly personalized nature, set themselves apart from their competition based on this property alone. In a world where the humanization of pets is going nowhere, as well as the fact that current dog food offerings are fragmented and oftentimes generalized (there are organic and natural food products but fine-tuned customization is hard to come across), I am optimistic on the value proposition of Eats. Management was adamant, within the Q2 FY’22 earnings conference call, that the AOV of the purchases associated with this offering are almost double that of a typical BarkBox treat/toy-based order, which when coupled with the company’s consistently high-margins, is something to be excited about. 

Lastly, another factor to consider is the misconceptions regarding the company’s churn rate. A lot of analysts, within their bear theses, have misdefined this metric and thus overstated the rate at which Bark is losing subscription customers. If management defines churn rate as the number of individuals that received a shipment during the 364 day period preceding the quarter, then the company would have a churn of 2.5% or retention rate of 97.5% [28].  Bark Bright in conjunction with Bark Eats, in my opinion will help keep this value very low once they scale, especially judging by the higher recurring nature of the need for dog food and other discretionary items in comparison to just toys and play-based offerings. 

8.0 Speculative Company Directions 

On a more speculative note, there is something to be said about the potential directions Bark could go with additional product offerings. The possible directions that I think are both the most plausible and the most appealing on a potential ROI basis are that of Pet Insurance referrals and Online Veterinary capabilities. Starting with Pet Insurance, IBIS World completed a study that estimated that the size of this US Market was approximately $1.7B, growing at a rate of 14.1% between 2016 and 2021 [29]. This fast-growing industry would most definitely be something Bark could venture into, not with Pet Insurance offerings per se, but more along the lines of leveraging a referral partnership. As an example, Trupanion, a leading Pet Insurance Provider, offers customers a referral payment, as outlined below:

Bark would be able to leverage their existing subscription base and generate significant revenue based off of referral fees alone. Most definitely a thought to ponder going forwards. An additional potential direction would be that of an Online Pet Pharmacy. Chewy, as an example, operates a PCAB accredited online platform that allows customers to easily fill prescriptions. The US Pet Medications Market generated $10.8B in sales throughout 2020, of which are increasingly garnered from online mediums. Regulatory abidance challenges aside, it is worth considering how Bark is dedicated to creating a frictionless and enjoyable dog-shopping experience, as well as the fact that pet pharmacies are primed for disruptions. represents another opportunity for Bark to create an all-encompassing pet subscription business.

9.0 Risks 

A risk that I see Bark facing is maintaining adequate incentivization for customers to become a member of their various subscription services. Although their churn rate is low, which to me is indicative of high customer satisfaction and reasonably effective marketing efforts, the company may struggle with a continuation of US dog-market/pet-owner penetration with their current subscription models. Playing devil’s advocate, although the company’s subscription services are evidently convenient, there may be a missed opportunity when it comes to the perks of being a subscriber in conjunction with the Bark Shop for example. As an investor, I would like to see Bark offer subscribers potential discounts to accessories, be offered exclusive products or faster shipping times (when logistics/freight improvements are made) etc. I believe this could also be a huge boost to the efforts the company is making with their ATB functionality at increasing the rate at which new products can be scaled/introduced to the customer base. In summary, in my opinion, more perks = more reasons to become a subscriber.

Another risk to consider is how Bark gets viewed amongst its de-SPAC counterparts. As of August 17th, only 24% of the 106 SPAC companies that have completed their SPAC mergers this year are trading above their $10 IPO price [31]. Whether this is attributable to the increased bout of regulatory scrutiny or due to the fact that Retail Investors are finally starting to see past the projections that many of these companies EVs were based upon, is still up in the air. Needless to say, the price action in SPAC land has not been pleasant to say the least. Largely without reason, I believe Bark has been lumped in amongst its counterparts, and its stock may have fell victim to SPAC-related hesitancy, as outlined below:

Lastly, outside of the general macroeconomic headwinds and attempts at improving marketing efficiencies the company is dealing with, the largest risk the company is facing, in my opinion, is the general misunderstanding of Bark as a whole, especially amongst a series of skeptic analysts. Whether that be with comparisons between Bark and its competitors, false pretenses made about KPIs and how these are calculated or an underestimation of the potential of the subscription-based dog market, I believe many are missing out on this story. Although many investors might not like the conservative nature of the company, they have beaten revenue guidance during the last two quarters and I see no reason for this not to be the case going forwards. At the end of the day, I would much rather invest in a company that is reasonable with their estimates in comparison to one that leads on investors in order to manipulate/artificially inflate their stock price.

10.0 Conclusion

Bark is a small and very speculative position for myself, one in which I believe presents an excellent risk to reward opportunity. Their unique products, reasonable valuation, great unit economics, headfast efforts made towards making both their operations and business better, and presence within an extremely resilient and anti-fragile market are the foundation of my thesis. Only time will tell if my assertions are corroborated or if a new influx of information proves me wrong, until then I am watching, contently, the progress that Bark is making.

Thank you for reading my analysis.

If you enjoyed this research piece, please give it a like, comment below and share! If you want to see more frequent investing-related content, give me a follow on twitter @MT_Capital1. If you have any suggestions for how I can improve my work or a company you would like to see analyzed next let me know in the comments below!

item.title: Camping World Q2'21
item.dc:creator: MT_Capital
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to my newsletter! If you’re new, subscribe below so you don’t miss any of my future weekly research pieces! 

Subscribe now

On August 3rd, 2021 Camping World Holdings released their Q2’21 Earnings Report. For the sake of continuously providing analytical clarity on my largest holding, I decided to write a report on some key takeaways, positive developments and things to be excited for with regards to Camping World’s future.

Disclaimer: The information and research contained herein is all my own opinion and should not be used as a substitution for proper due diligence. Please consult your financial advisor and evaluate your financial circumstances before making any investments.

This analysis will be structured as follows, please feel free to skip forward to sections that you feel are the most interesting:
