Without further ado, let’s get started. 

1.0 Earnings Highlights 

It should be noted that all dollar values from this point onwards will be in USD.

Camping World Holdings’ Operational Highlights from the Second Quarter can be seen outlined below: 

  • Revenue of $2.06B, an increase of approximately 28.3% or $455M on a YoY basis. 

  • Gross Profit increased 55.5% or ~$271M, recorded as $759.8M. 

  • Gross Profit Margins of 36.9%, a 644 bps increase.

  • Net Income of $246M, an increase of $83M YoY, or 50.8%. 

  • Net Income Margin of 11.9% in comparison to 10.2% at the same time last year.

  • Diluted EPS of $2.33, Adjusted EPS of $2.51 (Class A Common Stock).

  • Adjusted EBITDA of $333.3M, increasing 51% or $113M YoY.

  • Adjusted EBITDA Margin of 16.2%, increasing from 13.7% at the same time last year.

  • Vehicle inventories increased by $67.3M, attributable to a decrease in new vehicle inventory of ~$65.5M and an increase in used vehicle inventory of $132.8M.

  • 9 acquisitions of RV dealerships were made in 2021. This feat means that Camping World now has presence in 46/48 of the States within the US.

Marcus Lemonis, CEO of Camping World, made the following comments regarding the company’s Q2 performance [2]: 

“Our incredible growth and our enduring success over the decades is proof of that demand and a testament to the 360-degree business that we have built. As we enter our 56th year as the clear leader and disrupter in this industry, we will invest heavily in our people and technological evolutions, two of our greatest, single differentiators and continue to separate ourselves as the clear industry leader.”

2.0 Q2’21 Earnings Highlights

Contained herein will be analysis regarding the company’s Income Statement, Balance Sheet and Cash Flows. 

Income Statement 

Revenues:

As previously mentioned, Camping World reported $2.062B in Revenue for Q2’21. This represents a 28.3% or $455.1M increase YoY. The change in Revenues over the last few quarters can be seen outlined by the image below: 

Revenue obviously suffers from seasonality, which is understandable given the summer-centered nature of camping in general. Being that as it may, the company has been steadily improving in the second quarters of the last five years. Of further analytical importance is the distribution of Revenue between the company’s various verticals, which can be seen outlined for the most recent quarter and its previous year’s counterpart outlined below:

The percentage distribution of Revenues between RV/Outdoor Retail and Good Sam Services/Plans remained largely unchanged on a YoY basis. The percentage distribution between the various subcomponents of RV/Outdoor Retail was relatively stagnant, with the only noticeable change being that of a 5% Increase in Used Vehicle sales and a proportional decrease in New Vehicle sales in Q2 in comparison to the same time last year. In order to hone in on the health of Camping World, let’s look at some more specific metrics:

As previously mentioned New Vehicle Sales decreased on a YoY basis, but were counteracted with higher used vehicles sales. This coupled with the fact that the average selling price of both constituents increased on a YoY basis, an effort made in order to better the company’s value generation per transaction, was definitely a driving factor in Revenue growth:

These increased selling prices are not above MSRP (i.e. Manufacturer’s Suggested Retail Price), which stamps out any concerns related to price-gouging that analysts may have had. Demand is evidently increasing, which will continue to spur Revenue going forward. More specifically, the Vehicle Inventory Turnover Rates (i.e. how many times the company sells and replaces a unit in the given reporting period) for both new and used vehicles increased on a YoY basis, as seen outlined below:

Demand for experiential travel mechanisms and services will be a driver of business success going forward, and progress has been commendable, as seen outlined by the metrics below:

Both Active Customers and Good Sam Club Members increased on a YoY basis. I am very excited about the change in Good Sam Club Members, particularly since the company almost achieved double-digit growth in these metrics YoY. Services related to the Good Sam Club are sticky, i.e. the customer retention rate is high and associated revenues are recurring in nature. Continual and potential double-digit growth would result in proportional rise in Adjusted EBITDA likely to be in the ball park of Hundreds of Millions.

Cost of Revenues: 

The change in the company’s Cost of Revenues can be seen outlined in the following figure:

Increasing on a YoY basis, these values are not problematic, having increased proportionally to their Revenue counterparts. The largest concerns I had regarding Camping World’s CORs were related to supply chain constraints, the widespread material shortages and the increase in prices that usually coincides with these phenomena. Marcus Lemonis, in the Q2 earnings call was adamant on how the Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs) (Thor, Forest River and Winnebago) have focused on not significantly increasing the price of these RVs. When diligent cost controls are coupled with the 22% increase in new vehicle prices that Camping World implemented this quarter, it is hard not to forecast continual Revenue improvements going forward, particularly since New Vehicle Sales are such a large proportion of the company’s Total Revenues [3]. 

Operating Expenses: 

A breakdown of the company’s Q2 Operating Expenses can be seen outlined in the following table:

The biggest constituent of the company’s OPEX, Selling General and Administrative Expenses, and its change over the last few quarters is outlined below:

Being that the company’s Revenues increased by 28% it is no surprise that SG&A rose proportionally. With Camping World’s maturity, and a continual focus on e-commerce going forwards, I anticipate these values to rise in a slower manner than that of operational scale, respectively.

Of additional note is the restructuring that the company performed on their secured credit facilities, which reduced their principal by ~$39M, extended the term to 2028 and lowered margin rate by 25 bps. 

Margins and Profitability:

The change in Camping World Holdings’ Gross, EBIT, EBITDA and Net Income Margins over the course of the last few quarters can be seen outlined below: 

The company’s margins have never been better, an obvious turn-around from the quarters affected by the emergence of the pandemic. These changes can be attributed to the company’s headfast focus on improving customer experience, remaining adamant with their high margin Good Sam Product offerings, as well as the implementation of the company’s strategic shift, i.e. the move away from locations that did not add additional value that started to occur in 2019. I love the company’s focus on high-margin product offerings (Finance and Insurance, Good Sam Club and Good Sam Services Plans), which can be seen outlined below. This continued effort, of which coincides with their growing customer and Good Sam membership base will continue to drive ever-improving profitability going forwards:

The change in the company’s profitability on a GAAP Basis (Net Income) and Non-GAAP basis (Adjusted EBITDA) can be seen outlined below:

Net Income slightly improved on a YoY basis whereas Adjusted EBITDA improved to a much greater extent. These values are very positive, showcasing Camping World’s ability to continually improve their earnings despite many analysts last year deeming the feat impossible. Shareholders can be excited at the fact that the company is dedicated to achieving $1B yearly adjusted EBITDA (an objective I think is not far off on a TTM basis) and doubling down on Good Sam Club product offerings (they believe that double digit growth surrounding these high margin products is possible) [4]. I am very happy with these metrics. 

Balance Sheet: 

Camping World’s Assets are relatively liquid, composed primarily of Inventories (RVs, Retail etc) ,of Cash and Cash Equivalents, Contracts in Transit (Contracts that are awaiting payment) and Accounts Receivable. The company’s Long Term Assets consist of Operating Lease Assets, Property and Equipment, Goodwill and Deferred Tax Assets in order of descending magnitude.

The company’s Inventory position, in thousands, in comparison to the same period last year can be seen outlined below:

Current Liabilities are composed mainly of Floor Plan Notes Payable, Accounts Payable, Accrued liabilities, Deferred Revenues and Current Portion of Operating Lease Liabilities, in descending order. Long Term Debt and Finance Lease Liabilities are the main constituents of the company’s Long Term Liabilities.

Camping World has a rock-solid balance sheet, has adequately managed their liabilities and has enough inventory and cash to continue funding growth initiatives, acquisitions and ever-increasing customer demand going forwards.

Cash Flows: 

The change in Camping World’s Cash from Operations (CFO), Cash From Investing (CFI) and Cash from Financing (CFF) can be seen outlined below:

The company’s CFO, coming in positive for the quarter at $87.83M, down on a YoY basis but still a healthy value, consisting primarily of Net Income and Accounts Payable, offset by Receivables in Transit, Inventories and Operating Lease Liabilities. CFF improved in comparison to the same period last year, consisting primarily of the Proceeds from Long Term debt, offset by Payments on Long-term debt, repurchases of Class A common stock and contributions to LLC units. CFI was negative for the quarter, decreasing YoY and attributable primarily to the purchase of businesses, real property and property and equipment.

The company recorded a positive FCF of $72.93M for the quarter, down a YoY basis, linked to the company’s high aforementioned CFO and relatively low Capital Expenditures, of which primarily consisted of cash directed at Greenfield and Acquired Retail Locations and Existing Retail Locations. The company’s FCF is not an issue and will continue to be able to support expansion purchases and initiatives going forwards.

3.0 Positive Developments

There are a lot of things to be eager about as a shareholder of Camping World. The first item I would like to touch on is Electric World. This effort, first announced in the December of 2020, started off as a partnership between Camping World and Lordstown Motors, by where the companies would provide customers with all-electric RVs. In April of this year, this effort was moved further forward, with Camping World announcing that they will be establishing their first location in Draper, Utah [6]. Being that as it may, Lordstown has been subject to scrutiny as of late, from both shareholders and the SEC alike, for having an overstated order backlog and for insider trading activity occurring suspiciously close to a financial results announcement. As such, this partnership, by association, was not off to the best start. I was very content to see that in June, the companies decided to part ways, with Marcus Lemonis taking to Twitter and stating that the company planned on moving forward with Electric World without Lordstown Motors [7]. The company’s strategy revolving this new Business Vertical was elaborated upon further within the Q2 earnings conference call with Marcus making the following comments: 

“We are not linked in the electrification. Our leadership and disruption in the electrification of the recreation space is not linked to any one company. It is going through our company and our ability to distribute through our 40 some odd states and our 187 locations and our e-commerce platforms, the products and services on the electrification side that make our company money and add value to the consumer.”

I am happy to see Camping World, even with this new endeavor, is focused on customers not the Electric RV manufacturers they may have to work with. With the electrification of vehicles starting to occur around the globe, there is no doubt in my mind that this will eventually be a large source of Revenue for the company, especially since the company will be able to leverage their existing infrastructure and locations across the US to deliver these products to customers. 

Another positive development is how Camping World is leveraging their Good Sam RV Quote Valuator to deal with the demand for Used RVs. As previously mentioned and as outlined by the Used Vehicle Turnover Rate and the amount of Used Vehicle units sold, there has been quite the increase in Used Vehicle interest. Widespread shortages have gripped almost every industry, and has resulted in dealers not being able to find vehicles or satisfy customer demand. Camping World’s Good Sam RV Valuator Tool sets the company apart from its competitors, and helps them navigate these headwinds with ease.

This offering allows for Camping World to easily obtain Used RV inventory and provides an end-to-end service for customers looking to sell. As such, when coupled with the 100% YoY increase in Used Vehicle Inventory, Camping World will be able to meet customer demand while also ensuring they do not drain their stores going forward. 

Another exciting development,  in my opinion, is the company’s launch of its Peer to Peer (P2P) Rental Marketplace. This vertical, simply put, is a two-sided rental marketplace, allowing individuals to list their RVs on the platform and others to rent them in exchange for a fee. Camping World anticipates that customers will be able to fully interact with the marketplace in the fall, i.e. bookings and listings will be made available to all. Alongside the P2P platform, Camping World Holdings’ sister company, the Good Sam Club will provide products and services alongside RV rentals.  These will include rental protection, 24/7 roadsides support, as well as savings on both bookings and the service fees for club members. This offering is truly unique and will be a serious hit when coupled with dilligent marketing efforts in my opinion. Camping World has approximately 5.5M Active Customers and as such there is no shortage of individuals interacting with their platform. The P2P marketplace will be able to appeal to individuals that desire experiential travel, but do want to take the leap into owning an RV itself. Judging by the success of platforms such as AirBnB, of which are in the business of selling customers experiences, I believe this will be an enormous hit. Not only will P2P offer customers an opportunity to yield a return on their RV investment, but it will also allow Camping World to expand their customer base with individuals that would have otherwise stayed away and create another business offering that may provide lasting shareholder value. To put the potential of this opportunity into perspective, a competitor, Outdoorsy has been putting up some noticeable numbers, anticipating to reach $1B in sales this year. Camping World, which is a better business by almost every metric, will be able to scale their P2P rental service far beyond what Outdoorsy is able to, attributable to their Good Sam Club members. If the company were able to engage even 5% of their total member base within the P2P marketplace, this would generate noticeable EBITDA.

Camping World is also investing significantly in their service base. Currently there exists quite the disparity between the number of technicians and service stations and their total RVs in circulation counterpart [10]. As such, Camping World intends to build out more service locations as well as increase the number of technicians employed and their associated technical skillsets. Being that the service vertical contains products and offerings that are both high-churn and high-margin, this will undoubtedly be a driver of value in the coming quarters and years. This strategy also aligns with the improvements Camping World is trying to the retail-side of their operations. According to Marcus, the company will spend the next few years removing low-churn products from the store-floor, ensuring that even their retail locations are focused on generating meaningful and recurring conversions. Coupled with the fact that the company embarked on their strategic shift in 2019 showcases managements past and current focus on optimizing retail operations. 

For the sake of brevity, I will not cover every minute business development that one should be excited about. However, I will impart this last point to ponder. Camping World Holdings, through the aforementioned developments and Good Sam product offerings, has developed itself into more than just an Outdoor Retail and RV company. They have added a layer of high-margin and recurring revenue on top of their already thriving operations, of which will continue to grow and set them apart. When compared with their competition, Camping World is truly in its own realm of capabilities, and I believe this will not stop being the case anytime soon.

4.0 Marcus Lemonis 

I have said this before and I will say it again, Marcus Lemonis is what an investor should dream of when thinking of a CEO. Wisdom imparted on me by Nassim Taleb, through the study of his works, has instilled a focus on the phenomenon of “Skin in The Game” within my investing process. More specifically, my investments are usually centered around good companies with management who directly align their success, financial and otherwise, with that of their companies. These traits can be exhibited through an executive’s personal stake in the company itself and compensation packages focused on long-term company success rather than short-term price action (sometimes encouraged with stock option packages). I believe Marcus has one of the highest skin in the game ratings for Executives of publicly traded companies today. This can be seen with his ridiculously low yearly salary, and his stock ownership (through ML ACQ), both outlined below:

With an enormous sum of the man’s own money is aligned with the success of Camping Word, this is something that should help investors sleep well at night. Marcus is a talk less, do more, kind of CEO and I am content with him at the helm of the company’s ship.

5.0 Valuation

In my opinion, Camping World is undervalued relative to the growth the company is bolstering and the initiatives that they are in the process of implementing. These assertions can be corroborated by viewing the company’s price relative to FCF, and forward earnings as well as valuation relative to NTM EV to EBITDA and NTM EV to Sales.

6.0 My Camping World Thesis Revisited 

When I first wrote about the company a few months ago I stated the following: 

A company that has a dominant presence in its respective industry, a great management team with skin in the game, growth initiatives that are being executed at every turn, a strong balance sheet and free cash-flow and is being laughably ignored by market participants is something that all analysts dream of stumbling across.  I believe that Camping World Holdings is just that.  Camping World Holdings operates a business that has no competition in sight, bolsters a strong sales network across the United States, and leverages the love of the outdoors that all of us have engrained deep in our DNA. As such,  I see no reason for this company to not continue to perform over the next few years. 

Over the last few months and with the release of the company’s most recent earnings report, my thesis remains completely intact. With the company’s constant execution, ability to leverage tailwinds and stamp out the effect of headwinds, and business developments that I anticipate to add significantly to both the company’s Revenue and EBITDA, I sleep very well at night with Camping World as my largest position.

7.0 Conclusion

Camping World is excelling with respect to all measurable metrics, and hasn’t even finished building their business yet. With all of the aforementioned factors considered, I believe there is a fundamental case for this stock seeing triple digits. Only time will tell if this hunch comes into fruition.
